human_translation: Why do I birds since taught domesticated animals and non-domesticated animals, it also taught birds,
llm_translation: Birds, why do I need them? Since it was taught in regard to domestic animals and wild animals, let it also be taught in regard to birds.

hebrew_text: וּמוֹכְרוֹ לְגוֹי. פְּשִׁיטָא! לְאַפּוֹקֵי מֵהַאי תַּנָּא דְּתַנְיָא, בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: לֹא יִמְכּוֹר אָדָם חֲמֵצוֹ לְגוֹי אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן יוֹדֵעַ בּוֹ שֶׁיִּכְלֶה קוֹדֶם פֶּסַח. וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: כׇּל שָׁעָה שֶׁמּוּתָּר לֶאֱכוֹל — מוּתָּר לִמְכּוֹר.
human_translation: sell it to a gentile. obvious, to exclude of this tanna , as it was taught Beit Shammai say: A person not sell his leavened bread to a gentile unless he knows that will be consumed before Passover. And Beit Hillel say: entire time that it is permitted to eat it is permitted for him to sell it
llm_translation: And his selling to a non-Jew. Obviously! To come and derive from this Mishnah as it is taught, Beit Shammai say: A person may not sell his leaven to a non-Jew unless he knows that it will be consumed before Passover. And Beit Hillel say: Any time it is permitted to eat, it is permitted to sell.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא אוֹמֵר: כּוּתָּח וְכׇל מִינֵי כוּתָּח — אָסוּר לִמְכּוֹר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם קוֹדֶם לַפֶּסַח.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira, says: kutaḥ , and all types of kutaḥ , it is prohibited to sell thirty days before Passover.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Betera says: Kutach and all types of kutach - it is forbidden to sell thirty days before Passover.

hebrew_text: וּמוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה. פְּשִׁיטָא! לָא צְרִיכָא שֶׁחֲרָכוֹ קוֹדֶם זְמַנּוֹ. וְקָא מַשְׁמַע לַן כִּדְרָבָא, דְּאָמַר רָבָא: חֲרָכוֹ קוֹדֶם זְמַנּוֹ — מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה אֲפִילּוּ לְאַחַר זְמַנּוֹ.
human_translation: it is permitted to benefit obvious? No, it is necessary to teach this where one charred before its time, And it teaches us is in accordance with Rava. As Rava said: charred before its time, it is permitted to benefit from it even after its time,
llm_translation: And permitted for benefit. Obviously! Not necessary that his hole before its time. And it is implied to us like Rava, for Rava said: his hole before its time - permitted for benefit even after its time.

hebrew_text: עָבַר זְמַנּוֹ אָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָתוֹ. פְּשִׁיטָא! לָא צְרִיכָא, לְשָׁעוֹת דְּרַבָּנַן. דְּאָמַר רַב גִּידֵּל אָמַר רַב חִיָּיא בַּר יוֹסֵף אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הַמְקַדֵּשׁ מִשֵּׁשׁ שָׁעוֹת וּלְמַעְלָה, אֲפִילּוּ בְּחִיטֵּי קוּרְדִּנְיָתָא — אֵין חוֹשְׁשִׁין לְקִדּוּשִׁין.
human_translation: its time passes, it is prohibited to benefit from it. obvious? No, it is necessary for hours by rabbinic law. As Rav Giddel said Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: to one who betroths from the sixth hour, and onward even with wheat from the mountains, we are not concerned that betrothal
llm_translation: He passed his designated time, it is forbidden to benefit from it. Obviously! It is not necessary, for the hours of the Rabbis. For Rav Giddel said in the name of Rav Chiya bar Yosef who said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: One who sanctifies from six hours and onwards, even with wheat of Kurdistan - we are not concerned for the sanctity.

hebrew_text: וְלֹא יַסִּיק בּוֹ תַּנּוּר וְכִירַיִם. פְּשִׁיטָא! לָא צְרִיכָא, לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה דְּאָמַר אֵין בִּיעוּר חָמֵץ אֶלָּא שְׂרֵיפָה. סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וְאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה מִצְוָתוֹ בִּשְׂרֵיפָה, בַּהֲדֵי דְּקָא שָׂרֵיף לֵיהּ לִיתְהֲנֵי מִינֵּיהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: And one may not light an oven or a stove with obvious, No, it is necessary to Rabbi Yehuda, said the removal of leavened bread is through burning. it could enter your mind to say: Since Rabbi Yehuda said that its mitzva is burning, while one is burning it let him benefit from it. it teaches us
llm_translation: And not kindle in it an oven and two stoves. It is obvious! Not necessary, according to Rabbi Yehuda who says that the removal of leaven is only by burning. Is it your opinion that I would say: Since Rabbi Yehuda said his obligation is by burning, when he burns it, he derives benefit from it, it is evident to us.

hebrew_text: אָמַר חִזְקִיָּה: מִנַּיִן לְחָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח שֶׁאָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה? שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל חָמֵץ״ — לֹא יְהֵא בּוֹ הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה: טַעְמָא דִּכְתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל חָמֵץ״, הָא לָא כְּתַב ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: אִיסּוּר אֲכִילָה — מַשְׁמַע, אִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה — לָא מַשְׁמַע.
human_translation: Ḥizkiya said: From where that it is prohibited to benefit from leavened bread on Passover? As it is stated: “Leavened bread shall not be eaten” There shall be no permitted consumption of it The reason is that the Merciful One writes : “Leavened bread shall not be eaten.” Had not written: “Shall not be eaten,” I would have said prohibition of eating is implied the prohibition of benefit is not implied.
llm_translation: Hizkiyah said: From where do we derive that leaven on Passover is prohibited for benefit? As it is stated, "Leaven shall not be eaten" - there shall not be a permission for eating it. The reason that the Merciful One wrote "Leaven shall not be eaten," had it written simply "shall not be eaten," I would have said: Prohibition of eating - yes, prohibition of benefit - no.

hebrew_text: וּפְלִיגָא דְּרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: כׇּל מָקוֹם שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״, ״לֹא תֹאכַל״, ״לֹא תֹאכְלוּ״ — אֶחָד אִיסּוּר אֲכִילָה וְאֶחָד אִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה (מַשְׁמַע), עַד שֶׁיִּפְרֹט לְךָ הַכָּתוּב כְּדֶרֶךְ שֶׁפָּרַט לְךָ בִּנְבֵילָה.
human_translation: And disagrees with Rabbi Abbahu, Rabbi Abbahu said wherever it is stated: “It shall not be eaten,” “You, shall not eat,” “You, shall not eat,” both a prohibition of eating and a prohibition of benefit are implied, unless the verse specifies in the manner that it specified with regard to an animal carcass.
llm_translation: Disagreement of Rabbi Avahu. For Rabbi Avahu said: In every place where it says "do not eat," "you shall not eat," "you shall not eat" — it is one prohibition of eating and one prohibition of benefit, until the Scripture specifies for you as it specified for you in the case of a carcass.

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: ״לֹא תֹאכְלוּ כׇּל נְבֵלָה לַגֵּר אֲשֶׁר בִּשְׁעָרֶיךָ תִּתְּנֶנָּה וַאֲכָלָהּ אוֹ מָכֹר לְנׇכְרִי וְגוֹ׳״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא לַגֵּר בִּנְתִינָה וְלַגּוֹי בִּמְכִירָה. לַגֵּר בִּמְכִירָה מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לַגֵּר אֲשֶׁר בִּשְׁעָרֶיךָ תִּתְּנֶנָּה אוֹ מָכֹר״. לַגּוֹי בִּנְתִינָה מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״תִּתְּנֶנָּה וַאֲכָלָהּ אוֹ מָכֹר לְנָכְרִי״. נִמְצֵאתָ אוֹמֵר: אֶחָד גֵּר וְאֶחָד גּוֹי, בֵּין בִּמְכִירָה בֵּין בִּנְתִינָה, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר.
human_translation: As it was taught “You shall not eat of any unslaughtered animal; you may give it to the resident alien who is within your gates, that he may eat it; or you may sell it to a foreigner; I have only to a resident alien through giving and to a gentile through selling. From where to a resident alien through selling? The verse states: “You may give it to the resident alien who is within your gates…or you may sell it,” From where is it derived to a gentile through giving The verse states: “You may give it that he may eat it, or you may sell it to a foreigner.” you may say both a resident alien and a gentile, both through giving and through selling. the statement of Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: "You shall not eat any carcass; you may give it to the stranger within your gates, that he may eat it, or you may sell it to a foreigner." I have only learned this law regarding giving to a stranger and selling to a non-Jew. How do we know the law applies to selling to a stranger? The Talmud teaches: "You may give it to the stranger within your gates or sell it." How do we know the law applies to giving to a non-Jew? The Talmud teaches: "You may give it and he may eat it, or sell it to a foreigner." You find that the law applies whether the recipient is a stranger or a non-Jew, whether in selling or in giving – these are the words of Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר, דְּבָרִים כִּכְתָבָן: לַגֵּר בִּנְתִינָה וְלַגּוֹי בִּמְכִירָה. מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? אִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ כִּדְאָמַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר, לִיכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא: ״לַגֵּר אֲשֶׁר בִּשְׁעָרֶיךָ תִּתְּנֶנָּה וַאֲכָלָהּ וּמָכֹר״. ״אוֹ״ לְמָה לִי? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ לִדְבָרִים כִּכְתָבָן.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: matters are as they are written; to a resident alien through giving and to a gentile through selling. What is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda? If it could enter your mind in accordance with Rabbi Meir said, then let the Merciful One write: You may give it to the resident alien who is within your gates that he may eat it and sell it Why do I “or” Learn from it the matters are as they are written.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says, words as they are written: to the convert by way of gift and to the non-Jew by way of sale. What is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda's opinion? If it enters your mind as Rabbi Meir said, to write compassionately: "To the convert who is in your gates you shall give it and he shall eat it, or sell it." "Or" - why do I need it? Learn from it regarding words as they are written.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי מֵאִיר? ״אוֹ״ לְהַקְדִּים נְתִינָה דְגֵר לִמְכִירָה דְּגוֹי. וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? הָא לָא צָרִיךְ קְרָא: כֵּיוָן דְּגֵר אַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה לְהַחְיוֹתוֹ, וְגוֹי אִי אַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה לְהַחֲיוֹתוֹ, לָא צְרִיךְ קְרָא, סְבָרָא הוּא.
human_translation: And Rabbi Meir “or” to give precedence to giving to a resident alien over selling to a gentile. And Rabbi Yehuda this does not need a verse, since you are commanded to sustain a resident alien, and you are not commanded to sustain a gentile. There is no need for a verse it is logical inference.
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir? "Or" to prioritize the giving of a fish as a gift over selling it to a non-Jew. And Rabbi Yehuda? This does not require a verse: Since you are commanded to keep the fish alive, and a non-Jew, if you are not commanded to keep it alive, a verse is not necessary, it is a logical deduction.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרַבִּי מֵאִיר, דְּאָמַר: אֶחָד גֵּר וְאֶחָד גּוֹי, בֵּין בִּמְכִירָה בֵּין בִּנְתִינָה. מִדְּאִיצְטְרִיךְ קְרָא לְמִישְׁרֵא נְבֵילָה בַּהֲנָאָה — הָא כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה אֲסוּרִין בֵּין בַּאֲכִילָה בֵּין בַּהֲנָאָה.
human_translation: Granted, according to Rabbi Meir, who said to both a convert and a gentile, both through selling and through giving. From a verse was necessary to permit benefit from an animal carcass, all prohibitions in the Torah it is prohibited both to eat it and to derive benefit from it.
llm_translation: In truth, according to Rabbi Meir, who said: "One law applies to a convert and one law applies to a non-Jew, whether in a sale or in a gift. Since a verse is needed for a straightforward case of deriving benefit from a neveilah (forbidden animal) — this teaches us that all prohibitions in the Torah are forbidden, whether in eating or in benefit."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, דְּאָמַר: לִדְבָרִים כִּכְתָבָן הוּא דַּאֲתָא — הָא כׇּל אִיסּוּרִים שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה מְנָא לֵיהּ דַּאֲסוּרִין בַּהֲנָאָה? נָפְקָא לֵיהּ מִ״לַּכֶּלֶב תַּשְׁלִיכוּן אֹתוֹ״.
human_translation: However, according to Rabbi Yehuda, who said comes to matters are as they are written, from where does he derive all prohibitions mentioned in the Torah that it is prohibited to benefit He derives it you shall cast it to the dogs”
llm_translation: Rather, it is according to Rabbi Yehuda, who said: With regard to matters, as they are written, is it that he came — all prohibitions in the Torah, from where does he derive that they are prohibited for benefit? It is derived for him from "You shall cast it to the dog."

hebrew_text: אוֹתוֹ אַתָּה מַשְׁלִיךְ לַכֶּלֶב, וְאִי אַתָּה מַשְׁלִיךְ לַכֶּלֶב כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה. וְרַבִּי מֵאִיר? אוֹתוֹ אַתָּה מַשְׁלִיךְ לַכֶּלֶב, וְאִי אַתָּה מַשְׁלִיךְ לַכֶּלֶב חוּלִּין שֶׁנִּשְׁחֲטוּ בַּעֲזָרָה.
human_translation: It, you throw to a dog, but you not throw all prohibited by Torah law to a dog, And Rabbi Meir It, you throw to a dog, but you not throw a non-sacred animal that was slaughtered in the courtyard to a dog,
llm_translation: That you throw to the dog, and if you do not throw to the dog, all the prohibitions in the Torah. And Rabbi Meir? That you throw to the dog, and if you do not throw to the dog, non-sacred items that were slaughtered in the Temple courtyard.

hebrew_text: וְאִידַּךְ? חוּלִּין שֶׁנִּשְׁחֲטוּ בַּעֲזָרָה לָאו דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא הִיא.
human_translation: And the other non-sacrificial animal that was slaughtered in the courtyard is not by Torah law;
llm_translation: And the other opinion? Regular animals that were slaughtered in the Temple courtyard are not of biblical origin.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַבִּי יִצְחָק נַפָּחָא: וַהֲרֵי גִּיד הַנָּשֶׁה, דְּרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״עַל כֵּן לֹא יֹאכְלוּ בְנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל אֶת גִּיד הַנָּשֶׁה״, וּתְנַן: שׁוֹלֵחַ אָדָם יָרֵךְ לְגוֹי, וְגִיד הַנָּשֶׁה בְּתוֹכוֹ, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמְּקוֹמוֹ נִיכָּר!
human_translation: Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa raised an objection: And the sciatic nerve, as the Merciful One says: “Therefore the children of Israel may not eat the sciatic nerve” and we learned A person send the thigh to a gentile with the sciatic nerve inside it, due to its place is clear,
llm_translation: The text states: Rabbi Yitzchak Napacha raised an objection: But what about the sciatic nerve, concerning which the Merciful One said, "Therefore the children of Israel shall not eat the sciatic nerve"? And we learned in a Mishnah: If a person sends a thigh to a non-Jew, and the sciatic nerve is within it, it is recognizable because of its place!

hebrew_text: קָסָבַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: כְּשֶׁהוּתְּרָה נְבֵילָה — הִיא וְחֶלְבָּהּ וְגִידָהּ הוּתְּרָה. הָנִיחָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״יֵשׁ בְּגִידִין בְּנוֹתֵן טַעַם״. אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״אֵין בְּגִידִין בְּנוֹתֵן טַעַם״, מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר?
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu holds when it was permitted an animal carcass, it, its fats, and its sinews, permitted. It works out well according to the one who said that sinews give flavor, However, according to the one who says sinews do not give flavor what can be said?
llm_translation: Rabbi Avahu holds: When a neveilah is permitted, its fat and sinew are permitted. This is in accordance with the opinion that says, "The sinews have taste." But according to the opinion that says, "The sinews have no taste," what can be said?

hebrew_text: מַאן שָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ דְּאָמַר ״אֵין בְּגִידִין בְּנוֹתֵן טַעַם״ רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, דְּתַנְיָא: הָאוֹכֵל מִגִּיד הַנָּשֶׁה שֶׁל בְּהֵמָה טְמֵאָה, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה מְחַיֵּיב שְׁתַּיִם, וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן פּוֹטֵר.
human_translation: Whom did you hear that said sinews do not give flavor? Rabbi Shimon, as it was taught one who eats the sciatic nerve from a non-kosher domesticated animal, Rabbi Yehuda deems liable two And Rabbi Shimon exempts
llm_translation: One who heard him say, "There is no prohibition of gid hanasheh with taste," Rabbi Shimon, as it was taught: One who eats the sciatic nerve of a ritually impure animal, Rabbi Yehuda obligates him two sacrifices, and Rabbi Shimon exempts him.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הָכִי נָמֵי דְּאָסַר בַּהֲנָאָה, דְּתַנְיָא: גִּיד הַנָּשֶׁה מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: so too here, Rabbi Shimon prohibits benefit As it was taught It is permitted to benefit from the sciatic nerve; the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Shimon prohibits
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon HaKohen, also known as the one who prohibits benefit, as it was taught: The sciatic nerve is permitted for benefit, the words of Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Shimon prohibits.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי דָּם, דְּרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״כׇּל נֶפֶשׁ מִכֶּם לֹא תֹאכַל דָּם״, וּתְנַן: אֵלּוּ וָאֵלּוּ מִתְעָרְבִין בָּאַמָּה, וְיוֹצְאִין לְנַחַל קִדְרוֹן, וְנִמְכָּרִין לַגַּנָּנִין לְזַבֵּל, וּמוֹעֲלִין בּוֹ!
human_translation: And blood, as the Merciful One says: No soul of you shall eat blood, And we learned these and these, mix in the canal exit to the Kidron Valley and are sold to gardeners as a fertilizer. And misuses consecrated property.
llm_translation: And behold, blood, for the Merciful One said: "For the soul of the flesh is in the blood," and we learned: These and these mix in the Amah, and go out to the Kidron Valley, and are sold to the gardeners for fertilizer, and they are defiled by it!

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי דָּם דְּאִיתַּקַּשׁ לְמַיִם, דִּכְתִיב ״לֹא תֹּאכְלֶנּוּ עַל הָאָרֶץ תִּשְׁפְּכֶנּוּ כַּמָּיִם״ — מָה מַיִם מוּתָּרִין, אַף דָּם מוּתָּר.
human_translation: Blood is different, as it is juxtaposed to water. As it is written “You shall not eat it; you shall pour it out upon the earth like water” Just as it is permitted water, so too, it is permitted blood.
llm_translation: The blood that is difficult to dissolve in water, as it is written, "You shall not eat it; you shall pour it out on the ground like water" (Deuteronomy 12:16) — just as water is permissible, so too blood is permissible.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא, כַּמַּיִם הַמִּתְנַסְּכִים עַל גַּבֵּי הַמִּזְבֵּחַ! אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ ״כַּמַּיִם״ — רוֹב מַיִם. מִידֵּי ״רוֹב מַיִם״ כְּתִיב?! אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: כַּמַּיִם הַנִּשְׁפָּכִין, וְלֹא כַּמַּיִם הַנִּיסָּכִין.
human_translation: And say like water offered as a libation on the altar, Rabbi Abbahu said: “Like water [ kamayim ],” most water; And is it written: Most water? Rather, Rav Ashi said Like water that is poured out, and not like water that is offered as a libation.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And why not say, like water poured on the altar! Rabbi Abbahu said, "Like water" - abundant water. Is it written "abundant water" immediately after "like water"?! Rather, Rav Ashe said: Like water that is poured out, and not like water that is poured in.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא: כַּמַּיִם הַנִּשְׁפָּכִין לִפְנֵי עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה! הָתָם נָמֵי נִיסּוּךְ אִיקְּרִי, דִּכְתִיב ״יִשְׁתּוּ יֵין נְסִיכָם״.
human_translation: And say like water poured before idolatry, There, is also called a libation as it is written: and drink the wine of their libations”
llm_translation: And why? Like water that is poured before idol worship! There, regarding libation, it is called, as it is written, "Let them drink their libations."

hebrew_text: וּלְחִזְקִיָּה, לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא אִיתַּקַּשׁ דָּם לְמַיִם? לְכִדְרַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מִנַּיִן לְדַם קָדָשִׁים שֶׁאֵינוֹ מַכְשִׁיר — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״לֹא תֹּאכְלֶנּוּ עַל הָאָרֶץ תִּשְׁפְּכֶנּוּ כַּמָּיִם״, דָּם שֶׁנִּשְׁפָּךְ כַּמַּיִם — מַכְשִׁיר, שֶׁאֵינוֹ נִשְׁפָּךְ כַּמַּיִם — אֵינוֹ מַכְשִׁיר.
human_translation: According to Ḥizkiya, for what halakha is blood juxtaposed to water? to derive Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, as Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From where that the blood of sacrifices does not render susceptible As it is stated: “You shall not eat it; you shall pour it out upon the earth like water” Blood that is poured out like water, renders susceptible which is not poured out like water does not render susceptible
llm_translation: Regarding Hezekiah, what is the halakha concerning blood mixed with water? According to Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba, for Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yohanan: From where do we derive that the blood of holy offerings that is not fit – as it is stated, "You shall not eat it on the ground; you shall pour it out like water" (Deuteronomy 12:16)? Blood that is poured out like water is fit, but blood that is not poured out like water is not fit.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי אֵבֶר מִן הַחַי, דִּכְתִיב ״לֹא תֹאכַל הַנֶּפֶשׁ עִם הַבָּשָׂר״, וְתַנְיָא, רַבִּי נָתָן אוֹמֵר: מִנַּיִן שֶׁלֹּא יוֹשִׁיט אָדָם כּוֹס יַיִן לְנָזִיר וְאֵבֶר מִן הַחַי לִבְנֵי נֹחַ — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״וְלִפְנֵי עִוֵּר לֹא תִתֵּן מִכְשֹׁל״, הָא לִכְלָבִים — שְׁרֵי!
human_translation: And a limb from a living as it is written: and you shall not eat the life with the flesh” And it was taught Rabbi Natan says: From where that a person not offer a cup of wine to a nazirite, a limb from a living animal to a descendant of Noah, The verse states: “You shall not put a stumbling block before the blind” However, it is permitted to dogs.
llm_translation: And behold a limb from a living animal, as it is written "You shall not eat the soul with the flesh," and it was taught, Rabbi Natan says: From where do we derive that a person should not hand a cup of wine to a Nazirite and a limb from a living animal to the descendants of Noah? The Talmud teaches "And before the blind do not place a stumbling block," this applies to dogs - permitted!

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי אֵבֶר מִן הַחַי דְּאִיתַּקַּשׁ לְדָם, דִּכְתִיב: ״רַק חֲזַק לְבִלְתִּי אֲכֹל הַדָּם כִּי הַדָּם הוּא הַנָּפֶשׁ״.
human_translation: A limb from a living animal is different, as it is juxtaposed to blood. As it is written: “Only be steadfast in not eating the blood; for the blood is the life;
llm_translation: The limb of a living animal that is attached to blood is different, as it is written: "Only be strong not to eat the blood, for the blood is the life."

hebrew_text: וּלְחִזְקִיָּה, לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא אִיתַּקַּשׁ אֵבֶר מִן הַחַי לְדָם? אָמַר לָךְ, דָּם הוּא דְּאִיתַּקַּשׁ לְאֵבֶר מִן הַחַי: מָה אֵבֶר מִן הַחַי אָסוּר — אַף דָּם מִן הַחַי אָסוּר. וְאִי זֶה — זֶה דַּם הַקָּזָה, שֶׁהַנֶּפֶשׁ יוֹצְאָה בּוֹ.
human_translation: And according to Ḥizkiya, what halakha is a limb from a living animal juxtaposed to blood? He said to you It is blood that is juxtaposed to a limb from a living animal Just as a limb from a living animal is prohibited, so too, blood of a living being is prohibited. And which this This blood of bloodletting, through which the soul departs.
llm_translation: Regarding Hezekiah, for what purpose is a limb detached from a living animal for its blood? He said to you, it is the blood that is attached to a limb from a living animal: Just as a limb from a living animal is prohibited - so too, blood from a living animal is prohibited. And if this is the case - this is the blood of the neck, from which the soul departs.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי שׁוֹר הַנִּסְקָל, דְּרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל אֶת בְּשָׂרוֹ״, וְתַנְיָא: מִמַּשְׁמַע שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״סָקוֹל יִסָּקֵל הַשּׁוֹר״ אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁהִיא נְבֵלָה, וּנְבֵלָה אֲסוּרָה בַּאֲכִילָה?! וּמָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״? מַגִּיד לְךָ הַכָּתוּב שֶׁאִם שְׁחָטוֹ לְאַחַר שֶׁנִּגְמַר (אֶת) דִּינוֹ — אָסוּר.
human_translation: And an ox that is stoned, as the Merciful One says: and of its flesh shall not be eaten; And it was taught By inference from that which is stated: “The ox shall surely be stoned,” don’t I know that it is an animal carcass, and it is prohibited to eat an animal carcass? What the verse states: “Its shall not be eaten”? The verse is telling you that if one slaughtered after its verdict had been reached it is prohibited.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And behold, a bull that is to be stoned, for the Merciful One said: "Its flesh shall not be eaten," and it was taught: From what is heard, as it is stated "The bull shall be stoned," I do not know if it is a carcass, and is a carcass forbidden for consumption?! And what is the Talmud to say "shall not be eaten"? The Scripture informs you that if it was slaughtered after its judgment was completed, it is forbidden.

hebrew_text: אֵין לִי אֶלָּא בַּאֲכִילָה, בַּהֲנָאָה מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״וּבַעַל הַשּׁוֹר נָקִי״. מַאי מַשְׁמַע? שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן זוֹמָא אוֹמֵר: כְּאָדָם שֶׁאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״יָצָא פְּלוֹנִי נָקִי מִנְּכָסָיו״, וְאֵין לוֹ בָּהֶם הֲנָאָה שֶׁל כְּלוּם.
human_translation: I have only from eating from where from benefit The verse states: “But the owner of the ox shall be clear [ naki ].” From where may it be inferred Shimon ben Zoma says: like a person who says to his fellow: So-and-so was left clear [ naki ] of his property, and he has no benefit from it at all.
llm_translation: I have only in eating, in deriving benefit from where? Scripture says, "And the owner of the ox shall be clear." What does it imply? Shimon ben Zoma says: It is like a person who says to his friend, "So-and-so has gone out clean from his property," and he has no benefit from them at all.

hebrew_text: טַעְמָא דִּכְתַב ״וּבַעַל הַשּׁוֹר נָקִי״, דְּאִי מִ״לֹּא יֵאָכֵל״, אִיסּוּר אֲכִילָה — מַשְׁמַע, אִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה — לָא מַשְׁמַע!
human_translation: the reason is that wrote: “But the owner of the ox shall be clear.” As, if from: “It shall not be eaten,” prohibition of eating would be implied, the prohibition of benefit would not be implied.
llm_translation: Reason of that wrote "and the owner of the ox shall be innocent", because if "full" shall eat, prohibition eating implies, prohibition benefit not implies!

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״ אִיסּוּר אֲכִילָה וְאִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה מַשְׁמַע, ״וּבַעַל הַשּׁוֹר נָקִי״ לַהֲנָאַת עוֹרוֹ הוּא דַּאֲתָא. וְאִיצְטְרִיךְ, סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל אֶת בְּשָׂרוֹ״ כְּתִיב: בְּשָׂרוֹ — אִין, עוֹרוֹ — לָא, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Actually, “It shall not be eaten” indicates a prohibition of eating and a prohibition of benefit. “But the owner of the ox shall be clear,” comes to benefit from the hide And necessary it could enter your mind to say it is written: “Its flesh shall not be eaten,” its flesh, yes, its hide, no, teaches us
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Forever 'not to be eaten' implies prohibition of consumption and prohibition of benefit is implied, 'and the owner of the ox is innocent' refers to the benefit of its hide that comes. And it is necessary, as your mind may suggest: 'not to eat its flesh' is written: its flesh - no, its hide - yes, this is what it implies to us."

hebrew_text: וּלְהָנָךְ תַּנָּאֵי דְּמַפְּקִי לֵיהּ לְהַאי קְרָא לִדְרָשָׁה אַחֲרִינָא, לַחֲצִי כּוֹפֶר וְלִדְמֵי וְולָדוֹת, הֲנָאַת עוֹרוֹ מְנָא לְהוּ? נָפְקָא לְהוּ מֵ״אֶת בְּשָׂרוֹ״ — אֶת הַטָּפֵל לִבְשָׂרוֹ.
human_translation: And to those tanna’im who expound this verse: for another interpretation, half indemnity payment for offspring from where do they derive benefiting from hide? They derive “Of et its flesh.” that which is secondary to the flesh,
llm_translation: The scholars taught: when they derive from this verse for another exposition, for half of the atonement money and for substitutes and offspring, how do they derive benefit from his skin? They derive benefit from "his skin" — he wore the patch on his skin.

hebrew_text: וְאִידַּךְ? ״אֶת״ לָא דָּרֵישׁ.
human_translation: And the other does not interpret et
llm_translation: And the other? "Et" is not expounded.

hebrew_text: כִּדְתַנְיָא: שִׁמְעוֹן הָעַמְסוֹנִי, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ נְחֶמְיָה הָעַמְסוֹנִי, הָיָה דּוֹרֵשׁ כׇּל ׳אֶתִּים׳ שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה, כֵּיוָן שֶׁהִגִּיעַ לְ״אֶת ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ תִּירָא״ פֵּירַשׁ. אָמְרוּ לוֹ תַּלְמִידָיו: רַבִּי, כׇּל ׳אֶתִּים׳ שֶׁדָּרַשְׁתָּ מָה תְּהֵא עֲלֵיהֶן? אָמַר לָהֶם: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁקִּבַּלְתִּי שָׂכָר עַל הַדְּרִישָׁה, כָּךְ אֲנִי מְקַבֵּל שָׂכָר עַל הַפְּרִישָׁה. עַד שֶׁבָּא רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא וְדָרַשׁ: ״אֶת ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ תִּירָא״ — לְרַבּוֹת תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים.
human_translation: As it was taught Shimon HaAmmassoni, and some say it Neḥemya HaAmmassoni, would interpret all et in the Torah, Once he reached “You shall be in awe of [ et ] the Lord your God; he withdrew His students said to him: Rabbi, what will be with all the etim that you interpreted He said to them: Just as I received reward for the interpretation, so I shall receive reward for withdrawal until Rabbi Akiva came and expounded: “You shall be in awe of [ et ] the Lord your God”: to include Torah scholars,
llm_translation: As it was taught: Shimon HaAmsoni, and some say it was Nehemiah HaAmsoni, used to expound every "et" in the Torah. Once he reached the verse "You shall fear the Lord your God," he interpreted it. His disciples said to him: Rabbi, for all the "ets" that you have expounded, what will be their reward? He said to them: Just as I received reward for expounding, so too I receive reward for refraining. Until Rabbi Akiva came and expounded: "You shall fear the Lord your God" — to include the disciples of the sages.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי עׇרְלָה, דְּרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״עֲרֵלִים לֹא יֵאָכֵל״, וְתַנְיָא: ״עֲרֵלִים לֹא יֵאָכֵל״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא אִיסּוּר אֲכִילָה. מִנַּיִן שֶׁלֹּא יֵהָנֶה מִמֶּנּוּ, שֶׁלֹּא יִצְבַּע בּוֹ, וְלֹא יַדְלִיק בּוֹ אֶת הַנֵּר? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וַעֲרַלְתֶּם עׇרְלָתוֹ ... עֲרֵלִים לֹא יֵאָכֵל״ — לְרַבּוֹת אֶת כּוּלָּם.
human_translation: And fruit that grows on a tree during the first three years after it was planted [ orla ], as the Merciful One says: prohibited [ arelim ] it shall not be eaten” And it was taught prohibited it shall not be eaten”: I have only derived a prohibition to eat From where do I derive that one may not benefit from it, he may not paint with nor may he light a lamp with The verse states: “You shall count the fruit thereof [ orlato ] as prohibited [ araltem ]; prohibited [ arelim ] to you; it shall not be eaten.” to include all forms
llm_translation: Behold, regarding foreskin, for the Merciful One said: "Uncircumcised males shall not eat," and it was taught: "Uncircumcised males shall not eat," I have only the prohibition of eating. From where do we derive that one should not benefit from it, should not anoint with it, and should not light a candle with it? The Talmud teaches: "And you shall circumcise the foreskin of his flesh... uncircumcised males shall not eat" — to include all of them.

hebrew_text: טַעְמָא דִּכְתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״וַעֲרַלְתֶּם עׇרְלָתוֹ ... עֲרֵלִים״, הָא לָאו הָכִי, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: אִיסּוּר אֲכִילָה — מַשְׁמַע, אִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה — לָא מַשְׁמַע!
human_translation: The reason is that the Merciful One writes: “You shall count as prohibited [ araltem ]; shall it be prohibited [ arelim ].” However, were that not I would have said: The prohibition of eating is indicated the prohibition to benefit is not indicated.
llm_translation: Reason for which wrote the Merciful One "And you shall circumcise the foreskin of... uncircumcised," this is not so, I would say: Prohibition of eating — implies, prohibition of benefit — does not imply!

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״ מַשְׁמַע בֵּין אִיסּוּר אֲכִילָה בֵּין אִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה, וְשָׁאנֵי הָתָם דִּכְתִיב ״לָכֶם״. וְאִצְטְרִיךְ, סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וּכְתַב ״לָכֶם״ — שֶׁלָּכֶם יְהֵא, קָמַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Actually, “it shall not be eaten” indicates both a prohibition of eating and a prohibition to benefit. However, it is different there, as it is written: to you.” And, it was necessary it could enter your mind to say since it wrote “to you” it shall be yours, it teaches us
llm_translation: Forever "not shall be eaten" implies whether prohibition of eating or prohibition of benefit, and different there because it is written "for you." And it is necessary, it is logical to say: since it is written "for you" - it shall be yours, it teaches us.

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא הַשְׁתָּא דִּכְתִיבִי הָנָךְ קְרָאֵי, ״לָכֶם״ לְמָה לִי? לְכִדְתַנְיָא: ״לָכֶם״, לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הַנָּטוּעַ
human_translation: However, now that these verses are written, why do I “to you,” As it was taught “To you,” to include that which is planted
llm_translation: And rather this now that it is written "to you" - for what do I need it? As it was taught: "to you", to include the one planted.

hebrew_text: לְרַבִּים. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: לְהוֹצִיא אֶת הַנָּטוּעַ לְרַבִּים.
human_translation: for the public; Rabbi Yehuda says: to exclude a tree planted for the public,
llm_translation: To the many. Rabbi Yehuda says: to remove the planted item to the many.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּתַנָּא קַמָּא — דִּכְתִיב ״וּנְטַעְתֶּם״, לְיָחִיד מַשְׁמַע, לְרַבִּים לָא מַשְׁמַע. כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״לָכֶם״ — לְהָבִיא אֶת הַנָּטוּעַ לְרַבִּים. וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה: ״וּנְטַעְתֶּם״ מַשְׁמַע בֵּין לְרַבִּים בֵּין לְיָחִיד, וְ״לָכֶם״ בֵּין יָחִיד בֵּין רַבִּים מַשְׁמַע. הָוֵי רִבּוּי אַחַר רִבּוּי — וְאֵין רִבּוּי אַחַר רִבּוּי אֶלָּא לְמַעֵט.
human_translation: What is the reason of the first tanna ? As it is written: “And you shall plant.” to an individual is indicated, for the public is not indicated the Merciful One writes “for you” to include that which is planted for the public. And Rabbi Yehuda “and you shall plant” indicates both to for the public and for an individual; “for you” indicates both to an individual and for the public. is one amplificatory expression after another, one amplificatory expression after another is restrictive.
llm_translation: What is the reason that the first Tanna taught — as it is written "and you shall plant," it implies for an individual, it does not imply for many. The Merciful One wrote "for you" — to bring the one who planted for many. And Rabbi Yehuda: "and you shall plant" implies both for many and for an individual, and "for you" implies for both an individual and many. There is a ribbuy after a ribbuy — and a ribbuy after a ribbuy is only to exclude.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי תְּרוּמָה, דְּרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״וְכׇל זָר לֹא יֹאכַל קֹדֶשׁ״, וּתְנַן: מְעָרְבִין לְנָזִיר בְּיַיִן, וּלְיִשְׂרָאֵל בִּתְרוּמָה!
human_translation: And teruma , as the Merciful One says: “No stranger shall eat of the sacred food; And we learned One establish an eiruv , on behalf of a nazirite with wine, And on behalf of an Israelite with teruma ,
llm_translation: Behold the Trumah, for the Merciful One said: "And any stranger shall not eat holy things." And we learned: One may mix wine for a Nazirite, and for an Israelite with Trumah!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״תְּרוּמַתְכֶם״ — שֶׁלָּכֶם תְּהֵא. וְאִידַּךְ? ״תְּרוּמַתְכֶם״ — דְּכׇל יִשְׂרָאֵל קָאָמַר.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: It is different there, as the verse said: your teruma shall be yours; And the other “Your teruma ” of the entire Jewish people.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: The difference there is that the verse says "your contribution" - it should be yours. And the other? "Your contribution" - it means all of Israel.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי נָזִיר, דְּרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״מֵחַרְצַנִּים וְעַד זָג לֹא יֹאכֵל״, וּתְנַן: מְעָרְבִין לַנָּזִיר בְּיַיִן. אָמַר מָר זוּטְרָא: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״נִזְרוֹ״ — שֶׁלּוֹ יְהֵא.
human_translation: And the nazirite as the Merciful One says: he shall eat nothing from the seeds to the grape skin” And we learned One establish an eiruv a nazirite with wine Mar Zutra said: It is different there, as the verse said: “His naziriteship.” it shall be his;
llm_translation: Behold, regarding a Nazirite, for the Merciful One said: "From grape seeds to grape skins he shall not eat." And we learned: One may mix wine for a Nazirite. Mar Zutra said: It is different there, as the verse says "his separation" - let it be his.

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: ״קָדֹשׁ יִהְיֶה גַּדֵּל פֶּרַע שְׂעַר רֹאשׁוֹ״, גִּידּוּלוֹ קָדוֹשׁ, וְאֵין דָּבָר אַחֵר קָדוֹשׁ. מִידֵּי ״וְאֵין דָּבָר אַחֵר״ כְּתִיב?! אֶלָּא מְחַוַּורְתָּא כִּדְמָר זוּטְרָא.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: “He shall be sacred, he shall let the locks of the hair of his head grow long” the growth is sacred but no other element is sacred. And is it written: No other element Rather, it is clear in accordance with Mar Zutra.
llm_translation: Rav Ashe said: "Holy shall he be, let him grow the hair of his head long," his growth is holy, and there is nothing else holy. From where is it written "and there is nothing else"? Rather, it is a tradition like the teaching of Mar Zutra.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי חָדָשׁ, דְּרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״לֶחֶם וְקָלִי וְכַרְמֶל לֹא תֹאכְלוּ עַד עֶצֶם הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה״, וּתְנַן: קוֹצֵר לְשַׁחַת, וּמַאֲכִיל לַבְּהֵמָה!
human_translation: And new as the Merciful One says: “And you shall eat neither bread, nor parched grain, nor fresh stalks until this day itself, And we learned One harvest as fodder and feed it to his animal.
llm_translation: Behold, it is new, as the Merciful One said: "You shall not eat bread, roasted grain, or fresh ears until this very day," and we learned: One may harvest for destruction and feed to the animals!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב שְׁמַעְיָה: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם דְּאָמַר קְרָא: ״קְצִירְכֶם״ — קְצִירְכֶם שֶׁלָּכֶם יְהֵא. וְאִידַּךְ? ״קְצִירְכֶם״ — דְּכׇל יִשְׂרָאֵל מַשְׁמַע.
human_translation: Rav Shemaya said: It is different there, as the verse said: “Your harvest” your harvest will be yours. And the other “your harvest” of the entire Jewish people.
llm_translation: Rav Shemaya said: It is different there, as the verse says: "Your harvest" - your harvest shall be yours. And the other? "Your harvest" - that all of Israel may hear.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי שְׁרָצִים, דְּרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״שֶׁקֶץ הוּא לֹא יֵאָכֵל״, וּתְנַן: צַיָּידֵי חַיָּה וְעוֹפוֹת וְדָגִים שֶׁנִּזְדַּמְּנוּ לָהֶם מִינִין טְמֵאִין — מוּתָּרִין לְמוֹכְרָן לְגוֹיִם. שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּאָמַר קְרָא: ״לָכֶם״ — שֶׁלָּכֶם יְהֵא.
human_translation: And creeping animals, as the Merciful One says: is a detestable thing; it shall not be eaten” And we learned If hunters of undomesticated animals, birds, and fish happen to catch non-kosher species it is permitted for them to sell to gentiles. It is different there, as the verse said: “For you” they will be yours,
llm_translation: And behold, regarding swarming creatures, for the Merciful One said: "It is an abomination, it shall not be eaten." And we learned: Hunters of wild animals, birds, and fish that have species of unclean animals mixed among them - it is permitted to sell them to gentiles. It is different there, for the verse says: "to you" - it shall be yours.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, אֲפִילּוּ לְכַתְּחִלָּה נָמֵי! שָׁאנֵי הָכָא, דְּאָמַר קְרָא: ״יִהְיוּ״ — בַּהֲוָיָיתָן יְהוּ.
human_translation: If so, even also It is different here, as the verse said: “They shall be” they shall be as they are.
llm_translation: If so, even at the outset, yes! It is different here, as the verse says: "They shall be" - in their existence they shall be.

hebrew_text: וּלְחִזְקִיָּה, לְמָה לִי לְמִיכְתַּב ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״, וּמַיְיתֵי ״לָכֶם״ לְמִישְׁרְיֵיהּ? לָא לִכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״, וְלָא בָּעֵי ״לָכֶם״! אָמַר לָךְ חִזְקִיָּה, טַעְמָא דִּידִי נָמֵי מֵהָכָא.
human_translation: And according to Ḥizkiya, why do I to write: “It shall not be eaten,” and to say: “For you,” to permit them? Let the Merciful One not write: “It shall not be eaten,” and it will not need “For you.” Ḥizkiya said to you: My reason is also from here,
llm_translation: Regarding Hezekiah, why do I need it to be written "it shall not be eaten," and it brings "for you" to make it straight? It is not necessary for the Merciful One to write "it shall not be eaten," and it does not need "for you"! Hezekiah said to you, the reason is also derived from here.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי חָמֵץ, דְּרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל חָמֵץ״, וְתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי אוֹמֵר: תְּמַהּ עַל עַצְמְךָ הֵיאַךְ חָמֵץ אָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה כׇּל שִׁבְעָה? שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּאָמַר קְרָא: ״וְלֹא יֵרָאֶה לְךָ שְׂאוֹר״ — שֶׁלְּךָ יְהֵא.
human_translation: And leavened bread, the Merciful One says: “Leavened bread shall not be eaten,” it was taught Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: Be astounded with yourself; how is it prohibited benefit leavened bread all seven It is different there, as the verse said: neither shall there be leaven seen with you, it is yours,
llm_translation: Behold, regarding chametz, for the Merciful One said: "Chametz shall not be eaten." And it was taught: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean says: It is astonishing upon yourself, how is chametz prohibited for benefit all seven days? It is different there, as the verse states: "And no leaven shall be seen with you" — yours shall it be.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן? שֶׁלְּךָ אִי אַתָּה רוֹאֶה, אֲבָל אַתָּה רוֹאֶה שֶׁל אֲחֵרִים וְשֶׁל גָּבוֹהַּ. וְאִידַּךְ? תְּרֵי ״לְךָ״ כְּתִיבִי.
human_translation: And the Rabbis, you not see your own however, you see of others and to God And the other two “with you” written.
llm_translation: The Sages? Yours you do not see, but you see the property of others and that which is high. And the other? Two "yours" are written for you.

hebrew_text: וְאִידַּךְ? חַד — בְּגוֹי שֶׁכִּיבַּשְׁתּוֹ, וְחַד — בְּגוֹי שֶׁלֹּא כִּיבַּשְׁתּוֹ. וְאִידַּךְ? תְּלָתָא ״לְךָ״ כְּתִיבִי. וְאִידַּךְ? חַד — בִּשְׂאוֹר, וְחַד — בְּחָמֵץ. וּצְרִיכִי.
human_translation: And the other One with regard to a gentile whom he has conquered, And the other with regard to a gentile whom he has not conquered. And the other three “with you” written. And the other once leaven, and once leavened bread. And they are necessary
llm_translation: The other one? One - with a nation that dried it, and one - with a nation that did not dry it. And the other one? Three "to you" are written. And the other one? One - with leaven, and one - with sourdough. And it is necessary.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא כְּתַנָּאֵי. ״יֵעָשֶׂה לְכׇל מְלָאכָה״, מַה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְכׇל מְלָאכָה״, שֶׁיָּכוֹל לִמְלֶאכֶת גָּבוֹהַּ יְהֵא מוּתָּר, לִמְלֶאכֶת הֶדְיוֹט יְהֵא אָסוּר, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְכׇל מְלָאכָה״ — דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי.
human_translation: Let us say is parallel to a tanna’im . may be used for any other service; What the verse states: “For any other service”? might that to the Temple service it should be permitted However, to common use it should be prohibited the verse states: “For any other service,” the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili.
llm_translation: Let us say like the Tannaim: "Shall be done for all work," what does the Torah teach us to say: "for all work," that one may be permitted to perform a high-level work, but for a mundane work, it shall be prohibited. The Torah teaches us to say: "for all work" - these are the words of Rabbi Yosei HaGalili.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: שֶׁיָּכוֹל לִמְלֶאכֶת הֶדְיוֹט יְהֵא טָהוֹר, לִמְלֶאכֶת גָּבוֹהַּ יְהֵא טָמֵא, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְכׇל מְלָאכָה״.
human_translation: Rabbi Akiva says: might that to common use should be pure; to the Temple service it should be impure. the verse states: “For any other service,”
llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva says: One who is able to engage in common work should be considered pure, while one who is engaged in sacred work should be considered impure. It is taught in the Scripture: "For all work."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי, לְטוּמְאָה וּלְטׇהֳרָה לָא אִיצְטְרִיךְ קְרָא. כִּי אִיצְטְרִיךְ קְרָא — לְאִיסּוּר וּלְהֶיתֵּר. וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, אִיסּוּר וְהֶיתֵּר לָא צְרִיךְ קְרָא, כִּי אִיצְטְרִיךְ קְרָא — לְטוּמְאָה וּלְטׇהֳרָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei HaGelili with regard to purity and impurity no verse is necessary, The verse is necessary to prohibited or permitted And Rabbi Akiva prohibited or permitted no verse is necessary; it is necessary to ritual purity or impurity.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, for impurity and purity, does not require a verse. When does he require a verse? For prohibition and permission. And Rabbi Akiva, for prohibition and permission, does not require a verse, when does he require a verse? For impurity and purity.

hebrew_text: מַאי לָאו בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי, דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי סָבַר: ״לֹא תֹאכְלוּ״ מַשְׁמַע בֵּין אִיסּוּר אֲכִילָה בֵּין אִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה, וְכִי אֲתָא קְרָא לְמִישְׁרְיַיהּ לִנְבֵילָה — בַּהֲנָאָה הוּא דַּאֲתָא. וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא סָבַר: אִיסּוּר אֲכִילָה — מַשְׁמַע, אִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה לָא מַשְׁמַע. וְכִי אֲתָא קְרָא — לְטוּמְאָה וְטׇהֳרָה.
human_translation: What, is it not that they disagree about this, Rabbi Yosei HaGelili holds: “You shall not eat” indicates both the prohibition of eating and the prohibition of benefit; And when the verse came it came to permit benefit an animal carcass. And Rabbi Akiva holds: “You shall not eat” indicates a prohibition of eating; it does not indicate a prohibition of benefit. When the verse came it came ritual purity and impurity.
llm_translation: What is the reason that they do not argue about this? For Rabbi Yosei the Galilean holds: "Do not eat" implies prohibition of both consumption and benefit, and when the verse comes to permit regarding a carcass, it is regarding benefit. And Rabbi Akiva holds: Prohibition of consumption is implied, but prohibition of benefit is not implied. And when the verse comes, it is regarding ritual impurity and purity.

hebrew_text: לָא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא ״לֹא תֹאכְלוּ״ מַשְׁמַע בֵּין אִיסּוּר אֲכִילָה בֵּין אִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה. וְהָכָא בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי סָבַר: כְּשֶׁהוּתְּרָה נְבֵילָה — הִיא הוּתְּרָה, חֶלְבָּהּ וְגִידָהּ — לֹא הוּתְּרוּ. וְכִי אִיצְטְרִיךְ קְרָא — לְהֶיתֵּר הֲנָאָה הוּא דַּאֲתָא. וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא סָבַר: כְּשֶׁהוּתְּרָה נְבֵילָה — חֶלְבָּהּ וְגִידָהּ נָמֵי הוּתְּרוּ. וְכִי אִיצְטְרִיךְ קְרָא — לְטוּמְאָה וְטׇהֳרָה.
human_translation: No, that everyone “You shall not eat” indicates both a prohibition of eating and a prohibition of benefit. And here, they disagree about this: Rabbi Yosei HaGelili holds that when it was permitted an animal carcass, was permitted; its fat and its sinews were not permitted. And the verse is necessary to permit benefit Rabbi Akiva holds: When it was permitted from an animal carcass, it was also permitted its fat and sinews. the verse is necessary for purity and impurity.
llm_translation: Not, that all the world "do not eat" implies whether prohibition of eating or prohibition of benefit. And here in this case they dispute, Rabbi Yosei the Galilean holds: when the carcass is permitted — it is permitted, but its fat and sinew are not permitted. And if you require a verse — it is for the permission of benefit that it comes. And Rabbi Akiva holds: when the carcass is permitted — its fat and sinew are also permitted. And if you require a verse — it is for ritual impurity and purity.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי, אַשְׁכְּחַן חֵלֶב דְּשַׁרְיֵיהּ רַחֲמָנָא בַּהֲנָאָה, אֶלָּא גִּיד נֵימָא דְּאָסוּר! אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: הָכִי נָמֵי דְּאָסוּר. אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא, מַיְיתֵי לַהּ בְּקַל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה חֵלֶב שֶׁעָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת — מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה, גִּיד שֶׁאֵינוֹ עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, we find that the Merciful One permits benefit from fat; however, let us say the sinew is prohibited. If you wish, say it is indeed so that it is prohibited if you wish, say derives that through a fortiori If fat, for which one is punished with karet it is permitted benefit, nerve, the punishment is not karet , all the more so not
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean found that the fat of the sinew is permitted for benefit by the Merciful One, but the sinew itself is forbidden! If you wish, say: So indeed it is forbidden. If you wish, say, bring a logical argument: And if the fat that is subject to karet is permitted for benefit, then the sinew that is not subject to karet — all the more so it should be forbidden.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן דְּאָסַר? אִיכָּא לְמִיפְרַךְ, מָה לְחֵלֶב שֶׁכֵּן הוּתַּר מִכְּלָלוֹ אֵצֶל חַיָּה, תֹּאמַר בְּגִיד שֶׁלֹּא הוּתַּר מִכְּלָלוֹ אֵצֶל חַיָּה.
human_translation: And Rabbi Shimon, who prohibits can be refuted, What to fat? that it is released from its general with regard to non-domesticated animals, Can you say with regard to the nerve, which is not released from its general with regard to non-domesticated animals
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon prohibited? There is room to refute: Just as for fat, which is permitted from its general category when it comes to an animal, you would say the same for a sinew that is not permitted from its general category when it comes to an animal.

hebrew_text: וְאִידַּךְ? בִּבְהֵמָה קָאָמְרִינַן — בִּבְהֵמָה מִיהַת לָא אִישְׁתְּרִי.
human_translation: And the other we state with regard to a domesticated animal; in any case, with regard to a domesticated animal is not permitted.
llm_translation: And the other opinion? With regard to an animal we are saying - from an animal it is not permitted.

hebrew_text: מִכְּדֵי אוֹתְבִינְהוּ כׇּל הָנֵי קְרָאֵי וְשַׁנִּינְהוּ. חִזְקִיָּה וְרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ בְּמַאי פְּלִיגִי! בְּחָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח וְאַלִּיבָּא דְרַבָּנַן, בְּשׁוֹר הַנִּסְקָל וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּדִבְרֵי הַכֹּל. חִזְקִיָּה נָפֵיק לֵיהּ מִ״לֹּא יֵאָכֵל״, וְרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ נָפֵיק לֵיהּ מִנְּבֵילָה.
human_translation: Since we raised objections from all of these verses and answered them, with regard to what do Ḥizkiya and Rabbi Abbahu disagree? with leavened bread on Passover, in accordance with the Rabbis, with an ox that is stoned, in accordance with everyone. Ḥizkiya derived from “It shall not be eaten,” and Rabbi Abbahu derived from an animal carcass.
llm_translation: In order to understand all those verses, they explained. Hezekiah and Rabbi Abahu, what do they argue about? With regard to leaven on Passover and the view of the Rabbis, with regard to an ox that is stoned and the view of everyone. Hezekiah derived from "it shall not be eaten," and Rabbi Abahu derived from a carcass.

hebrew_text: מִכְּדִי בֵּין לְמָר וּבֵין לְמָר אֲסוּרִין בַּהֲנָאָה, מַאי בֵּינַיְיהוּ? אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ חוּלִּין שֶׁנִּשְׁחֲטוּ בָּעֲזָרָה. חִזְקִיָּה סָבַר: ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״ — לְמַעוֹטֵי הָנֵי, ״אֹתוֹ״ — לְמַעוֹטֵי חוּלִּין שֶׁנִּשְׁחֲטוּ בַּעֲזָרָה.
human_translation: Now, both according to Master and according to Master, it is prohibited benefit what is between them? between them is non-sacrificial animals that were slaughtered in the courtyard. Ḥizkiya holds: “It shall not be eaten” to exclude these “It to exclude non-sacrificial animals slaughtered in the courtyard,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Between one Master and another Master, they are prohibited in benefit, what is the difference between them? There is a difference between them - secular animals that were slaughtered in the Temple. Hezekiah holds: "It shall not be eaten" - to exclude those, "it" - to exclude secular animals that were slaughtered in the Temple.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ סָבַר: ״אֹתוֹ״ — לְמַעוֹטֵי הָנֵי, חוּלִּין שֶׁנִּשְׁחֲטוּ בַּעֲזָרָה לָאו דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא נִינְהוּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu holds “It to exclude these non-sacrificial animals slaughtered in the courtyard is not by Torah law,
llm_translation: Rabbi Avahu holds: "That" - to exclude those, non-sacred animals that were slaughtered in the Temple are not considered of biblical origin.

hebrew_text: יָתֵיב הָהוּא מֵרַבָּנַן קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי, וְיָתֵיב וְקָאָמַר מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: מִנַּיִן לְכׇל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה דְּכִי הֵיכִי דַּאֲסוּרִין בַּאֲכִילָה הָכִי נָמֵי אֲסוּרִין בַּהֲנָאָה? וּמַאי נִיהוּ — חָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח וְשׁוֹר הַנִּסְקָל. מִנַּיִן?! תִּיפּוֹק לֵיהּ מִ״לֹּא יֵאָכֵל״! ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״, אִיסּוּר אֲכִילָה — מַשְׁמַע לֵיהּ, אִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה — לָא מַשְׁמַע לֵיהּ.
human_translation: One of the Sages sat before Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani, and he sat and said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: From where is it derived to all the prohibitions in the Torah that just as it is prohibited to eat them, so too, it is prohibited to benefit from them? And what are leavened bread on Passover and an ox that is stoned. from where? Derive “It shall not be eaten.” he derived a prohibition of eating “It shall not be eaten”; he did not derive a prohibition of benefit
llm_translation: The one, a Sage, was sitting before Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani, and he was sitting and saying in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: From where do we derive that all prohibitions in the Torah, just as they are prohibited in consumption, so too are they prohibited in benefit? And what is the example? — Chametz on Passover and an ox that is stoned. From where?! Let him derive it from "it shall not be eaten"! "It shall not be eaten," a prohibition of consumption — he accepts it, a prohibition of benefit — he does not accept it.

hebrew_text: תִּיפּוֹק לֵיהּ מִנְּבֵילָה?! סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, דְּאָמַר: דְּבָרִים כִּכְתָבָן.
human_translation: Derive from animal carcass. holds in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, who said matters are as they are written,
llm_translation: He should go out from a carcass?! He thought like Rabbi Yehuda, who said: Words as they are written.

hebrew_text: אִי סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, תִּיפּוֹק לֵיהּ מֵהֵיכָא דְּנָפְקָא לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, מִ״לַּכֶּלֶב תַּשְׁלִיכוּן אֹתוֹ״!
human_translation: If he holds in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, let him derive from where Rabbi Yehuda derives it, from you shall cast it to the dog”
llm_translation: If she thinks like Rabbi Yehuda, she should push him away from where he came out to Rabbi Yehuda, "You shall throw it to the dogs!"

hebrew_text: קָסָבַר: חוּלִּין שֶׁנִּשְׁחֲטוּ בָּעֲזָרָה דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא. מִנַּיִן, דִּכְתִיב: ״כׇּל חַטָּאת אֲשֶׁר יוּבָא מִדָּמָהּ וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: holds non-sacrificial animals that were slaughtered in the courtyard is by Torah law, from where As it is written: “And no sin-offering, of which any of the blood is brought
llm_translation: He holds: Non-sacred animals that were slaughtered in the Temple courtyard are considered biblically valid. From where do we derive this? As it is written: "Any sin offering whose blood is brought forth..."

hebrew_text: שֶׁאֵין תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״בָּאֵשׁ תִּשָּׂרֵף״, וּמָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״בָּאֵשׁ תִּשָּׂרֵף״? אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לְגוּפוֹ, דִּכְתִיב ״וְהִנֵּה שֹׂרָף״, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לְכׇל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה.
human_translation: As no the verse to state: “It shall be burnt with fire”; And what the verse state: “It shall be burnt with fire”? If it does not matter itself as it is written: and, behold, it was burnt” apply it to the matter of all the prohibitions in the Torah.
llm_translation: The Talmud does not say "he shall be burned with fire," so what does the Talmud say "he shall be burned with fire"? If it is not relevant to its subject matter, as it is written "and behold, it is burning," give it relevance to all prohibitions in the Torah.

hebrew_text: וְאִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לַאֲכִילָה, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לְאִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה.
human_translation: And if it does not the matter of eating, apply it to the matter of the prohibition of benefit.
llm_translation: And if it is not a matter for eating, give it the status of forbidden benefit.

hebrew_text: אִי, מָה כָּאן בִּשְׂרֵיפָה — אַף כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה בִּשְׂרֵיפָה! אָמַר קְרָא ״בַּקֹּדֶשׁ ... בָּאֵשׁ תִּשָּׂרֵף״, בַּקֹּדֶשׁ — בִּשְׂרֵיפָה, וְאֵין כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה בִּשְׂרֵיפָה.
human_translation: Lest just as here, with burning, so too, all the prohibited in the Torah with burning, the verse said: “In the sacred place…shall be burnt with fire” in the sacred place with burning, but all prohibited in the Torah not with burning.
llm_translation: Here is the English translation of the Talmudic text: "If, what is here with burning — so too all prohibitions in the Torah with burning! The verse says, 'In the holy... with fire it shall be burned,' in the holy — with burning, and there are no prohibitions in the Torah with burning."

hebrew_text: וְהַאי ״בַּקֹּדֶשׁ ... בָּאֵשׁ תִּשָּׂרֵף״ לְהָכִי הוּא דַּאֲתָא?! הַאי מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן! דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: ״בַּקֹּדֶשׁ ... בָּאֵשׁ תִּשָּׂרֵף״ — לִימֵּד עַל חַטָּאת שֶׁשּׂוֹרְפִין אוֹתָהּ בַּקֹּדֶשׁ. וְאֵין לִי אֶלָּא זוֹ בִּלְבַד, פְּסוּלֵי קׇדְשֵׁי קָדָשִׁים וְאֵמוּרֵי קָדָשִׁים קַלִּים מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״(וְכׇל) בַּקֹּדֶשׁ ... בָּאֵשׁ תִּשָּׂרֵף״.
human_translation: And did this “In the sacred place…shall be burnt with fire,” come to this It is needed in accordance with Rabbi Shimon, as it was taught Rabbi Shimon says: “In the sacred place…shall be burnt with fire”; taught that one burn a sin-offering in the sacred place, And I have only this, From where do I derive that disqualified offerings of the most sacred order and portions consumed of offerings of minor sanctity The verse states: “In the sacred place…shall be burnt with fire.”
llm_translation: This "in the holy... it shall be burned with fire" - is this the reason why it came?! This one requires it for like Rabbi Shimon! For it was taught, Rabbi Shimon says: "in the holy... it shall be burned with fire" - he taught about the sin offering that is burned in the holy place. And I have only this, how do we know that disqualified holy items and light holy items are also burned? The verse teaches: "(And all) in the holy... it shall be burned with fire."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ, רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן רַבָּךְ מֵהַאי קְרָא קָאָמַר לַהּ: ״וְאִם יִוָּתֵר מִבְּשַׂר הַמִּלֻּאִים וּמִן הַלֶּחֶם עַד הַבֹּקֶר וְגוֹ׳״, שֶׁאֵין תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״, וּמָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״ — אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לְגוּפֵיהּ, דְּהָא כְּתִיב ״וְשָׂרַפְתָּ אֶת הַנּוֹתָר בָּאֵשׁ״, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לִשְׁאָר אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה. וְאִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לַאֲכִילָה, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לְאִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה.
human_translation: said to him: Rabbi Yonatan, your teacher, said that from this verse: “And if the flesh of the consecration or of the bread, remains until the morning, As no the verse to state: “It shall not be eaten,” what the verse states: “It shall not be eaten”? If it does not refer to the matter itself, as it is written “Then you shall burn the leftover with fire,” refer it to the matter of the other prohibitions in the Torah. And if it does not refer to the matter of eating, refer it to the matter of the prohibition of benefit.
llm_translation: He said to him, "Rabbi Yonatan, your teacher, from this verse he said to her: 'And if it is left over from the flesh of the ordination offering and from the bread until morning, etc.' - because the Talmud does not say 'it shall not be eaten,' and what does the Talmud say 'it shall not be eaten' - if it is not relevant to itself, for it is written 'and you shall burn the remainder with fire,' give it relevance to other prohibitions in the Torah. And if it is not relevant to eating, give it relevance to the prohibition of benefit."

hebrew_text: אִי, מָה כָּאן בִּשְׂרֵיפָה, אַף כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה בִּשְׂרֵיפָה! אָמַר קְרָא ״וְשָׂרַפְתָּ אֶת הַנּוֹתָר״ — נוֹתָר בִּשְׂרֵיפָה, וְאֵין כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה בִּשְׂרֵיפָה.
human_translation: Lest just as here, with burning, so too, all the prohibited in the Torah, with burning, the verse said: “You shall burn the leftover,” leftover with burning; however, all prohibitions in the Torah not with burning,
llm_translation: If, what here in burning, also all prohibitions in the Torah in burning! Scripture says "and you shall burn the remainder" - remainder in burning, and all prohibitions in the Torah in burning.

hebrew_text: וְהַאי ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״ לְהָכִי הוּא דַּאֲתָא? הַאי מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל כִּי קֹדֶשׁ הוּא״ — כׇּל שֶׁבַּקֹּדֶשׁ פָּסוּל, בָּא הַכָּתוּב לִיתֵּן לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה עַל אֲכִילָתוֹ.
human_translation: And did this “It shall not be eaten,” come this This is needed in accordance with Rabbi Elazar, as Rabbi Elazar said “It shall not be eaten, because it is sacred,” the verse comes to place a negative eating on whatever has been disqualified in the sacred place.
llm_translation: This "shall not be eaten," for this reason did it come? This one requires it for the teaching of Rabbi Elazar. For Rabbi Elazar said: "It shall not be eaten because it is holy" - anything that is disqualified in matters of holiness, the verse comes to say "you shall not do" regarding its consumption.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לְעוֹלָם מִקְרָא קַמָּא, וְאֵיפוֹךְ: דְּלִיכְתּוֹב ״בָּאֵשׁ תִּשָּׂרֵף״, וְלָא בָּעֵי ״לֹא תֵאָכֵל״, מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״לֹא תֵאָכֵל״ — אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לְגוּפוֹ, דְּנָפְקָא לֵיהּ מִדְּרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לְכׇל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה. וְאִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לַאֲכִילָה, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לְאִיסּוּר הֲנָאָה.
human_translation: Abaye said: Actually, from the first verse And reverse Let write: “It shall be burnt with fire,” and it not need “Shall not be eaten.” what the verse state: “It shall not be eaten”? If it does not apply to matter itself, as that was derived from Rabbi Elazar apply it to all prohibitions in the Torah, And if it does not eating, apply it to the prohibition of benefit.
llm_translation: Abaye said: Always prioritize the first verse, and the opposite: for it is written "it shall be burned with fire," and not "it shall not be eaten." What is the teaching when it says "it shall not be eaten" — if it is not relevant to its substance, as it was derived from Rabbi Elazar, give it relevance to all prohibitions in the Torah. And if it is not relevant to eating, give it relevance to the prohibition of benefit.

hebrew_text: אִי מָה כָּאן בִּשְׂרֵיפָה, אַף כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה בִּשְׂרֵיפָה. אָמַר קְרָא ״הַנּוֹתָר״ — הַנּוֹתָר בִּשְׂרֵיפָה, וְאֵין כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה בִּשְׂרֵיפָה.
human_translation: Lest just as here, with burning, so too, all the prohibited in the Torah, with burning, the verse said: the leftover,” leftover be with burning; however, all prohibited in the Torah not with burning.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: If here in burning, so too all prohibitions in the Torah in burning. Scripture says "the remainder" - the remainder in burning, and all prohibitions in the Torah in burning.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב פָּפָּא לְאַבָּיֵי: וְאֵימָא לְיַחוֹדֵי לֵיהּ לָאו לְגוּפֵיהּ הוּא דַּאֲתָא, דְּאִי מִדְּרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר — אֵין לוֹקִין עַל לָאו שֶׁבִּכְלָלוֹת.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said to Abaye: And Say comes to designate a negative itself. As, if from Rabbi Elazar, one is not flogged for a negative stated in general terms.
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Papa to Abbaye: And why not say that he came for its own uniqueness, not for itself, for if according to Rabbi Elazar - they do not flog for a negative commandment that includes positives.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא, מֵהָכָא: ״וְהַבָּשָׂר אֲשֶׁר יִגַּע בְּכׇל טָמֵא לֹא יֵאָכֵל בָּאֵשׁ יִשָּׂרֵף״, שֶׁאֵין תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״, מַה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״?
human_translation: Rather, Rav Pappa said from here: “And the flesh that touches any impure thing shall not be eaten; it shall be burnt with fire. As no the verse to state: “It shall not be eaten,” what the verse states: “It shall not be eaten”?
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Papa said, from here: "And the flesh that touches any unclean thing shall not be eaten; it shall be burned with fire." The Torah does not need to say "shall not be eaten," so why does the Torah say "shall not be eaten"?

hebrew_text: אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לְגוּפוֹ, דְּהָא נָפְקָא לֵיהּ מִקַּל וָחוֹמֶר מִמַּעֲשֵׂר הַקַּל: וּמָה מַעֲשֵׂר הַקַּל, אָמְרָה תּוֹרָה ״לֹא בִעַרְתִּי מִמֶּנּוּ בְּטָמֵא״ — בְּשַׂר קֹדֶשׁ חָמוּר לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?!
human_translation: If it does not matter itself, as that derived by an a fortiori from tithe, which lenient If tithe, which is lenient the Torah said neither have I removed it while impure” consecrated meat, stringent, all the more so not
llm_translation: If it is not relevant to his body, for it is derived from a fortiori argument from the lighter tithe: And what is the lighter tithe? The Torah said, "I have not eaten of it while in mourning" - holy flesh is stringent, how much more so?!

hebrew_text: וְכִי תֵּימָא ״אֵין מַזְהִירִין מִן הַדִּין״. הֶקֵּישָׁא הוּא, דִּכְתִיב: ״לֹא תוּכַל לֶאֱכֹל בִּשְׁעָרֶיךָ מַעְשַׂר דְּגָנְךָ תִּירֹשְׁךָ וְיִצְהָרֶךָ וּבְכֹרֹת בְּקָרְךָ וְגוֹ׳״ —
human_translation: And if you say we do not warn, through logical derivation it is a juxtaposition. As it is written: “You may not eat within your gates the tithe of your grain, or of your wine, or of your oil, or the firstborn of your herd
llm_translation: "And if you say, 'We are not cautious about the law.' It is a comparison, as it is written: 'You may not eat within your gates the tithe of your grain, your wine, your oil, the firstborn of your herd, etc.' —"

hebrew_text: מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״? אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לְגוּפוֹ, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לְכׇל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה. וְאִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לַאֲכִילָה, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לַהֲנָאָה.
human_translation: what purpose the verse state: “It shall not be eaten” If it does not the matter itself, apply it to the matter of all prohibited in the Torah. And if it does not eating, apply it to the prohibition of benefit.
llm_translation: What is the Talmud saying "he shall not eat"? If it is not relevant to his body, attribute it to all prohibitions in the Torah. And if it is not relevant to eating, attribute it to pleasure.

hebrew_text: אִי, מָה כָּאן בִּשְׂרֵיפָה — אַף כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה בִּשְׂרֵיפָה! אָמַר קְרָא ״הַנּוֹתָר״ — הַנּוֹתָר בִּשְׂרֵיפָה, וְאֵין כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה בִּשְׂרֵיפָה.
human_translation: Lest just as here, with burning, so too, all the prohibited in the Torah with burning, the verse said: “The leftover,” that the leftover with burning; however, all prohibited in the Torah not with burning.
llm_translation: Here is the English word-for-word translation of the Talmudic text: "If, what here in burning — also all prohibitions in the Torah in burning! Said Scripture 'the remainder' — the remainder in burning, and no all prohibitions in the Torah in burning."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: וְאֵימָא, לַעֲבוֹר עָלָיו בִּשְׁנֵי לָאוִין. לָאו מִי אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: אָכַל פּוּטִיתָא — לוֹקֶה אַרְבַּע.
human_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: And say violates two prohibitions. didn’t Abaye say If one ate a small water creature putita he is flogged four
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: And why not, to transgress upon him with two negative commandments. Did not Abaye say: If one eats a pittance - he is liable for lashes fourfold.

hebrew_text: נְמָלָה — לוֹקֶה חָמֵשׁ.
human_translation: an ant, he is flogged five
llm_translation: Ant: "Nemalah - lokeh chamesh."

hebrew_text: צִירְעָה — לוֹקֶה שֵׁשׁ! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: כֹּל הֵיכָא דְּאִיכָּא לְמִדְרַשׁ — דָּרְשִׁינַן, וְלָא מוֹקְמִינַן בְּלָאוֵי יַתִּירֵי.
human_translation: a hornet, he is flogged six said to him: Anywhere that it is possible to expound we expound, and we do not establish additional negative
llm_translation: Tzir'ah - he receives lashes six! He said to him: wherever there is a place for interpretation - we interpret, and we do not establish with unnecessary stringencies.

hebrew_text: ״וְהַבָּשָׂר אֲשֶׁר יִגַּע בְּכׇל טָמֵא לֹא יֵאָכֵל״ דְּרֵישֵׁיהּ לְמָה לִי? לְרַבּוֹת עֵצִים וּלְבוֹנָה. ״וְהַבָּשָׂר כׇּל טָהוֹר יֹאכַל בָּשָׂר״ דְּסֵיפֵיהּ לְמָה לִי? לְרַבּוֹת אֵימוּרִין.
human_translation: Why do I the beginning “And the flesh that touches any impure thing shall not be eaten” to include wood and incense; Why do I the end “And as for the flesh, every one that is pure may eat of it” to include sacrificial parts
llm_translation: "And the flesh that touches any unclean thing shall not be eaten." Why do I need its interpretation? To include wood and frankincense. "And the flesh of any clean animal may be eaten." Why do I need its conclusion? To include sayings.

hebrew_text: אֵימוּרִין מֵהָתָם נָפְקָא, דְּתַנְיָא: ״וְהַנֶּפֶשׁ אֲשֶׁר תֹּאכַל בָּשָׂר מִזֶּבַח הַשְּׁלָמִים אֲשֶׁר לַה׳״ — לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הָאֵימוּרִין!
human_translation: sacrificial parts is derived from there, as it was taught “But the soul that eats from the flesh of the sacrifice of peace-offerings, which belong to the Lord, to include sacrificial parts,
llm_translation: Sayings from there come out, as it is taught: "And the soul that will eat flesh of the sacrifice of peace offerings to the Lord" - to include the sayings!

hebrew_text: הָתָם טוּמְאַת הַגּוּף — בְּכָרֵת, הָכָא טוּמְאַת בָּשָׂר — בְּלָאו.
human_translation: There, impurity of the body; with karet . Here, impurity of the flesh, of a negative
llm_translation: There, impurity of the body — with excision; here, impurity of flesh — with a negative commandment.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה אֵין לוֹקִין עֲלֵיהֶן אֶלָּא דֶּרֶךְ אֲכִילָתָן. לְמַעוֹטֵי מַאי? אָמַר רַב שִׁימִי בַּר אָשֵׁי: לְמַעוֹטֵי שֶׁאִם אָכַל חֵלֶב חַי, שֶׁפָּטוּר.
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: all prohibitions in the Torah, one may be flogged for them only manner of consumption. To exclude what Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: To exclude where one eats raw fat; that is exempt,
llm_translation: Rabbi Avahu said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: All prohibitions in the Torah, one is only liable for them through their normal form of consumption. What is excluded? Rav Shimi bar Ashe said: Excluded are cases where one ate raw fat, for which he is exempt.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְאָמְרִי, אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה אֵין לוֹקִין עֲלֵיהֶן אֶלָּא דֶּרֶךְ הֲנָאָתָן. לְמַעוֹטֵי מַאי? אָמַר רַב שִׁימִי בַּר אָשֵׁי: לְמַעוֹטֵי שֶׁאִם הִנִּיחַ חֵלֶב שֶׁל שׁוֹר הַנִּסְקָל עַל גַּבֵּי מַכָּתוֹ, שֶׁהוּא פָּטוּר. וְכׇל שֶׁכֵּן אוֹכֵל חֵלֶב חַי, שֶׁהוּא פָּטוּר.
human_translation: Some say Rabbi Abbahu said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: all prohibitions in the Torah, one is flogged for them only benefit manner. To exclude what Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: To exclude where one placed the fat of an ox that is stoned on his wound that, he is exempt And all the more so one who eats raw fat is exempt,
llm_translation: There are those who say, Rabbi Avahu said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: All prohibitions in the Torah, one is not liable for them except in a way that benefits them. What is the exclusion for? Rav Shimi bar Ashe said: The exclusion is for one who left the fat of an ox that was stoned on top of its wound, he is exempt. And certainly one who eats live fat is exempt.

hebrew_text: אִתְּמַר נָמֵי, אָמַר רַב אַחָא בַּר עַוְיָה אָמַר רַב אַסִּי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הִנִּיחַ חֵלֶב שֶׁל שׁוֹר הַנִּסְקָל עַל גַּבֵּי מַכָּתוֹ — פָּטוּר, לְפִי שֶׁכׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה אֵין לוֹקִין עֲלֵיהֶם אֶלָּא דֶּרֶךְ הֲנָאָתָן.
human_translation: It was also stated Rav Aḥa bar Avya said Rav Asi said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: one placed the fat of an ox that is stoned on his wound he is exempt, because all prohibitions in the Torah, one is flogged for them only benefit manner.
llm_translation: It was stated: Naḥmei said, Rav Aḥa bar Avya said, Rav Assi said, Rabbi Yoḥanan said: If the fat of an ox that was stoned is left on its wound - he is exempt, because all prohibitions in the Torah are not punishable except in a way that benefits them.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא, אַף אֲנַן נָמֵי תְּנֵינָא: אֵין סוֹפְגִין אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים מִשּׁוּם עׇרְלָה, אֶלָּא עַל הַיּוֹצֵא מִן הַזֵּיתִים וּמִן הָעֲנָבִים בִּלְבַד. וְאִילּוּ מִתּוּתִים תְּאֵנִים וְרִמּוֹנִים — לָא. מַאי טַעְמָא — לָאו מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא קָאָכֵיל לְהוּ דֶּרֶךְ הֲנָאָתָן?!
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: We, too, have also learned One absorbs the forty due to orla only for seeps from olives, and from grapes, In contrast, mulberries, figs, and pomegranates not What is the reason not because he is not eating them in their usual manner of benefit?
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said, "We also learned: One does not soak fruits for forty days due to the prohibition of 'orlah, except for olives and grapes alone. But for mulberries, figs, and pomegranates - no. What is the reason? It is not because he is feeding them, but because it is not their usual manner of enjoyment!"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: בִּשְׁלָמָא אִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן פְּרִי גּוּפָא דְּלָא קָאָכֵיל לֵיהּ דֶּרֶךְ הֲנָאָתוֹ — שַׁפִּיר, אֶלָּא הָכָא, מִשּׁוּם דְּזֵיעָה בְּעָלְמָא הוּא.
human_translation: Abaye said to him Granted, had the taught us the fruit itself, as he is not eating it in its usual manner of benefit, it well. However, here, because it is merely moisture
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: In truth, if we were to hear the fruit of its body that it does not eat for its own benefit - it is fine, but here, because it is merely excretion, it is not.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הַכֹּל מוֹדִים בְּכִלְאֵי הַכֶּרֶם שֶׁלּוֹקִין עֲלֵיהֶן אֲפִילּוּ שֶׁלֹּא כְּדֶרֶךְ הֲנָאָתָן, מַאי טַעְמָא — מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא כְּתִיב בְּהוּ אֲכִילָה.
human_translation: Abaye said: All concede with regard to diverse kinds in a vineyard that one is flogged for them even not in their usual manner. What is the reason because no eating is written about them
llm_translation: Abaye said: Everyone agrees regarding the bundles of his vineyard that we may glean from them, even not in the usual manner of their benefit. What is the reason? Because it is not written in them "for eating."

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי, אִיסִי בֶּן יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: מִנַּיִן לְבָשָׂר בְּחָלָב שֶׁהוּא אָסוּר? נֶאֱמַר כָּאן ״כִּי עַם קָדוֹשׁ אַתָּה״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן ״וְאַנְשֵׁי קֹדֶשׁ תִּהְיוּן לִי״. מָה לְהַלָּן אָסוּר, אַף כָּאן אָסוּר.
human_translation: raises an objection. Isi ben Yehuda says: From where that it is prohibited meat in milk? It is stated here: “For you are a sacred people And it is stated there: “And you shall be sacred men unto Me; Just as there, it is prohibited so too here, it is prohibited
llm_translation: Challenger: Isi son of Judah raises an objection: From where do we derive that meat cooked in milk is prohibited? It is stated here, "For you are a holy people," and it is stated elsewhere, "And you shall be holy men to Me." Just as it is prohibited there, so too here it is prohibited.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין לִי אֶלָּא בַּאֲכִילָה, בַּהֲנָאָה מִנַּיִן? אָמַרְתָּ, קַל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה עׇרְלָה שֶׁלֹּא נֶעֶבְדָה בָּהּ עֲבֵירָה, אֲסוּרָה בַּהֲנָאָה. בָּשָׂר בְּחָלָב שֶׁנֶּעֶבְדָה בּוֹ עֲבֵירָה, אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁיְּהֵא אָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה?
human_translation: I have derived only eat from where benefit You state an a fortiori If orla , through which no sin has been committed, it is prohibited benefit meat in milk, through which a sin has been committed, is it not right that it should be prohibited benefit
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And I have only in eating, in benefit from where? You said, a fortiori: And what uncircumcision that not was served in it transgression, forbidden in benefit. Meat in milk that was served in it transgression, it is not the law that it should be forbidden in benefit?" English translation: "And I have only in eating, in benefit from where? You said, a fortiori: And what uncircumcision that not was served in it transgression, forbidden in benefit. Meat in milk that was served in it transgression, it is not the law that it should be forbidden in benefit?"

hebrew_text: מָה לְעׇרְלָה שֶׁכֵּן לֹא הָיְתָה לָהּ שְׁעַת הַכּוֹשֶׁר — תֹּאמַר בְּבָשָׂר בְּחָלָב שֶׁהָיְתָה לוֹ שְׁעַת הַכּוֹשֶׁר! חָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח יוֹכִיחַ — שֶׁהָיָה לוֹ שְׁעַת הַכּוֹשֶׁר, וְאָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה.
human_translation: What to orla , as it never had a time when it was fit? you say with regard to meat in milk, which had a time when it was fit? Let leavened bread on Passover prove as it had a time when it was fit, and it is prohibited benefit
llm_translation: What about foreskin, that it did not have a moment of validity - you will say in meat cooked in milk that it had a moment of validity! Chametz on Passover will prove - that it had a moment of validity, and is forbidden for benefit.

hebrew_text: מָה לְחָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח — שֶׁכֵּן עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת, תֹּאמַר בְּבָשָׂר בְּחָלָב שֶׁאֵינוֹ עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת! כִּלְאֵי הַכֶּרֶם יוֹכִיחוּ, שֶׁאֵין עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת — וְאָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה.
human_translation: What leavened bread on Passover, as is punished with karet ? you say with regard to meat in milk, who is not punished with karet ? Let diverse kinds in the vineyard prove as is not punished with karet , and it is prohibited benefit
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "What is the punishment of chametz on Passover? — That it is punishable by karet. You might say regarding meat cooked with milk, which is not punishable by karet! Let the laws of kilayim prove it, that there is no punishment of karet — yet it is forbidden to derive benefit from it."

hebrew_text: וְאִם אִיתָא, נִיפְרוֹךְ: מָה לְכִלְאֵי הַכֶּרֶם — שֶׁכֵּן לוֹקִין עֲלֵיהֶן אֲפִילּוּ שֶׁלֹּא כְּדֶרֶךְ הֲנָאָתָן.
human_translation: And if it is so we can challenge as one is flogged even if he benefit from them in an unusual manner?
llm_translation: "And if it is stated, 'Nifroch': What for the destruction of vineyards - that they are liable even if not in the usual manner of their benefit."

hebrew_text: וְאַבָּיֵי, ״תֹּאמַר״ בְּמַאי?! תֹּאמַר בְּבָשָׂר בְּחָלָב שֶׁאֵין לוֹקִין עָלָיו אֶלָּא דֶּרֶךְ הֲנָאָתוֹ — אַטּוּ בְּבָשָׂר בְּחָלָב אֲכִילָה כְּתִיבָה בֵּיהּ?!
human_translation: And Abaye you say, with regard to what You say with regard to meat in milk one is flogged only for benefit in the usual manner, is that to say eating is written with regard to meat in milk?
llm_translation: And Abbaye said, "You will say, with what? You will say with meat in milk that one only lashes him for it in a way of its benefit - is eating written in it?!"

hebrew_text: וְאִידַּךְ דְּקָא מוֹתֵיב לַהּ! סָבַר, לְהָכִי קָא גָּמַר מִנְּבֵילָה. מָה נְבֵילָה דֶּרֶךְ הֲנָאָתָהּ — אַף בָּשָׂר בְּחָלָב דֶּרֶךְ הֲנָאָתוֹ.
human_translation: And the other who raised this objection, for this derives from an animal carcass. Just as an animal carcass when benefit in the usual manner, so too, meat in milk, benefit in the usual manner.
llm_translation: And the other one is objecting to him! He thinks, thus he concludes from neveilah. Just as neveilah is for its benefit - so too, meat in milk is for its benefit.

hebrew_text: וְאַבָּיֵי: לְהָכִי לֹא כָּתַב אֲכִילָה בְּגוּפוֹ, לוֹמַר שֶׁלּוֹקִין עָלָיו אֲפִילּוּ שֶׁלֹּא כְּדֶרֶךְ הֲנָאָתוֹ.
human_translation: And Abaye for this did not write eating itself to say that one is flogged even benefit in an unusual manner.
llm_translation: And Abbaye: To say thus, he did not write eating in his body, to say that they remove it from him even not in the way of his pleasure.

hebrew_text: וְלִיפְרוֹךְ: מָה לְכִלְאֵי הַכֶּרֶם שֶׁכֵּן לֹא הָיְתָה לוֹ שְׁעַת הַכּוֹשֶׁר! אָמַר רַבִּי אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה: זֹאת אוֹמֶרֶת כִּלְאֵי הַכֶּרֶם עִיקָּרָן נֶאֱסָרִין, הוֹאִיל וְהָיְתָה לָהֶן שְׁעַת הַכּוֹשֶׁר קוֹדֶם הַשְׁרָשָׁה.
human_translation: Let challenge: What to diverse kinds in a vineyard, as had no time that it was fit Rabbi Adda bar Ahava said: that is to say that diverse kinds in a vineyard, their roots are forbidden since they had a time when they were fit, before taking root.
llm_translation: To separate: What about the forbidden mixtures of the vineyard, that it did not have a moment of validity! Rabbi Adda bar Ahava said: This means that the forbidden mixtures of the vineyard are primarily prohibited, since they had a moment of validity before the planting.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב שְׁמַעְיָה: הַמַּעֲבִיר עָצִיץ נָקוּב בַּכֶּרֶם, אִם הוֹסִיף מָאתַיִם — אָסוּר. הוֹסִיף אִין, לֹא הוֹסִיף לָא!
human_translation: Rav Shemaya raised an objection one who transfers a perforated pot into a vineyard, if increases two-hundredth is prohibited If it increases, yes, if it does not increase, no,
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Rav Shemaya raised a contradiction: One who passes a perforated flowerpot through a vineyard, if he added two hundred plants — it is prohibited. If he did not add two hundred plants, he did not add two hundred plants!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא, תְּרֵי קְרָאֵי כְּתִיבִי: כְּתִיב ״הַזָּרַע״ וּכְתִיב ״הַמְּלֵאָה״, הָא כֵּיצַד? זָרוּעַ מֵעִיקָּרוֹ — בְּהַשְׁרָשָׁה. זָרוּעַ וּבָא, הוֹסִיף — אִין, לֹא הוֹסִיף — לָא.
human_translation: Rava said: Two verses are written It is written: “The seed,” and it is written: “The fullness,” How these planted initially upon taking root. planted and brought its increases yes, its does not increase, no,
llm_translation: Rava said, "Two verses are written: it is written 'the seed' and it is written 'the fullness,' how so? If he sowed from its beginning — at the root. If he sowed and it came up, if he added — no, if he did not add — yes."
