hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: בַּכֹּל מִתְרַפְּאִין, חוּץ מֵעֲצֵי אֲשֵׁירָה. הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִי נֵימָא דְּאִיכָּא סַכָּנָה — אֲפִילּוּ עֲצֵי אֲשֵׁירָה נָמֵי! וְאִי דְּלֵיכָּא סַכָּנָה — אֲפִילּוּ כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה נָמֵי לָא?!
human_translation: Rabbi Ya’akov said Rabbi Yoḥanan said One heal oneself with any substance except for wood of a tree designated for idolatry [ asheira ]. What are the circumstances? If we say there is danger even the wood of an asheira . And if where there is no danger, all the prohibited in the Torah also not
llm_translation: Rabbi Yaakov said, Rabbi Yochanan said: In all cases healing is permitted, except for the wood of the Asherah tree. How so? If it is said that there is danger - even the wood of the Asherah tree is also forbidden! And if there is no danger - even all the prohibitions in the Torah are also not forbidden?!

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם דְּאִיכָּא סַכָּנָה, וַאֲפִילּוּ הָכִי עֲצֵי אֲשֵׁירָה לָא. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אִם נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכׇל נַפְשְׁךָ״, לָמָּה נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכׇל מְאֹדֶךָ״. וְאִם נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכׇל מְאֹדֶךָ״, לָמָּה נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכׇל נַפְשְׁךָ״?
human_translation: Actually, there is danger, and even so, not the wood of an asheira . As it was taught Rabbi Eliezer says: If it is stated: and with all your soul,” why is it stated: “And with all your might” And if it is stated: “With all your might,” why is it stated: “With all your soul”?
llm_translation: Forever there is danger, and even so, the trees of the Asherah are not forbidden. As it was taught: Rabbi Eliezer says: If it is stated "with all your soul," why is it stated "with all your might"? And if it is stated "with all your might," why is it stated "with all your soul"?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לוֹמַר לָךְ: אִם יֵשׁ אָדָם שֶׁגּוּפוֹ חָבִיב עָלָיו מִמָּמוֹנוֹ — לְכָךְ נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכׇל נַפְשְׁךָ״. וְיֵשׁ אָדָם שֶׁמָּמוֹנוֹ חָבִיב עָלָיו מִגּוּפוֹ — לְכָךְ נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכׇל מְאֹדֶךָ״.
human_translation: Rather, to tell you if there is a person whose body is more beloved to him than his property, therefore it is stated: “With all your soul.” And there is a person whose property is more beloved to him than his body, therefore it is stated: “With all your might.”
llm_translation: Rather to say to you: If there is a person whose body is dearer to him than his money - therefore it is said, "with all your soul." And there is a person whose money is dearer to him than his body - therefore it is said, "with all your might."

hebrew_text: כִּי אֲתָא רָבִין אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: בַּכֹּל מִתְרַפְּאִין, חוּץ מֵעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה וְגִילּוּי עֲרָיוֹת
human_translation: When Ravin came said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One heal oneself with any substance except for idolatry or forbidden sexual relations
llm_translation: When Ravin came, Rabbi Yochanan said: "In all ailments they are healed, except for idolatry and sexual immorality."

hebrew_text: וּשְׁפִיכוּת דָּמִים.
human_translation: or bloodshed.
llm_translation: And the shedding of blood.

hebrew_text: עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה — הָא דַּאֲמַרַן. גִּילּוּי עֲרָיוֹת וּשְׁפִיכוּת דָּמִים, דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: ״כִּי כַּאֲשֶׁר יָקוּם אִישׁ עַל רֵעֵהוּ וּרְצָחוֹ נֶפֶשׁ כֵּן הַדָּבָר הַזֶּה״. וְכִי מָה עִנְיַן רוֹצֵחַ אֵצֶל נַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה?
human_translation: idolatry from that we said, forbidden sexual relations and murder? As it was taught Rabbi says: for as when a man rises against his neighbor, and slays him, so too with this matter” What does a murderer have to do with a betrothed young woman
llm_translation: Foreign worship - this that we said. Revelation of forbidden relationships and shedding of blood, as it was taught, Rabbi says: "When a man rises against his neighbor and murders him, so is this matter." And what is the case of a murderer with a betrothed maiden?

hebrew_text: הֲרֵי זֶה בָּא לְלַמֵּד, וְנִמְצָא לָמֵד. מַקִּישׁ רוֹצֵחַ לְנַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה: מָה נַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה — נִיתָּן לְהַצִּילָהּ בְּנַפְשׁוֹ, אַף רוֹצֵחַ — נִיתָּן לְהַצִּילוֹ בְּנַפְשׁוֹ. וְנַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה מֵרוֹצֵחַ: מָה רוֹצֵחַ — יֵהָרֵג וְאַל יַעֲבוֹר, אַף נַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה — תֵּהָרֵג וְאַל תַּעֲבוֹר.
human_translation: comes to teach and it turns out it derives juxtaposes a murderer to a betrothed young woman just as one may save her by life, so too, one may save by life. a young betrothed woman from murderer. Just as a murderer he be killed and not transgress so too, a betrothed young woman she be killed and not transgress
llm_translation: Behold, this one comes to teach, and is found to have learned. He juxtaposes a murderer to a betrothed maiden: Just as for a betrothed maiden - he may save her at the cost of his own life, so too for a murderer - he may be saved at the cost of his own life. And a betrothed maiden from a murderer: Just as for a murderer - he shall be killed and not transgress, so too for a betrothed maiden - she shall be killed and not transgress.

hebrew_text: וּשְׁפִיכוּת דָּמִים גּוּפֵיהּ מְנָלַן? סְבָרָא הוּא: כִּי הָהוּא דַּאֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרָבָא, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מָרֵי דּוּרַאי אֲמַר לִי: זִיל קַטְלֵיהּ לִפְלָנְיָא, וְאִי לָא — קָטְלִינָא לָךְ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לִיקְטְלוּךְ וְלָא תִּיקְטוֹל, מַאי חָזֵית דִּדְמָא דִידָךְ סוּמָּק טְפֵי? דִּילְמָא דְּמָא דְּהָהוּא גַּבְרָא סוּמָּק טְפֵי.
human_translation: And from where do we this murder itself? It is logical reasoning similar a certain man who came before Rava said to him: A local official said to me: Go kill so-and-so, and if not I will kill you. said to him: he should kill you and you should not kill. What did you think, that your blood is redder Perhaps that man’s blood is redder.
llm_translation: The shedding of blood, where is its source? It is a logical deduction: For that one who came before Rava, he said to him: "My master, so-and-so told me, 'Go kill that person,' and if not - I will kill you." He said to him: "Let him kill you and do not kill, what did you see that your blood is redder? Perhaps the blood of that man is redder."

hebrew_text: מָר בַּר רַב אָשֵׁי אַשְׁכְּחֵיהּ לְרָבִינָא דְּשָׁיֵיף לַהּ לִבְרַתֵּיהּ בְּגוּהַרְקֵי דְעׇרְלָה. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אֵימוֹר דַּאֲמוּר רַבָּנַן בִּשְׁעַת הַסַּכָּנָה, שֶׁלֹּא בִּשְׁעַת הַסַּכָּנָה מִי אֲמוּר?
human_translation: Mar bar Rav Ashi found Ravina rubbing his daughter with unripe guharkei of orla said to him: Say the Sages said at a time of danger; who says when not a time of danger?
llm_translation: Mar bar Rav Ashi found Ravina examining his son with a lamp of circumcision. He said to him: "Say, what do the Rabbis say in a time of danger, that which is not in a time of danger, who says?"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הַאי אִישָּׁתָא צְמִירְתָּא נָמֵי כִּשְׁעַת הַסַּכָּנָה דָּמְיָא. אִיכָּא דְאָמְרִי, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִידֵּי דֶּרֶךְ הֲנָאָה קָא עָבֵידְנָא?
human_translation: said to him: A high fever is also deemed a time of danger, Some say said to him Am I deriving benefit in a usual manner?
llm_translation: He said to him: This man's wife is like a bundle of myrrh at the time of danger. Some say, he said to him: Are we doing something that brings pleasure along the way?

hebrew_text: אִיתְּמַר: הֲנָאָה הַבָּאָה לוֹ לְאָדָם בְּעַל כׇּרְחוֹ, אַבָּיֵי אָמַר: מוּתֶּרֶת, וְרָבָא אָמַר: אֲסוּרָה.
human_translation: It was stated: benefit that comes to a person against his will, Abaye said: permitted, and Rava said: prohibited.
llm_translation: It was stated: Pleasure that comes to a person against his will, Abbaye said: permitted, and Rava said: forbidden.

hebrew_text: אֶפְשָׁר וְקָא מִיכַּוֵּין, לָא אֶפְשָׁר וְקָמִיכַּוֵין — כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דְּאָסוּר. לָא אֶפְשָׁר וְלָא מִיכַּוֵּין — כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דִּשְׁרֵי. כִּי פְּלִיגִי דְּאֶפְשָׁר וְלָא מִיכַּוֵּין.
human_translation: it is possible and he intends it is not possible and he intends everyone agrees that it is prohibited, not possible and he does not intend everyone agrees that it is permitted, Where they disagree where it is possible he does not intend
llm_translation: It is possible and it is not possible, and it is not possible and it is possible - everyone agrees that it is forbidden. It is not possible and it is not possible - everyone agrees that it is permitted. When do they disagree? When it is possible and it is not possible.

hebrew_text: וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, דְּאָמַר: דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין מִתְכַּוֵּין אָסוּר — כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דְּאָסוּר. כִּי פְּלִיגִי אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, דְּאָמַר: דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין מִתְכַּוֵּין מוּתָּר. אַבָּיֵי כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, וְרָבָא אָמַר: עַד כָּאן לָא קָא אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן — אֶלָּא הֵיכָא דְּלָא אֶפְשָׁר, אֲבָל הֵיכָא דְּאֶפְשָׁר — לָא.
human_translation: And according to Rabbi Yehuda, who said an unintentional act is prohibited, everyone agrees that it is prohibited, Where they disagree in accordance with of Rabbi Shimon, said an unintentional act is permitted. Abaye in accordance with Rabbi Shimon. And Rava say: Rabbi Shimon stated only where it is not possible However, where it is possible no,
llm_translation: And the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, who said: a matter that is not intended is forbidden - everyone agrees that it is forbidden. For they disagree in the statement of Rabbi Shimon, who said: a matter that is not intended is permitted. Abbaye is like Rabbi Shimon, and Rava said: Rabbi Shimon did not say this except where it is not possible, but where it is possible - no.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי: אֶפְשָׁר וְלָא מִיכַּוֵּין — הַיְינוּ פְּלוּגְתַּיְיהוּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן. לָא אֶפְשָׁר וְלָא קָא מִיכַּוֵּין — כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דִּשְׁרֵי. כִּי פְּלִיגִי, דְּלָא אֶפְשָׁר וְקָא מִיכַּוֵּין. וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן דְּאָזֵיל בָּתַר כַּוּוֹנָה — כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דְּאָסוּר, כִּי פְּלִיגִי אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, דְּאָמַר: לָא שְׁנָא מִתְכַּוֵּין וְלָא שְׁנָא שֶׁאֵין מִתְכַּוֵּין, אֶפְשָׁר אָסוּר.
human_translation: Some say it is possible and he does not intend this is the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon. it is not possible and he does not intend everyone agrees that it is permitted Where they disagree where it is not possible and he intends According to Rabbi Shimon, who follows intent, everyone agrees it is prohibited. Where they disagree in accordance with of Rabbi Yehuda, who said: There is no difference one intends or does not intend; possible it is prohibited.
llm_translation: There are those who say: it is possible and not precise - that is the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon. It is not possible and not precise - everyone agrees that it is permitted. When they disagree, it is because it is not possible and it is precise. And according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, who follows the intention - everyone agrees that it is forbidden, for when they disagree it is according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, who says: whether one intends or does not intend, it is possible that it is forbidden.

hebrew_text: אַבָּיֵי כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: Abaye in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: Abbaye like Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: וְרָבָא אָמַר לָךְ: עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה שֶׁאֵין מִתְכַּוֵּין כְּמִתְכַּוֵּין — אֶלָּא לְחוּמְרָא, אֲבָל מִתְכַּוֵּין כְּשֶׁאֵין מִתְכַּוֵּין לְקוּלָּא — לָא.
human_translation: And Rava said to you: Rabbi Yehuda stated one who lacks intent as one who has intent only with regard to a stringency. However, one who has intent as one who lacks intent to a leniency, no.
llm_translation: Rava said to you: Until here did Rabbi Yehuda not say that one does not intend as one intends, except for stringency, but if one intends when one does not intend for leniency - no.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: מְנָא אָמֵינָא לַהּ — דְּתַנְיָא: אָמְרוּ עָלָיו עַל רַבָּן יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי שֶׁהָיָה יוֹשֵׁב בְּצִילּוֹ שֶׁל הֵיכָל, וְדוֹרֵשׁ כׇּל הַיּוֹם כּוּלּוֹ. וְהָא הָכָא דְּלָא אֶפְשָׁר וּמִיכַּוֵין, וְשָׁרֵי.
human_translation: Abaye said: From where do I say As it was taught They said about Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai that he would sit in the shade of the Sanctuary and expound all day long. And here, isn’t it it was not possible and he intended and it was permitted?
llm_translation: Abaye said: From where do I say this to her? — As it was taught: They said about Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai that he used to sit in the shade of the sanctuary and expound all day. And here, where it is not possible and there are distractions, it is permitted.

hebrew_text: וְרָבָא אָמַר: שָׁאנֵי הֵיכָל דִּלְתוֹכוֹ עָשׂוּי.
human_translation: And Rava said The Sanctuary is different, as it was constructed for its interior.
llm_translation: And Rava said: The difference is that the inner chamber of the Temple is made.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: מְנָא אָמֵינָא לַהּ, (דְּתַנְיָא) לוּלִין הָיוּ פְּתוּחִין בַּעֲלִיַּית בֵּית קׇדְשֵׁי הַקֳּדָשִׁים, שֶׁבָּהֶן מְשַׁלְשְׁלִין אֶת הָאוּמָּנִים בְּתֵיבוֹת כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יָזוּנוּ עֵינֵיהֶם מִבֵּית קׇדְשֵׁי הַקֳּדָשִׁים. וְהָא הָכָא דְּלָא אֶפְשָׁר וְקָא מִיכַּוֵּין — וְאָסוּר.
human_translation: Rava said: From where do I say this? As it was taught There were openings in the loft of the Holy of Holies through which they would lower artisans in containers so that their eyes would not gaze And here, isn’t where it was not possible And will intend it prohibited.
llm_translation: Rava said: From where do I say this? (As it was taught) Loulins were open in the upper story of the chambers of the Holy of Holies, in which they would jostle the craftsmen in boxes so that their eyes would not gaze upon the chambers of the Holy of Holies. But here, where it is not possible and they are gazing - it is forbidden.

hebrew_text: וְתִסְבְּרָא?! וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי מִשּׁוּם בַּר קַפָּרָא: קוֹל וּמַרְאֶה וָרֵיחַ אֵין בָּהֶן מִשּׁוּם מְעִילָה! אֶלָּא, מַעֲלָה עָשׂוּ בְּבֵית קׇדְשֵׁי הַקֳּדָשִׁים.
human_translation: And can you understand Didn’t Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi say Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said in the name of Bar Kappara: The sound the sight and smell are not subject to misuse of consecrated property? Rather, they established a higher standard the Holy of Holies
llm_translation: And was created?! And Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi in the name of Bar Kappara: Sound, sight, and smell have no aspect of a garment! Rather, they ascended in the Holy of Holies.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי, אָמַר רָבָא: מְנָא אָמֵינָא לַהּ? דְּתַנְיָא: אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי מִשּׁוּם בַּר קַפָּרָא: קוֹל וּמַרְאֶה וָרֵיחַ אֵין בָּהֶן מִשּׁוּם מְעִילָה. מְעִילָה — הוּא דְּלֵיכָּא, הָא אִיסּוּרָא — אִיכָּא.
human_translation: Some say Rava said: From where do I say this? As it was taught Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said in the name of Bar Kappara: The sound the sight and smell are not subject to misuse of consecrated property. there is no misuse of consecrated property However, there is a prohibition
llm_translation: There are some who say, Rava said: From where do I know this? As it was taught: Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi in the name of Bar Kappara: Sound, sight, and smell do not involve any transgression. Transgression - that is not present, but prohibition - there is.

hebrew_text: מַאי לָאו, לְאוֹתָן הָעוֹמְדִין בִּפְנִים, דְּלָא אֶפְשָׁר וְקָא מִיכַּוֵּין — וְאָסוּר! לָא, לְאוֹתָן הָעוֹמְדִין בַּחוּץ.
human_translation: What, is it not to those standing inside it is not possible And they intend it is prohibited. No, to those who are standing outside.
llm_translation: What is the reason? For those who stand inside, as it is not possible and they are waiting - and it is forbidden! No, for those who stand outside.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא. אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי מִשּׁוּם בַּר קַפָּרָא: קוֹל וּמַרְאֶה וָרֵיחַ אֵין בָּהֶן מִשּׁוּם מְעִילָה. וְרֵיחַ אֵין בּוֹ מִשּׁוּם מְעִילָה? וְהָא תַּנְיָא: הַמְפַטֵּם אֶת הַקְּטוֹרֶת לְהִתְלַמֵּד בָּהּ, אוֹ לְמוֹסְרָהּ לַצִּיבּוּר — פָּטוּר. לְהָרִיחַ בָּהּ — חַיָּיב. וְהַמֵּרִיחַ בָּהּ — פָּטוּר, אֶלָּא שֶׁמָּעַל!
human_translation: itself. Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said in the name of Bar Kappara: The sound the sight and smell are not subject to misuse of consecrated property. Isn’t smell subject to misuse of consecrated property? Wasn’t it taught One who prepares the incense to teach or to transfer it to the community is exempt to smell it, he is liable And one who smells exempt however, he has misused consecrated property.
llm_translation: Body. Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi in the name of Bar Kappara: Sound, sight, and smell do not have the status of a covering. And smell does not have the status of a covering? But it was taught: One who smells the incense to learn from it, or to teach it to the congregation - is exempt. If one smells it - is obligated. And one who causes others to smell it - is exempt, except for the one who raises it up!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: קוֹל וּמַרְאֶה אֵין בָּהֶן מִשּׁוּם מְעִילָה, לְפִי שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶן מַמָּשׁ. וְרֵיחַ לְאַחַר שֶׁתַּעֲלֶה תִּמְרוֹתוֹ — אֵין בּוֹ מִשּׁוּם מְעִילָה, הוֹאִיל וְנַעֲשֵׂית מִצְוָתוֹ.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Pappa said: Sound and sight are not subject to misuse of consecrated property, because they have no substance. And the smell after the column of smoke rises is not subject to misuse of consecrated property, since its mitzva has been performed.
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Papa said: Sound and sight do not have the status of a covering, because they are not tangible. And smell, once its fragrance has risen - it does not have the status of a covering, since its obligation has been fulfilled.

hebrew_text: לְמֵימְרָא דְּכֹל הֵיכָא דְּנַעֲשֵׂית מִצְוָתוֹ אֵין בּוֹ מִשּׁוּם מְעִילָה?! וַהֲרֵי תְּרוּמַת הַדֶּשֶׁן, דְּנַעֲשֵׂית מִצְוָתָהּ — וְיֵשׁ בָּהּ מִשּׁוּם מְעִילָה. דִּכְתִיב: ״וְשָׂמוֹ אֵצֶל הַמִּזְבֵּחַ״ — שֶׁלֹּא יְפַזֵּר, ״וְשָׂמוֹ״ — שֶׁלֹּא יֵהָנֶה.
human_translation: Is that to say that any where its mitzva has been performed, is not subject to misuse of consecrated property? And the removal of ashes its mitzva has been performed, and subject to misuse of consecrated property, as it is written: and he shall put them beside the altar” that he not scatter “And he shall put them” that one not benefit
llm_translation: In the matter of every place where his commandment is fulfilled, there is no prohibition of misuse?! And behold, the offering of the ashes, whose commandment is fulfilled - and it has a prohibition of misuse. As it is written: "And he shall put it beside the altar" - that it should not be scattered, "and he shall put it" - that it should not be benefited from.

hebrew_text: מִשּׁוּם דְּהָווּ תְּרוּמַת הַדֶּשֶׁן וּבִגְדֵי כְהוּנָּה שְׁנֵי כְתוּבִין הַבָּאִין כְּאֶחָד, וְכׇל שְׁנֵי כְתוּבִין הַבָּאִין כְּאֶחָד אֵין מְלַמְּדִין.
human_translation: because the removal of ashes and the priestly garments are two verses that come as one. two verses that come as one do not teach
llm_translation: Because the heave offering of the ashes and the priestly garments are two written laws that come as one, and any two written laws that come as one do not teach us anything.

hebrew_text: תְּרוּמַת הַדֶּשֶׁן — הָא דַּאֲמַרַן. בִּגְדֵי כְהוּנָּה, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְהִנִּיחָם שָׁם״ — מְלַמֵּד שֶׁטְּעוּנִין גְּנִיזָה.
human_translation: removal of ashes is that which we said. the priestly garments? As it is written: and he shall leave them there” teaches that they require burial.
llm_translation: Tractate: Trumot Hadeshin - This is what we say: The priestly garments, as it is written: "And he shall leave them there" - this teaches that they are to be stored away.

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לְרַבָּנַן דְּאָמְרִי מְלַמֵּד שֶׁטְּעוּנִין גְּנִיזָה, אֶלָּא לְרַבִּי דּוֹסָא דִּפְלִיג עֲלַיְיהוּ, דְּאָמַר: אֲבָל רְאוּיִין הֵן לְכֹהֵן הֶדְיוֹט, וּמַאי ״וְהִנִּיחָם שָׁם״ — שֶׁלֹּא יִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ בָּהֶם בְּיוֹם כִּפּוּרִים אַחֵר, מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר?
human_translation: It works out well according to the Rabbis, who say teaches that they require burial. However, according to Rabbi Dosa, who disagrees with them says: but they are fit by a common priest, And what “And he shall leave them there”? that may not use them on another Yom Kippur. what can be said?
llm_translation: The sages left it as they say, that they are fit for genizah, but for Rabbi Dosa who disagreed with them, saying: "But they are suitable for a lay priest." And what is the meaning of "and he shall leave them there" - that one should not make use of them on another Yom Kippur. What can be said in response?

hebrew_text: מִשּׁוּם דְּהָווּ תְּרוּמַת הַדֶּשֶׁן וְעֶגְלָה עֲרוּפָה שְׁנֵי כְתוּבִין הַבָּאִין כְּאֶחָד, וְכׇל שְׁנֵי כְתוּבִין הַבָּאִין כְּאֶחָד אֵין מְלַמְּדִין.
human_translation: because removal of ashes and the heifer whose neck is broken, are two verses that come as one. And two verses that come as one do not teach
llm_translation: Because the heave offering of the ashes and the calf whose neck is broken are two written laws that come as one, and any two written laws that come as one do not teach us anything.

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר אֵין מְלַמְּדִין, אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מְלַמְּדִין — מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר? תְּרֵי מִיעוּטֵי כְּתִיבִי: כְּתִיב ״וְשָׂמוֹ״, וּכְתִיב ״הָעֲרוּפָה״.
human_translation: It works out well according to the one who said they do not teach However, according to the one who said they do teach what can be said? Two exclusions are written it is written: “And he shall put it.” it is written: “The which had its neck broken”
llm_translation: The one who says we do not teach, what is there to say to him? Two minimal scriptural verses: it is written "and they shall place," and it is written "the cursed one."

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הִכְנִיסָה לְרִבְקָה וְדָשָׁה — כְּשֵׁירָה. בִּשְׁבִיל שֶׁתִּינַק וְתָדוּשׁ — פְּסוּלָה.
human_translation: Come hear one brought into a cow pen, and it threshes it is valid. so that it may nurse and so it will thresh it is disqualified
llm_translation: Come and hear: If she brought it in to Rivkah and she threshed it - it is fit. Because she will nurse and thresh - it is unfit.

hebrew_text: וְהָא הָכָא דְּלָא אֶפְשָׁר וְקָא מִיכַּוֵּין, וְקָתָנֵי פְּסוּלָה! שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דִּכְתִיב: ״אֲשֶׁר לֹא עֻבַּד בָּהּ״, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: And here, isn’t it where it was not possible and he intended And it is teaching that is disqualified It is different there, as it is written: “Which has not been used for work” in any case.
llm_translation: And here, where it is not possible and yet they are preparing, and it teaches invalid! It is different there, as it is written: "which has not been worked with," in any case.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי אֲפִילּוּ רֵישָׁא נָמֵי!
human_translation: If so, even to the first clause.
llm_translation: If so, even the beginning is also considered!

hebrew_text: הָא לָא דָּמְיָא אֶלָּא לְהָא: שָׁכַן עָלֶיהָ עוֹף — כְּשֵׁירָה, עָלָה עָלֶיהָ זָכָר — פְּסוּלָה. מַאי טַעְמָא?
human_translation: This is comparable only to that a bird landed on it valid, a male mounted it it is unfit What is the reason
llm_translation: Here is the English word-for-word translation of the Talmudic text: Talmudic text: This one is comparable only to this: if a bird dwells upon it - it is fit, if a male mounts it - it is unfit. What is the reason?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: אִי כְּתִיב ״עָבַד״ וְקָרֵינַן ״עָבַד״ — עַד דְּעָבֵיד בָּהּ אִיהוּ. אִי כְּתִיב ״עוּבַּד״ וְקָרֵינַן ״עוּבַּד״ — אֲפִילּוּ מִמֵּילָא נָמֵי.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said If it were written: “He worked [ avad ],” and we read: “He worked [ avad ],” until he, used it If it were written: “It was worked [ ubbad ],” and we read: “It was worked [ ubbad ],” even on its own it is also
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: If it is written "avad" and we read it as "avad" - until He performs it. If it is written "u'vad" and we read it as "u'vad" - even from the beginning.

hebrew_text: הַשְׁתָּא דִּכְתִיב ״עָבַד״ וְקָרֵינַן ״עוּבַּד״ — עוּבַּד דּוּמְיָא דְּעָבַד. מָה עָבַד דְּנִיחָא לֵיהּ, אַף עוּבַּד דְּנִיחָא לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Now that it is written: “He worked [ avad ],” but we read “It was worked [ ubbad ],” it is worked in a similar he works. just as works that is beneficial to him, so too, it is worked that causes him to benefit
llm_translation: The Gemara when it is written "avad" and we read "u'vad" - "u'vad" is similar to "avad." Just as "avad" is pleasing to him, so too "u'vad" is pleasing to him.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: אֲבֵידָה, לֹא יִשְׁטָחֶנָּה לֹא עַל גַּבֵּי מִטָּה וְלֹא עַל גַּבֵּי מַגּוֹד לְצוֹרְכּוֹ, אֲבָל שׁוֹטְחָהּ לְצוֹרְכָּהּ עַל גַּבֵּי מִטָּה וְעַל גַּבֵּי מַגּוֹד. נִזְדַּמְּנוּ לוֹ אוֹרְחִין, לֹא יִשְׁטָחֶנָּה לֹא עַל גַּבֵּי מִטָּה וְלֹא עַל גַּבֵּי מַגּוֹד, בֵּין לְצוֹרְכָּהּ בֵּין לְצוֹרְכּוֹ.
human_translation: Come hear a lost item, he not spread it out over a bed or over a frame for his purposes, However, he spread it out over a bed or a frame for its sake If guests happen to him, he may not spread it out, neither for its sake nor for his purpose.
llm_translation: Come and hear: A lost object, one may not place it neither on the bed nor on the stool for its need, but one may place it for its need on the bed and on the stool. If guests arrived, one may not place it neither on the bed nor on the stool, whether for its need or for their need.

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם דְּקָלֵי לַהּ, אִי מִשּׁוּם עֵינָא בִּישָׁא, אִי מִשּׁוּם גַּנָּבֵי.
human_translation: It is different there, as damaging it, either due to the evil eye or due to the thieves
llm_translation: The difference there is that he is light to her, either because of modesty, or because of thieves.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: מוֹכְרֵי כְסוּת מוֹכְרִין כְּדַרְכָּן, וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יִתְכַּוֵּין בַּחַמָּה מִפְּנֵי הַחַמָּה, וּבַגְּשָׁמִים מִפְּנֵי הַגְּשָׁמִים. וְהַצְּנוּעִין מַפְשִׁילִין לַאֲחוֹרֵיהֶם בְּמַקֵּל.
human_translation: Come hear Clothing merchants sell them as they normally would provided he does not intend in the sun from the sun, or in the rain from the rain. However, the modest suspend on a stick behind them.
llm_translation: Come and hear: Sellers of garments sell them in their usual manner, provided that they do not become heated by the sun because of the sun, and in the rain because of the rain. And the modest ones walk behind them with a stick.

hebrew_text: וְהָא הָכָא דְּאֶפְשָׁר לְמֶעְבַּד כִּצְנוּעִין, וְכִי לָא מְכַוֵּין — שְׁרֵי. תְּיוּבְתָּא לְמַאן דְּמַתְנֵי לִישָּׁנָא קַמָּא דְּרָבָא, תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: And here, isn’t it it is possible to act like the modest when one does not intend it is permitted a conclusive refutation to he who taught the first version Rava’s a conclusive refutation.
llm_translation: And here, where it is possible to do discreetly, and if not, it is permitted. It is better according to the one who taught the Mishnah in front of Rava, it is better.

hebrew_text: וְלֹא יַסִּיק בּוֹ וְכוּ׳. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: תַּנּוּר שֶׁהִסִּיקוֹ בִּקְלִיפֵּי עׇרְלָה אוֹ בְּקַשִּׁין שֶׁל כִּלְאֵי הַכֶּרֶם, חָדָשׁ — יוּתַּץ, יָשָׁן — יוּצַן.
human_translation: one may not light with The Sages taught an oven that one lit with the peels of orla or with straw of diverse kinds in a vineyard, new it be shattered. old it be cooled,
llm_translation: "And not to kindle in it, etc." The Rabbis taught: A stove that was plastered with the peels of uncircumcised produce or with grapevines, if it is new - it shall be smashed, if it is old - it shall be smoothed.

hebrew_text: אָפָה בּוֹ אֶת הַפַּת, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: הַפַּת אֲסוּרָה, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: הַפַּת מוּתֶּרֶת. בִּישְּׁלָהּ עַל גַּבֵּי גֶּחָלִים — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל מוּתָּר.
human_translation: one baked bread in Rabbi says: It is prohibited the bread, And the Rabbis say: It is permitted the bread. he cooked over the coals everyone agrees it is permitted.
llm_translation: He baked in it the bread, Rabbi says: the bread is forbidden, and the sages say: the bread is permitted. If he cooked it on coals - the words of all are permitted.

hebrew_text: וְהָא תַּנְיָא: בֵּין חָדָשׁ וּבֵין יָשָׁן יוּצַן! לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — רַבִּי, וְהָא — רַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Wasn’t it taught Whether an old or a new it be cooled; not difficult. This Rabbi And that Rabbis.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And it was taught: Whether new or old, they are valid! There is no difficulty: here — Rabbi, and here — the Rabbis." English translation: "And it was taught: Whether new or old, they are valid! There is no difficulty: here — Rabbi, and here — the Rabbis."

hebrew_text: אֵימוֹר דְּשָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי מִשּׁוּם דְּיֵשׁ שֶׁבַח עֵצִים בַּפַּת. זֶה וָזֶה גּוֹרֵם מִי שָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ? אֶלָּא, לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, הָא — רַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Say you heard that Rabbi because there is improvement from the wood in the bread, both this and that cause it, did you hear him Rather, not difficult. This Rabbi Eliezer, that the Rabbis,
llm_translation: Tractate: Eimor d'shamaat leih l'Rabbi mi'shum d'yesh shevach eitzim bapat. Zeh vazeh goreim mi shamaat leih? Ella, la kashya: Ha - Rabbi Eliezer, ha - Rabbanan.

hebrew_text: הֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר? אִילֵימָא רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר דִּשְׂאוֹר, דִּתְנַן: שְׂאוֹר שֶׁל חוּלִּין וְשֶׁל תְּרוּמָה שֶׁנָּפְלוּ לְתוֹךְ עִיסָּה, וְאֵין בָּזֶה כְּדֵי לְהַחְמִיץ וְאֵין בָּזֶה כְּדֵי לְהַחְמִיץ, וְנִצְטָרְפוּ וְחִמְּצוּ — רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אַחַר אַחֲרוֹן אֲנִי בָּא, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: בֵּין שֶׁנָּפַל אִיסּוּר לְכַתְּחִלָּה, וּבֵין שֶׁנָּפַל אִיסּוּר לְבַסּוֹף — לְעוֹלָם אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר
human_translation: Which Rabbi Eliezer If you say Rabbi Eliezer leaven, as we learned non-sacred leaven and teruma fell into dough, and neither one is enough to cause to become leavened bread, they joined and caused to become leavened bread, Rabbi Eliezer says: I follow the final And the Rabbis say: Whether the prohibited item, fell first or the prohibited item fell last, it never prohibited
llm_translation: Be Rabbi Eliezer? If you will say Rabbi Eliezer of sourdough, as we learned: sourdough of common dough and of terumah that fell into dough, and there is not in this enough to leaven, and there is not in this enough to leaven, and they combined and leavened - Rabbi Eliezer says: "After the last one I come," and the sages say: "Whether an issur fell in at the beginning, or whether an issur fell in at the end - it never prohibits."

hebrew_text: עַד שֶׁיְּהֵא בּוֹ כְּדֵי לְהַחְמִיץ. וְאָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא שֶׁקָּדַם וְסִילֵּק אֶת הָאִיסּוּר, אֲבָל לֹא קָדַם וְסִילֵּק אֶת הָאִיסּוּר — אָסוּר, אַלְמָא זֶה וְזֶה גּוֹרֵם אָסוּר.
human_translation: until there is enough to cause to become leavened bread. And Abaye said: taught only he first removed the prohibited However, if he did not first remove the prohibited leaven, is prohibited Apparently, both this and that cause it is prohibited.
llm_translation: Until it has the time to sour. And Abaye said: They only taught this when one precedes and removes the prohibition, but if one does not precede and remove the prohibition - it is forbidden. This implies that both this and that cause it to be forbidden.

hebrew_text: וּמִמַּאי דְּטַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר כְּאַבָּיֵי? דִּילְמָא טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר מִשּׁוּם דְּאַחַר אַחֲרוֹן אֲנִי בָּא — לָא שְׁנָא קָדַם וְסִילֵּק אֶת הָאִיסּוּר, לָא שְׁנָא לֹא קָדַם וְסִילֵּק אֶת הָאִיסּוּר. אֲבָל בְּבַת אַחַת, הָכִי נָמֵי דִּשְׁרֵי!
human_translation: from where that the reason for Rabbi Eliezer’s is in accordance with Abaye’s Perhaps the reason for Rabbi Eliezer’s is due to I follow the final And it is no different he first removed the prohibited item and it is no different he did not first remove the prohibited item. However, at once it should be permitted,
llm_translation: And from what is the reason of Rabbi Eliezer like Abbaye? Perhaps the reason of Rabbi Eliezer is because he comes after the last one - it does not matter if he came before and removed the prohibition, or if he did not come before and removed the prohibition. But in one case, thus it is fitting!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר דַּעֲצֵי אֲשֵׁירָה, דִּתְנַן: נָטַל הֵימֶנָּה עֵצִים — אֲסוּרִין בַּהֲנָאָה. הִסִּיק בָּהֶן אֶת הַתַּנּוּר, חָדָשׁ — יוּתַּץ, יָשָׁן — יוּצַן.
human_translation: Rather, Rabbi Eliezer wood from an asheira . As we learned one took wood from it is prohibited to benefit from it. one lit an oven with new it be broken. old it be cooled.
llm_translation: Rather, Rabbi Eliezer maintains regarding the matter of the Asherah, as we have learned: If one takes wood from it - it is forbidden for benefit. If one kindles the oven with them, whether it is new - it will be smashed, or old - it will be left.

hebrew_text: אָפָה בּוֹ אֶת הַפַּת — אֲסוּרִין בַּהֲנָאָה. נִתְעָרְבָה בְּאַחֲרוֹת וַאֲחֵרוֹת בַּאֲחֵרוֹת — כּוּלָּן אֲסוּרִין בַּהֲנָאָה. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: יוֹלִיךְ הֲנָאָה לְיָם הַמֶּלַח. (אָמַר) לוֹ: אֵין פִּדְיוֹן לַעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה.
human_translation: one baked bread it is prohibited to benefit from it. was mixed together with other and other was mixed with other it is prohibited to derive benefit from all Rabbi Eliezer says: He casts the benefit into the Dead Sea [ Yam HaMelaḥ ]. said to him: Idolatry cannot be redeemed.
llm_translation: He baked in it the bread - forbidden in benefit. It got mixed with others and others with others - all of them are forbidden in benefit. Rabbi Eliezer says: Let the benefit go to the Dead Sea. He said to him: There is no redemption for idolatry.

hebrew_text: אֵימוֹר דְּשָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה — דַּחֲמִיר אִיסּוּרַהּ, בִּשְׁאָר אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה מִי שָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ? אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן, אַמַּאן תִּרְמְיַיהּ? וְעוֹד, הָא תַּנְיָא בְּהֶדְיָא: וְכֵן הָיָה רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹסֵר בְּכׇל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה.
human_translation: Say that you heard that Rabbi Eliezer with regard to idolatry, whose prohibition is stringent. with regard to other prohibitions in the Torah, did you hear him Rather, if so to whom will you attribute And furthermore, wasn’t taught explicitly And, similarly, Rabbi Eliezer would prohibit with regard to all prohibitions in the Torah.
llm_translation: Tractate: Eimor d'sham'at leih l'Rabbi Eliezer ba'avodah zarah - d'chamir isurah, bish'ar isurin shebatorah mi sham'at leih? Ela im kein, aman tirmeih? Ve'od, ha tanya b'hedya: Ve'chen hayah Rabbi Eliezer oser b'kol isurin shebatorah.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: אִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר ״זֶה וָזֶה גּוֹרֵם אָסוּר״ — רַבִּי הַיְינוּ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, וְאִם תִּמְצֵי לוֹמַר ״זֶה וָזֶה גּוֹרֵם מוּתָּר״, וְהָכָא מִשּׁוּם דְּיֵשׁ שֶׁבַח עֵצִים בְּפַת הוּא — הָנֵי קְעָרוֹת וְכוֹסוֹת וּצְלוֹחִיּוֹת אֲסִירִי.
human_translation: Abaye said: If you say, both this and that cause, it is prohibited, Rabbi is Rabbi Eliezer, And if you say both this and that cause, it is permitted, and here, it is because there is improvement from the wood in the bread these bowls, cups, and flasks be prohibited,
llm_translation: Abaye said: If you find to say "this and this cause it to be forbidden" - this is Rabbi Eliezer. And if you find to say "this and this cause it to be permitted," and here because there is praise for wood in dough - those bowls and cups and ladles are forbidden.

hebrew_text: כִּי פְּלִיגִי בְּתַנּוּר וּקְדֵירָה: לְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״זֶה וָזֶה גּוֹרֵם אָסוּר״ — אָסוּר. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״זֶה וָזֶה גּוֹרֵם מוּתָּר״ — שְׁרֵי.
human_translation: When disagree is where an oven and a pot According to the one who says both this and that cause it is prohibited, it is prohibited according to the one who says both this and that cause, it is permitted, it is permitted
llm_translation: When they argue about an oven and a pot: according to the one who says, "This and this cause a prohibition" - it is prohibited. According to the one who says, "This and this cause it to be permitted" - it is permitted.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי: אֲפִילּוּ לְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״זֶה וָזֶה גּוֹרֵם מוּתָּר״, קְדֵירָה — אֲסוּרָה, דְּהָא קַבְּלָה בִּישּׁוּלָא מִקַּמֵּי דְּנִיתֵּן עֵצִים דְּהֶיתֵּירָא.
human_translation: Some say even according to the one who says both this and that cause, it is permitted, the pot is prohibited, since it holds the food before the permitted wood is placed
llm_translation: There are those who say: Even according to the one who says "both this and that cause it to be permitted," a pot is forbidden, because it has received heat before it received the permitted wood.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: תַּנּוּר שֶׁהִסִּיקוֹ בִּקְלִיפֵּי עׇרְלָה, אוֹ בְּקַשִּׁין שֶׁל כִּלְאֵי הַכֶּרֶם, חָדָשׁ — יוּתַּץ, יָשָׁן — יוּצַן. אָפָה בּוֹ אֶת הַפַּת, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: הַפַּת מוּתֶּרֶת, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: הַפַּת אֲסוּרָה. וְהָתַנְיָא אִיפְּכָא! שְׁמוּאֵל אִיפְּכָא תָּנֵי.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said Rav Yehuda said Shmuel said: an oven that one lit with peels of orla or with straw diverse kinds in a vineyard, new it be shattered. old it be cooled. one baked bread in it, Rabbi says: The bread is permitted, and the Rabbis say: The bread is prohibited. Wasn’t the reverse taught Shmuel teaches the reverse,
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said, Rav Yehudah said Shmuel: A stove that was plastered with the peels of uncircumcised produce, or with grapevines that are prohibited for use in a vineyard, if it is new - it should be smashed, if it is old - it should be scorched. If one baked bread in it, Rabbi says: the bread is permitted, and the sages say: the bread is prohibited. And it was taught in a contradictory manner! Shmuel taught in a contradictory manner.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: בְּעָלְמָא קָסָבַר שְׁמוּאֵל הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי מֵחֲבֵירוֹ וְלֹא מֵחֲבֵירָיו, וּבְהָא — אֲפִילּוּ מֵחֲבֵירָיו. וְסָבַר אַתְנְיַיהּ אִיפְּכָא, כִּי הֵיכִי דְּנֵיקוּם רַבָּנַן לְאִיסּוּרָא.
human_translation: And if you wish, say: generally, Shmuel holds halakha is in accordance with Rabbi over his colleague not over his colleagues And in this even over his colleagues. And holds: I will reverse in order to establish the Rabbis’ as a prohibition.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: In general, Shmuel holds that the halakha follows Rabbi over his colleagues, but not over his colleagues' colleagues, and in this case—even over his colleagues' colleagues. And he holds that the Mishnah is stated in the opposite manner, so that the Rabbis' decree may be upheld.

hebrew_text: בִּישְּׁלָהּ עַל גַּבֵּי גֶּחָלִים — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל הַפַּת מוּתֶּרֶת. (אָמַר) רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל, וְרַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אָשֵׁי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, חַד אָמַר: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא גֶּחָלִים עוֹמְמוֹת, אֲבָל גֶּחָלִים לוֹחֲשׁוֹת — אֲסוּרִין, וְחַד אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ גֶּחָלִים לוֹחֲשׁוֹת נָמֵי מוּתָּרִין.
human_translation: one cooked over coals everyone agrees that the bread is permitted. Rav Yehuda said Shmuel said and Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said Rabbi Yoḥanan said One said: They taught only dim coals, however, glowing coals, prohibited. And one said: Even the coals are glowing, also permitted.
llm_translation: She cooked it on hot coals - the words of all, bread is permitted. Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel, and Rabbi Chiya bar Ashi said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan, one said: They only taught about glowing coals, but smoldering coals - are forbidden, and one said: Even smoldering coals are also permitted.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר לוֹחֲשׁוֹת אֲסוּרִין, מִשּׁוּם דְּיֵשׁ שֶׁבַח עֵצִים בַּפַּת. אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר אֲפִילּוּ לוֹחֲשׁוֹת מוּתָּרוֹת, פַּת דְּאָסַר דְּיֵשׁ שֶׁבַח עֵצִים בַּפַּת לְרַבִּי הֵיכִי מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לֵיהּ? אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: כְּשֶׁאֲבוּקָה כְּנֶגְדּוֹ.
human_translation: Granted, according to the one who said glowing prohibited, because there is improvement from the wood in the bread. However, according to the one said even glowing permitted, where do you find the case Rabbi deems bread to be prohibited because there is improvement from wood in it? Rav Pappa said: when a flame is opposite
llm_translation: In truth, according to the one who says whisperings are forbidden, because there is praise of wood in the dough. But according to the one who says even whisperings are permitted, how does he find the prohibition of dough, since there is praise of wood in the dough for Rabbi? Rav Papa said: When there is dust opposite it.

hebrew_text: מִכְּלָל דְּרַבָּנַן דִּפְלִיגִי עֲלֵיהּ — שָׁרוּ אֲפִילּוּ כְּשֶׁאֲבוּקָה כְּנֶגְדּוֹ, אֶלָּא עֵצִים דְּאִיסּוּרָא לְרַבָּנַן הֵיכִי מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לְהוּ? אָמַר רַב אַמֵּי בַּר חָמָא: בְּשַׁרְשִׁיפָא.
human_translation: by inference that the Rabbis who disagree with permit even when the flame is opposite it? But where do you find the case it is prohibited according to the Rabbis wood? Rav Ami bar Ḥama said: in a stool
llm_translation: From the principle of the sages who disputed it - they permitted even when it is like a torch opposite it, but how do the sages find wood for burning? Rav Ammi bar Hama said: with a root.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא מֵרַב חִסְדָּא: תַּנּוּר שֶׁהִסִּיקוֹ בַּעֲצֵי הֶקְדֵּשׁ, וְאָפָה בּוֹ הַפַּת, לְרַבָּנַן דְּשָׁרוּ בְּקַמַּיְיתָא, מַאי? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הַפַּת אֲסוּרָה. וּמָה בֵּין זוֹ לְעׇרְלָה?! אָמַר רָבָא: הָכִי הַשְׁתָּא?! עׇרְלָה בְּטֵילָה בְּמָאתַיִם, הֶקְדֵּשׁ אֲפִילּוּ בְּאֶלֶף לֹא בָּטֵיל.
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama raised a dilemma before Rav Ḥisda: an oven that one kindled with consecrated wood and baked bread in it, according to the Rabbis, who permitted in the first what is the halakha ? He said to him: The bread is prohibited. What is the difference between this and orla Rava said: How can be compared? Orla is nullified two hundred; consecrated is not nullified even in one thousand.
llm_translation: The student asked Ramei son of Hama from Rav Chisda: They set up an oven with wood of hekdesh, and baked bread in it, according to the Rabbis who permitted it in Kamayista, what is the ruling? He said to him: The bread is forbidden. And what is the difference between this and orlah?! Rava said: Is it so now?! Orlah is nullified in two hundred, hekdesh is not nullified even in a thousand.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: אִי קַשְׁיָא לֵיהּ — הָא קַשְׁיָא: וַהֲלֹא מָעַל הַמַּסִּיק, וְכׇל הֵיכָא דְּמָעַל הַמַּסִּיק נָפְקוּ לְהוּ לְחוּלִּין!
human_translation: Rather, Rava said: If it was difficult for this is difficult: Didn’t the kindler misuse consecrated property, And any where the kindler misuses consecrated property is transferred to non-sacred
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: If it is difficult for him - this is difficult: But did he not ascend the roof, and wherever he ascended the roof, they went out to him for mundane matters!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: הָכָא בַּעֲצֵי שְׁלָמִים עָסְקִינַן, וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, דְּאָמַר: הֶקְדֵּשׁ בְּשׁוֹגֵג מִתְחַלֵּל, בְּמֵזִיד אֵינוֹ מִתְחַלֵּל.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: Here, we are dealing with wood for peace-offerings. And in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, said: unwittingly consecrated property, it becomes desecrated intentionally, it is not desecrated
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: Here we are dealing with the wood of peace-offerings, and according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda who said: "One who sanctifies unintentionally becomes desecrated, but intentionally does not become desecrated."

hebrew_text: בְּמֵזִיד מַאי טַעְמָא לָא? כֵּיוָן דְּלָאו בַּר מְעִילָה — הוּא לָא נָפֵיק לְחוּלִּין. שְׁלָמִים נָמֵי, כֵּיוָן דְּלָאו בַּר מְעִילָה נִינְהוּ — לָא נָפְקָא לְחוּלִּין.
human_translation: What is the reason intentionally not Since not subject to misuse of consecrated property, it is not transferred to non-sacred peace-offerings as well. Since it is not subject to misuse of consecrated property, it is not transferred to non-sacred
llm_translation: Intentionally, what is the reason for no? Since not in the cloak — he did not go out to secular matters. Peace-offerings also, since not in the cloak they are — they do not go out to secular matters.

hebrew_text: וְכׇל הֵיכָא דְּמָעַל הַמַּסִּיק נָפְקִי לְחוּלִּין? וְהָא תַּנְיָא: כׇּל הַנִּשְׂרָפִין — אֶפְרָן מוּתָּר, חוּץ מֵעֲצֵי אֲשֵׁירָה. וְאֵפֶר הֶקְדֵּשׁ — לְעוֹלָם אָסוּר.
human_translation: And anywhere the kindler misuse of consecrated property is it transferred to non-sacred Wasn’t taught all that must be burned, their ashes are permitted except for wood from an asheira ? And consecrated ash is prohibited forever.
llm_translation: And all where that transgress the boundary go out to profane? And this teaches: All that are burned — Ephraim is permitted, except for the trees of Asherah. And ashes of the hekdesh — forever forbidden.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: כְּגוֹן שֶׁנָּפְלָה דְּלֵיקָה מֵאֵילֶיהָ בַּעֲצֵי הֶקְדֵּשׁ, דְּלֵיכָּא אִינָשׁ דְּנִמְעוֹל. רַב שְׁמַעְיָה אָמַר: בְּאוֹתָן שֶׁטְּעוּנִין גְּנִיזָה. דְּתַנְיָא: ״וְשָׂמוֹ״ בְּנַחַת, ״וְשָׂמוֹ״ כּוּלּוֹ, ״וְשָׂמוֹ״ שֶׁלֹּא יְפַזֵּר.
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama said: where a fire began on its own among consecrated wood and there is no one who misused consecrated property. Rav Shemaya said: with those that require burial, As it was taught “And he shall put it” gently; “and he shall put it” all of it; “and he shall put it” that he not scatter
llm_translation: Ramei bar Ḥama said: For example, if a flame falls from its place onto consecrated wood, where there is no one to be concerned. Rav Shemaya said: In such cases, they are to be stored away. As it was taught: "And he shall set it down" gently, "and he shall set it down" completely, "and he shall set it down" so that it will not scatter.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר אֵין בִּיעוּר וְכוּ׳. תַּנְיָא, אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: אֵין בִּיעוּר חָמֵץ אֶלָּא שְׂרֵיפָה, וְהַדִּין נוֹתֵן: וּמָה נוֹתָר שֶׁאֵינוֹ בְּ״בַל יֵרָאֶה״ וּ״בַל יִמָּצֵא״ — טָעוּן שְׂרֵיפָה, חָמֵץ שֶׁיֶּשְׁנוֹ בְּ״בַל יֵרָאֶה״ וּ״בַל יִמָּצֵא״ — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן שֶׁטָּעוּן שְׂרֵיפָה!
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: The removal of leavened bread is only burning. It was taught Rabbi Yehuda said: The removal of leavened bread is only through burning. And a logical derivation leads Just as left over which is not subject to It shall not be seen, and: It shall not be found, requires burning, so too, leavened bread, as it is subject to It shall not be seen, and: It shall not be found, all the more so not that it requires burning?
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: There is no removal, etc. It was taught: Rabbi Yehuda said: There is no removal of leaven except by burning, and the same applies to what is left over that is not "seen" or "found" - it requires burning. Leaven that is within the category of "seen" or "found" - all the more so it requires burning!

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ לוֹ: כׇּל דִּין שֶׁאַתָּה דָּן תְּחִלָּתוֹ לְהַחְמִיר וְסוֹפוֹ לְהָקֵל אֵינוֹ דִּין. לֹא מָצָא עֵצִים לְשׂוֹרְפוֹ יְהֵא יוֹשֵׁב וּבָטֵל? וְהַתּוֹרָה אָמְרָה: ״תַּשְׁבִּיתוּ שְּׂאוֹר מִבָּתֵּיכֶם״, בְּכׇל דָּבָר שֶׁאַתָּה יָכוֹל לְהַשְׁבִּיתוֹ!
human_translation: said to him: Any logical derivation that you derive initial is stringent but whose subsequent are lenient is not logical derivation. did not find wood to burn he sit idly And the Torah said: “You shall remove leaven from your houses” in any manner which you can remove it.
llm_translation: They said to him: Every judgment that you judge, begin with being stringent and end with being lenient is not a judgment. If he did not find wood to burn it, should he sit and annul it? And the Torah said: "You shall remove the leaven from your houses," in every matter that you are able to remove it!

hebrew_text: חָזַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְדָנוֹ דִּין אַחֵר: נוֹתָר אָסוּר בַּאֲכִילָה וְחָמֵץ אָסוּר בַּאֲכִילָה. מָה נוֹתָר בִּשְׂרֵיפָה — אַף חָמֵץ בִּשְׂרֵיפָה.
human_translation: Then Rabbi Yehuda presented a different logical derivation It is prohibited to eat the leftover and it is prohibited to eat leavened bread. just as the leftover requires burning, so too, leavened bread requires burning.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda reviewed and judged another case: leftover is forbidden in eating, and leaven is forbidden in eating. Just as leftover is burned, so too leaven is burned.

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ לוֹ: נְבֵילָה תּוֹכִיחַ, שֶׁאֲסוּרָה בַּאֲכִילָה וְאֵינָהּ טְעוּנָה שְׂרֵיפָה! אָמַר לָהֶן, הֶפְרֵשׁ: נוֹתָר אָסוּר בַּאֲכִילָה וּבַהֲנָאָה, וְחָמֵץ אָסוּר בַּאֲכִילָה וּבַהֲנָאָה. מָה נוֹתָר טָעוּן שְׂרֵיפָה — אַף חָמֵץ טָעוּן שְׂרֵיפָה.
human_translation: They said to him: an animal carcass can prove as eating is prohibited and it does not require burning. He said to them: difference It is prohibited to eat and benefit from the leftover and it is prohibited to eat and benefit from leavened bread. Just as the leftover requires burning, so too, leavened bread requires burning.
llm_translation: They said to him: A carcass proves, that it is forbidden in eating and it is not required burning! He said to them, distinguish: leftover is forbidden in eating and in benefit, and leaven is forbidden in eating and in benefit. Just as leftover requires burning — so too leaven requires burning.

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ לוֹ: שׁוֹר הַנִּסְקָל יוֹכִיחַ, שֶׁאָסוּר בַּאֲכִילָה וּבַהֲנָאָה — וְאֵינוֹ טָעוּן שְׂרֵיפָה. אָמַר לָהֶן, הֶפְרֵשׁ: נוֹתָר אָסוּר בַּאֲכִילָה וּבַהֲנָאָה וְעָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת, וְחָמֵץ אָסוּר בַּאֲכִילָה וּבַהֲנָאָה וְעָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת, מָה נוֹתָר בִּשְׂרֵיפָה — אַף חָמֵץ בִּשְׂרֵיפָה. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: חֶלְבּוֹ שֶׁל שׁוֹר הַנִּסְקָל יוֹכִיחַ, שֶׁאָסוּר בַּאֲכִילָה וּבַהֲנָאָה וְעָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת — וְאֵין טָעוּן שְׂרֵיפָה!
human_translation: said to him: an ox that is stoned can prove as it is prohibited to eat and benefit and it does not require burning. He said to them: difference It is prohibited to eat and benefit from the leftover punished with karet . And it is prohibited to eat and benefit from leavened bread, and punished with karet . Just as the leftover burning, so too, leavened bread burning. They said to him: the fats of an ox that is stoned can prove as it is prohibited to eat benefit punished with karet , and they do not require burning.
llm_translation: They said to him: A bull that is stoned shall prove that it is forbidden for consumption and benefit, and does not require burning. He said to them: Distinguish: leftover leaven is forbidden for consumption and benefit, and the punishment is excision, and leaven is forbidden for consumption and benefit, and the punishment is excision, what is leftover for burning - also leaven for burning. They said to him: The fat of a bull that is stoned shall prove that it is forbidden for consumption and benefit, and the punishment is excision - and does not require burning!

hebrew_text: חָזַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְדָנוֹ דִּין אַחֵר: נוֹתָר יֶשְׁנוֹ בְּ״בַל תּוֹתִירוּ״, וְחָמֵץ בְּ״בַל תּוֹתִירוּ״. מָה נוֹתָר בִּשְׂרֵיפָה — אַף חָמֵץ בִּשְׂרֵיפָה.
human_translation: Then Rabbi Yehuda presented a different logical derivation: leftover is in And you shall not leave over. And leavened bread is in And you shall not leave over, Just as leftover is subject to burning, so too, leavened bread is subject to burning.
llm_translation: Rebbe Yehuda reviewed and judged another case: "Leftover yeast in 'do not leave overnight' and leaven in 'do not leave overnight.' Just as what is leftover in burning — so too leaven in burning."

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ לוֹ: אָשָׁם תָּלוּי וְחַטַּאת הָעוֹף הַבָּא עַל הַסָּפֵק לִדְבָרֶיךָ יוֹכִיחוּ, שֶׁהֵן בְּ״בַל תּוֹתִירוּ״. שֶׁאָנוּ אוֹמְרִים בִּשְׂרֵיפָה, וְאַתָּה אוֹמֵר בִּקְבוּרָה! שָׁתַק רַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: They said to him: According to your opinion, an uncertain guilt-offering and a bird as a sin-offering in a case of doubt will prove as they are in And you shall not leave over, As we say that they are subject to burning, but you say is subject to burial. Rabbi Yehuda was silent,
llm_translation: They said to him: A hanging guilt-offering and a sin-offering of a bird that comes for a doubt according to your words they shall prove, for they are in the category of "do not leave over." For we say in the case of burning, and you say in the case of burial! Rabbi Yehuda remained silent.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף, הַיְינוּ דְּאָמְרִי אִינָשֵׁי: כַּפָּא דַּחֲטָא נַגָּרָא — בְּגַוַּוהּ נִשְׂרוֹף חַרְדְּלָא.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: This is as people say: In the spoon that the carpenter made, the mustard will burn his
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said, this is what people say: "The palm of a sin-offering is burned in its own fat."

hebrew_text: (אָמַר אַבָּיֵי:) סַדָּנָא בְּסַדָּנֵי יְתֵיב — מִדְּוִיל יְדֵיהּ מִשְׁתַּלֵּים.
human_translation: Abaye said He who made the stocks [ saddana ] shall sit in the stocks; he is repaid through his handiwork.
llm_translation: (אָמַר אַבָּיֵי:) סַדָּנָא בְּסַדָּנֵי יְתֵיב — מִדְּוִיל יְדֵיהּ מִשְׁתַּלֵּים. (Avaye said:) A demon sits among the demons - when he stretches out his hands, they become intertwined.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: גִּירָאָה בְּגִירֵיהּ מִקְּטִיל — מִדְּוִיל יְדֵיהּ מִשְׁתַּלֵּים.
human_translation: Rava said He who made the arrows shall be killed with his arrows; he is repaid through his handiwork.
llm_translation: Rava said: A convert in his convertness from a minor — from the womb his hands are established.

hebrew_text: וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים מְפָרֵר וְזוֹרֶה וְכוּ׳. אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ, הֵיכִי קָאָמַר: מְפָרֵר וְזוֹרֶה לָרוּחַ, וּמְפָרֵר וּמֵטִיל לַיָּם. אוֹ דִילְמָא: מְפָרֵר וְזוֹרֶה לָרוּחַ, אֲבָל מֵטִיל לַיָּם בְּעֵינֵיהּ. תְּנַן נָמֵי גַּבֵּי עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה כִּי הַאי גַוְונָא, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: שׁוֹחֵק וְזוֹרֶה לָרוּחַ, אוֹ מֵטִיל לַיָּם. וְאִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: הֵיכִי קָאָמַר? שׁוֹחֵק וְזוֹרֶה לָרוּחַ, וְשׁוֹחֵק וּמֵטִיל לַיָּם. אוֹ דִילְמָא שׁוֹחֵק וְזוֹרֶה לָרוּחַ, אֲבָל מֵטִיל לַיָּם בְּעֵינֵיהּ.
human_translation: And the Rabbis say one crumble and throw into the wind A dilemma was raised before With regard to what are they speaking? crumble and throw into the wind crumble and throw into the sea? Or perhaps one crumble and throw into the wind, but he cast into the sea in its pure, unadulterated form, We also learned with regard to idolatry in a case like this Rabbi Yosei says: He grind and throw into the wind or cast it into the sea. And a dilemma was raised before With regard to what are they speaking? grind and throw into the wind or grind and throw into the sea? Or he grind and throw into the wind; however, he throw into the sea in its pure,
llm_translation: The sages say: "Scattering and sowing, etc." It was asked of them: How should one understand this? Is it that one scatters and sows to the wind, and scatters and casts into the sea? Or perhaps: one scatters and sows to the wind, but casts into the sea in her eyes. We also learned similarly regarding idolatry: in this case, Rabbi Yosei says: "Laughing and sowing to the wind, or casting into the sea." And it was asked of them: How should one understand this? Laughing and sowing to the wind, and laughing and casting into the sea? Or perhaps laughing and sowing to the wind, but casting into the sea in her eyes.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה: מִסְתַּבְּרָא עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה דִּלְיָם הַמֶּלַח קָא אָזְלָא — לָא בָּעֵי שְׁחִיקָה. חָמֵץ דְּלִשְׁאָר נְהָרוֹת קָאָזֵיל — בָּעֵי פֵּירוּר. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב יוֹסֵף: אַדְּרַבָּה, אִיפְּכָא מִסְתַּבְּרָא: עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה דְּלָא מִמִּיסָּה — בָּעֵי שְׁחִיקָה. חָמֵץ דְּמִמִּיס — לָא בָּעֵי פֵּירוּר.
human_translation: Rabba said: It stands to reason that since idols are thrown into the Dead Sea, they do not need grinding, leavened bread that thrown into other rivers, needs crumbling Rav Yosef said to him: On the contrary, the opposite is reasonable. Idols, which do not disintegrate need grinding. leavened bread, which disintegrates in the water does not need crumbling.
llm_translation: Rabba said: It is logical that idol worship of the people of the salt marshes does not require grinding - it does not need to be broken up. But leaven of the remaining rivers does require sifting - it needs to be separated. Rav Yosef said to him: Master Rabba, reverse the reasoning: idol worship that does not require grinding - it requires breaking up. Leaven that requires grinding - it does not need to be separated.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַבָּה, תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵף. תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַבָּה: הָיָה מְהַלֵּךְ בַּמִּדְבָּר — מְפָרֵר וְזוֹרֶה לָרוּחַ. הָיָה מְהַלֵּךְ בִּסְפִינָה — מְפָרֵר וּמֵטִיל לַיָּם. תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵף: הָיָה מְהַלֵּךְ בַּמִּדְבָּר — שׁוֹחֵק וְזוֹרֶה לָרוּחַ. הָיָה מְהַלֵּךְ בִּסְפִינָה — שׁוֹחֵק וּמֵטִיל לַיָּם.
human_translation: was taught in accordance with Rabba was taught in accordance with Rav Yosef. was taught in accordance with Rabba: one was walking in the desert he crumble and throw it into the wind. he was traveling on a ship, he crumble and throw it into the sea. was taught in accordance with Rav Yosef: one was walking in the desert he grind it and throw it into the wind. he was traveling on a ship, he grind it and throw it into the sea.
llm_translation: It was taught in the school of Rabah, it was taught in the school of Rav Yosef. It was taught in the school of Rabah: If he was walking in the desert - he would break and scatter to the wind. If he was walking on a ship - he would break and cast into the sea. It was taught in the school of Rav Yosef: If he was walking in the desert - he would laugh and scatter to the wind. If he was walking on a ship - he would laugh and cast into the sea.

hebrew_text: שְׁחִיקָה קַשְׁיָא לְרַבָּה, פֵּירוּר קַשְׁיָא לְרַב יוֹסֵף. שְׁחִיקָה לְרַבָּה לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — לְיָם הַמֶּלַח, הָא — לִשְׁאָר נְהָרוֹת. פֵּירוּר לְרַב יוֹסֵף לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — בְּחִיטֵּי, הָא — בְּנַהֲמָא.
human_translation: grinding is difficult for Rabba, crumbling is difficult for Rav Yosef, grinding is not difficult for Rabba. This into the Dead Sea. That into other rivers. crumbling is not difficult for Rav Yosef. This with of wheat That to bread.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Shechikah kashya to Rabba, peirur kashya to Rav Yosef. Shechikah to Rabba la kashya: ha - leyam hamelach, ha - lishar neẖarot. Peirur to Rav Yosef la kashya: ha - beẖittei, ha - benahama." English translation: "A question of Shechikah to Rabba, a question of Peirur to Rav Yosef. The question of Shechikah to Rabba is not difficult: here - to the Dead Sea, here - to other rivers. The question of Peirur to Rav Yosef is not difficult: here - with wheat, here - with barley."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ חָמֵץ שֶׁל גּוֹי שֶׁעָבַר עָלָיו הַפֶּסַח — מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה, וְשֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל — אָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֹא יֵרָאֶה לְךָ שְׂאוֹר״.
human_translation: It is permitted to benefit from leavened bread of a gentile over which Passover has elapsed, it is prohibited to benefit from of a Jew as it is stated: neither shall there be leaven seen with you,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: Leaven of a gentile that passed over the Passover is permitted for benefit, and that of an Israelite is forbidden for benefit, as it is stated: "No leaven shall be seen with you."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַנִּי מַתְנִיתִין? לָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְלָא רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן וְלָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי. מַאי הִיא? דְּתַנְיָא: חָמֵץ, בֵּין לִפְנֵי זְמַנּוֹ בֵּין לְאַחַר זְמַנּוֹ — עוֹבֵר עָלָיו בְּלָאו. תּוֹךְ זְמַנּוֹ — עוֹבֵר עָלָיו בְּלָאו וְכָרֵת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: Who is the mishna? It is not Rabbi Yehuda, and it is not Rabbi Shimon, and it is not Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. What is As it was taught leavened bread, whether before its time, or after its time, transgresses a negative mitzva. During its time, transgresses a negative mitzva and karet . the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara, who is the Tanna of this Mishnah? Not Rabbi Yehuda, not Rabbi Shimon, and not Rabbi Yosei the Galilean. What is it? As it was taught: Chametz, whether before its designated time or after its designated time - one transgresses a negative commandment. During its designated time - one transgresses a negative commandment and receives karet, according to the words of Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: חָמֵץ לִפְנֵי זְמַנּוֹ וּלְאַחַר זְמַנּוֹ — אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵר עָלָיו בְּלֹא כְּלוּם. תּוֹךְ זְמַנּוֹ — עוֹבֵר עָלָיו בְּכָרֵת וּבְלָאו. וּמִשָּׁעָה שֶׁאָסוּר בַּאֲכִילָה אָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה, אֲתָאן לְתַנָּא קַמָּא. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי אוֹמֵר: תְּמַהּ עַל עַצְמְךָ, הֵיאַךְ חָמֵץ אָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה כׇּל שִׁבְעָה!
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: leavened bread, before its time and after its time, does not transgress any During its time one karet and transgresses a negative mitzva And from the time that it is prohibited to eat it is prohibited to benefit we have come to the first tanna , Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: Be astounded with yourself. How can it be prohibited to benefit from leavened bread for all seven
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: Leaven before its time and after its time - one does not transgress upon it without any penalty. During its time - one transgresses upon it with karet and lashes. And from the moment it is forbidden for consumption, it is forbidden for benefit. We come to the first Mishnah. Rabbi Yosei the Galilean says: Wonder about yourself, how is it that leaven is forbidden for benefit for seven days!

hebrew_text: וּמִנַּיִן לָאוֹכֵל חָמֵץ מִשֵּׁשׁ שָׁעוֹת וּלְמַעְלָה שֶׁהוּא עוֹבֵר בְּלֹא תַעֲשֶׂה — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֹא תֹאכַל עָלָיו חָמֵץ״, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: From where that one who eats leavened bread from the sixth hour and onward transgresses a negative mitzva? As it is stated: You shall eat no leavened bread with it; This is the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And from where do we derive that one who eats leaven from six hours and onwards transgresses a negative commandment? Because it is stated: "You shall not eat leavened bread with it," the words of Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן: וְכִי אֶפְשָׁר לוֹמַר כֵּן? וַהֲלֹא כְּבָר נֶאֱמַר ״לֹא תֹאכַל עָלָיו חָמֵץ שִׁבְעַת יָמִים תֹּאכַל עָלָיו מַצּוֹת״! אִם כֵּן, מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״לֹא תֹאכַל עָלָיו חָמֵץ״? בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁיֶּשְׁנוֹ בְּקוּם אֱכוֹל מַצָּה — יֶשְׁנוֹ בְּבַל תֹּאכַל חָמֵץ, וּבְשָׁעָה שֶׁאֵינוֹ בְּקוּם אֱכוֹל מַצָּה — אֵינוֹ בְּבַל תֹּאכַל חָמֵץ.
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon said to him: Is it possible to say this? Isn’t it already stated: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it; for seven days you shall eat matzot ”? If so, what the verse states: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it”? at a time when he is get up and eat matza , he is subject to You shall eat no leavened bread. And at a time when he is get up and eat matza , he is not subject to You shall eat no leavened bread.
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Shimon: Is it possible to say so? Has it not already been said, "You shall not eat leavened bread with it; for seven days you shall eat with it unleavened bread"? If so, what is the Talmud to say, "You shall not eat leavened bread with it"? When one is able to eat matzah, he is in a state of obligation not to eat leavened bread, and when he is not able to eat matzah, he is not in a state of obligation not to eat leavened bread.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? תְּלָתָא קְרָאֵי כְּתִיבִי: ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל חָמֵץ״, ״וְכׇל מַחְמֶצֶת לֹא תֹאכֵלוּ״, ״לֹא תֹאכַל עָלָיו חָמֵץ״. חַד לִפְנֵי זְמַנּוֹ, וְחַד לְאַחַר זְמַנּוֹ, וְחַד לְתוֹךְ זְמַנּוֹ.
human_translation: What is the reason of Rabbi Yehuda? There are three verses are written “Leavened bread shall not be eaten” “And all that which is leavened you shall not eat; “You shall eat no leavened bread with it” One before its time, One after its time And one verse during Passover
llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda? Three verses are written: "You shall not eat leavened bread," "And all leaven you shall not eat," "You shall not eat leaven with it." One for before its appointed time, one for after its appointed time, and one for during its appointed time.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן: חַד לְתוֹךְ זְמַנּוֹ. ״וְכׇל מַחְמֶצֶת״ מִבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְתַנְיָא: אֵין לִי אֶלָּא שֶׁנִּתְחַמֵּץ מֵאֵלָיו. מֵחֲמַת דָּבָר אַחֵר מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כׇּל מַחְמֶצֶת לֹא תֹאכֵלוּ״.
human_translation: And Rabbi Shimon One to during its time. “And all that which is leavened is required as it was taught I have only if it became leavened on its own, From where do I derive due to another substance The verse states: “All that which is leavened you shall not eat.”
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon: One within its time. "And all leavened" - he requires it according to the teaching: I have only that which has leavened from it. From where do we derive another matter? The Torah teaches: "You shall not eat any leavened bread."

hebrew_text: ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל חָמֵץ״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי אוֹמֵר: מִנַּיִן לְפֶסַח מִצְרַיִם שֶׁאֵין חִימּוּצוֹ נוֹהֵג אֶלָּא יוֹם אֶחָד? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל חָמֵץ״, וּסְמִיךְ לֵיהּ: ״הַיּוֹם אַתֶּם יֹצְאִים״.
human_translation: “Leavened bread shall not be eaten” is required As it was taught Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: From where that the leavened bread the Passover in Egypt applied for only one day? The verse states: “Leavened bread shall not be eaten,” juxtaposed to “This day you go forth
llm_translation: The Talmudic text states: "לֹא יֵאָכֵל חָמֵץ" - From where does one derive this according to the teaching of Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, who says: From where do we learn regarding the Passover of Egypt that its leavening is only practiced for one day? The Scripture teaches: "לֹא יֵאָכֵל חָמֵץ" (No leaven shall be eaten), and it is juxtaposed with: "הַיּוֹם אַתֶּם יֹצְאִים" (Today you are leaving).

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, מֵחֲמַת דָּבָר אַחֵר מְנָא לֵיהּ? מִדְּאַפְּקֵיהּ רַחֲמָנָא בִּלְשׁוֹן מַחְמֶצֶת.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yehuda, from where does he due to another substance that the Merciful One expresses with the term: “That which is leavened”;
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda, because of another matter, he counted it for him? Since the Merciful One expressed it in the language of sourdough.

hebrew_text: דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי מְנָא לֵיהּ? אִי בָּעֵית אֵימָא: מִדִּסְמִיךְ לֵיהּ ״הַיּוֹם״. אִי בָּעֵית אֵימָא: סְמוּכִין לָא דָּרֵישׁ.
human_translation: of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili from where does If you wish, say that from that “this day” is juxtaposed to it. If you wish, say does not employ homiletic juxtaposition
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean asks about it? If you wish, say: from the proximity of "today." If you wish, say: they are not close to expound.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: וּמִנַּיִן לְאוֹכֵל חָמֵץ מִשֵּׁשׁ שָׁעוֹת וּלְמַעְלָה שֶׁהוּא עוֹבֵר בְּלֹא תַעֲשֶׂה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֹא תֹאכַל עָלָיו חָמֵץ״, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן: וְכִי אֶפְשָׁר לוֹמַר כֵּן? וַהֲלֹא כְּבָר נֶאֱמַר ״לֹא תֹאכַל עָלָיו חָמֵץ שִׁבְעַת יָמִים תֹּאכַל עָלָיו מַצּוֹת״.
human_translation: The Master said From where that one who eats leavened bread from the sixth hour and onward transgresses a negative mitzva? As it is stated: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it”; this is the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon said to him: And is it possible to say this? Isn’t it already stated: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it; for seven days you shall eat matzot ,”
llm_translation: Master said: And from where do we know that one who eats leaven from six hours and onwards transgresses a negative commandment, as it is stated: "You shall not eat leavened bread with it," the words of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon said to him: Can it really be said thus? Has it not already been stated: "You shall not eat leavened bread with it; for seven days you shall eat unleavened bread," Exodus 13:6?

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, שַׁפִּיר קָאָמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן? וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אָמַר לָךְ: הָהוּא — לְקוֹבְעוֹ חוֹבָה אֲפִילּוּ בַּזְּמַן הַזֶּה הוּא דַּאֲתָא.
human_translation: And Rabbi Shimon is saying well to Rabbi Yehuda, Rabbi Yehuda said to you: comes to establish it as an obligation even nowadays.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda, is he saying well to Rabbi Shimon? And Rabbi Yehuda said to him: That one - to establish an obligation even in this time, that is what he is coming for.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, לְקוֹבְעוֹ חוֹבָה מְנָא לֵיהּ? נָפְקָא לֵיהּ מִ״בָּעֶרֶב תֹּאכְלוּ״. וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְטָמֵא וְשֶׁהָיָה בְּדֶרֶךְ רְחוֹקָה. סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וּבְפֶסַח לֹא יֹאכַל — מַצָּה וּמָרוֹר נָמֵי לָא נֵיכוֹל. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: And Rabbi Shimon, from where does he to establish it as an obligation He derives it from in the evening, you shall eat And Rabbi Yehuda, requires it for one who is impure or on a distant journey It could enter your mind to say that since he will not eat the Paschal lamb, he is also not to eat matza and bitter herbs. teaches us
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon, to one who establishes a debt, from where does he count it? It is derived for him from "In the evening, you shall eat." And Rabbi Yehuda, he requires it for one who is impure and was on a distant road. Is it your opinion that I say: Since he will not eat the Paschal offering, he will also not be able to eat matzah and bitter herbs. This is what we have heard.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, טָמֵא וְשֶׁהָיָה בְּדֶרֶךְ רְחוֹקָה לָא אִיצְטְרִיךְ קְרָא, דְּלָא גָּרַע מֵעָרֵל וּבֶן נֵכָר. דִּכְתִיב: ״וְכׇל עָרֵל לֹא יֹאכַל בּוֹ״ — בּוֹ הוּא אֵינוֹ אוֹכֵל, אֲבָל אוֹכֵל הוּא בְּמַצָּה וּבְמָרוֹר. וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה: כְּתִיב בְּהַאי וּכְתִיב בְּהַאי.
human_translation: And Rabbi Shimon, a verse is not necessary one who is impure or on a distant journey as he is no worse than an uncircumcised man or a resident alien. As it is written: “And no uncircumcised man shall eat of it” “of it” it, he does not eat; however, he eat matza and bitter herbs. And Rabbi Yehuda, it is written in this And it is written in that
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon, impure and was on a distant road, not needed verse, for not less than uncircumcised and son of a foreigner. As it is written: "And no uncircumcised person shall eat of it" — of it he does not eat, but he eats it with matzah and maror. And Rabbi Yehuda: Written in this one and written in that one.

hebrew_text: מַנִּי מַתְנִיתִין? אִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה — חָמֵץ סְתָמָא קָאָמַר, אֲפִילּוּ דְּגוֹי. וְאִי רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן —
human_translation: whose is the mishna If Rabbi Yehuda, said leavened bread without stipulation even of a gentile And if Rabbi Shimon,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Who is the Tanna of the Mishnah? If it is Rabbi Yehuda - he is speaking about regular leaven, even of a non-Jew. And if it is Rabbi Shimon -

hebrew_text: דְּיִשְׂרָאֵל נָמֵי מִישְׁרֵא קָא שָׁרֵי! וְאִי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי — אֲפִילּוּ תּוֹךְ זְמַנּוֹ נָמֵי מִישְׁרֵא קָא שָׁרֵי בַּהֲנָאָה.
human_translation: also permits owned by a Jew. And if Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, he would permit to benefit even during
llm_translation: The people of Israel are trustworthy, for Rabbi Yosei the Galilean said: Even within his designated time, one is trustworthy for financial matters.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב: לְעוֹלָם רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, וְיָלֵיף שְׂאוֹר דַּאֲכִילָה מִשְּׂאוֹר דִּרְאִיָּיה. מָה שְׂאוֹר דִּרְאִיָּיה — שֶׁלְּךָ אִי אַתָּה רוֹאֶה, אֲבָל אַתָּה רוֹאֶה שֶׁל אֲחֵרִים וְשֶׁל גָּבוֹהַּ. אַף שְׂאוֹר דַּאֲכִילָה — שֶׁלְּךָ אִי אַתָּה אוֹכֵל, אֲבָל אַתָּה אוֹכֵל שֶׁל אֲחֵרִים וְשֶׁל גָּבוֹהַּ.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: Actually, is Rabbi Yehuda, and derives the eating of leaven from seeing leaven. seeing leaven you should not see your own But you may see to others, and to God. Similarly, eating leaven you may not eat your own but you may eat of others or to God
llm_translation: Rav Acha bar Yaakov said: Always follow Rabbi Yehuda, and prefer the leaven of consumption over the leaven of sight. Just as the leaven of sight - you do not see yours, but you see that of others and of the high places. So too, the leaven of consumption - you do not eat yours, but you eat that of others and of the high places.

hebrew_text: וּבְדִין הוּא דְּאִיבְּעִי לֵיהּ לְמִיתְנֵא דַּאֲפִילּוּ בַּאֲכִילָה נָמֵי שְׁרֵי, וְאַיְּידֵי דִּתְנָא דְּיִשְׂרָאֵל אָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה — תְּנָא נָמֵי דְּגוֹי מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה. וּבְדִין הוּא דְּאִיבְּעִי לֵיהּ לְמִיתְנֵא דַּאֲפִילּוּ בְּתוֹךְ זְמַנּוֹ מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה, וְאַיְּידֵי דִּתְנָא דְּיִשְׂרָאֵל לְאַחַר זְמַנּוֹ — תְּנָא נָמֵי דְּגוֹי לְאַחַר זְמַנּוֹ.
human_translation: And by right it taught even the eating is permitted but since taught that it is forbidden to benefit from a Jew he also taught it is permitted to benefit from a gentile. And by right it taught that it is permitted to benefit from But since taught Jew after he also taught after
llm_translation: It is a matter of law that if one wants to give it to him to teach that even in eating it is permitted, and since a Tanna taught that a Jew is forbidden to benefit — let a Tanna also teach that a non-Jew is permitted to benefit. And it is a matter of law that if one wants to give it to him to teach that even within its time it is permitted to benefit, and since a Tanna taught that a Jew after its time is forbidden — let a Tanna also teach that a non-Jew after its time is forbidden.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: לְעוֹלָם רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הִיא. וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, קְנָסָא קָנֵיס, הוֹאִיל וְעָבַר עֲלֵיהּ בְּבַל יֵרָאֶה וּבַל יִמָּצֵא.
human_translation: Rava said: Actually, is Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Shimon incurs a penalty. Since he transgressed it shall not be seen and it shall not be found,
llm_translation: Rava said: Always it is Rabbi Shimon who is correct. And Rabbi Shimon, when he acquired a fine, since he transgressed it, it will not be seen and it will not be found.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרָבָא, הַיְינוּ דְּקָתָנֵי: שֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל אָסוּר, מִשּׁוּם שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״לֹא יֵרָאֶה״. אֶלָּא לְרַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב, מִשּׁוּם ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל חָמֵץ״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ!
human_translation: Granted, according to Rava, this is that which was taught belonged to a Jew is forbidden because it is stated: “It shall not be seen” But according to Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov, should have said due to “Leavened bread shall not be eaten”
llm_translation: In truth, according to Rava, that is what is taught: that of a Jew is forbidden, because it is stated "it shall not be seen." But according to Rav Acha bar Yaakov, because of "leaven shall not be eaten," he requires it!

hebrew_text: מִי סָבְרַתְּ אַסֵּיפָא קָאֵי?! אַרֵישָׁא קָאֵי וְהָכִי קָאָמַר: חָמֵץ שֶׁל גּוֹי שֶׁעָבַר עָלָיו הַפֶּסַח מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה, מִשּׁוּם שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״לֹא יֵרָאֶה לְךָ״ — שֶׁלְּךָ אִי אַתָּה רוֹאֶה, אֲבָל אַתָּה רוֹאֶה שֶׁל אֲחֵרִים וְשֶׁל גָּבוֹהַּ. וְיָלֵיף שְׂאוֹר דַּאֲכִילָה מִשְּׂאוֹר דִּרְאִיָּיה.
human_translation: Do you hold is referring to the latter clause It is referring to the first clause and this is it is saying: Leavened bread of a gentile, over which Passover has elapsed, it is permissible to benefit from due to it is stated: “It shall not be seen by you.” you may not see your own but you may see to others and to God. And he derives about of eating leaven from of seeing leaven.
llm_translation: Who holds that the conclusion is standing?! The beginning is standing, and thus it says: The leaven of a gentile that the Passover has passed over is permitted for benefit, because it is stated "it shall not be seen for you" - yours you may not see, but you may see that of others and that which is high. And it is derived: the leaven for consumption from the leaven for sight.

hebrew_text: וְאָזְדוּ לְטַעְמַיְיהוּ: דְּאִיתְּמַר, הָאוֹכֵל שְׂאוֹר שֶׁל גּוֹי שֶׁעָבַר עָלָיו הַפֶּסַח, לְדִבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, רָבָא אָמַר: לוֹקֶה, וְרַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב אָמַר: אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה.
human_translation: follow their reasoning. For it was stated one who eats leaven of a gentile over which Passover has elapsed, according to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, Rava said: He is flogged, And Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: He is not flogged.
llm_translation: And they went to their reasons: for it was said, one who eats leaven of a gentile that the Passover has passed over it, according to the words of Rabbi Yehuda, Rava said: he is liable, and Rav Acha bar Yaakov said: he is not liable.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: לוֹקֶה, לָא יָלֵיף רַבִּי יְהוּדָה שְׂאוֹר דַּאֲכִילָה מִשְּׂאוֹר דִּרְאִיָּיה. וְרַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב אָמַר: אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה, יָלֵיף שְׂאוֹר דַּאֲכִילָה מִשְּׂאוֹר דִּרְאִיָּיה.
human_translation: Rava said he is flogged, Rabbi Yehuda does not derive eating leaven from seeing leaven. Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: He is not flogged, learns eating leaven from seeing leaven,
llm_translation: Rava said: One who is lashed, Rabbi Yehuda does not differentiate between leaven for consumption and leaven for sight. And Rav Acha bar Yaakov said: He is not lashed, differentiate between leaven for consumption and leaven for sight.

hebrew_text: וַהֲדַר בֵּיהּ רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב מֵהַהִיא, דְּתַנְיָא: הָאוֹכֵל חָמֵץ שֶׁל הֶקְדֵּשׁ בַּמּוֹעֵד — מָעַל. וְיֵשׁ אוֹמְרִים: לֹא מָעַל.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov retracted that As it was taught One who eats consecrated leavened bread during the festival misuse And some say: He is not of misuse
llm_translation: And he returned, Rav Acha bar Yaakov from there, as it was taught: One who eats leaven of the holy offering on the appointed time - transgresses. And some say: Does not transgress.

hebrew_text: מַאן יֵשׁ אוֹמְרִים? אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: רַבִּי נְחוּנְיָא בֶּן הַקָּנָה הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא: רַבִּי נְחוּנְיָא בֶּן הַקָּנָה הָיָה עוֹשֶׂה אֶת יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים כַּשַּׁבָּת לְתַשְׁלוּמִין.
human_translation: whom is Some say, Rabbi Yoḥanan said: This is Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana. As it was taught Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana would render Yom Kippur the same as Shabbat with regard to payment
llm_translation: Who says? Rabbi Yochanan said: It is Rabbi Nechunia ben Hakanah. As it was taught: Rabbi Nechunia ben Hakanah used to treat Yom Kippur like Shabbat in terms of compensation.

hebrew_text: מָה שַׁבָּת מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּנַפְשׁוֹ וּפָטוּר מִן הַתַּשְׁלוּמִין, אַף יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּנַפְשׁוֹ וּפָטוּר מִתַּשְׁלוּמִין.
human_translation: Just as Shabbat is liable to death and exempt from payment, so too, Yom Kippur is liable to death and is exempt from payment.
llm_translation: Shabbat is liable with his soul and exempt from payments, so too Yom Kippur is liable with his soul and exempt from payments.

hebrew_text: רַב יוֹסֵף אָמַר: בְּפוֹדִין אֶת הַקֳּדָשִׁים לְהַאֲכִילָן לִכְלָבִים קָמִיפַּלְגִי.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: one redeem consecrated items in order to feed them to dogs, disagree.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: "We redeem the consecrated items in order to feed them to the dogs," he stumbled.

hebrew_text: מַאן דְּאָמַר מָעַל, קָסָבַר: פּוֹדִין אֶת הַקֳּדָשִׁים לְהַאֲכִילָן לִכְלָבִים. וּמַאן דְּאָמַר לֹא מָעַל, קָסָבַר: אֵין פּוֹדִין.
human_translation: The one who said he misused holds one redeem consecrated items in order to feed them to dogs. And the one who said that he did not misuse holds not be redeemed
llm_translation: One who says "ma'al," holds: We redeem consecrated items to feed them to dogs. And one who says "lo ma'al," holds: We do not redeem.

hebrew_text: רַב אַחָא בַּר רָבָא תְּנָא לָהּ
human_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Rava taught
llm_translation: Rav Acha bar Rava taught it to her.

hebrew_text: לְהָא שְׁמַעְתָּא מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵף בְּהָא לִישָּׁנָא: דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא אֵין פּוֹדִין אֶת הַקֳּדָשִׁים לְהַאֲכִילָן לִכְלָבִים, וְהָכָא בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי: בְּדָבָר הַגּוֹרֵם לְמָמוֹן כְּמָמוֹן דָּמֵי.
