human_translation: this halakha in the name of Rav Yosef with the following formulation: Everyone agrees that one not redeem consecrated items in order to feed them to dogs. And here, they disagree an item that can cause a financial is considered to be of monetary
llm_translation: To hear a matter from the name of Rav Yosef in this case: In all the world, one may not redeem consecrated items to feed them to dogs, and here in this case, the dispute arises: In a matter that causes monetary loss, it is considered as actual monetary loss.

hebrew_text: מַאן דְּאָמַר מָעַל, קָסָבַר: דָּבָר הַגּוֹרֵם לְמָמוֹן — כְּמָמוֹן דָּמֵי. וּמַאן דְּאָמַר לֹא מָעַל, קָסָבַר: דָּבָר הַגּוֹרֵם לְמָמוֹן — לָאו כְּמָמוֹן דָּמֵי.
human_translation: The one who said he misused holds that an item that can cause a financial is considered to be of monetary And the one who said he did not misuse holds an item that can cause a financial is not considered to be of monetary
llm_translation: One who says "he transgressed," holds: a matter that causes monetary liability - it is as actual monetary liability. And one who says "he did not transgress," holds: a matter that causes monetary liability - it is not as actual monetary liability.

hebrew_text: רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב אָמַר: דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא דָּבָר הַגּוֹרֵם לְמָמוֹן — כְּמָמוֹן דָּמֵי, וְהָכָא בִּפְלוּגְתָּא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן קָמִיפַּלְגִי: מַאן דְּאָמַר לֹא מָעַל — כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה. וּמַאן דְּאָמַר מָעַל — כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov Everyone agrees that an item that can cause a financial is considered to be of monetary and here they disagree with regard to dispute as Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon. the one who said he did not misuse in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, And the one who said he misused in accordance with Rabbi Shimon,
llm_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Ya'akov said: Everything in the world that causes financial loss is considered as though it were actual money. Here, in the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, the one who says "did not act treacherously" follows the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, and the one who says "acted treacherously" follows the opinion of Rabbi Shimon.

hebrew_text: וְהָא רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב הוּא דְּאָמַר דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה יָלֵיף שְׂאוֹר דַּאֲכִילָה מִשְּׂאוֹר דִּרְאִיָּיה! אֶלָּא הֲדַר בֵּיהּ רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב מֵהַהִיא.
human_translation: But isn’t it Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov who said Rabbi Yehuda derives eating leaven from seeing leaven? Rather, Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov retracted that
llm_translation: And this, Rav Acha bar Yaakov, he is the one who said that Rabbi Yehuda would prefer the leaven of eating over the leaven of seeing! Rather, Rav Acha bar Yaakov retracted from that.

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אֲמַר: דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא — אֵין פּוֹדִין, וְדָבָר הַגּוֹרֵם לְמָמוֹן — לָאו כְּמָמוֹן דָּמֵי, וְהָכָא בִּפְלוּגְתָּא דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי וְרַבָּנַן קָמִיפַּלְגִי. מַאן דְּאָמַר מָעַל — כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי. וּמַאן דְּאָמַר לֹא מָעַל — כְּרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said that everyone that one does not redeem and an item that can cause a financial is not considered to be of monetary And here, they disagree with regard to dispute as Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and the Rabbis. the one who said he misused in accordance with Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, And the one who said he did not misuse in accordance with the Rabbis,
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: In cases of doubt in the world — we do not redeem, and a matter that causes a loss of money — it is not like actual money, and here in the dispute between Rabbi Yosei the Galilean and the Rabbis, they disagree. Whoever says it is a trespass — is like Rabbi Yosei. And whoever says it is not a trespass — is like the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב: חָמֵץ בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בֵּין בְּמִינוֹ בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ — אָסוּר. שֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בְּמִינוֹ — אָסוּר, שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ — מוּתָּר.
human_translation: Rav said: leavened bread During its time leavened bread is forbidden whether with its own type, or with another type Not during its time with its own type it is prohibited. with another type it is permitted.
llm_translation: Rav said: Chametz in its proper time, whether of its kind or not of its kind — forbidden. Not in its proper time, of its kind — forbidden; not of its kind — permitted.

hebrew_text: בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן? אִילֵימָא בְּנוֹתֵן טַעַם, שֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ מוּתָּר? הָא יְהֵיב טַעְמָא!
human_translation: With what are we dealing? If you say that gives flavor not during its time with another type is it permitted? Doesn’t it give flavor
llm_translation: In what are we dealing? Perhaps with giving a reason, that not in its proper time, that not in its proper species is permitted? But he gave a reason!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא בְּמַשֶּׁהוּ. חָמֵץ בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בֵּין בְּמִינוֹ בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ אָסוּר, רַב לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דְּרַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה, בְּמִינוֹ — בְּמַשֶּׁהוּ, שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ — בְּנוֹתֵן טַעַם.
human_translation: Rather, with any amount, leavened bread during its time is forbidden, whether with its own type or with another type Rav to his of reasoning As Rav and Shmuel who both say: any forbidden by the Torah its own type, any amount with another type give flavor
llm_translation: Rather, with regard to itself. Chametz in its proper time, whether of its kind or not of its kind is prohibited. Rav according to his reasoning, for Rav and Shmuel both said: All prohibitions in the Torah, of its kind — in its proper time, not of its kind — one gives a reason.

hebrew_text: רַב גָּזַר חָמֵץ בִּזְמַנּוֹ שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ אַטּוּ מִינוֹ. וְשֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ בְּמִינוֹ — אָסוּר, כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: Rav rendered an decree leavened bread during its time another type due to with its own type is forbidden not during its time, with its own type is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda,
llm_translation: Rav Gazar chametz bizmano shelo bimino atu mino. Veshelo bizmano bimino - asur, kerabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: וְשֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ — מוּתָּר, דְּשֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ אַטּוּ מִינוֹ — כּוּלֵּי הַאי לָא גָּזְרִינַן.
human_translation: But another type it is permitted, because no so far to render a decree with regard to another type not during its time, due to the same type
llm_translation: And that which is not in its species — permissible, for that which is not in its time and that which is not in its species, even its species — all this we do not decree.

hebrew_text: שְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: חָמֵץ בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בְּמִינוֹ — אָסוּר, שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ — מוּתָּר. שֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בֵּין בְּמִינוֹ בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ — מוּתָּר. חָמֵץ בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בְּמִינוֹ — אָסוּר, שְׁמוּאֵל לְטַעְמֵיהּ — דְּרַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה, בְּמִינוֹ — אֲסוּרִין בְּמַשֶּׁהוּ, שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ — בְּנוֹתֵן טַעַם.
human_translation: Shmuel said leavened bread during its time with its own type it is forbidden, with another type it is permitted. If it not during its time of whether with its own type or with another type it is permitted. leavened bread with the same type during its time is forbidden, Shmuel to his reasoning As Rav and Shmuel who both say: any prohibited by the Torah its own type, any amount with another type give flavor
llm_translation: Samuel said: Leaven in its proper time, of its kind — forbidden, not of its kind — permitted. Not in its proper time, whether of its kind or not of its kind — permitted. Leaven in its proper time, of its kind — forbidden, according to Samuel's reasoning — for Rav and Samuel both said: All prohibitions in the Torah, of its kind — are forbidden, not of its kind — are given reason.

hebrew_text: שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינָן אַטּוּ מִינָן לָא גָּזַר. שֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בֵּין בְּמִינָן בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינָן — מוּתָּרִין, כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן.
human_translation: did not render a decree with another type due to its same type. not during its time, is permitted, whether with its own type or with another type. in accordance with Rabbi Shimon,
llm_translation: Not in its species, we decree not in its species not decreed. Not in its time, whether in its species or not in its species - permissible, as Rabbi Shimon.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: חָמֵץ בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בֵּין בְּמִינוֹ וּבֵין שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ — אָסוּר בְּנוֹתֵן טַעַם. שֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בֵּין בְּמִינָן בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינָן — מוּתָּר.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: leavened bread during its time whether with its own type or another type it becomes prohibited only when give flavor not during its time it is permitted, of whether of its own type or another type
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: If it is leavened at its proper time, whether of its kind or not of its kind — it is forbidden to derive benefit. If it is not at its proper time, whether of its kind or not of its kind — it is permitted.

hebrew_text: חָמֵץ בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בֵּין בְּמִינוֹ בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ בְּנוֹתֵן טַעַם — רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה, בֵּין בְּמִינָן בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינָן — בְּנוֹתֵן טַעַם. שֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בֵּין בְּמִינוֹ בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ מוּתָּרִין, כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן.
human_translation: leavened bread during its time whether with its own type or with another type when it gives flavor Rabbi Yoḥanan to his reasoning As Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish who both say: any forbidden by the Torah whether of its own type or another type is prohibited when to give flavor not during its time it is permitted, whether of its own type or another type in accordance with Rabbi Shimon,
llm_translation: Leaven in its proper time, whether of its kind or not of its kind, imparts flavor — Rabbi Yochanan according to his reasoning, for Rabbi Yochanan and Reish Lakish both said: All prohibitions in the Torah, whether of its kind or not of its kind, impart flavor. Not in its proper time, whether of its kind or not of its kind, are permitted, like Rabbi Shimon.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: הִלְכְתָא חָמֵץ בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בֵּין בְּמִינוֹ בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ — אָסוּר בְּמַשֶּׁהוּ, כְּרַב. שֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ, בֵּין בְּמִינוֹ בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ — מוּתָּר, כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן.
human_translation: Rava said: The halakha is leavened bread during its time with its own type or with another type, it is forbidden, any amount in accordance with Rav. Not during its time with its own type or with another type, it is permitted, in accordance with Rabbi Shimon,
llm_translation: Rava said: The halakha is that vinegar in its proper time, whether of its kind or not of its kind — it is prohibited in its own substance, like Rav. Not in its proper time, whether of its kind or not of its kind — it is permitted, like Rabbi Shimon.

hebrew_text: וּמִי אָמַר רָבָא הָכִי? וְהָאָמַר רָבָא: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן קְנָסָא קָנֵיס, הוֹאִיל וְעָבַר עָלָיו בְּ״בַל יֵרָאֶה״ וּ״בַל יִמָּצֵא״!
human_translation: Did Rava say this, But didn’t Rava say Rabbi Shimon imposed a penalty since he transgressed it shall not be seen and it shall not be found?
llm_translation: And who said thus? Did Rava say so? But Rava said: Rabbi Shimon K'Nasa acquired, since he passed over him with "Bal Yera'eh" and "Bal Yimatzeh"!

hebrew_text: הָנֵי מִילֵּי בְּעֵינֵיהּ, אֲבָל עַל יְדֵי תַּעֲרוֹבֶת — לָא. וְאַזְדָּא רָבָא לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דְּאָמַר רָבָא: כִּי הֲוֵינַן בֵּי רַב נַחְמָן, כִּי הֲווֹ נָפְקִי שִׁבְעָה יוֹמֵי דְפִסְחָא אֲמַר לַן: פּוּקוּ וּזְבִינוּ חֲמִירָא דִּבְנֵי חֵילָא.
human_translation: This applies in its pure but a mixture, no, And Rava follows his reasoning, as Rava said: While we were in Rav Naḥman’s house, when the seven days of Passover had passed, he said to us: Go and buy leavened bread from the gentiles
llm_translation: These matters in her eyes, but through a mixture - no. And Rava became angry with his reasons, for Rava said: When we were in the house of Rav Nachman, when the seven days of Passover came out, he said to us: Go out and buy the expensive wine of the sons of the upper class.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב: קְדֵירוֹת בַּפֶּסַח יִשָּׁבְרוּ. וְאַמַּאי? לַשְׁהִינְהוּ אַחַר הַפֶּסַח, וְלֶיעְבַּד בְּהוּ שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינָן! גְּזֵירָה דִּילְמָא אָתוּ לְמֶיעְבַּד בְּהוּ בְּמִינוֹ.
human_translation: Rav said: pots during Passover be broken, And why Let him retain after Passover and prepare of another type in them. a rabbinic decree that perhaps one will come to prepare a mixture of the same type in
llm_translation: Rav said: Pots on Passover should be broken. And why? To prevent them from being used after Passover, and to avoid using them for something else! A decree lest one come to use them for their intended purpose.

hebrew_text: וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: לֹא יִשָּׁבְרוּ, אֲבָל מַשְׁהֵי לְהוּ לְאַחַר זְמַנּוֹ, וְעָבֵיד בְּהוּ בֵּין בְּמִינוֹ בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא בְּמִינוֹ.
human_translation: And Shmuel said: They not be broken. Rather, he retain them until after its time, and prepare either the same type or another type in them.
llm_translation: Samuel said: They should not be broken, but if they remain beyond their time, one may perform with them whether they are of their kind or not of their kind.

hebrew_text: וְאַזְדָּא שְׁמוּאֵל לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דְּאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל לְהָנְהוּ דִּמְזַבְּנֵי כַּנְדֵי: אַשְׁווֹ זְבִינֵי אַכַּנְדַיְכִי, וְאִי לָא — דָּרְשִׁינָא לְכוּ כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן.
human_translation: And Shmuel follows his reasoning, as Shmuel said to the pot merchants, Level the prices for your pots. And if not I will teach you is in accordance with Rabbi Shimon,
llm_translation: And it was established according to Shmuel's reasoning, for Shmuel said to those who sell pitchers: "If you sell Canaanite pitchers, make them like Canaanite pitchers, but if not, we interpret for you like Rabbi Shimon."

hebrew_text: וְלִידְרוֹשׁ לְהוּ, דְּהָא שְׁמוּאֵל כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן סְבִירָא לֵיהּ! אַתְרֵיהּ דְּרַב הֲוָה.
human_translation: Let him teach to them, for Shmuel holds in accordance with Rabbi Shimon, It was Rav’s locale,
llm_translation: And to inquire into it, for Samuel holds like Rabbi Shimon's opinion! His place was in Rav's academy.

hebrew_text: הָהוּא תַּנּוּרָא דִּטְחוֹ בֵּיהּ טִיחְיָא. אַסְרֵהּ רָבָא בַּר אֲהִילַאי לְמֵיכְלֵיהּ לְרִיפְתָּא אֲפִילּוּ בְּמִילְחָא לְעוֹלָם, דִּילְמָא אָתֵי לְמֵיכְלֵיהּ בְּכוּתָּחָא.
human_translation: a certain oven that they smeared with grease Rava bar Ahilai prohibited eating this bread even with salt, forever lest one eat with kutaḥ ,
llm_translation: That oven in which plaster has been placed, Rava son of Ahilai prohibited eating bread baked in it even with salt forever, lest one come to eat it with kutach.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: אֵין לָשִׁין אֶת הָעִיסָּה בְּחָלָב, וְאִם לָשׁ — כׇּל הַפַּת כּוּלָּהּ אֲסוּרָה, מִפְּנֵי הֶרְגֵּל עֲבֵירָה. כַּיּוֹצֵא בוֹ,
human_translation: raises an objection one not knead the dough with milk, and if he knead all of the bread is prohibited due to a habitual transgression. Similarly,
llm_translation: Challenger: One may not knead the dough with milk, and if one did knead it - all the bread is entirely forbidden, due to the habit of transgression. And the like thereof.

hebrew_text: אֵין טָשִׁין אֶת הַתַּנּוּר בְּאַלְיָה. וְאִם טָשׁ — כׇּל הַפַּת כּוּלָּהּ אֲסוּרָה, עַד שֶׁיַּסִּיק אֶת הַתַּנּוּר. הָא הוּסַּק הַתַּנּוּר — מִיהָא שְׁרֵי. תְּיוּבְתָּא דְּרָבָא בַּר אֲהִילַאי, תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: one not smear the oven with the fat tail [ alya ] And if one smear all of the bread is prohibited, until one kindles the oven that the oven was kindled it is permitted in any case. conclusive refutation of Rava bar Ahilai is a conclusive refutation
llm_translation: One does not cover the oven with a thick layer of ashes. And if one did cover it, all the bread is entirely prohibited until one clears the oven. Once the oven is cleared, the bread is permitted. This is the statement of Rava bar Ahilai, this is the statement.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: וְכִי מֵאַחַר דְּאִיתּוֹתַב רָבָא בַּר אֲהִילַאי, אַמַּאי קָאָמַר רַב: קְדֵירוֹת בַּפֶּסַח יִשָּׁבְרוּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָתָם תַּנּוּר שֶׁל מַתֶּכֶת, הָכָא בִּקְדֵירָה שֶׁל חֶרֶס.
human_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Since Rava bar Ahilai was refuted, why did Rav say pots on Passover be broken? said to him: There, a metal oven, here, to an earthenware pot,
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: And since Rava, son of Ahilai, wrote, why does Rav say: Should pots on Passover be broken? He said to him: There, it is a metal oven, here it is an earthenware pot.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא הָא וְהָא בְּשֶׁל חֶרֶס. זֶה — הֶסֵּיקָן מִבִּפְנִים, וְזֶה — הֶסֵּיקָן מִבַּחוּץ. וְכִי תֵּימָא: הָכִי נָמֵי לֶיעְבַּד לֵיהּ הַסָּקָה מִבִּפְנִים — חָיֵיס עֲלֵיהּ מִשּׁוּם דְּפָקְעָה.
human_translation: If you wish, say both this, and that, are earthenware, This, is kindled from the inside, that, is kindled from the outside, And if you say, so too he should perform the kindling inside be concerned lest it burst
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: This one and this one were with earthenware vessels. This one - he sealed them from the inside, and this one - he sealed them from the outside. And if you say: Is it so that one should work with it the vessel sealed from the inside - he is liable for it because it will burst.

hebrew_text: הִלְכָּךְ הַאי בּוּכְיָא הֶסֵּיקוֹ מִבַּחוּץ הוּא — וְאָסוּר, וְאִי מַלְּיֵיהּ גּוּמְרֵי — שַׁפִּיר דָּמֵי.
human_translation: Therefore, this griddle the kindling is from the outside and prohibited. But if he fills it with coals, it seems well
llm_translation: Therefore, this Buḵya they sealed from the outside - and it is forbidden, and if its contents are finished - it is fine, for it is like a sealed vessel.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: הָנֵי סַכִּינֵי בְּפִסְחָא הֵיכִי עָבְדִינַן לְהוּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לְדִידִי חַדְתָּא קָא עָבְדִינַן. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: תִּינַח מָר דְּאֶפְשָׁר לֵיהּ, דְּלָא אֶפְשָׁר לֵיהּ מַאי? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אֲנָא, כְּעֵין חַדְתָּא קָאָמֵינָא: קַתַּיְיהוּ בְּטִינָא, וּפַרְזְלַיְיהוּ בְּנוּרָא, וַהֲדַר מְעַיֵּילְנָא לְקַתַּיְיהוּ בְּרוֹתְחִין. וְהִלְכְתָא: אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי בְּרוֹתְחִין וּבִכְלִי רִאשׁוֹן.
human_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: these knives, how do we prepare them during Passover? said to him: For me, we craft new ones. said to him: well for Master, as you are able what one who is unable He said to him: I was speaking of like new the handles in mud, the metal with fire And then I place the handles in boiling water And the halakha is this, that, in boiling water, in a primary vessel.
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashei: How do we prepare those knives for Passover? He said to him: We prepare them for my benefit. He said to him: Leave it, Master, for it is possible for him, what is not possible for him? He said to him: I, like a new one, am standing: We place them in clay, and their handles in fire, and then we immerse them in boiling water. And the halakha is: Both in boiling water and in a first vessel.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: עֵץ פָּרוּר מַגְעִילוֹ בְּרוֹתְחִין וּבִכְלִי רִאשׁוֹן. קָסָבַר: כְּבוֹלְעוֹ כָּךְ פּוֹלְטוֹ.
human_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: A wooden ladle be purged in boiling water in a primary vessel holds As it absorbs so it emits it.
llm_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: One may soak the wood of a fig tree in boiling water and in a first vessel. He holds: Just as it absorbs, so it releases.

hebrew_text: בְּעוֹ מִינֵּיהּ מֵאַמֵּימָר: הָנֵי מָאנֵי דְקוּנְיָא, מַהוּ לְאִישְׁתַּמּוֹשֵׁי בְּהוּ בְּפִסְחָא? יְרוּקָּא לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ — דְּוַדַּאי אֲסִירִי. כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ אוּכָּמֵי וְחִיוָּרֵי, מַאי? וְהֵיכָא דְּאִית בְּהוּ קַרְטוּפָנֵי, לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, דְּוַדַּאי אֲסִירִי. כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ דְּשִׁיעִי, מַאי?
human_translation: They raised a dilemma before Ameimar: certain glazed [ konya ] vessels, what is with regard to using them during Passover? green not be raised, they are certainly prohibited Let the dilemma be raised black and white What And not be raised when they have cracks; as they are certainly prohibited. Let the dilemma be raised smooth What
llm_translation: Inquired of him Amemar: Those utensils of Konya, what about using them on Passover? A leek does not require for you — for surely it is prohibited. If you require for yourself lentils and chickpeas, what? And in a place where there are leeks, you do not require for yourself, for surely it is prohibited. If you require for yourself a radish, what?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: חֲזֵינָא לְהוּ דְּמִידַיְּיתֵי, אַלְמָא בָּלְעִי, וַאֲסִירִי. וְהַתּוֹרָה הֵעִידָה עַל כְּלִי חֶרֶס שֶׁאֵינוֹ יוֹצֵא מִידֵי דּוֹפְיוֹ לְעוֹלָם.
human_translation: said to him: I saw that is expelled [ demidayeti ]? Apparently they absorb and are prohibited, and the Torah testified about earthenware vessels they will never leave their defective
llm_translation: He said to him: "We see that it is standing still, which means it is not swallowing and is forbidden. And the Torah testified regarding an earthenware vessel that it does not leave its impurity forever."

hebrew_text: וּמַאי שְׁנָא לְעִנְיַן יֵין נֶסֶךְ, דְּדָרֵישׁ מָרִימָר: מָאנֵי דְקוּנְיָא, בֵּין אוּכָּמֵא בֵּין חִיוָּרֵי וּבֵין יְרוּקֵּי — שְׁרֵי? וְכִי תֵּימָא: יֵין נֶסֶךְ — דְּרַבָּנַן, חָמֵץ — דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, כׇּל דְּתַקּוּן רַבָּנַן — כְּעֵין דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא תַּקּוּן. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: זֶה תַּשְׁמִישׁוֹ עַל יְדֵי חַמִּין, וְזֶה תַּשְׁמִישׁוֹ עַל יְדֵי צוֹנֵן.
human_translation: What is different wine libation, As Mareimar taught: A glazed vessel is permitted whether it is black, white, or green And if you say wine libation, rabbinic and that of leavened bread, by Torah all that the Sages instituted, they instituted similar to Torah said to him: this use is with hot But this its use is with cool
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And what is the difference regarding libation wine, that Marimar expounded: "What is the difference if it is red, whether it is thick, or whether it is clear — is it permitted?" And if you would say: libation wine — of the Rabbis, vinegar — of the Torah, all that the Rabbis instituted — is like the Torah's institution. He said to him: This one is used with hot water, and this one is used with cold water.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַב חִיָּיא בַּר אָשֵׁי אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: כׇּל הַכֵּלִים שֶׁנִּשְׁתַּמְּשׁוּ בָּהֶן חָמֵץ בְּצוֹנֵן — מִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ בָּהֶן מַצָּה, חוּץ מִן בֵּית שְׂאוֹר, הוֹאִיל שֶׁחִימּוּצוֹ קָשֶׁה. אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: וּבֵית חֲרוֹסֶת — כְּבֵית שְׂאוֹר שֶׁחִימּוּצוֹ קָשֶׁה דָּמֵי.
human_translation: Rava bar Abba said that Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said that Shmuel said: Any vessel that was used for leavened bread while cool can be used for matza , exception the leaven container since its leavening is potent, Rav Ashi said: And the spice container, has the same as the leaven container whose leavening is potent.
llm_translation: Rava son of Abba said, Rav Ḥiyya son of Ashi said in the name of Shmuel: All vessels that were used with cold chametz, one may use them with matzah, except for a sourdough vessel, since its fermentation is strong. Rav Ashi said: And a clay vessel is like a sourdough vessel, since its fermentation is strong.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: הָנֵי אַגָּנֵי דְמָחוֹזָא, הוֹאִיל וּתְדִירִי לְמֵילַשׁ בְּהוּ חֲמִירָא, וּמְשַׁהוּ בְּהוּ חֲמִירָא — כְּבֵית שְׂאוֹר שֶׁחִימּוּצוֹ קָשֶׁה דָּמֵי. פְּשִׁיטָא? מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: כֵּיוָן דִּרְוִיחָא, שָׁלֵיט בְּהוּ אַוֵּירָא וְלָא בָּלְעִי, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Rava said: certain bowls of Meḥoza, since it is common to knead leavened bread in them and store the leavened bread in them, they are considered to be like a leaven container whose leavening is potent. obvious Lest you say since are spacious, the air dominates them and they do not absorb he teaches us
llm_translation: Rava said: Those wine barrels of Mahoza, since they are accustomed to being filled with strong wine, and something strong is placed in them — like a house of leaven whose walls are hard — it is obvious? What might you say: Since it is spacious, the air has control over it and does not swallow it, it is evident to us.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ גּוֹי שֶׁהִלְוָה אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל עַל חֲמֵצוֹ, אַחַר הַפֶּסַח — מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה. וְיִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁהִלְוָה אֶת גּוֹי עַל חֲמֵצוֹ, אַחַר הַפֶּסַח — אָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה.
human_translation: a gentile lent money to a Jew, leavened bread as after Passover one is permitted to benefit from a Jew lent money to a gentile, leavened bread after Passover it is forbidden to benefit
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: A gentile who lent money to a Jew with interest on his chametz after Passover — it is permitted to derive benefit from it. And a Jew who lent money to a gentile with interest on his chametz after Passover — it is prohibited to derive benefit from it.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אִיתְּמַר: בַּעַל חוֹב, אַבָּיֵי אָמַר: לְמַפְרֵעַ הוּא גּוֹבֶה. וְרָבָא אָמַר: מִכָּאן וּלְהַבָּא הוּא גּוֹבֶה. כׇּל הֵיכָא דְּאַקְדֵּישׁ לֹוֶה וְזַבֵּין לֹוֶה — כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דְּאָתֵי מַלְוֶה וְטָרֵיף,
human_translation: It was stated creditor Abaye said: He retroactively collects And Rava said: he acquires from that point forward, Anywhere that the debtor consecrated or sold everyone agrees the creditor can come and seize
llm_translation: Gemara: It was stated: A creditor, Abbaye said: He is entitled to collect his debt from the best property of the debtor. And Rava said: From here and onwards he is entitled to collect his debt. Wherever a person consecrates property to him and sells it, the entire world agrees that if a lender comes and collects his debt, he renders it invalid.

hebrew_text: וְאָתֵי מַלְוֶה וּפָרֵיק. דִּתְנַן: מוֹסִיף עוֹד דִּינָר וּפוֹדֶה אֶת הַנְּכָסִים הָאֵלּוּ. כִּי פְּלִיגִי דְּזַבֵּין מַלְוֶה, וְקַדֵּישׁ מַלְוֶה.
human_translation: Or come and redeem As we learned add an additional dinar and redeem this property. When they disagree when the creditor sold or consecrated
llm_translation: And comes the lender and the borrower. As we learned in a Mishnah: "He adds another dinar and redeems these properties." For they dispute whether the lender sells and the borrower sanctifies.

hebrew_text: אַבָּיֵי אָמַר, לְמַפְרֵעַ הוּא גּוֹבֶה: כֵּיוָן דִּמְטָא זִמְנֵיהּ וְלָא פַּרְעֵיהּ, אִיגַּלַּאי מִילְּתָא לְמַפְרֵעַ דְּמֵעִיקָּרָא בִּרְשׁוּתֵיהּ הֲוָה קָאֵי, וְשַׁפִּיר אַקְדֵּישׁ, וְשַׁפִּיר זַבֵּין. וְרָבָא אָמַר, מִכָּאן וּלְהַבָּא הוּא גּוֹבֶה: כֵּיוָן דְּאִילּוּ הֲווֹ לֵיהּ זוּזֵי, הֲוָה מְסַלֵּיק לְהוּ בְּזוּזֵי — אִישְׁתְּכַח דְּהַשְׁתָּא קָא קָנֵי.
human_translation: Abaye said: He retroactively acquires Since the time arrived and he did not repay it has become clear retroactively that it was in jurisdiction at the outset. he did well to consecrate or sell Rava said: He collects it from that point forward, since if the had money he would remove the with money It is found acquires now,
llm_translation: Abaye said, "It is a matter of defiance." Since his time arrived and he did not pay, the matter of defiance that was initially in his possession, he is now revealed, and it is proper to consecrate, and it is proper to sell. Rava said, "From here and onwards it is a matter of defiance." Since if he had money, he would have paid with money - it is evident that now he acquires with money.

hebrew_text: וּמִי אָמַר רָבָא הָכִי? וְהָאָמַר רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: רְאוּבֵן שֶׁמָּכַר שָׂדֶה לְשִׁמְעוֹן בְּאַחְרָיוּת וּזְקָפָן עָלָיו בְּמִלְוֶה, וּמֵת רְאוּבֵן, וַאֲתָא בַּעַל חוֹב דִּרְאוּבֵן וְטָרֵיף לֵיהּ מִשִּׁמְעוֹן, וַאֲתָא שִׁמְעוֹן וּפַיְּיסֵיהּ בְּזוּזֵי —
human_translation: Did Rava say this? But didn’t Rami bar Ḥama say: Reuven sold a field to Shimon with a guarantee set up as a loan. Reuven died and a creditor of Reuven’s came seized from Shimon, And Shimon went and appeased with money
llm_translation: And who said thus, Rava? But didn't Ramei bar Ḥama say: Reuben who sold a field to Simeon on credit, and Simeon established a claim against him for a loan, and Reuben died, and the creditor of Reuben came and tore it from Simeon, and Simeon came and appeased him with money —

hebrew_text: דִּינָא הוּא דְּאָתוּ בְּנֵי רְאוּבֵן וְאָמְרִי לֵיהּ לְשִׁמְעוֹן: אֲנַן, מִטַּלְטְלֵי שְׁבַק אֲבוּן גַּבָּךְ, וּמִטַּלְטְלֵי דְיַתְמֵי לְבַעַל חוֹב לָא מִשְׁתַּעְבְּדִי.
human_translation: By right, Reuven’s sons come and say to Shimon our father left us movable property in your hands, and, movable property that has been left to orphans is not mortgaged to a creditor.
llm_translation: The law is that the sons of Reuben came and said to Simeon: "We, who are movable, have left your father's grain, and movable property does not become subject to a creditor."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רָבָא: אִי פִּיקֵּחַ שִׁמְעוֹן — מַגְבֵּי לְהוּ אַרְעָא, וַהֲדַר גָּבֵי לַהּ מִינַּיְיהוּ. דְּאָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: יְתוֹמִים שֶׁגָּבוּ קַרְקַע בְּחוֹבַת אֲבִיהֶם — בַּעַל חוֹב חוֹזֵר וְגוֹבֶה אוֹתָהּ מֵהֶן.
human_translation: And Rava said If Shimon is clever he will pay them real estate can then collect from them As Rav Naḥman said: orphans collect real estate for a debt owed to their father creditor can come and seize this from them
llm_translation: And Rava said: If Shimon took possession - he collects land for them, and then collects from them. As Rav Nachman said: Orphans who collected a plot of land as a debt owed by their father - the creditor returns and collects it from them.

hebrew_text: אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא ״לְמַפְרֵעַ הוּא גּוֹבֶה״, אַמְּטוּ לְהָכִי חוֹזֵר וְגוֹבֶה אוֹתָהּ מֵהֶן — דִּכְמַאן דְּגָבוּ מֵחַיִּים דַּאֲבוּהוֹן דָּמֵי. אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ ״מִכָּאן וּלְהַבָּא הוּא גּוֹבֶה״, אַמַּאי חוֹזֵר וְגוֹבֶה אוֹתָהּ מֵהֶן? הָא הָוֵי כְּמַאן דִּזְבֵין יַתְמֵי נִכְסֵי דָּמֵי, וְאִילּוּ קָנֵי יַתְמֵי נִכְסֵי, מִי קָא מִשְׁתַּעְבְּדִי לְבַעַל חוֹב?
human_translation: Granted, if you say collects retroactively, due to this he can then collect from them, because it is considered as though he collected it during their father’s lifetime. However, if you say he collects from this point forward, why can he then collect from them? It is as though the orphans purchased this property. And if orphans buy property, does indebted to a creditor
llm_translation: If you say, "It is considered as a loan," they can retract and take it back from them - for it is like someone who collects from the orphans of his father. But if you say, "From here and onwards it is considered a gift," why can they retract and take it back from them? It is as if one were purchasing the orphans' property with money, and if one were to purchase the orphans' property, who would be obligated to the creditor?

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּאָמַר לְהוּ: כִּי הֵיכִי דְּמִשְׁתַּעְבַּדְנָא לֵיהּ לַאֲבוּכוֹן, מִשְׁתַּעְבַּדְנָא נָמֵי לְבַעַל חוֹב דַּאֲבוּכוֹן — מִדְּרַבִּי נָתָן. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי נָתָן אוֹמֵר: מִנַּיִן לַנּוֹשֶׁה בַּחֲבֵירוֹ מָנֶה וַחֲבֵירוֹ בַּחֲבֵירוֹ, שֶׁמּוֹצִיאִין מִזֶּה וְנוֹתְנִין לָזֶה? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְנָתַן לַאֲשֶׁר אָשַׁם לוֹ״.
human_translation: It is different there, as said to just as I am indebted to your father, so too, I am indebted to your father’s creditor. from of Rabbi Natan As it was taught Rabbi Natan says: From where that when one lends one hundred [ maneh ] to his fellow, and that fellow to fellow, that we take from this one, and give it to that one, The verse states: “And he shall give it to him whom he has wronged”
llm_translation: The matter is different there, for he said to them: "In the way that I am obligated to the father, I am also obligated to the creditor of the father" - from Rabbi Natan. As it was taught: Rabbi Natan says: From where do we learn that one can collect a debt from his friend's guarantor, and the guarantor from his friend's guarantor, such that they take from this one and give to that one? The Torah teaches: "And he shall give it to the one to whom he is guilty."

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: גּוֹי שֶׁהִלְוָה אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל עַל חֲמֵצוֹ — אַחַר הַפֶּסַח מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא ״לְמַפְרֵעַ הוּא גּוֹבֶה״ — אַמְּטוּ לְהָכִי מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה.
human_translation: We learned a gentile lent money to a Jew, leavened bread as after Passover one is permitted to benefit from Granted, if you say he retroactively collects it is due to this one is permitted to benefit from it
llm_translation: We learned in a Mishnah: A gentile who lent money to a Jew with interest on his leavened bread - after Passover, it is permitted to derive benefit from it. If you say, "It is for the interest that he lent," - even so, it is permitted to derive benefit from it.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ ״מִכָּאן וּלְהַבָּא הוּא גּוֹבֶה״, אַמַּאי מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה? בִּרְשׁוּתָא דְיִשְׂרָאֵל הֲוָה קָאֵי! הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — כְּשֶׁהִרְהִינוֹ אֶצְלוֹ.
human_translation: But if you say he collects it from this point forward, why one be permitted to benefit from was in the possession of a Jew With what are we dealing here? he deposited [ hirhin ] with
llm_translation: Instead, if you say, "From here and onwards is the boundary," why is it permitted for benefit? Because it was within the domain of a Jew! What are we dealing with here? When we saw it by him.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא כְּתַנָּאֵי: יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁהִלְוָה לְגוֹי עַל חֲמֵצוֹ — לְאַחַר הַפֶּסַח אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵר. מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי מֵאִיר אָמְרוּ: עוֹבֵר. מַאי לָאו, בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי: דְּמָר סָבַר לְמַפְרֵעַ הוּא גּוֹבֶה, וּמָר סָבַר מִכָּאן וּלְהַבָּא הוּא גּוֹבֶה?
human_translation: Let us say parallel to tanna’im . a Jew lends money to a gentile leavened bread as then does not commit any transgression after Passover. They said in the name of Rabbi Meir that he commits a transgression. What, isn’t it that they disagree about this, that one Sage, holds because he retroactively collects and one Sage, holds he collects it from this point forward,
llm_translation: Let us say like the Tannaim: If a Jew borrowed from a non-Jew with leavened bread - after Passover he does not transgress. In the name of Rabbi Meir they said: he does transgress. What is the reason? In this they argue: for one Master holds that he is liable from here and onwards, and the other Master holds that he is liable from here and onwards?

hebrew_text: וְתִסְבְּרָא? אֵימָא סֵיפָא: אֲבָל גּוֹי שֶׁהִלְוָה לְיִשְׂרָאֵל עַל חֲמֵצוֹ — לְאַחַר הַפֶּסַח דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל עוֹבֵר. וְהָא אִיפְּכָא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ: לְמַאן דְּאָמַר הָתָם ״אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵר״ — הָכָא עוֹבֵר. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר הָתָם ״עוֹבֵר״ — הָכָא אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵר!
human_translation: And you understand Say the latter clause However, if a gentile lends to a Jew with leavened bread after Passover everyone agrees that he commits a transgression. However, it needed the opposite according to the one who said there, he does not commit a transgression, here, he does commit a transgression. And according to the one who said there, he does commit a transgression, here, he does not commit a transgression.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And should you suggest? Say the latter part: But a gentile who lent to a Jew with interest on his leavened bread — after Passover, everyone agrees he transgresses. But this is a contradiction: to whom does it go according to? To the one who says there "he does not transgress" — here he transgresses. To the one who says there "he transgresses" — here he does not transgress!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — כְּגוֹן שֶׁהִרְהִינוֹ אֶצְלוֹ, וְקָמִיפַּלְגִי בִּדְרַבִּי יִצְחָק. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: מִנַּיִן לְבַעַל חוֹב שֶׁקּוֹנֶה מַשְׁכּוֹן? שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וּלְךָ תִּהְיֶה צְדָקָה״. אִם אֵינוֹ קוֹנֶה מַשְׁכּוֹן — צְדָקָה מִנַּיִן? מִכָּאן לְבַעַל חוֹב שֶׁקּוֹנֶה מַשְׁכּוֹן.
human_translation: Rather, with what are we dealing here? where he, deposited with him, and they disagree with regard to of Rabbi Yitzḥak. As Rabbi Yitzḥak said: From where that a creditor acquires collateral As it is stated: and it shall be a righteousness for you If does not acquire the collateral, from where is the righteousness From here that a creditor acquires the collateral.
llm_translation: Rather, here we are dealing with what? For example, that he saw him, and he disagrees with Rabbi Yitzchak. For Rabbi Yitzchak said: From where does a creditor who acquires collateral derive his right? As it is stated: "And righteousness shall be your reward." If he does not acquire collateral, from where does righteousness come? Hence, for a creditor who acquires collateral.

hebrew_text: תַּנָּא קַמָּא סָבַר: הָנֵי מִילֵּי יִשְׂרָאֵל מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל הוּא, דְּקָרֵינָא בֵּיהּ ״וּלְךָ תִּהְיֶה צְדָקָה״, אֲבָל יִשְׂרָאֵל מִגּוֹי — לָא קָנֵי.
human_translation: The first tanna holds this applies only when a Jew from a Jew, such that I would read “It shall be righteousness for you” However, a Jew from a gentile, he does not acquire
llm_translation: We learned in the first teaching: He holds that these words of Israel are from Israel, as we read in it, "And righteousness shall be to you," but if Israel is from the nations - he does not acquire.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי מֵאִיר סָבַר, קַל וָחוֹמֶר: יִשְׂרָאֵל מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל קָנֵי, יִשְׂרָאֵל מִגּוֹי לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?! אֲבָל גּוֹי שֶׁהִלְוָה אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל עַל חֲמֵצוֹ — אַחַר הַפֶּסַח דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל עוֹבֵר. הָתָם וַדַּאי גּוֹי מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל לָא קָנֵי.
human_translation: Rabbi Meir holds an a fortiori inference: a Jew acquires from Jew, all the more so not from a gentile? However, a gentile who lends money to a Jew with leavened bread as everyone agrees he transgresses There, the gentile certainly does not acquire from the Jew,
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir holds, a fortiori: If a Jew acquires from another Jew, surely a Jew from a non-Jew?! But if a non-Jew lent to a Jew with leavened bread - after Passover, everyone agrees. There, certainly a non-Jew does not acquire from a Jew.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: גּוֹי שֶׁהִלְוָה יִשְׂרָאֵל עַל חֲמֵצוֹ — אַחַר הַפֶּסַח מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה. נְהִי נָמֵי דְּהִרְהִינוֹ אֶצְלוֹ, הָא אָמְרַתְּ גּוֹי מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל לָא קָנֵי? לָא קַשְׁיָא הָא — דְּאָמַר לֵיהּ ״מֵעַכְשָׁיו״, הָא — דְּלָא אָמַר לֵיהּ ״מֵעַכְשָׁיו״.
human_translation: We learned a gentile lent money to a Jew, leavened bread as after Passover one is permitted to benefit from Even granted he deposited with him, didn’t you say a gentile does not acquire from a Jew, This is not difficult, this when said to him from now, And that when he did not say from now
llm_translation: We learned in the Mishnah: A gentile who lent money to a Jew with interest on his leavened bread - after Passover, it is permitted to derive benefit from it. The Gemara raises an objection: But if we say that a gentile does not acquire from a Jew, is it not difficult? This is not difficult - that he said to him, "from now," this is why he did not say to him, "from now."

hebrew_text: ומְנָא תֵּימְרָא דְּשָׁנֵי לֵיהּ בֵּין הֵיכָא דְּאָמַר ״מֵעַכְשָׁיו״ וּבֵין הֵיכָא דְּלָא אָמַר ״מֵעַכְשָׁיו״, דְּתַנְיָא: גּוֹי שֶׁהִרְהִין פַּת פּוּרְנִי אֵצֶל יִשְׂרָאֵל — אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵר, וְאִם אָמַר לוֹ ״הִגַּעְתִּיךָ״ — עוֹבֵר. מַאי שְׁנָא רֵישָׁא וּמַאי שְׁנָא סֵיפָא? אֶלָּא לָאו, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: שָׁאנֵי הֵיכָא דְּאָמַר לֵיהּ ״מֵעַכְשָׁיו״ לְהֵיכָא דְּלָא אָמַר לֵיהּ ״מֵעַכְשָׁיו״. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: From where do you say that he distinguishes between where he said from now and where he did not say from now? As it was taught a gentile deposited with a Jew bread baked in an oven [ purni ] he, does not transgress However, if he said to him: I have made them yours he transgresses what is different in the first clause and what is different in the latter clause? Rather, one not conclude from it that there is a difference between where he says to him from now and where he does not say to him from now? conclude from it
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And from where do we derive that one may differentiate between a case where he said "from now" and a case where he did not say "from now"? For it was taught: A gentile who kneaded dough in the presence of a Jew - he does not transgress, but if he said to him, "I have touched you" - he transgresses. What is the difference between the first clause and the last clause? Rather, understand it as follows: In a case where he said to him "from now" and in a case where he did not say to him "from now." Understand from it. English translation:

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: חֲנוּת שֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל וּמְלַאי שֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל, וּפוֹעֲלֵי גוֹיִם נִכְנָסִין לְשָׁם — חָמֵץ שֶׁנִּמְצָא שָׁם אַחַר הַפֶּסַח אָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה, וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר בַּאֲכִילָה. חֲנוּת שֶׁל גּוֹי וּמְלַאי שֶׁל גּוֹי וּפוֹעֲלֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל נִכְנָסִין וְיוֹצְאִין לְשָׁם — חָמֵץ שֶׁנִּמְצָא שָׁם אַחַר הַפֶּסַח מוּתָּר בַּאֲכִילָה, וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר בַּהֲנָאָה.
human_translation: The Sages taught a store a Jew and contents belong to the Jew, and gentile workers would enter there it is forbidden to benefit from the leavened bread that is found there after Passover, and needless to say, to eat a store a gentile and its contents belong to the gentile, and Jewish workers enter and exit the leavened bread that is found there after Passover permitted to eat it needless to say, to benefit from
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: The shop of a Jew and the merchandise of a Jew, and the workers of non-Jews enter there - leaven that is found there after Passover is prohibited for benefit, and needless to say for consumption. The shop of a non-Jew and the merchandise of a non-Jew, and the workers of Jews enter and exit there - leaven that is found there after Passover is permitted for consumption, and needless to say for benefit.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ חָמֵץ שֶׁנָּפְלָה עָלָיו מַפּוֹלֶת הֲרֵי הוּא כִּמְבוֹעָר. רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: כׇּל שֶׁאֵין הַכֶּלֶב יָכוֹל לְחַפֵּשׂ אַחֲרָיו.
human_translation: Leavened bread upon which a rockslide has fallen is considered as though it has been eliminated, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Any that a dog cannot search after it
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: If leaven falls on it, behold, it is as if it were burned. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Anywhere that a dog cannot search after it.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: וְצָרִיךְ שֶׁיְּבַטֵּל בְּלִבּוֹ. תָּנָא: כַּמָּה חֲפִישַׂת הַכֶּלֶב — שְׁלֹשָׁה טְפָחִים.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: required to nullify in his heart taught How much, will a dog search? three handbreadths
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara said Rav Ḥisda: And he needs to nullify in his heart. It was taught in a baraita: How much does a dog’s digging reach? Three handbreadths.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵף לְרַב אָשֵׁי: הָא דְּאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל כְּסָפִים אֵין לָהֶם שְׁמִירָה אֶלָּא בַּקַּרְקַע, מִי בָּעֵינַן שְׁלֹשָׁה טְפָחִים אוֹ לָא? אֲמַר לֵיהּ הָכָא מִשּׁוּם רֵיחָא בָּעֵינַן שְׁלֹשָׁה טְפָחִים. הָתָם מִשּׁוּם אִיכַּסּוֹיֵי מֵעֵינָא הוּא, וְלָא בָּעֵי שְׁלֹשָׁה. וְכַמָּה? אָמַר רַפְרָם בַּר פָּפָּא מִסִּיכְרָא: טֶפַח.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Yosef, said to Rav Ashi: With regard to that which Shmuel said, money is considered to be guarded only in the ground, is it necessary three handbreadths deep, or not? He said to him: Here, due to smell, three handbreadths are required. There, it is in order to conceal it from view. it is not required three how Rafram bar Pappa Sikhra said: One handbreadth
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Acha, son of Rav Yosef, said to Rav Ashi: This that Shmuel said, coins do not have protection except in the ground, do we require three handbreadths or not? He said to him, here we require three handbreadths because of the smell. There, it is for concealment purposes, and it does not require three. And how much? Rafhram bar Papa from Sikra said: a handbreadth.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הָאוֹכֵל תְּרוּמַת חָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח, בְּשׁוֹגֵג — מְשַׁלֵּם קֶרֶן וָחוֹמֶשׁ, בְּמֵזִיד — פָּטוּר מִתַּשְׁלוּמִין וּמִדְּמֵי עֵצִים.
human_translation: If one unwittingly eats teruma of leavened bread on Passover, he must pay the principal and an fifth. intentionally he is exempt from payment; its monetary in wood,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who eats leavened bread as Terumah on Passover, unintentionally - pays the principal and a fifth; intentionally - exempt from payment of fines and the value of the wood.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תְּנַן הָתָם: הָאוֹכֵל תְּרוּמָה בְּשׁוֹגֵג — מְשַׁלֵּם קֶרֶן וָחוֹמֶשׁ, אֶחָד הָאוֹכֵל וְאֶחָד הַשּׁוֹתֶה
human_translation: We learned there, One who unwittingly eats teruma pays the principal and an fifth, both one who eats and one who drinks
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches there: One who eats terumah unintentionally - he pays the principal and a fifth, both the one who ate and the one who drank.

hebrew_text: וְאֶחָד הַסָּךְ, אֶחָד תְּרוּמָה טְמֵאָה וְאֶחָד תְּרוּמָה טְהוֹרָה — מְשַׁלֵּם חוֹמֶשׁ וְחוּמְשָׁא דְחוּמְשָׁא.
human_translation: And one who anoints both ritually impure teruma as well as ritually pure teruma , he must pay fifth an fifth of the fifth.
llm_translation: And one the measure, one terumah impure and one terumah pure - he pays a fifth and a fifth of a fifth.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: כְּשֶׁהוּא מְשַׁלֵּם, לְפִי מִדָּה מְשַׁלֵּם אוֹ לְפִי דָמִים מְשַׁלֵּם? כׇּל הֵיכָא דְּמֵעִיקָּרָא שָׁוְיָא אַרְבְּעָה זוּזֵי וּלְבַסּוֹף שָׁוְיָא זוּזָא — לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, דְּוַדַּאי כִּדְמֵעִיקָּרָא מְשַׁלֵּם לְפִי דָּמִים, דְּלָא גָּרַע מִגַּזְלָן. דִּתְנַן: כׇּל הַגַּזְלָנִין מְשַׁלְּמִין כִּשְׁעַת הַגְּזֵלָה,
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before When he pays does he pay according to the measure or according to its monetary Anywhere that is worth four zuz at the outset, and is worth one zuz at the end, do not raise a dilemma, he is certainly to pay according to the monetary at the outset. that he is no worse than a thief, As we learned All thieves must repay at the time it was stolen,
llm_translation: He asked them: When he pays, does he pay according to the measure or according to the value? Wherever at the outset it was worth four zuz, and in the end it was worth one zuz - you need not ask, for surely he pays according to the value, as he does not lose from the thief. For we learned: All thieves pay at the time of the theft.

hebrew_text: כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ דְּמֵעִיקָּרָא שָׁוְיָא זוּזָא וּלְבַסּוֹף שָׁוְיָא אַרְבְּעָה, מַאי? לְפִי מִדָּה מְשַׁלֵּם, דְּאָמַר לֵיהּ: גְּרִיוָא אֲכַל — גְּרִיוָא מְשַׁלֵּם. אוֹ דִילְמָא לְפִי דָמִים מְשַׁלֵּם: בְּזוּזָא אֲכַל — בְּזוּזָא מְשַׁלֵּם.
human_translation: You can raise the dilemma, where it was worth one zuz at the outset, and at the end, it was worth four zuz . What he pay according to the measure as the say to him: You ate a se’a and you pay a se’a , or perhaps he according to the monetary he ate a zuz he pay a zuz ?
llm_translation: When you claim that initially it was worth one coin and ultimately it was worth four, what is the reason? According to the measure of compensation, for it was said to him: If a beast consumed, a beast compensates. Or perhaps it is based on the value of the blood, for if it consumed one coin, it compensates with one coin.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף, תָּא שְׁמַע: אָכַל גְּרוֹגְרוֹת וְשִׁילֵּם לוֹ תְּמָרִים תָּבֹא עָלָיו בְּרָכָה. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא לְפִי מִדָּה מְשַׁלֵּם — אַמְּטוּ לְהָכִי תָּבֹא עָלָיו בְּרָכָה, דְּאָכֵיל גְּרִיוָא דִגְרוֹגְרוֹת דְּשָׁוְיָא זוּזָא, וְקָא יָהֵיב גְּרִיוָא דִתְמָרִים דְּשָׁוְיָא אַרְבְּעָה. אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ לְפִי דָמִים מְשַׁלֵּם — אַמַּאי תָּבֹא עָלָיו בְּרָכָה? בְּזוּזָא אֲכַל — בְּזוּזָא קָא מְשַׁלֵּם!
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: Come hear One who ate dried figs and paid with dates, a blessing rest upon him, Granted, if you say that one repay according to the measure due to this a blessing rest upon him, as he ate a se’a of dried figs that are worth one zuz and gave a se’a of dates worth four zuz . However, if you say that repay according to the monetary should a blessing rest upon him? He ate a zuz worth and he paid a zuz worth
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said, come and hear: One who eats dried figs and pays for them with dates, blessing comes upon him. If you say, it is because he pays according to the measure, let him eat dried figs worth one zuz, and give dried figs worth four zuz. But if you say, it is because he pays with blood, why should blessing come upon him? He ate dried figs worth one zuz, and he pays with dried figs worth one zuz!

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לְעוֹלָם לְפִי דָמִים מְשַׁלֵּם, וְאַמַּאי תָּבֹא עָלָיו בְּרָכָה? דַּאֲכַל מִידֵּי דְּלָא קָפֵיץ עֲלֵיהּ זָבֹינֵיהּ, וְקָא מְשַׁלֵּם מִידֵּי דְּקָפֵיץ עֲלֵיהּ זָבֹינֵיהּ.
human_translation: Abaye said: Actually, he repay according to the monetary and why blessing rest upon him? because he ate an item that buyers don’t jump at, but paid with an item that buyers jump at.
llm_translation: Abaye said: Always one should pay according to the value of the blood, and why should a blessing come upon him? Because he has eaten from what his buyers did not jump upon, and he is paying from what his buyers jumped upon.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: הָאוֹכֵל תְּרוּמַת חָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח, בְּשׁוֹגֵג מְשַׁלֵּם קֶרֶן וָחוֹמֶשׁ. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא לְפִי מִדָּה מְשַׁלֵּם — שַׁפִּיר. אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ לְפִי דָמִים מְשַׁלֵּם, חָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח בַּר דָּמִים הוּא? אִין, הָא מַנִּי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי הִיא, דְּאָמַר חָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה.
human_translation: We learned One who unwittingly eats teruma of leavened bread on Passover pay the principal and an fifth. Granted, if you say that he pay according to the measure it is well. However, if you say he pay according to the monetary is leavened bread on Passover of monetary Yes, whose is this It is Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who said it is permissible to benefit from leavened bread on Passover.
llm_translation: We learned in the Mishnah: One who eats leavened bread on Passover, unintentionally, must pay the principal and a fifth. If you say he pays according to the measure, it is well. But if you say he pays according to the value, is leavened bread on Passover considered like blood? No, this is the opinion of Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, who said leavened bread on Passover is permitted for benefit.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, אֵימָא סֵיפָא: בְּמֵזִיד פָּטוּר מִן הַתַּשְׁלוּמִין וּמִדְּמֵי עֵצִים, אִי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי, אַמַּאי פָּטוּר מִן הַתַּשְׁלוּמִין וּמִדְּמֵי עֵצִים?!
human_translation: If that is so, say the latter clause If intentionally, then he is exempt from payment and from for its monetary wood. if Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, why exempt from payment and for its monetary in wood?
llm_translation: If so, say the latter part: intentionally exempt from the payments and from the fines for wood. If it is according to Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, why is he exempt from the payments and from the fines for wood?!

hebrew_text: סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי נְחוּנְיָא בֶּן הַקָּנָה. דְּתַנְיָא: רַבִּי נְחוּנְיָא בֶּן הַקָּנָה הָיָה עוֹשֶׂה אֶת יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים כַּשַּׁבָּת לְתַשְׁלוּמִין וְכוּ׳.
human_translation: He holds in accordance with Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana, as it was taught Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana rendered Yom Kippur the same as Shabbat with regard to payment.
llm_translation: He thought like Rabbi Neḥunia ben HaQana. As it was taught: Rabbi Neḥunia ben HaQana used to treat Yom Kippur like Shabbat in terms of payment, and so on.

hebrew_text: כְּתַנָּאֵי: הָאוֹכֵל תְּרוּמַת חָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח — פָּטוּר מִן הַתַּשְׁלוּמִין וּמִדְּמֵי עֵצִים, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא. רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי מְחַיֵּיב. אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי: וְכִי מָה הֲנָאָה יֵשׁ לוֹ בָּהּ? אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי לְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: וּמָה הֲנָאָה יֵשׁ לָאוֹכֵל תְּרוּמָה טְמֵאָה בִּשְׁאָר כׇּל יְמוֹת הַשָּׁנָה, שֶׁמְּשַׁלֵּם!
human_translation: like tanna’im , If one eats teruma of leavened bread on Passover, he is exempt from payment and its monetary in wood; the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri deems liable Rabbi Akiva said to Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri: What benefit he derive from this? Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said to Rabbi Akiva: What benefit one derive from eating ritually impure teruma on the rest of the days of the year, pay
llm_translation: Tannaite: One who eats leavened bread on Passover - exempt from the penalties and from the payment for wood, the words of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri obligates. Rabbi Akiva said to Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri: And what benefit does he have from it? Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri said to Rabbi Akiva: And what benefit does one who eats impure terumah have on all the other days of the year, that he pays!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ: לֹא! אִם אָמַרְתָּ בִּתְרוּמָה טְמֵאָה בִּשְׁאָר יְמוֹת הַשָּׁנָה, שֶׁאַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין לוֹ בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה, יֵשׁ לוֹ בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר הַסָּקָה, תֹּאמַר בָּזֶה — שֶׁאֵין לוֹ בָּהּ לֹא הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה וְלֹא הֶיתֵּר הַסָּקָה! הָא לְמָה זֶה דּוֹמֶה — לִתְרוּמַת תּוּתִים וַעֲנָבִים שֶׁנִּטְמְאָה, שֶׁאֵין לוֹ בָּהּ לֹא הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה וְלֹא הֶיתֵּר הַסָּקָה.
human_translation: said to him: No, If you say in ritually impure teruma on the rest of the days of the year, that although it is not permissible to eat it, is permitted to burn it shall you say with regard to this, that is not permitted to be eaten or burned? Rather, to what may this be compared? to teruma of berries and grapes that became ritually impure, which is not permitted to be eaten or burned,
llm_translation: He said to him: No! If you say that a ritually impure offering is valid for consumption during the rest of the year, even though it does not have permission for eating, it has permission for burning. You might say about this — that it does not have permission for either eating or burning! What is this comparable to — to the terumah of crushed olives and grapes that became impure, which does not have permission for either eating or burning.

hebrew_text: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — בְּמַפְרִישׁ תְּרוּמָה וְהֶחֱמִיצָה, אֲבָל מַפְרִישׁ תְּרוּמַת חָמֵץ — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל אֵינָהּ קְדוֹשָׁה.
human_translation: In what is this statement said, he separated teruma and it became leavened However, if he separated the teruma from leavened bread during Passover, everyone agrees that it is not consecrated,
llm_translation: In what case are these words spoken? When one separates terumah and it becomes leavened, but if one separates terumat chametz, everyone agrees that it is not considered holy.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא אִידַּךְ: ״וְנָתַן לַכֹּהֵן אֶת הַקֹּדֶשׁ״ — דָּבָר הָרָאוּי לִהְיוֹת קֹדֶשׁ. פְּרָט לָאוֹכֵל תְּרוּמַת חָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח, שֶׁפָּטוּר מִן הַתַּשְׁלוּמִים וּמִדְּמֵי עֵצִים, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב. וְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר חַסָּמָא מְחַיֵּיב. אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב לְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר חַסָּמָא: וְכִי מָה הֲנָאָה יֵשׁ לוֹ בָּהּ? אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר חַסָּמָא לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב: וְכִי מָה הֲנָאָה יֵשׁ לוֹ לָאוֹכֵל תְּרוּמָה טְמֵאָה בִּשְׁאָר יְמוֹת הַשָּׁנָה, שֶׁמְּשַׁלֵּם?
human_translation: It was taught another and shall give to the priest the sacred item” an item that is fit to be consecrated, to the exclusion of one who eats teruma of leavened bread on Passover, who is exempt from payment its monetary as wood; Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov. Rabbi Elazar Ḥisma deems liable Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov said to Rabbi Elazar Ḥisma: What benefit can derive from this Rabbi Elazar Ḥisma said to Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov: What benefit can one derive from eating ritually impure teruma on the rest of the days of the year, pay
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: "And he shall give the holy thing to the kohen" - something fitting to be holy. This excludes one who eats leavened bread on Passover, who is exempt from payment of fines and from payment for wood, the words of Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov. And Rabbi Elazar Chasama obligates him. Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov said to Rabbi Elazar Chasama: And what benefit does he have from it? Rabbi Elazar Chasama said to Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov: And what benefit does one who eats impure terumah have in the rest of the year, that he pays?

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ: לֹא! אִם אָמַרְתָּ בִּתְרוּמָה טְמֵאָה בִּשְׁאָר יְמוֹת הַשָּׁנָה, שֶׁאַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין לוֹ בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה יֵשׁ לוֹ בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר הַסָּקָה, תֹּאמַר בָּזוֹ — שֶׁאֵין לוֹ בָּהּ לֹא הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה וְלֹא הֶיתֵּר הַסָּקָה! אָמַר לוֹ: אַף בְּזוֹ יֵשׁ לוֹ בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר הַסָּקָה, שֶׁאִם רָצָה הַכֹּהֵן — מְרִיצָהּ לִפְנֵי כַּלְבּוֹ, אוֹ מַסִּיקָהּ תַּחַת תַּבְשִׁילוֹ.
human_translation: said to him: No, If you say in ritually impure teruma on the rest of the days of year, that although it is not permissible to eat it, is permitted to burn it shall you say with regard to this, that is not permitted to be eaten or burned? said to him: Even is permitted to be burned, for if the priest wishes, he may throw it before his dog or burn it under his food,
llm_translation: He said to him: No! If you said regarding impure terumah during the rest of the days of the year, that even though it does not have permission for consumption, it has permission for burning, you would say regarding this — that it does not have permission for either consumption or burning! He said to him: Even regarding this, it has permission for burning, for if the priest wishes, he may burn it before his dog, or use it as fuel beneath his cooking pot.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי כּוּלְּהוּ סְבִירָא לְהוּ חָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח אָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה, וּבְהָא פְּלִיגִי, דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא סָבַר: לְפִי דָמִים מְשַׁלֵּם, וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי סָבַר: לְפִי מִדָּה מְשַׁלֵּם.
human_translation: Abaye said: Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, Rabbi Akiva, and Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri all hold it is forbidden to benefit from leavened bread during Passover. And they disagree with regard to the following Rabbi Akiva holds one pays according to the monetary And Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri holds one pays according to the measure
llm_translation: Abaye said: Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov, Rabbi Akiva, and Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri all hold that chametz on Passover is forbidden for benefit, and they disagree in this matter, for Rabbi Akiva holds: one pays according to the value of the blood, and Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri holds: one pays according to the measure.

hebrew_text: פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי נָמֵי כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא סְבִירָא לֵיהּ, דְּאָמַר לְפִי דָמִים מְשַׁלֵּם. וְהָתָם הַיְינוּ טַעְמָא דְּקָא מְחַיֵּיב — מִשּׁוּם דְּסָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי, דְּאָמַר: חָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: obvious? lest you say Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri also holds in accordance with Rabbi Akiva one pay according to the monetary And there, this is the reason that deems him liable because he holds in accordance with Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who said: It is permissible to benefit from leavened bread during Passover. he teaches us
llm_translation: It is obvious! What might you say: Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri is similar to Rabbi Akiva, he holds, for he said one pays with blood. And there, that is the reason he obligates — because he holds like Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, who said: Chametz on Passover is permitted for benefit, this is what he implies to us.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא הָכִי נָמֵי? אִם כֵּן, נַהְדַּר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי לְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא כִּי הֵיכִי דְּמַהְדַּר לֵיהּ רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר חַסָּמָא לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב.
human_translation: And say it is indeed so, If this was Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri should have responded to Rabbi Akiva in the same way Rabbi Elazar Ḥisma responded to Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov,
llm_translation: And why not say it like this? If so, Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri is honored to Rabbi Akiva, just as Rabbi Elazar Chasama is honored to Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הָאוֹכֵל כְּזַיִת תְּרוּמָה מְשַׁלֵּם קֶרֶן וָחוֹמֶשׁ, אַבָּא שָׁאוּל אוֹמֵר: עַד שֶׁיְּהֵא בּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה. מַאי טַעְמָא דְּתַנָּא קַמָּא — אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְאִישׁ כִּי יֹאכַל קֹדֶשׁ בִּשְׁגָגָה״, וַאֲכִילָה בִּכְזַיִת.
human_translation: The Rabbis taught: who eats an olive-bulk of teruma pay the principal and an fifth. Abba Shaul says: unless worth a peruta . What is the reason for the first tanna ? the verse states: “And if a man eats a sacred item in error, eating is an olive-bulk.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: One who eats the size of an olive of Terumah must pay the principal and a fifth. Abba Shaul says: Until it is worth a perutah. What is the reason for the first Tanna? — Because the verse states: "And if a man shall eat of the holy thing unwittingly," and eating is compared to an olive.

hebrew_text: וְאַבָּא שָׁאוּל, מַאי טַעְמָא? אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְנָתַן״, וְאֵין נְתִינָה פָּחוֹת מִשָּׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה. וְאִידַּךְ נָמֵי, הָא כְּתִיב ״יֹאכַל״! הָהוּא, פְּרָט לְמַזִּיק הוּא דַּאֲתָא.
human_translation: And what is the reason for Abba Shaul? The verse states: “And he shall give,” and less than the value of a peruta is not giving. And the other too, isn’t it written: “Eats,” That comes to exclude one who damages
llm_translation: And Abba Saul, what is the reason? The verse says: "and he shall give," and giving is not less than the value of a perutah. And the other one, is it not written "he shall eat"! That one excludes a potential harm-causer that comes.

hebrew_text: וְתַנָּא קַמָּא, הָכְתִיב ״וְנָתַן״! הַהוּא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְדָבָר הָרָאוּי לִהְיוֹת קֹדֶשׁ (פְּרָט לָאוֹכֵל תְּרוּמַת חָמֵץ בַּפֶּסַח).
human_translation: And the first tanna , Isn’t it written “And he shall give”? That is necessary an item that is fit to be consecrated, to exclude one who eats teruma of leavened bread on Passover,
llm_translation: And it was taught in the first Tanna, it is written "and he shall give"! That one requires it for a matter fitting to be holy (excluding one who eats leavened bread on Passover).

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הָאוֹכֵל תְּרוּמָה פָּחוֹת מִכְּזַיִת — מְשַׁלֵּם אֶת הַקֶּרֶן וְאֵינוֹ מְשַׁלֵּם אֶת הַחוֹמֶשׁ. הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? אִי דְּלֵית בֵּיהּ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה — קֶרֶן נָמֵי לָא לִישַׁלֵּם, וְאִי דְּאִית בֵּהּ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה — חוֹמֶשׁ נָמֵי לִישַׁלֵּם! לְעוֹלָם דְּאִית בֵּהּ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה, וַאֲפִילּוּ הָכִי, כֵּיוָן דְּלֵית בֵּיהּ כְּזַיִת — מְשַׁלֵּם אֶת הַקֶּרֶן וְאֵינוֹ מְשַׁלֵּם אֶת הַחוֹמֶשׁ.
human_translation: The Sages taught One who eats less than an olive-bulk of teruma must pay the principal, but is not to pay the fifth. What are the circumstances If there was not the value of a peruta he should also not pay for the principal But if there was the value of a peruta he should pay the fifth as well. Actually, that there was the value of a peruta and nonetheless, since was not an olive-bulk, he is to pay the principal, but he does not pay the fifth.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: One who eats less than an olive-bulk of Terumah - he pays the principal but does not pay the fifth. How so? If it does not contain the value of a perutah - he does not pay the principal, and if it does contain the value of a perutah - he pays the fifth! Actually, if it does contain the value of a perutah, and even so, since it does not contain the value of an olive-bulk - he pays the principal but does not pay the fifth.

hebrew_text: אַמְרוּהָ רַבָּנַן קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב פָּפָּא הָא דְּלָא כְּאַבָּא שָׁאוּל, דְּאִי כְּאַבָּא שָׁאוּל, הָאָמַר: כֵּיוָן שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהּ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה, אַף עַל גַּב דְּלֵית בֵּיהּ כְּזַיִת. אָמַר לְהוּ רַב פָּפָּא: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא אַבָּא שָׁאוּל, אַבָּא שָׁאוּל תַּרְתֵּי בָּעֵי.
human_translation: The Sages said before Rav Pappa this is not in accordance with Abba Shaul. As, if it were in accordance with Abba Shaul, didn’t he say: because there is the value of a peruta , even if it is not an olive-bulk? Rav Pappa said to them: even you say Abba Shaul, Abba Shaul requires two
llm_translation: The sages said before Rav Papa: This is not like Abba Saul, for if it were like Abba Saul, he would say: Once there is in it the value of a prutah, even though it does not have the size of an olive. Rav Papa said to them: Even if you were to say Abba Saul, Abba Saul requires two.

hebrew_text: וּמִי בָּעֵי אַבָּא שָׁאוּל תַּרְתֵּי? וְהָא תְּנַן, אַבָּא שָׁאוּל אוֹמֵר: אֶת שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה — חַיָּיב בְּתַשְׁלוּמִין, אֶת שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה — אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב בְּתַשְׁלוּמִין. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: לֹא אָמְרוּ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה אֶלָּא לְעִנְיַן מְעִילָה בִּלְבַד, אֲבָל לִתְרוּמָה — אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב עַד שֶׁיְּהֵא בּוֹ כְּזַיִת. וְאִם אִיתָא, ״כֵּיוָן שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ כְּזַיִת״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ. תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: Does Abba Shaul require two Didn’t we learn Abba Shaul says: that which is the value of a peruta one is liable to compensation that which does not contain the value of a peruta he is not liable to compensation said to They said worth a peruta only with regard to misuse however, with regard to teruma , one is liable only when he eats an olive-bulk And if it is so, They should Since it is an olive-bulk, a conclusive refutation,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Who requires two Abba Sha'ul? And we learned, Abba Sha'ul says: If it has a value of a prutah - he is obligated in payment, if it does not have a value of a prutah - he is not obligated in payment. They said to him: They only said a value of a prutah regarding the matter of a cloak alone, but for terumah - he is not obligated until it is the size of an olive. And if it is, "since it is the size of an olive" - who requires it. The matter stands.

hebrew_text: וְאַף רַב פָּפָּא הֲדַר בֵּיהּ, דְּתַנְיָא: ״וְחָטְאָה בִּשְׁגָגָה״ — פְּרָט לְמֵזִיד. וַהֲלֹא דִּין הוּא: וּמָה שְׁאָר מִצְוֹת שֶׁחַיָּיב בָּהֶן כָּרֵת — פּוֹטֵר בָּהֶן אֶת הַמֵּזִיד, מְעִילָה שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ כָּרֵת — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁפָּטַר אֶת הַמֵּזִיד?
human_translation: Rav Pappa also retracted As it was taught “and sins through error” excludes one who intentionally not an a fortiori inference, Just as other mitzvot for which one is liable karet exempts one intentionally, is it not right that misuse which does not karet , exempt one who acts intentionally?
llm_translation: And also Rav Papa returned to it, as it was taught: "And if she sinned unintentionally" - excluding intentional sin. But is this not logical? And what about other commandments for which one is liable to receive karet - one is exempt from intentional sin, but for a transgression that does not incur karet, is it not logical that it exempts intentional sin?

hebrew_text: לֹא! אִם אָמַרְתָּ בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת שֶׁכֵּן לֹא חִיֵּיב בָּהֶן מִיתָה, תֹּאמַר בִּמְעִילָה, שֶׁחִיֵּיב בָּהּ מִיתָה! תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״בִּשְׁגָגָה״ — פְּרָט לְמֵזִיד.
human_translation: No, if you say that the rest of the mitzvot, one is not liable death shall you say that misuse one is liable death the verse states “through error” exclude one intentionally.
llm_translation: No! If you say regarding other commandments that one is not liable to death for them, will you say regarding embezzlement, that one is liable to death for it! The Talmud teaches: "Unintentionally" - this excludes intentional.

hebrew_text: וַאֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק לְרַב חִיָּיא בַּר אָבִין: הַאי תַּנָּא מֵעִיקָּרָא אַלִּימָא לֵיהּ כָּרֵת, וּלְבַסּוֹף אַלִּימָא לֵיהּ מִיתָה!
human_translation: And Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin This tanna initially karet to be stronger and subsequently death to be stronger
llm_translation: And Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said to Rav Chiya bar Avin: This Mishna initially holds that he is liable for karet, and ultimately holds that he is liable for death!

hebrew_text: וַאֲמַר לֵיהּ, הָכִי קָאָמַר: לֹא! אִם אָמַרְתָּ בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת — שֶׁכֵּן לֹא חִיֵּיב בָּהֶן מִיתָה בְּפָחוֹת מִכְּזַיִת, תֹּאמַר בִּמְעִילָה — שֶׁחִיֵּיב בָּהּ מִיתָה בְּפָחוֹת מִכְּזַיִת. וַאֲמַר לֵיהּ: תָּנוּחַ דַּעְתְּךָ שֶׁהִנַּחְתָּ אֶת דַּעְתִּי. וַאֲמַר לֵיהּ: מַאי נִיחוּתָא, דְּרַבָּה וְרַב שֵׁשֶׁת שָׁדוּ בֵּיהּ נַרְגָּא: מַאן שָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ דְּאָמַר
human_translation: And said to him that this is he is saying: No, If you say the rest of the mitzvot, for one is not liable to death less than an olive-bulk shall you say with regard to misuse for one is liable to death less than an olive-bulk? said to him: May your mind be settled, as you have settled my mind said to him: What is settling Rabba and Rav Sheshet threw an axe at Who did you hear that said
llm_translation: And he said to him, thus he said: No! If you say regarding other commandments - that he is not liable to death for them less than the size of an olive, you would say regarding embezzlement - that he is liable to death for it less than the size of an olive. And he said to him: Let your mind be at ease that you have set my mind at ease. And he said to him: What comfort is there that Rabbah and Rav Sheshet argued about it: who did you hear say

hebrew_text: הֵזִיד בִּמְעִילָה בְּמִיתָה — רַבִּי הִיא, דְּתַנְיָא: הֵזִיד בִּמְעִילָה, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: בְּמִיתָה, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: בָּאַזְהָרָה.
human_translation: one who intentionally misuses to death Rabbi As it was taught one who intentionally misuses Rabbi says death The Rabbis say: a warning,
llm_translation: Intentionally in the cloak, in death - Rabbi Hiya, as it was taught: Intentionally in the cloak, Rabbi says: in death, and the Sages say: in warning.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי? אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: גָּמַר ״חֵטְא״ ״חֵטְא״ מִתְּרוּמָה. מָה תְּרוּמָה בְּמִיתָה — אַף מְעִילָה בְּמִיתָה.
human_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Rabbi Abbahu said: He derives sin sin with regard to teruma . Just as teruma death so too, misusing death
llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi's statement? Rabbi Avahu said: He completed "sin" "sin" with regard to terumah. Just as terumah is with regard to death - so too me'ilah is with regard to death.

hebrew_text: וּמִינַּהּ: מָה תְּרוּמָה בִּכְזַיִת אַף מְעִילָה בִּכְזַיִת!
human_translation: From this Just as one an olive-bulk of teruma , so too, misusing an olive-bulk
llm_translation: And its type: What is the terumah in an olive's size, so too the cloak in an olive's size!

hebrew_text: וּמַתְקִיף לַהּ רַב פָּפָּא: מִמַּאי דְּרַבִּי כְּרַבָּנַן סְבִירָא לֵיהּ? דִּילְמָא כְּאַבָּא שָׁאוּל סְבִירָא לֵיהּ, דְּאָמַר: יֵשׁ בָּהּ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה — אַף עַל גַּב דְּלֵית בַּהּ כְּזַיִת.
human_translation: Rav Pappa strongly objects to From where Rabbi holds in accordance with the Rabbis Perhaps he holds in accordance with Abba Shaul, who said contains the value of a peruta of teruma , even if it is less than an olive-bulk.
llm_translation: And Rav Papa objects to her: From where does Rabbi hold that he agrees with Rabbanan? Perhaps he agrees with Abba Shaul, who said: If it has the value of a perutah, even though it does not have the size of an olive.

hebrew_text: וְהָא רַב פָּפָּא הוּא דְּאָמַר דְּאַבָּא שָׁאוּל תַּרְתֵּי בָּעֵי, אֶלָּא שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: הֲדַר בֵּיהּ.
human_translation: But isn’t Rav Pappa the one who said Abba Shaul said requires two Rather, learn from this retracted
llm_translation: And this, Rav Papa, he said, that Abba Saul requires two things, rather, hear from it: he reconsidered.

hebrew_text: מָר בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבְנָא אָמַר, הָכִי קָאָמַר: לֹא! אִם אָמַרְתָּ בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת — שֶׁלֹּא עָשָׂה בָּהֶן שֶׁאֵין מִתְכַּוֵּין כְּמִתְכַּוֵּין, שֶׁאִם נִתְכַּוֵּין לַחְתּוֹךְ אֶת הַתָּלוּשׁ וְחָתַךְ אֶת הַמְחוּבָּר — שֶׁפָּטוּר, תֹּאמַר בִּמְעִילָה, שֶׁאִם נִתְכַּוֵּין לְהִתְחַמֵּם בְּגִיזֵּי חוּלִּין וְנִתְחַמֵּם בְּגִיזֵּי עוֹלָה — שֶׁמָּעַל.
human_translation: Mar, son of Rabbana, said This is it is saying: No, if you say with regard to the rest of the mitzvot, where acting without intent is not treated with intent, if one intended to cut detached and cut attached he is exempt shall you say with regard to misuse that if one intended to warm himself with non-sacred shearings, he warmed himself with shearings from a burnt-offering, he has misused
llm_translation: Mar, son of Ravina, said, thus he said: No! If you say regarding other commandments - that he did not do them with intent as one does with intent, that if he intended to cut the suspended and cut the attached - he is exempt, you will say regarding a cloak, that if he intended to warm himself with secular wool and warmed himself with wool of a burnt offering - he is liable.

hebrew_text: רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק אָמַר, הָכִי קָאָמַר: לֹא! אִם אָמַרְתָּ בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת, שֶׁכֵּן לֹא מִתְחַיֵּיב בָּהֶן שֶׁאֵין מִתְעַסֵּק כְּמִתְעַסֵּק, שֶׁאִם נִתְכַּוֵּין לְהַגְבִּיהַּ אֶת הַתָּלוּשׁ, וְחָתַךְ אֶת הַמְחוּבָּר — שֶׁפָּטוּר. תֹּאמַר בִּמְעִילָה, שֶׁאִם הוֹשִׁיט יָדוֹ לִכְלִי לִיטּוֹל חֵפֶץ וְסָךְ יָדוֹ בְּשֶׁמֶן שֶׁל קוֹדֶשׁ — שֶׁמָּעַל.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said this is it is saying: No, if you say with regard to rest of the mitzvot, where one who is acting unawares is not liable as is acting aware if one intended to lift detached cut attached he is exempt; shall you say with regard to misuse where if one places his hand in a vessel to take an object places his hand in consecrated oil he has misused
llm_translation: Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said, thus he said: No! If you say regarding other commandments, that similarly one is not obligated in them unless he is fully engaged, that if one intended to lift the hanging and cut the attached - he is exempt. You may say in regards to wearing, that if he extends his hand to a vessel to take an object and his hand is anointed with holy oil - he is liable.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — בְּמַפְרִישׁ תְּרוּמָה וְהֶחְמִיצָה, אֲבָל הִפְרִישׁ חָמֵץ תְּרוּמָה — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל אֵינָהּ קְדוֹשָׁה.
human_translation: The Master said In what is this statement said one separated teruma and it became leavened However, if he separated teruma from leavened bread everyone agrees that it is not consecrated
llm_translation: Master said: In what case are these words spoken? In a case where one separated terumah and it became leavened, but if one separated leaven as terumah - everyone agrees it is not considered holy.

hebrew_text: מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק, אָמַר קְרָא: ״תִּתֵּן לוֹ״ — וְלֹא לְאוּרוֹ.
human_translation: From where are these matters Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said the verse states: shall you give to him” and not to his fire.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Mena hanei milei? Amar Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak, amar kra: 'Titain lo' - v'lo le'uro." English translation: "What are these words? Rav Nachman son of Yitzchak said, the verse says: 'You shall give it to him' - and not to his light."

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: אֵין תּוֹרְמִין מִן הַטְּמֵאָה לַטְּהוֹרָה, וְאִם תָּרַם בְּשׁוֹגֵג — תְּרוּמָתוֹ תְּרוּמָה. וְאַמַּאי? לֵימָא: ״לוֹ״ וְלֹא לְאוּרוֹ! לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָתָם הָיְתָה לוֹ שְׁעַת הַכּוֹשֶׁר, הָכָא לֹא הָיְתָה לוֹ שְׁעַת הַכּוֹשֶׁר.
human_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, raised an objection One may not separate from ritually impure for ritually pure but if one unwittingly separated his teruma is teruma . And why Let say: “to him” and not to his fire, not difficult. There, it had a period of fitness, Here, it did not have a period of fitness,
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, raised an objection: One does not separate terumah from impure produce to pure produce, and if one separated it unintentionally - his terumah is terumah. And why? Let him say: "for him" and not for his benefit! It is not difficult: There, he had a moment of fitness, but here, he did not have a moment of fitness.

hebrew_text: וּדְלֹא הָיְתָה לוֹ שְׁעַת הַכּוֹשֶׁר, הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? כְּגוֹן דְּאַחְמֵיץ בִּמְחוּבָּר. אֲבָל אַחְמֵיץ בְּתָלוּשׁ — הָכִי נָמֵי דְּקָדְשָׁה? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִין, ״בִּגְזֵירַת עִירִין פִּתְגָמָא וּבְמֵאמַר קַדִּישִׁין שְׁאֵילְתָא״, וְכֵן מוֹרִין בְּבֵי מִדְרְשָׁא כְּווֹתִי.
human_translation: What are the circumstances which did not have a period of fitness where it leavened attached However, it leavened detached indeed become consecrated said to Yes, “The matter is by the decree of the watchers, and the sentence by the word of the sacred ones” And so too, in the study hall, they teach in accordance with my
llm_translation: And if he did not have a moment of fitness, how is the value? For example, if he leavened in a mixture. But if he leavened in a hanging state — is it also considered sanctified? He said to him: No, "by the decree of the sages is the statement, and by the word of the holy ones is the question," and so do we teach in the study hall like this.

hebrew_text: כִּי אֲתָא רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יְהוֹשֻׁעַ,
human_translation: When Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, came,
llm_translation: When Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, came.

hebrew_text: אָמַר: אָמַר קְרָא ״רֵאשִׁית״ — שֶׁשְּׁיָרֶיהָ נִיכָּרִין לְיִשְׂרָאֵל, יָצְתָה זוֹ שֶׁאֵין שְׁיָרֶיהָ נִיכָּרִין.
human_translation: he said the verse states: first fruits that its remnants are recognizable for an Israelite, This is excluded as there is no recognizable remnant
llm_translation: He said: Scripture says "beginning" - that its leftovers are recognizable to Israel, this one emerged that its leftovers are not recognizable.

hebrew_text: יָתֵיב רַב אַחָא בַּר רַב עַוְיָא קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב חִסְדָּא, וְיָתֵיב וְאָמַר מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: עֲנָבִים שֶׁנִּטְמְאוּ — דּוֹרְכָן פָּחוֹת פָּחוֹת מִכְּבֵיצָה, וְיֵינָן כָּשֵׁר לִנְסָכִין. אַלְמָא קָסָבַר: מַשְׁקִין מִיפְקָד פְּקִידִי, לְאֵימַת קָא מִיטַּמְּאִי — לְכִי סָחֵיט לְהוּ. לְכִי סָחֵיט לְהוּ לֵיתֵיהּ לְשִׁיעוּרֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Rav Avya sat before Rav Ḥisda, and he sat and said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: grapes that became ritually impure, tread on them less than an egg-bulk at a time, and the wine kosher for libations Apparently holds: The liquid is stored when do become ritually impure? when one squeezes them, when one squeezes them, there is less than the measure
llm_translation: Sat Rav Ahah bar Rav Avya before Rav Ḥisda, and he sat and said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: Grapes that became impure - one should press them little by little from the winepress, and their wine is fit for libations. This implies that he holds: liquids are susceptible to ritual impurity only when they are gathered together; when are they susceptible to impurity? - when one presses them. When one presses them, he should not leave them for their measure.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, כְּבֵיצָה נָמֵי? דְּהָתְנַן: טְמֵא מֵת שֶׁסָּחַט זֵיתִים וַעֲנָבִים כְּבֵיצָה מְכֻוֶּונֶת — טְהוֹרִין! הָתָם — דְּאִי עֲבַד, הָכָא — לְכַתְּחִלָּה. גְּזֵירָה דִּילְמָא אָתֵי לְמֶיעְבַּד יוֹתֵר מִכְּבֵיצָה.
human_translation: If that is so, then even an egg-bulk Didn’t we learn one who is ritually impure a corpse who squeezed olives or grapes exact an egg-bulk, is pure. There, after the fact; here, ab initio , a decree lest one come to perform more than an egg-bulk,
llm_translation: If so, is it like an egg? For it was taught: If one who is impure due to contact with a corpse squeezes olives and grapes like a properly prepared egg - they are pure! There, it is because if he did so, but here, as an initial measure. A decree lest one come to do more than a properly prepared egg.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב חִסְדָּא: מַאן צָיֵית לָךְ וּלְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן רַבָּךְ? וְכִי טוּמְאָה שֶׁבָּהֶן לְהֵיכָן הָלְכָה? אַלְמָא קָא סָבַר: מַשְׁקִין מִיבְלָע בְּלִיעִי. וְכֵיוָן דְּאִיטַּמּוֹ לֵיהּ אוּכְלָא, אִיטַּמּוֹ לֵיהּ מַשְׁקִין.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said to Who will listen to you and to Rabbi Yoḥanan your teacher As, where did the impurity that was in go? apparently holds: Liquids are absorbed And since the flesh of the grape became ritually impure, the liquid became ritually impure
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Ḥisdah: Who has authority for you and for your teacher, Rabbi Yoḥanan, your teacher? And is there impurity in them, where is the halakha?
