To distinguish and to state specifically: In what case are these words said? — For example, when he boiled and ultimately stuck, but if he stuck and ultimately boiled — are they exempt? English translation:

hebrew_text: חַסּוֹרֵי מְחַסְּרָא, וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — שֶׁהִרְתִּיחַ וּלְבַסּוֹף הִדְבִּיק, אֲבָל הִדְבִּיק וּלְבַסּוֹף הִרְתִּיחַ — נַעֲשָׂה כְּמִי שֶׁעֲשָׂאָן בַּחַמָּה, וּפְטוּרִין.
human_translation: is incomplete and is teaching the following: In what is this statement said? where one heated and afterward pasted However, one placed and afterward boiled it is as though it had been cooked in the sun, and exempt
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Hasorei mechassera, vehachi katanei: Bameh devarim amurim — shehirteich ulevasof hidbik, aval hidbik ulevasof hirteich — na'asah kemishe'asaan bachamah, u'pturin."

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: יוֹצְאִין בְּמַצָּה הִינָא וּבְמַצָּה הָעֲשׂוּיָה בְּאִילְפָּס. הָכָא נָמֵי, שֶׁהִרְתִּיחַ וּלְבַסּוֹף הִדְבִּיק.
human_translation: Come hear fulfill with half-baked matza and pot-boiled matza . Here too, where one heated and afterward he pasted
llm_translation: Come and hear: One fulfills the obligation with matzah that is raw and with matzah that is baked on the coals. Here it is stated, because he boiled it and in the end it became sticky.

hebrew_text: מַאי מַצָּה הִינָא? אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: כׇּל שֶׁפּוֹרְסָהּ וְאֵין חוּטִין נִמְשָׁכִין הֵימֶנָּה. אָמַר רָבָא: וְכֵן לַחְמֵי תוֹדָה. פְּשִׁיטָא, הָכָא ״לֶחֶם״ כְּתִיב, וְהָכָא ״לֶחֶם״ כְּתִיב!
human_translation: What is half-baked matza ? Rav Yehuda said Shmuel said: any that when broken no strands emerge from its sides. Rava said: And likewise the loaves of the thanks-offering obvious here, “bread” is written, and there, “bread” is written
llm_translation: What is the definition of matzah? Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel: Any dough that is spread out and the threads do not pull away from it. Rava said: The same applies to loaves of thanksgiving. It is obvious, here it is written "bread," and here it is written "bread"!

hebrew_text: מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא, הוֹאִיל וּכְתִיב ״וְהִקְרִיב מִמֶּנּוּ
human_translation: lest you say Since it is written “And he shall present from it
llm_translation: What is the reasoning? Since it is written, "And he shall offer from it..."

hebrew_text: אֶחָד מִכׇּל קׇרְבָּן״, ״אֶחָד״ — שֶׁלֹּא יִטּוֹל פָּרוּס, וְהָכָא כְּמַאן דִּפְרִיסָא דָּמְיָא, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: one out of each offering “one” that not take a broken and here it is considered as though it were broken. teaches us
llm_translation: "One from all offering", "one" - that he should not take a penny, and here, like one who spreads blood, it implies to us.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: הַמְּעִיסָּה — בֵּית שַׁמַּאי פּוֹטְרִין, וּבֵית הִלֵּל מְחַיְּיבִין. הַחֲלִיטָה — בֵּית שַׁמַּאי מְחַיְּיבִין, וּבֵית הִלֵּל פּוֹטְרִין. אֵיזֶהוּ הַמְּעִיסָּה וְאֵיזֶהוּ הַחֲלִיטָה? הַמְּעִיסָּה — קֶמַח שֶׁעַל גַּבֵּי מוּגְלָשִׁין, הַחֲלִיטָה — מוּגְלָשִׁין שֶׁעַל גַּבֵּי קֶמַח.
human_translation: raises an objection: me’isa , Beit Shammai exempt and Beit Hillel obligate one ḥalita , Beit Shammai obligate and Beit Hillel exempt. What is me’isa and what is ḥalita ? Me’isa flour on boiling water [ muglashin ], ḥalita boiling water on flour.
llm_translation: Challenger: One who mixes - Beit Shammai exempts, and Beit Hillel obligates. One who separates - Beit Shammai obligates, and Beit Hillel exempts. What is considered mixing and what is considered separating? Mixing - flour on top of water, separating - water on top of flour.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם אָבִיו: זֶה וָזֶה לִפְטוּר, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ: זֶה וָזֶה לְחִיּוּב, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אֶחָד זֶה וְאֶחָד זֶה, עֲשָׂאָן בְּאִילְפָּס — פָּטוּר, בְּתַנּוּר — חַיָּיב.
human_translation: Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said in the name of his father: From this, and that, is exempt And some say this and that, is obligated And the Rabbis say: this and that, prepared them in a pot, he is exempt in an oven, he is obligated
llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, says in the name of his father: "This and that are exempt," and some say: "This and that are liable," and the sages say: "Both this and that, if done with an oven - exempt, if done with a furnace - liable."

hebrew_text: וְתַנָּא קַמָּא, מַאי שְׁנָא הַמְּעִיסָּה וּמַאי שְׁנָא חֲלִיטָה? אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל, וְכֵן אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה וְאִיתֵּימָא רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: כְּמַחֲלוֹקֶת בְּזוֹ כָּךְ מַחֲלוֹקֶת בְּזוֹ, וְתַבְרָא, מִי שֶׁשָּׁנָה זוֹ לֹא שָׁנָה זוֹ.
human_translation: And the first tanna , what is different me’isa and what is different ḥalita ? Rav Yehuda said Shmuel said, and likewise Rabbi Yehuda said, and some say Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: As dispute with regard to this so dispute with regard to that And a break he who taught this did not teach that
llm_translation: And it was taught in the first Tanna, what is the difference between Me'isah and Chalitah? Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel, and so said Rav Yehudah and it was also said by Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: Just as there is a dispute in this, so too there is a dispute in this, and it is clear, one who changes this does not change this.

hebrew_text: קָתָנֵי מִיהַת: וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים אֶחָד זֶה וְאֶחָד זֶה שֶׁעֲשָׂאָן בְּאִילְפָּס — פָּטוּר, בְּתַנּוּר — חַיָּיב, תְּיוּבְתָּא דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן! אָמַר לָךְ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: תַּנָּאֵי הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא: יָכוֹל יְהֵא מְעִיסָּה וַחֲלוּטָה חַיָּיבִין בַּחַלָּה, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לֶחֶם״.
human_translation: In any event, is teaching the Rabbis say: this and that, if one prepared them in a pot exempt in an oven obligated a conclusive refutation of Rabbi Yoḥanan, Rabbi Yoḥanan said to you: It is tanna’im , as it was taught might obligated ḥalla me’isa and ḥaluta ; the verse states “bread”
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: And the Sages say: whether one made them with a mold - he is exempt; in an oven - he is liable. This is the view of Rabbi Yochanan! Rabbi Yochanan said to you: It is a dispute of the Tannaim. As it was taught: One might have thought that dough and batter are liable for the obligation of challah, therefore the verse states: "bread."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אֵין לֶחֶם אֶלָּא הָאָפוּי בְּתַנּוּר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הַיְינוּ תַּנָּא קַמָּא! אֶלָּא לָאו, מַעֲשֵׂה אִילְפָּס אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ, תַּנָּא קַמָּא סָבַר: מַעֲשֵׂה אִילְפָּס חַיָּיבִין, וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה סָבַר: מַעֲשֵׂה אִילְפָּס פְּטוּרִין.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: Bread is nothing other is baked in an oven. Rabbi Yehuda is the same as the first tanna . Rather, is it not the between them is pot-boiled stew? The first tanna maintains obligated pot-boiled stew, And Rabbi Yehuda maintains: exempt pot-boiled stew,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: There is no bread except that which is baked in an oven. Rabbi Yehuda, is that the first Tanna? Rather, no, there is a difference between them. The first Tanna holds: One is liable for the case of Ilfas, and Rabbi Yehuda holds: One is exempt for the case of Ilfas.

hebrew_text: לָא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא מַעֲשֵׂה אִילְפָּס פְּטוּרִין, וְהָכָא כְּגוֹן שֶׁחָזַר וַאֲפָאוֹ בְּתַנּוּר קָא מִיפַּלְגִי. דְּתַנָּא קַמָּא סָבַר: כֵּיוָן שֶׁחָזַר וַאֲפָאוֹ בְּתַנּוּר — לֶחֶם קָרֵינַן בֵּיהּ, וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה סָבַר: אֵין לֶחֶם אֶלָּא הָאָפוּי בְּתַנּוּר מֵעִיקָּרָא, וְכֵיוָן דְּמֵעִיקָּרָא לָאו בְּתַנּוּר אֲפִיָּיה — לָאו לֶחֶם הוּא.
human_translation: No, that everyone agrees pot-boiled stew is exempt and here they disagree where one subsequently baked it in the oven. The first tanna maintains that since subsequently baked it in the oven, it is called bread, And Rabbi Yehuda maintains bread is nothing other is initially baked in an oven, and since was not initially baked in an oven, it is not bread.
llm_translation: Not, that all the world, the incident of Ilfas are exempt, and here, for example, that he returned and baked in an oven, he is disputing. For it was taught: The first Tanna holds: Since he returned and baked in an oven - we call it bread, and Rabbi Yehuda holds: Bread is only that which is baked in an oven originally, and since it is not baked originally in an oven, it is not considered bread.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְאָפוּ עֶשֶׂר נָשִׁים לַחְמְכֶם בְּתַנּוּר אֶחָד״. לֶחֶם הָאָפוּי בְּתַנּוּר אֶחָד — קָרוּי לֶחֶם, וְשֶׁאֵין אָפוּי בְּתַנּוּר אֶחָד — אֵין קָרוּי לֶחֶם.
human_translation: Rava said: What is the reason of Rabbi Yehuda? As it is written: “And ten women shall bake your bread in one oven” bread baked in one oven is called bread, and that is not baked in one oven, is not called bread.
llm_translation: Rava said: What is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda, as it is written: "And bake ten loaves of bread in one oven." Bread that is baked in one oven is called bread, and if it is not baked in one oven, it is not called bread.

hebrew_text: יָתֵיב רַבָּה וְרַב יוֹסֵף אֲחוֹרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי זֵירָא, וְיָתֵיב רַבִּי זֵירָא קַמֵּיהּ דְּעוּלָּא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבָּה לְרַבִּי זֵירָא, בְּעִי מִינֵּיהּ מֵעוּלָּא: הִדְבִּיק מִבִּפְנִים וְהִרְתִּיחַ מִבַּחוּץ, מַהוּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מַאי אֵימָא לֵיהּ? דְּאִי אָמֵינָא לֵיהּ, אָמַר לִי: הֵי נִיהוּ מַעֲשֵׂה אִילְפָּס!
human_translation: Rabba and Rav Yosef sat behind Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Zeira sat before Ulla Rabba said to Rabbi Zeira: Raise dilemma of Ulla: one pasted inside and heated it from the outside, what is He said to him: Why should I say For if I say to him, he say to me: What is pot-boiled stew?
llm_translation: Rabba and Rav Yosef were sitting behind Rabbi Zeira, and Rabbi Zeira was sitting in front of Ulla. Rabba said to Rabbi Zeira, "Ask Ulla about his actions: he stuck from the inside and boiled from the outside, what is it?" He said to him: "What should I say to him? For if I tell him, he will say to me: 'Be a disciple of Ilfas!'"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב יוֹסֵף לְרַבִּי זֵירָא, בְּעוֹ מִינֵּיהּ מֵעוּלָּא: הִדְבִּיק מִבִּפְנִים וַאֲבוּקָה כְּנֶגְדּוֹ, מַהוּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מַאי אֵימָא לֵיהּ? דְּאִי אָמֵינָא לֵיהּ, אָמַר לִי: רוֹב עֲנִיִּים עוֹשִׂין כֵּן.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said to Rabbi Zeira: Raise the dilemma of Ulla: If one pasted inside a torch opposite it, what is He said to him: Why should I say As if I say to him, he say to me: majority poor people do this
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said to Rabbi Zeira, "With regard to his heresy from Ulla: If he stuck from inside and the dust is opposite him, what is it?" He said to him: What should I say to him? For if I say to him, he said to me: Most poor people do so.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אַסִּי: עִיסָּה שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי, לְדִבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר — פְּטוּרָה מִן הַחַלָּה, לְדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים — חַיֶּיבֶת בְּחַלָּה.
human_translation: Rav Asi said: dough of second-tithe in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Meir, exempt from ḥalla in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis, obligated ḥalla
llm_translation: Rav Assi said: Dough of the second tithe, according to the words of Rabbi Meir - exempt from challah; according to the words of the Sages - obligated in challah.

hebrew_text: מַצּוֹת שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי, לְדִבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר — אֵין אָדָם יוֹצֵא בָּהּ יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּפֶּסַח, לְדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים — יוֹצֵא בָּהּ יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּפֶּסַח.
human_translation: matzot of second-tithe In accordance with the statement of Rabbi Meir, a person cannot fulfill his obligation on Passover with this In accordance with the statement of the Rabbis, one fulfill his obligation with on Passover.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Matsot shel ma'aser sheni, ledivrei Rabbi Meir - ein adam yotze bah yedei chovato bapesach, ledivrei chachamim - yotze bah yedei chovato bapesach." Translation: "The unleavened bread of the second tithe, according to the words of Rabbi Meir - a person does not fulfill his obligation with it for Passover; according to the words of the Sages - he fulfills his obligation with it for Passover."

hebrew_text: אֶתְרוֹג שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי, לְדִבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר — אֵין יוֹצֵא בּוֹ יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּיוֹם טוֹב, לְדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים — אָדָם יוֹצֵא בּוֹ יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּיוֹם טוֹב.
human_translation: a citron of second-tithe In accordance with the statement of Rabbi Meir, one cannot fulfill his obligation on festival with this In accordance with the statement of the Rabbis, a person can use this to fulfill his obligation on festival
llm_translation: Citron of second tithe, according to the words of Rabbi Meir - one does not fulfill his obligation with it on the festival day; according to the Sages - one fulfills his obligation with it on the festival day.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב פָּפָּא: בִּשְׁלָמָא עִיסָּה, דִּכְתִיב ״עֲרִיסֹתֵיכֶם״ — מִשֶּׁלָּכֶם.
human_translation: Rav Pappa strongly objects to this Granted, dough, as it is written: “your dough” from that belongs to you.
llm_translation: Rav Papa objects to her: With regard to a dough offering, for it is written "your dough" - meaning yours.

hebrew_text: אֶתְרוֹג נָמֵי, דִּכְתִיב ״וּלְקַחְתֶּם לָכֶם״, ״לָכֶם״ — מִשֶּׁלָּכֶם יְהֵא. אֶלָּא מַצָּה, מִי כְּתִיב ״מַצַּתְכֶם״?
human_translation: a citron too, as it is written: “And you shall take for yourselves “for yourselves” must belong to you. However, matza , is it written your matza ?
llm_translation: Citron is equivalent, as it is written "and you shall take for yourselves," "for yourselves" - from what is yours it shall be. Rather, matzah, who is it written "your matzot"?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא, וְאִיתֵּימָא רַב יֵימַר בַּר שֶׁלֶמְיָא: אָתְיָא ״לֶחֶם״ ״לֶחֶם״. כְּתִיב הָכָא ״לֶחֶם עֹנִי״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם ״וְהָיָה בַּאֲכׇלְכֶם מִלֶּחֶם הָאָרֶץ״. מָה לְהַלָּן — מִשֶּׁלָּכֶם, אַף כָּאן — מִשֶּׁלָּכֶם.
human_translation: Rava said, and some say Rav Yeimar bar Shelamya derived “bread” “bread.” It is written here, “Poor man’s bread” and it is written there, “And it shall be that when you eat of the bread of the land, Just as there, from that belongs to you, so too here, from that belongs to you.
llm_translation: Rava said, and some say Rav Yeimar son of Shelemya said: It comes "lechem" "lechem." It is written here "lechem oni," and it is written there "and it shall be when you eat of the bread of the land." Just as there - from yours, so too here - from yours.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ: עִיסָּה שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי פְּטוּרָה מִן הַחַלָּה, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: חַיֶּיבֶת. לֵימָא מְסַיַּיע?! הַיְינוּ הָךְ!
human_translation: Let us say supports dough of second-tithe exempt from ḥalla the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: obligated Let us say that it supports him. This is to that
llm_translation: Let us say it assists him: Dough of second tithe is exempt from hallah, the words of Rabbi Meir. And the sages say: It is obligated. Let us say it assists him?! That is it!

hebrew_text: הָכִי קָאָמַר (לֵיהּ): לֵימָא מִדִּפְלִיגִי בְּעִיסָּה, בְּהָנָךְ נָמֵי פְּלִיגִי. אוֹ דִילְמָא, שָׁאנֵי הָתָם דִּכְתִיב ״עֲרִיסֹתֵיכֶם״ ״עֲרִיסֹתֵיכֶם״ תְּרֵי זִימְנֵי.
human_translation: This is what is saying: Let us say from they disagree with regard to dough, so too, they disagree with regard to these Or perhaps it is different there, as it is written: “Your dough,” “your dough,” twice.
llm_translation: So he said to him: Let us say that they argue regarding dough, they agree regarding hanach. Or perhaps, it is different there because it is written "your kneading troughs" twice.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ: מַהוּ שֶׁיֵּצֵא אָדָם יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּחַלָּה שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם? אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי — לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, הַשְׁתָּא בְּחוּלִּין לָא נָפֵיק, בְּחַלָּתוֹ מִיבַּעְיָא?! כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish raised a dilemma: What is that a person fulfill his obligation with ḥalla second-tithe in Jerusalem? In accordance with Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, do not raise dilemma. Now cannot fulfill with non-sacred is necessary with its ḥalla ? When you raise the dilemma, in accordance with Rabbi Akiva.
llm_translation: Inquiry of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: What is the law regarding a person who puts his hands into his second tithe dough in Jerusalem? According to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei the Galilean - it should not be a concern for you, now in mundane matters it does not come out, should it come out in his dough?! When it should be a concern for you is according to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva.

hebrew_text: בְּחוּלִּין הוּא דְּנָפֵיק — דְּאִי מִיטַּמּוּ יֵשׁ לָהֶן הֶיתֵּר בְּמוֹשָׁבוֹת. אֲבָל חַלָּה, דְּאִי מִטַּמְּיָא לֵית לַהּ הֶיתֵּר בְּמוֹשָׁבוֹת, וְלִשְׂרֵיפָה אָזְלָא — לָא נָפֵיק.
human_translation: it is with non-sacred that one fulfill for if becomes ritually impure can be permitted in habitation However, ḥalla , which, if it becomes ritually impure, cannot be permitted in habitation, but goes, for burning, cannot fulfill
llm_translation: In mundane matters, it emerges — for if they become ritually impure, they have permission in their dwellings. But with regards to dough, if it becomes ritually impure, it does not have permission in their dwellings, and for burning it goes — it does not emerge.

hebrew_text: אוֹ דִילְמָא: אָמְרִינַן הוֹאִיל וְאִילּוּ לֹא קָרָא עָלֶיהָ שֵׁם וְאִיטַּמַּי — אִית לָהּ הֶיתֵּר בְּמוֹשָׁבוֹת, וְנָפֵיק בָּהּ, הַשְׁתָּא נָמֵי נָפֵיק.
human_translation: Or perhaps we say: Since, if one had not designated and it had become ritually impure, be permitted in habitation, fulfill with it, now too, fulfill with it,
llm_translation: Or perhaps: we say, since he did not recite a blessing over it and it became prohibited — it has additional leniency in its sitting, and it goes out with it, now too it goes out.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְאָמְרִי: הָא וַדַּאי לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, דְּוַדַּאי אָמְרִינַן ״הוֹאִיל״. כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ חַלָּה הַלָּקוּחַ בְּכֶסֶף מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי.
human_translation: Some say this certainly do not raise the dilemma, as we certainly Since, when you raise the dilemma, ḥalla that was purchased with second-tithe money,
llm_translation: There are those who say: "This, for sure, is not necessary for you," for sure we say "since." When it is necessary for you, a loaf that was purchased with second tithe money.

hebrew_text: וְאַלִּיבָּא דְרַבָּנַן לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, כֵּיוָן דְּאָמְרִי יִפָּדֶה — הַיְינוּ מַעֲשֵׂר. כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, דְּאָמַר — יִקָּבֵר.
human_translation: And in accordance with the Rabbis, do not raise dilemma, since they say that can be redeemed this is tithe Rather, when you raise the dilemma, in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, who said be buried.
llm_translation: And the statement of the sages does not require for you, since they said "he shall surely redeem" - that is referring to tithe. When it requires for you, in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, who said - "he shall surely bury."

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן: הַלָּקוּחַ בְּכֶסֶף מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי שֶׁנִּטְמָא — יִפָּדֶה. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: יִקָּבֵר.
human_translation: As we learned that was purchased with second-tithe money that became ritually impure, be redeemed Rabbi Yehuda says: be buried.
llm_translation: We learned in a Mishnah: If one purchased with second tithe money that became ritually impure - it must be redeemed. Rabbi Yehuda says: It should be buried.

hebrew_text: מִי אָמְרִינַן: הוֹאִיל וְאִי לָא לָקוּחַ הָוֵי, וְהוֹאִיל וְלֹא קָרָא עָלֶיהָ שֵׁם וְאִיטַּמַּי — יֵשׁ לוֹ הֶיתֵּר בְּמוֹשָׁבוֹת, וְנָפֵיק בֵּיהּ, הַשְׁתָּא נָמֵי נָפֵיק בֵּיהּ.
human_translation: Do we say Since, if it were not purchased and since, if one had not designated it and it became ritually impure, permitted in habitation, fulfill with it
llm_translation: We say: Since if it was not acquired, it is considered acquired, and since a name was not called upon it and it was sealed - he has permission in his dwelling places, and he may go out with it, now he may go out with it.

hebrew_text: אוֹ דִילְמָא: חַד ״הוֹאִיל״ אָמְרִינַן, תְּרֵי ״הוֹאִיל״ לָא אָמְרִינַן? אָמַר רָבָא: מִסְתַּבְּרָא שֵׁם מַעֲשֵׂר חַד הוּא.
human_translation: Or perhaps we say one Since, but we do not say two Since. Rava said: It stands to reason the category of tithe is a single
llm_translation: Or perhaps: One "ho'il" we say, two "ho'il" we do not say? Rava said: The name of one tithe makes sense.

hebrew_text: חַלַּת תּוֹדָה וּרְקִיקֵי נָזִיר וְכוּ׳. מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? אָמַר רַבָּה: דְּאָמַר קְרָא
human_translation: loaves of a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers From where are these matters Rabba said: As the verse states:
llm_translation: A thanksgiving offering cake and the unleavened bread of a Nazirite, etc. Whence are these matters derived? Rabah said: As the verse states:

hebrew_text: ״וּשְׁמַרְתֶּם אֶת הַמַּצּוֹת״ — מַצָּה הַמִּשְׁתַּמֶּרֶת לְשֵׁם מַצָּה. יָצְתָה זוֹ שֶׁאֵין מִשְׁתַּמֶּרֶת לְשֵׁם מַצָּה, אֶלָּא לְשׁוּם זֶבַח.
human_translation: “And you shall guard the matzot ” matza that has been guarded for the purpose matza, excludes this which was not guarded for the purpose matza but for the purpose of a sacrifice.
llm_translation: "And you shall observe the matzot" - matzah that is preserved for the sake of matzah. This one emerged that is not preserved for the sake of matzah, but for the sake of a sacrifice.

hebrew_text: רַב יוֹסֵף אָמַר, אָמַר קְרָא: ״שִׁבְעַת יָמִים מַצּוֹת תֹּאכֵלוּ״ — מַצָּה הַנֶּאֱכֶלֶת לְשִׁבְעַת יָמִים. יָצְתָה זוֹ שֶׁאֵינָהּ נֶאֱכֶלֶת לְשִׁבְעַת יָמִים, אֶלָּא לְיוֹם וָלַיְלָה.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said the verse states: “Seven days you shall eat matzot ” matza that be eaten for seven days. excludes this which cannot be eaten for seven days, but for day and night.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said, the verse says: "Seven days you shall eat matzot" - matzah that is eaten for seven days. This excludes one that is not eaten for seven days, but only for a day and a night.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַבָּה, וְתַנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵף. תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַבָּה: יָכוֹל יֵצֵא יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּחַלּוֹת תּוֹדָה וּרְקִיקֵי נָזִיר, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וּשְׁמַרְתֶּם אֶת הַמַּצּוֹת״ — מַצָּה הַמִּשְׁתַּמֶּרֶת לְשֵׁם מַצָּה. יָצְתָה זוֹ שֶׁאֵינָהּ מִשְׁתַּמֶּרֶת לְשֵׁם מַצָּה, אֶלָּא לְשׁוּם זֶבַח.
human_translation: It was taught in accordance with Rabba, and it was taught in accordance with Rav Yosef. It was taught in accordance with Rabba: might that one can fulfill his obligation with the loaves of a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers; the verse states: “And you shall guard the matzot ,” matza that has been guarded for the purpose of matza excludes this which was not guarded for the purpose matza but for the purpose of a sacrifice.
llm_translation: It was taught in the school of Rabah, and it was taught in the school of Rav Yosef. It was taught in the school of Rabah: One might have thought that he fulfills his obligation with loaves of thanksgiving and unleavened cakes of a Nazirite vow. The verse teaches us: "And you shall observe the matzot" - matzah that is preserved for the sake of matzah. If it emerged not preserved for the sake of matzah, but for the sake of a sacrifice.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵף: יָכוֹל יֵצֵא אָדָם יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּחַלּוֹת תּוֹדָה וּרְקִיקֵי נָזִיר, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״שִׁבְעַת יָמִים מַצּוֹת תֹּאכֵלוּ״ — מַצָּה הַנֶּאֱכֶלֶת לְשִׁבְעָה. יָצְתָה זוֹ שֶׁאֵינָהּ נֶאֱכֶלֶת לְשִׁבְעָה, אֶלָּא לְיוֹם וָלַיְלָה.
human_translation: It was taught in accordance with Rav Yosef: might that a person can fulfill his obligation with the loaves of a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers; the verse states: “Seven days you shall eat matzot ,” matza that be eaten for seven excludes this as it cannot be eaten for seven days but for a day and a night.
llm_translation: It was taught in the school of Rav Yosef: One might have thought that a person can fulfill his obligation with thanksgiving loaves and unleavened wafers of a Nazirite. The Torah teaches us: "Seven days you shall eat unleavened bread" - unleavened bread that is eaten for seven days. This excludes one that is not eaten for seven days, but only for a day and a night.

hebrew_text: וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ מִ״לֶּחֶם עֹנִי״ — מִי שֶׁנֶּאֱכָל בַּאֲנִינוּת. יָצָא זֶה שֶׁאֵינוֹ נֶאֱכָל בַּאֲנִינוּת, אֶלָּא בְּשִׂמְחָה!
human_translation: let him derive “bread of affliction [ leḥem oni ]” with be eaten in acute mourning. excludes this which is not eaten in acute mourning but in of joy,
llm_translation: "And it shall be given to him 'from the bread of affliction' - one who eats in poverty. This one has fulfilled his obligation even if he does not eat in poverty, but with joy!"

hebrew_text: סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, דְּאָמַר ״עָנִי״ כְּתִיב.
human_translation: maintain in accordance with Rabbi Akiva, who said oni , is written,
llm_translation: He thought to her like Rabbi Akiva, who said, "Poor" is written.

hebrew_text: וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ דְּהָוֵה לֵיהּ מַצָּה עֲשִׁירָה!
human_translation: And let him derive that it is matza ashira ,
llm_translation: And let it come out that he has rich matzah!

hebrew_text: אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר רַב יִצְחָק: רְבִיעִית הִיא, וּמִתְחַלֶּקֶת הִיא לְכַמָּה חַלּוֹת.
human_translation: Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said: is a quarter and is divided between several loaves,
llm_translation: Shmuel bar Rav Yitzchak said: It is a quarter, and it is divided into how many loaves.

hebrew_text: וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ דְּאֵינָן נֶאֱכָלוֹת בְּכׇל מוֹשָׁבוֹת!
human_translation: And let him derive that cannot be eaten in every habitation.
llm_translation: And let it come out that they are not eaten in all settlements!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: זֹאת אוֹמֶרֶת חַלּוֹת תּוֹדָה וּרְקִיקֵי נָזִיר נֶאֱכָלִין בְּנוֹב וְגִבְעוֹן.
human_translation: Reish Lakish said: That is to say, the loaves of the thanks-offering and the nazirite’s wafers be eaten in Nov and Givon.
llm_translation: Reish Lakish said: This means that the loaves of thanksgiving and the thin cakes of a Nazirite may be eaten in Nob and Gibeon.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, אָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעַאי: שָׁאַלְתִּי אֶת רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר — מַהוּ שֶׁיֵּצֵא אָדָם בְּחַלּוֹת תּוֹדָה וּרְקִיקֵי נָזִיר? אָמַר לִי: לֹא שָׁמַעְתִּי. בָּאתִי וְשָׁאַלְתִּי לִפְנֵי רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ, אָמַר לִי: הֲרֵי אָמְרוּ, חַלּוֹת תּוֹדָה וּרְקִיקֵי נָזִיר שֶׁעֲשָׂאָן לְעַצְמוֹ — אֵין אָדָם יוֹצֵא בָּהֶן, לִמְכּוֹר בַּשּׁוּק — יוֹצֵא בָּהֶן.
human_translation: It was taught Rabbi Ilai said: I asked Rabbi Eliezer What is that a person fulfill with the loaves of a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers? He said to me: I did not hear I went and asked Rabbi Yehoshua, said to me: They said, loaves for a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers that prepared for his own a person cannot fulfill his obligation with them. to sell in the market, he fulfill with them.
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Ilai said: I asked Rabbi Eliezer, "What is the law regarding a person who goes out on loaves of thanksgiving and unleavened cakes of a Nazirite?" He said to me, "I have not heard." I came and asked before Rabbi Yehoshua, and he said to me, "Behold, it was stated: Loaves of thanksgiving and unleavened cakes of a Nazirite that one made for himself - a person does not fulfill his obligation with them; however, if he wishes to sell them in the market, he may fulfill his obligation with them."

hebrew_text: כְּשֶׁבָּאתִי וְהִרְצֵיתִי דְּבָרִים לִפְנֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, אָמַר לִי: בְּרִית! הֵן הֵן הַדְּבָרִים שֶׁנֶּאֶמְרוּ לוֹ לְמֹשֶׁה בְּסִינַי. אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי: בְּרִית, הֵן הֵן הַדְּבָרִים שֶׁנֶּאֶמְרוּ לוֹ לְמֹשֶׁה בְּסִינַי? וְלָא טַעְמָא בָּעֲיָא?!
human_translation: When I returned and recited matters to Rabbi Eliezer, he said to me covenant, these are the matters that were stated to Moses on Mount Sinai. Some say covenant! these the matters that were stated to Moses on Mount Sinai? And doesn’t require a reason?
llm_translation: When I came and wanted to say words before Rabbi Eliezer, he said to me: "Covenant! These are the words that were said to Moses at Sinai." Is there anyone who says: "Covenant! These are the words that were said to Moses at Sinai?" And does he not require a reason?!

hebrew_text: וְטַעְמָא מַאי? אָמַר רַבָּה: כֹּל לַשּׁוּק אִימְּלוֹכֵי מִימְּלֵךְ. אָמַר: אִי מִזְדַּבַּן — מִזְדַּבַּן, אִי לָא מִזְדַּבַּן — אִיפּוֹק בְּהוּ אֲנָא.
human_translation: And what is the reason Rabba said: anything in the market, change his mind He say: If it is sold, it is sold; if it is not sold I will fulfill with it.
llm_translation: The reason what? Said Rabah: All to the market go from the king. He said: If they are friendly — they are friendly, if not — I will go with them.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ וְאֵלּוּ יְרָקוֹת שֶׁאָדָם יוֹצֵא בָּהֶן יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּפֶּסַח: בַּחֲזֶרֶת, בְּתַמְכָא, וּבְחַרְחֲבִינָא וּבְעוּלְשִׁין וּבְמָרוֹר. יוֹצְאִין בָּהֶן בֵּין לַחִין בֵּין יְבֵשִׁין, אֲבָל לֹא כְּבוּשִׁין וְלֹא שְׁלוּקִין וְלֹא מְבוּשָּׁלִין.
human_translation: And these are the vegetables with which a person fulfill his obligation on Passover: with ḥazeret , with chervil [ tamkha ], and with field eryngo [ ḥarḥavina ], and with endives [ olashin ], and with maror . One fulfills obligation with them whether fresh whether dry. However, not pickled nor over-boiled [ shaluk ] nor they are boiled [ mevushal ].
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: And with these vegetables, a person fulfills his obligation on Passover: with lettuce, endive, wild lettuce, and horseradish. One may eat them whether moist or dry, but not cooked, nor pickled, nor boiled.

hebrew_text: וּמִצְטָרְפִין לִכְזַיִת, וְיוֹצְאִין בַּקֶּלַח שֶׁלָּהֶן. וּבִדְמַאי, וּבְמַעֲשֵׂר רִאשׁוֹן שֶׁנִּטְּלָה תְּרוּמָתוֹ, וּמַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי וְהֶקְדֵּשׁ שֶׁנִּפְדּוּ.
human_translation: And join together to an olive-bulk, And one fulfills their stalk, And with doubtfully tithed with first-tithe whose teruma has been taken and second-tithe and consecrated property that were redeemed.
llm_translation: And they combine for the olive's measure, and they go out with their peel. And with demai, and with the first tithe that its terumah was taken, and the second tithe and consecrated items that were redeemed.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ חֲזֶרֶת — חַסָּא. עוּלְשִׁין — הִינְדְּבִי. תַּמְכָא, אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה: תְּמַכְתָּא שְׁמָהּ. חַרְחֲבִינָא, אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ: אַצְווֹתָא דְּדִיקְלָא. וּבְמָרוֹר — מְרִירָתָא.
human_translation: Ḥazeret lettuce. Olashin hindevi . tamkha , Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: It is called temakhta ḥarḥavina , Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: that around the palm tree. And with maror . merirata .
llm_translation: Gemar chazeret - chasa. Ulshin - hindbi. Tamkha, amar Rabba bar bar Ḥana: Temakhta shemah. Ḥarchavina, amar Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: Atzvota de'dikla. Uv'maror - merirata.

hebrew_text: תָּנֵי בַּר קַפָּרָא, אֵלּוּ יְרָקוֹת שֶׁאָדָם יוֹצֵא בָּהֶן יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּפֶּסַח: בְּעוּלְשִׁין, וּבְתַמְכָא, בְּחַרְחֲלִין, בְּחַרְחֲבִינִין, וּבְחִזְרִין. רַב יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אַף עוּלְשֵׁי שָׂדֶה וְעוּלְשֵׁי גִינָּה וַחֲזֶרֶת.
human_translation: Bar Kappara teaches: These are the vegetables with which a person fulfill his obligation on Passover: With endives, chervil, ḥarḥallin , field eryngo, and ḥazeret . Rav Yehuda says: Also wild endives, garden endives, and ḥazeret .
llm_translation: Bar Kappara taught: These are the vegetables with which one fulfills his obligation on Passover: beet leaves, Egyptian beans, wild lettuce, wild endive, and lettuce. Rav Yehudah says: Also field beet leaves, garden beet leaves, and horseradish.

hebrew_text: עוּלְשֵׁי גִינָּה וַחֲזֶרֶת? הָא תְּנָא לַהּ רֵישָׁא! הָכִי קָאָמַר: אַף עוּלְשֵׁי שָׂדֶה כְּעוּלְשֵׁי גִינָּה וַחֲזֶרֶת. רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: אַף עַסְווֹס וְטוּרָא וּמָר יְרוֹאָר. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: עַסְווֹס וְטוּרָא אֶחָד הוּא. וּמָר — זֶה הוּא יְרוֹאָר.
human_translation: garden endives and ḥazeret ? These were taught in the first clause. this is is saying: Even wild endives are garden endives and ḥazeret Rabbi Meir says: asvas , and tura , and sweet myrrh [ mar yero’ar ] also Rabbi Yosei said to him: Asvas and tura one and mar is yero’ar .
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Oulshei ginah vachazeret? Ha tana lah reishah! Hachi ka'amar: Af oulshei sadeh keoulshei ginah vachazeret. Rabbi Meir omer: Af asvos vetura umar yeruar. Amar lei Rabbi Yosei: Asvos vetura echad hu. Umar - zeh hu yeruar." English translation: "Those who are negligent in the matter of a garden and a vegetable patch? This was taught at the beginning! This is what he is saying: Even those negligent in a field are like those negligent in a garden and a vegetable patch. Rabbi Meir says: Even a horse, a mule, and a donkey. Rabbi Yosei said to him: A horse and a mule are one. And a donkey - this is a donkey."

hebrew_text: תָּנֵי דְּבֵי (רַבִּי) שְׁמוּאֵל: אֵלּוּ יְרָקוֹת שֶׁאָדָם יוֹצֵא בָּהֶן יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּפֶּסַח: בַּחֲזֶרֶת, בְּעוּלְשִׁין, וּבְתַמְכָא, וּבְחַרְבִּינִין, וּבְחַרְגִּינִין, וּבְהִרְדּוּפְנִין. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אַף חֲזֶרֶת יוּלִין וַחֲזֶרֶת גַּלִּין כַּיּוֹצֵא בָּהֶן.
human_translation: the school of Rabbi Samuel teaches: These are the vegetables with which a person fulfill his obligation on Passover: With ḥazeret , endives, chervil, field eryngo, ḥarginnin , and hardofannin . Rabbi Yehuda says: also ḥazeret yolin and ḥazeret gallin , similar to
llm_translation: The schools of Rabbi Shmuel taught: These are the vegetables with which one fulfills his obligation on Passover: lettuce, endive, tamarisk, beet leaves, wild lettuce, and dandelion. Rabbi Yehuda says: Even lettuce that is tender and lettuce that is tough are included in them.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אִילְעָא אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: אַף עַרְקַבָּלִים, וְחָזַרְתִּי עַל כׇּל תַּלְמִידָיו וּבִקַּשְׁתִּי לִי חָבֵר, וְלֹא מָצָאתִי. וּכְשֶׁבָּאתִי לִפְנֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב, הוֹדָה לִדְבָרַי.
human_translation: Rabbi Ile’a said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: also arkablim . And I went around all of students looking for a colleague but I did not find But when I came before Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, he conceded to my statement.
llm_translation: Rabbi Ilai says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: Even the Arakbalim, and I reviewed all his students and sought a companion for myself, but did not find. And when I came before Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov, he acknowledged my words.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ שָׂרָף. רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן בְּרוֹקָה אוֹמֵר: כֹּל שֶׁפָּנָיו מַכְסִיפִין. אֲחֵרִים אוֹמְרִים: [כׇּל] יָרָק מַר יֵשׁ לוֹ שָׂרָף וּפָנָיו מַכְסִיפִין. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מִדִּבְרֵי כּוּלָּן נִלְמַד, יָרָק מַר יֵשׁ לוֹ שָׂרָף וּפָנָיו מַכְסִיפִין. אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: הֲלָכָה כַּאֲחֵרִים.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: Any that has sap Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says: Anything whose surface is light Aḥerim say: Any bitter herb has sap and whose surface is light Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From the statements of all these we can learn a bitter green herb has sap and its surface is light Rav Huna said: The halakha is in accordance with Aḥerim .
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehudah says: anyone who has a saraf. Rabbi Yochanan ben Beroka says: anyone whose face turns pale. Others say: any bitter vegetable has a saraf and his face turns pale. Rabbi Yochanan said: from all their words we learn, a bitter vegetable has a saraf and his face turns pale. Rav Huna said: the halakha is like the others.

hebrew_text: רָבִינָא אַשְׁכְּחֵיהּ לְרַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרָבָא דַּהֲוָה מְהַדַּר אַמְּרִירָתָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מַאי דַּעְתָּיךְ, דִּמְרִירִין טְפֵי? וְהָא חֲזֶרֶת תְּנַן. וְתַנָּא דְּבֵי שְׁמוּאֵל: חֲזֶרֶת, וְאָמַר רַבִּי אוֹשַׁעְיָא: מִצְוָה בַּחֲזֶרֶת. וְאָמַר רָבָא: מַאי חֲזֶרֶת — חַסָּא.
human_translation: Ravina found Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, searching for merirata He said to him: What is your opinion, that is most bitter, but we learned ḥazeret And the school of Shmuel taught ḥazeret And Rabbi Oshaya said: mitzva ḥazeret , and Rava said: What is ḥazeret ? lettuce [ ḥassa ].
llm_translation: Rabinah found Rav Acha, son of Rava, who was arranging the Ammirata. He said to him: What is your opinion, that we make the wine sour? But didn't we learn: And it was taught in the school of Shmuel: souring, and Rabbi Oshaya said: it is a mitzvah to sour. And Rava said: What is souring? - vinegar.

hebrew_text: מַאי חַסָּא — דְּחַס רַחֲמָנָא עִילָּוַון. וְאָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: לָמָּה נִמְשְׁלוּ מִצְרִיִּים כְּמָרוֹר? לוֹמַר לָךְ: מָה מָרוֹר זֶה שֶׁתְּחִילָּתוֹ רַךְ וְסוֹפוֹ קָשֶׁה — אַף מִצְרִיִּים תְּחִילָּתָן רַכָּה וְסוֹפָן קָשָׁה. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הֲדַרִי בִּי.
human_translation: What is lettuce [ ḥassa ]? that God has mercy [ ḥas ] on us. And Rabbi Samuel bar Naḥmani said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Why are the Egyptians likened to bitter herbs to tell you just as these bitter herbs are soft at first and harsh in the end, so too, the Egyptians were soft at first, but were harsh in the end, ḥazeret , said to I retract
llm_translation: What is "Hasa"? - that the Merciful One has compassion on high. And Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said in the name of Rabbi Yonatan: Why were the Egyptians compared to bitter herbs? To tell you: Just as this bitter herb, its beginning is soft and its end is hard - so too, the beginning of the Egyptians was soft and their end was hard. He said to him: Recant.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב רְחוּמִי לְאַבָּיֵי: מִמַּאי דְּהַאי מָרוֹר מִין יָרָק הוּא? אֵימָא מְרִירָתָא דְכוּפְיָא? דּוּמְיָא דְּמַצָּה: מָה מַצָּה גִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע — אַף מָרוֹר גִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע. וְאֵימָא הִירְדּוּף? דּוּמְיָא דְּמַצָּה: מָה מַצָּה מִין זְרָעִים — אַף מָרוֹר מִין זְרָעִים.
human_translation: Rav Reḥumi said to Abaye: From where that this bitter herb is a type of vegetable? say the bile of a kufya similar to matza ; just as matza that grows from the ground, so too, bitter herbs that grows from the ground. oleander similar to matza ; just as matza a type of plant, so too, bitter herbs a type of plant
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Rechumi to Abbaye: From what is this bitter herb? Say, is it the bitterness of cudweed? Resembles matzah: Just as matzah is grown from the ground — so too, bitter herb is grown from the ground. And say, is it lettuce? Resembles matzah: Just as matzah is from seeds — so too, bitter herb is from seeds.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא הַרְזִיפוּ! דּוּמְיָא דְּמַצָּה: מָה מַצָּה שֶׁנִּיקַּחַת בְּכֶסֶף מַעֲשֵׂר — אַף מָרוֹר שֶׁנִּיקָּח בְּכֶסֶף מַעֲשֵׂר.
human_translation: say harzipu , similar to matza ; just as matza that can be purchased with tithe money, so too, bitter herbs that can be purchased with tithe money.
llm_translation: And why not "harzifu"! Resembles matzah: Just as matzah that is acquired with silver of tithe — so too maror that is acquired with silver of tithe.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבָּה בַּר רַב חָנִין לְאַבָּיֵי: אֵימָא מָרוֹר חַד! ״מְרוֹרִים״ כְּתִיב. וְאֵימָא ״מְרוֹרִים״ תְּרֵי! דּוּמְיָא דְּמַצָּה: מָה מַצָּה מִינִין הַרְבֵּה — אַף מָרוֹר מִינִין הַרְבֵּה.
human_translation: Rabba bar Rav Ḥanin said to Abaye: say that bitter herb one it is written: “Bitter herbs” But say that “bitter herbs” two similar to matza ; just as matza many types so too, bitter herbs many types
llm_translation: He said to him, Rabba bar Rav Huna said to Abbaye: Let's say one bitter herb! "Bitter herbs" is written. And let's say two bitter herbs! Similar to matzah: Just as we count many matzot - so too, we count many bitter herbs.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר רַב הוּנָא אָמַר רַב: יְרָקוֹת שֶׁאָמְרוּ חֲכָמִים שֶׁאָדָם יוֹצֵא בָּהֶן יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּפֶּסַח, כּוּלָּן נִזְרָעִין בַּעֲרוּגָה אַחַת. לְמֵימְרָא דְּלֵית בְּהוּ מִשּׁוּם כִּלְאַיִם?
human_translation: Rabba bar Rav Huna said Rav said: vegetables that the Sages said a person can fulfill with them his obligation on Passover, they all be planted in one bed. That is to say that diverse kinds does not apply to them?
llm_translation: Rabba bar Rav Huna said in the name of Rav: Vegetables that the Sages said one fulfills his obligation with them on Passover, all of them are sown in one furrow. Is it to say that there is no issue of kilayim?

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רָבָא: חֲזֶרֶת וַחֲזֶרֶת גַּלִּין, עוּלְשִׁין וְעוּלְשֵׁי שָׂדֶה, כְּרֵישִׁין וּכְרֵישֵׁי שָׂדֶה, כּוּסְבָּר וְכוּסְבַּר שָׂדֶה, חַרְדָּל וְחַרְדָּל מִצְרִי, וְדַלַּעַת הַמִּצְרִי וְהָרְמוּצָה — אֵינָם כִּלְאַיִם זֶה בָּזֶה. חֲזֶרֶת וַחֲזֶרֶת גַּלִּין — אִין, חֲזֶרֶת וְעוּלְשִׁין — לֹא!
human_translation: Rava raised an objection Ḥazeret and ḥazeret gallin ; endive and wild endive; leek and wild leek; coriander and wild coriander; mustard and Egyptian mustard; and Egyptian gourd and harmutza , are not diverse kinds together. ḥazeret and ḥazeret gallin , yes, ḥazeret and endives, no,
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: "Chazeret and chazeret galin, ulshin and ulshei sadeh, kreishin and kreishei sadeh, kusbar and kusbar sadeh, chardal and chardal mitzri, and dalaat hamitzri and haramutzah - they are not considered kilayim with each other. Chazeret and chazeret galin - no, chazeret and ulshin - no!"

hebrew_text: וְכִי תֵּימָא כּוּלְּהוּ בַּהֲדָדֵי קָתָנֵי לְהוּ. וְהָא אָמַר רַב: זוּגוֹת זוּגוֹת קָתָנֵי!
human_translation: And lest you say that all are taught together, but didn’t Rav say were taught in pairs,
llm_translation: And if you say, all of them are taught in the name of Hadadei. But Rav said: It is taught in pairs, in pairs!

hebrew_text: מַאי נִזְרָעִין דְּאָמַר רַב — נִזְרָעִין כְּהִלְכָתָן. כְּהִלְכָתָן? תְּנֵינָא:
human_translation: What planted, which Rav said? be properly planted. properly, we learned
llm_translation: What are the seeds that Rav said - seeds according to their law. According to their law? We learned:

hebrew_text: עֲרוּגָה שֶׁהִיא שִׁשָּׁה עַל שִׁשָּׁה טְפָחִים — זוֹרְעִין בְּתוֹכָהּ חֲמִשָּׁה זֵרְעוֹנִין, אַרְבַּע — עַל אַרְבַּע רוּחוֹת הָעֲרוּגָה, וְאַחַת בָּאֶמְצַע. מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: הָנֵי מִילֵּי בִּזְרָעִין, אֲבָל בִּירָקוֹת — לָא, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: bed that is six by six handbreadths one plant in it five seeds, four on the four sides of the bed and one in the middle. Lest you say that applies only to seeds, but with regard to vegetables, no, teaches us
llm_translation: A raised bed that is six by six handbreadths - within it one sows five seeds, four - on the four sides of the raised bed, and one in the middle. What might you say: those matters are with seeds, but with vegetables - no, it is clear to us.

hebrew_text: לְמֵימְרָא דִּירָקוֹת אַלִּימָא מִזְּרָעִים? וְהָתְנַן: כׇּל מִינֵי זְרָעִים אֵין זוֹרְעִין בַּעֲרוּגָה אַחַת, כׇּל מִינֵי יְרָקוֹת זוֹרְעִין בַּעֲרוּגָה אַחַת! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא הָנֵי מָרוֹר מִין זְרָעִים נִינְהוּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Is that to say that vegetables are stronger than seeds? But didn’t we learn multiple types of seeds, one not plant in one bed, however, multiple types of vegetables, one plant in one bed? Lest you say these bitter herbs are a type of seed, teaches us
llm_translation: In the matter of planting seeds, perhaps one should include seeds of vegetables? And we learned in a Mishnah: "All types of seeds are not planted in one furrow, but all types of vegetables are planted in one furrow!" Lest you say that those bitter herbs are considered seeds, it is evident to us.

hebrew_text: זְרָעִים סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ? וְהָא תְּנַן — יְרָקוֹת, וְתָנֵי בַּר קַפָּרָא — יְרָקוֹת, וְתָנֵי דְּבֵי שְׁמוּאֵל — יְרָקוֹת! חֲזֶרֶת אִיצְטְרִיכָא לֵיהּ. סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וְסוֹפָהּ לְהַקְשׁוֹת — נִיתֵּיב לַהּ רַוְוחָא טְפֵי.
human_translation: Could it enter your mind seeds? But didn’t we learn vegetables And bar Kappara taught: Vegetables. And the school of Shmuel taught: Vegetables. necessary for ḥazeret . It could enter your mind to say since ultimately hardens one give it more space
llm_translation: Seeds, has it entered your mind? But we learned - vegetables, and Bar Kappara teaches - vegetables, and the School of Shmuel teaches - vegetables! A contradiction arises for him. Has it entered your mind, I say: Since its end is to harden - a little space is left for it.

hebrew_text: לָאו אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא, קֶלַח שֶׁל כְּרוּב שֶׁהוּקְשָׁה מַרְחִיבִין לוֹ בֵּית רוֹבַע! אַלְמָא: כֵּיוָן דְּסוֹפוֹ לְהַקְשׁוֹת יָהֲבִינַן לֵיהּ רַוְוחָא טְפֵי, הָכָא נָמֵי נִיתֵּיב לַהּ רַוְוחָא טְפֵי, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Didn’t Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, say: a stalk of cabbage that has hardened, one allow a beit rova for it, Apparently, since it will ultimately harden, one give it more space. Here too, one give it more space. teaches us
llm_translation: The text reads: "Did not Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina, say: The leaf of the cherub, when it becomes hard, we widen for it a quarter cubit! This implies: Since its end is destined to become hard, we give it extra space. Here too, we provide it with extra space, and this is what we have learned."

hebrew_text: יוֹצְאִין בָּהֶן בֵּין לַחִין בֵּין יְבֵשִׁין כּוּ׳. אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא בַּקֶּלַח, אֲבָל בֶּעָלִין, לַחִין — אִין, יְבֵשִׁין — לָא.
human_translation: fulfill obligation with whether fresh whether dried. Rav Ḥisda said: They taught only to the stem. However, to the leaves, moist, yes, dry, no,
llm_translation: Out with them, whether moist or dry. Rav Ḥisdah said: They only taught this with regard to vegetables, but with regard to fruits, moist—yes, dry—no.

hebrew_text: וְהָא מִדְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא ״בַּקֶּלַח שֶׁלָּהֶן״, מִכְלָל דְּרֵישָׁא עָלִין? פָּרוֹשֵׁי קָא מְפָרֵשׁ: כִּי קָתָנֵי בֵּין לַחִין בֵּין יְבֵשִׁין — אַקֶּלַח.
human_translation: But from that it is taught the last clause In their stems, be inferred that the first clause leaves. is explaining When taught whether fresh whether dried, to the stem,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And this is learned in the latter part, "in their basket," does it imply that they ascend from the earlier part? The commentators explain: for it is taught whether moist or dry - a basket.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: יוֹצְאִין בָּהֶן וּבַקֶּלַח שֶׁלָּהֶן, בֵּין לַחִין בֵּין יְבֵשִׁין, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: לַחִין — יוֹצְאִין בָּהֶן, יְבֵשִׁין — אֵין יוֹצְאִין בָּהֶן. וְשָׁוִין שֶׁיּוֹצְאִין בָּהֶן כְּמוּשִׁין. אֲבָל לֹא כְּבוּשִׁין וְלֹא שְׁלוּקִין וְלֹא מְבוּשָּׁלִין.
human_translation: raises an objection fulfill with or with their stems, whether fresh whether dried; the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: fresh fulfill with them; dry cannot fulfill with them. And everyone agrees that fulfill with them withered However, neither pickled, nor over-boiled, nor boiled.
llm_translation: The Tanna raises an objection: One may go out with them and with their lids, whether they are moist or dry - these are the words of Rabbi Meir. But the Sages say: If they are moist, one may go out with them; if they are dry, one may not go out with them. And it is equal whether they are moist or dry. However, not if they are soaked, nor squeezed, nor pickled.

hebrew_text: כְּלָלוֹ שֶׁל דָּבָר: כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ טַעַם מָרוֹר — יוֹצְאִין בּוֹ, וְכֹל שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ טַעַם מָרוֹר — אֵין יוֹצְאִין בּוֹ. תַּרְגּוּמָא אַקֶּלַח. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵין יוֹצְאִין בָּהֶן כְּמוּשִׁין. מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בְּרַבִּי צָדוֹק אָמְרוּ: יוֹצְאִין בָּהֶן כְּמוּשִׁין.
human_translation: The principle is: Anything that has the taste of bitter herbs, fulfill with it; but anything that does not have the taste of bitter herbs, one cannot fulfill with it. Interpret to the stem The Sages taught: cannot fulfill with them withered. They said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok: fulfill with them withered.
llm_translation: The general principle: anything that has a bitter taste - one may fulfill their obligation with it, and anything that does not have a bitter taste - one may not fulfill their obligation with it. The translation is "akelach." The Rabbis taught: one may not fulfill their obligation with them like with water. In the name of Rabbi Eliezer son of Rabbi Zadok, they said: one may fulfill their obligation with them like with water.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: מַהוּ שֶׁיֵּצֵא אָדָם יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּמָרוֹר שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם? אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ: הַשְׁתָּא בְּמַצָּה דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא נָפֵיק, בְּמָרוֹר דְּרַבָּנַן מִיבַּעְיָא?
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama raised a dilemma: What is that a person fulfill his obligation with bitter herbs of second-tithe in Jerusalem? In accordance with Rabbi Akiva, do not raise this dilemma. Now of matza , by Torah fulfill obligation is necessary bitter herbs, which by rabbinic
llm_translation: Ba'ei Ramei bar Ḥama inquired: What is the law regarding a person who fulfills his obligation with the bitterness of the second tithe in Jerusalem? According to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, it should not be asked of you: Now, with regard to matzah, which is from the Torah, it is required to be eaten with maror, which is from the Rabbis?

hebrew_text: כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי, מַאי? בְּמַצָּה דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא הוּא דְּלָא נָפֵיק, אֲבָל מָרוֹר דְּרַבָּנַן נָפֵיק?
human_translation: When you raise the dilemma, in accordance with Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, What is it is with regard to matza by Torah not fulfill however, bitter herbs, by rabbinic w, fulfill
llm_translation: When you ask about the opinion of Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, what is it? It is regarding the biblical matzah that does not come out, but the maror of the Rabbis does come out?

hebrew_text: אוֹ דִילְמָא: כׇּל דְּתַקִּינוּ רַבָּנַן — כְּעֵין דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא תַּקּוּן. אָמַר רָבָא: מִסְתַּבְּרָא מַצָּה וּמָרוֹר.
human_translation: Or perhaps, everything that the Sages instituted, they instituted similar by Torah Rava said: It stands to reason matza and bitter herbs,
llm_translation: Perhaps: all that the Rabbis established - is like a decree of the Torah. Rava said: It makes sense for matzah and maror.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֵין שׁוֹרִין אֶת הַמּוּרְסָן לְתַרְנְגוֹלִים, אֲבָל חוֹלְטִין. הָאִשָּׁה לֹא תִּשְׁרֶה אֶת הַמּוּרְסָן שֶׁתּוֹלִיךְ בְּיָדָהּ לַמֶּרְחָץ, אֲבָל שָׁפָה הִיא בִּבְשָׂרָהּ יָבֵשׁ. לֹא יִלְעוֹס אָדָם חִיטִּין וְיַנִּיחַ עַל מַכָּתוֹ, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהֵן מַחְמִיצוֹת.
human_translation: One not soak coarse bran for chickens, However, one pour boiling water A woman not soak coarse bran to bring by hand to the bathhouse however, she rub on her dry skin. A person not chew wheat and place it on his wound, due to that will be leavened
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One may not feed the bran to chickens, but one may sift it. A woman should not remove the bran that is in her hand to the bathroom, but she may rub it on her dry skin. A person should not soak wheat and place it on his wound, because they cause fermentation.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵלּוּ דְּבָרִים שֶׁאֵין בָּאִין לִידֵי חִימּוּץ: הָאָפוּי, וְהַמְבוּשָּׁל, וְחָלוּט שֶׁחֲלָטוֹ בְּרוֹתְחִין. מְבוּשָּׁל? אַדִּמְבַשֵּׁל לֵיהּ, מַחְמַע! אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: הָאָפוּי שֶׁבִּישְּׁלוֹ קָאָמַר.
human_translation: The Sages taught: The following do not come to leavening: baked, or boiled, or over-boiled in hot water. boiled When it is boiled it will become leavened. Rav Pappa said: said it was baked and boiled,
llm_translation: The Sages taught: These are the things that do not lead to souring: the raw, the cooked, and the pickled that were pickled in hot water. Cooked? Until it is cooked, it spoils! Rav Papa said: It is the raw that was cooked that he is referring to.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: קֶמַח שֶׁנָּפַל לְתוֹכוֹ דֶּלֶף, אֲפִילּוּ כׇּל הַיּוֹם כּוּלּוֹ — אֵינוֹ בָּא לִידֵי חִימּוּץ, אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: וְהוּא דְּעָבֵיד טִיף לַהֲדֵי טִיף.
human_translation: It was taught Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: flour into which dripping, even the entire day will not come to leavening, Rav Pappa said: And that is if one drop drips into the other,
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: If flour that had water seep into it, even if the entire day has passed - it does not become susceptible to leavening. Rav Papa said: This is when he is kneading drop by drop.

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי דְּבֵי רַבִּי שֵׁילָא: וָתִיקָא שְׁרֵי. וְהָתַנְיָא וָתִיקָא אָסוּר?! לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — דְּעַבְדֵיהּ בְּמִישְׁחָא וּמִילְחָא, הָא — דְּעַבְדֵיהּ בְּמַיָּא וּמִילְחָא.
human_translation: The school of Rabbi Sheila say: Vatika , permitted But wasn’t it taught vatika is forbidden? not difficult. This in which it was prepared with oil and salt, that prepared with water and salt,
llm_translation: The House of Rabbi Sheilah said: "Vatika is permitted." But it was taught: "Vatika is forbidden?!" It is not difficult: this one - who does it with oil and salt, and this one - who does it with water and salt.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר זוּטְרָא: לָא לִימַחֵי אִינִישׁ קִדְרָא בְּקִמְחָא דַאֲבִישֻׁנָא, דִּילְמָא לָא בְּשִׁיל שַׁפִּיר, וְאָתֵי לִידֵי חִימּוּץ. אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: לָא לִיחְלוֹט אִינִישׁ
human_translation: Mar Zutra said: A person should not line of a pot with roasted flour, lest was not properly roasted and it will come to leavening Rav Yosef said: A person should not scald
llm_translation: Master Zutra said: A person should not knead a pot of flour with vinegar, lest it not be good for baking, and it leads to spoilage. Rav Yosef said: A person should not soak dough in vinegar.

hebrew_text: תְּרֵי חִיטֵּי בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי, דִּילְמָא אָזְלָא חֲדָא וְיָתְבָה בְּצִירְיָא דַחֲבֶרְתַּהּ, וְלָא סָלֵיק לְהוּ דִּיקּוּלָא דְמַיָּא מֵאַרְבַּע רוּחָתָא, וְאָתֵי לִידֵי חִימּוּץ.
human_translation: two wheat grains in boiling water lest one move and rest in the slit [ tzirya ] of the other, preventing the column [ dikkula ] of water from entering four sides and will come to leavening.
llm_translation: Two wheat grains in the courtyard of Hadadei, perhaps one went and settled in the storehouse of his friend, and did not reach the threshing floor of water from the four winds, and it came to be through rotting.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לָא לִיחְרוֹךְ אִינִישׁ תְּרֵי שֻׁבְלֵי בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי, דִּילְמָא נָפְקִי מַיָּא מֵהַאי וּבָלַע אִידַּךְ, וְאָתְיָא לִידֵי חִימּוּץ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: אִי הָכִי, אֲפִילּוּ חֲדָא נָמֵי, דִּילְמָא נָפֵיק מֵהַאי רֵישָׁא וּבָלַע אִידַּךְ רֵישָׁא! אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: מֵי פֵירוֹת נִינְהוּ, וּמֵי פֵירוֹת אֵינָן מַחְמִיצִין.
human_translation: And Abaye said: A person not roast two stalks together, lest water leave one and be absorbed by the other, and it come to leavened. Rava said to him: If so, even one lest the leave one end and be absorbed by other end. Rather, Rava said: it is fruit juice, and fruit juice does not leaven
llm_translation: And Abaye said: A person should not mix two bundles together with each other, lest water come out of this one and be absorbed by the other, leading to fermentation. Rava said to him: If so, even if one bundle alone, lest water come out of the first bundle and be absorbed by the other bundle! Rather, Rava said: They are considered fruit juices, and fruit juices do not ferment.

hebrew_text: וַהֲדַר בֵּיהּ אַבָּיֵי מֵהַהִיא, דְּכׇל אַגַּב מֵדָלַיְיהוּ לָא מַחְמְצִי. דְּאָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הַאי חַצְבָּא דַאֲבִישֻׁנָא, סְחִיפָא — שְׁרֵי, זְקִיפָא — אָסוּר. רָבָא אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ זְקִיפָא — נָמֵי שְׁרֵי, מֵי פֵירוֹת נִינְהוּ, וּמֵי פֵירוֹת אֵינָן מַחְמִיצִין.
human_translation: And Abaye retracted that that anything that is absorbing not become leavened As Abaye said: this jug used for roasting, inverted it is permitted, upright it is prohibited, Rava said: Even upright, it is also permitted. This is fruit juice, and fruit juice does not leaven
llm_translation: And afterwards Abaye from that said, for all that is above them is not leavened. For Abaye said: This jug of vinegar, if it is tilted - it is permitted, if it is upright - it is forbidden. Rava said: Even if it is upright, it is still permitted, for they are considered fruit juice, and fruit juice does not leaven.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵין לוֹתְתִין שְׂעוֹרִין בַּפֶּסַח. וְאִם לָתַת, נִתְבַּקְּעוּ — אֲסוּרוֹת, לֹא נִתְבַּקְּעוּ — מוּתָּרוֹת.
human_translation: The Sages taught: One not soak barley on Passover And if one did soak it split, it is prohibited. it did not split, it is permitted.
llm_translation: The sages taught: One may not use barley for the Passover offering. And if one did use it, if they burst open - they are forbidden; if they did not burst open - they are permitted.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: שׁוֹרָן בְּחוֹמֶץ, וְחוֹמֶץ צוֹמְתָן. אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: אֵין הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי.
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei says: he soak it in vinegar, and vinegar will cause to contract, Shmuel said: The halakha in not in accordance with Rabbi Yosei.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei says: "A bull in vinegar, and vinegar in their nostrils." Shmuel said: The halakha is not like Rabbi Yosei.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר מָר עוּקְבָא: לֹא נִתְבַּקְּעוּ מַמָּשׁ, אֶלָּא כׇּל שֶׁאִילּוּ מַנִּיחָן עַל פִּי חָבִית וְהֵן נִתְבַּקְּעוֹת מֵאֵילֵיהֶן, וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: נִתְבַּקְּעוּ מַמָּשׁ. עֲבַד שְׁמוּאֵל עוֹבָדָא בְּדוּרָא דְּבֵי בַּר חָשׁוּ נִתְבַּקְּעוּ מַמָּשׁ.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said Mar Ukva said: not it actually split Rather, if were placed on a barrel they split by themselves, And Shmuel said: it actually split. Shmuel took action in the village of bar Ḥashu’s house. actually split,
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisdah said in the name of Mar Ukva: They did not actually split, rather, as long as one places them on the mouth of a barrel and they split from their own weight. And Samuel said: They actually split. Samuel performed an action in the village of Bar Ḥashu, and they actually split.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה: בַּעַל נֶפֶשׁ לֹא יִלְתּוֹת. מַאי אִירְיָא בַּעַל נֶפֶשׁ? אֲפִילּוּ כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא נָמֵי, דְּהָא תַּנְיָא: אֵין לוֹתְתִין שְׂעוֹרִין בַּפֶּסַח! הָכִי קָאָמַר: בַּעַל נֶפֶשׁ — אֲפִילּוּ חִיטִּין דִּשְׁרִירִי לֹא יִלְתּוֹת.
human_translation: Rabba said: A pious person will not soak Why particularly a pious person? everyone as well, as it was taught One not soak barley on Passover. this is is saying: A pious person not even soak wheat, which is firmer
llm_translation: Rabba said: A Baal Nefesh should not delay. What is meant by a Baal Nefesh? Even all the people in the world agree, as it is taught: Do not delay the barley offerings on Passover! This is what he is saying: A Baal Nefesh - even the finest wheat should not delay.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב נַחְמָן: מַאן דְּצָיֵית לֵיהּ לְאַבָּא — אָכֵיל נַהֲמָא דְעִיפּוּשָׁא. דְּהָא בֵּי רַב הוּנָא לָתְתִי, וּבֵי רָבָא בַּר אָבִין לָתְתִי. וְרָבָא אָמַר: אָסוּר לִלְתּוֹת.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman said to Anyone who listens to Abba, will eat moldy bread As in Rav Huna’s house they would soak and in Rava bar Avin’s house they would soak But Rava said: prohibited to soak
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Nachman: Whoever desires to anger his father - let him eat the fat of the tail. For in the house of Rav Huna they would give it, and in the house of Rava bar Avin they would give it. And Rava said: It is forbidden to eat.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הָא דְּתַנְיָא: אֵין לוֹתְתִין שְׂעוֹרִין בַּפֶּסַח. שְׂעוֹרִין הוּא דְּלָא, הָא חִיטֵּי — שְׁרֵי. לָא מִיבַּעְיָא קָאָמַר. לָא מִיבַּעְיָא חִיטִּין, כֵּיוָן דְּאִית בֵּיהּ צִירְיָא — עָיְילִי בְּהוּ מַיָּא, אֲבָל שְׂעָרֵי דְּשִׁיעִי — אֵימָא שַׁפִּיר דָּמֵי, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Rather, that which is taught One not soak barley on Passover, it is barley that not permitted wheat, speaking Needless to say. Needless to say, wheat since have a slit through which water will enter, However, barley, which is smooth say seems well, teaches us
llm_translation: Rather, this that was taught: One may not use barley for the Passover. Barley, that is not permissible, but wheat — is permitted. He is not stating a difficulty. He is not stating a difficulty regarding wheat, since it contains gluten — it absorbs water, but barley of the sixth year — one might say it resembles wheat, it is clear to us.

hebrew_text: הֲדַר אָמַר רָבָא: מוּתָּר לִלְתּוֹת. דְּתַנְיָא: יוֹצְאִין בְּפַת נְקִיָּה וְהַדְרָאָה, וְאִי אֶפְשָׁר נְקִיָּה בְּלֹא לְתִיתָה.
human_translation: Rava then said: it is permitted to soak as it was taught One fulfill with loaf refined and with coarse And it is impossible refined without soaking
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: Rava said: It is permitted to plaster. As it was taught: They go out with clean plaster and with rough plaster, and it is impossible for it to be clean without plaster.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רַב פָּפָּא לְרָבָא: הַקְּמָחִין וְהַסְּלָתוֹת שֶׁל גּוֹיִם, שֶׁל כְּפָרִים — טְהוֹרִים, וְשֶׁל כְּרַכִּין — טְמֵאִין.
human_translation: Rav Pappa raised an objection to Rava flour and refined flour to gentiles, in villages are ritually pure, and in cities are ritually impure.
llm_translation: He raised an objection to him, Rav Papa to Rava: The flour and the loaves of non-Jews, of villages - pure, and of cities - impure.

hebrew_text: דִּכְפָרִים מַאי טַעְמָא? לָאו מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא לָתְתִי, וְקָא קָרֵי לֵיהּ סוֹלֶת!
human_translation: in villages, what is the reason not due to that they do not soak And is called refined flour.
llm_translation: "Dikfarim, what is the reason? Not because it is not given, and it is called 'flour'!"

hebrew_text: תַּרְגּוּמָא אַקִּמְחָא. בָּתַר דְּנָפֵיק אָמַר: מַאי טַעְמָא לָא אֵימָא לֵיהּ מֵהָא דְּאָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא אָמַר רַב יִרְמְיָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: חִיטִּין שֶׁל מְנָחוֹת אֵין לוֹתְתִין אוֹתָם, וְקָא קָרֵי לְהוּ סוֹלֶת.
human_translation: interpret to flour, After left, said: What is the reason he did not say from this that Rabbi Zeira said Rav Yirmeya said Shmuel said: wheat for meal-offerings, one not soak it, is called refined flour?
llm_translation: "I will establish a translation." After he left, he said: What is the reason that I should not say to him from what Rabbi Zeira said in the name of Rav Yirmeya said in the name of Shmuel: The wheat of meal-offerings, one does not offer them, yet it is called fine flour."

hebrew_text: הֲדַר אָמַר רָבָא: מִצְוָה לִלְתּוֹת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״וּשְׁמַרְתֶּם אֶת הַמַּצּוֹת״ — אִי לָא דְּבָעֵי לְתִיתָה שִׁימּוּר לְמַאי? אִי שִׁימּוּר דְּלִישָׁה — שִׁימּוּר דְּלִישָׁה לָאו שִׁימּוּר הוּא.
human_translation: Rava then said: a mitzva to soak as it is stated: “And you shall guard the matzot ” If not that requires soaking, for what guarding If guarding when kneading, guarding while kneading is not guarding.
llm_translation: Rava said: It is a commandment to roast, as it is stated, "And you shall observe the matzot" - if not for roasting, what is the observance for? If the observance is not for roasting, is it not an observance?

hebrew_text: דְּאָמַר רַב הוּנָא: בְּצֵקוֹת שֶׁל גּוֹיִם — אָדָם מְמַלֵּא כְּרֵיסוֹ מֵהֶן, וּבִלְבַד שֶׁיֹּאכַל כְּזַיִת מַצָּה בָּאַחֲרוֹנָה. בָּאַחֲרוֹנָה — אִין, בָּרִאשׁוֹנָה — לָא,
human_translation: As Rav Huna said: dough by gentiles, a person fill his stomach with them provided that he eats an olive-bulk of matza in the end, in the end, yes, in the beginning, no,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rabbi Huna said: In the dough of gentiles — a person may fill his basket from them, but only eat a olive-sized piece of matzah at the end. At the end — no, at the beginning — yes.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא? מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא עֲבַד בְּהוּ שִׁימּוּר. וְלַעְבֵּיד לֵיהּ שִׁימּוּר מֵאֲפִיָּה וְאֵילָךְ! אֶלָּא לָאו שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ, שִׁימּוּר מֵעִיקָּרָא בָּעֵינַן.
human_translation: What is the reason because did not perform guard But one perform guard it from baking and onward. Rather, isn’t it conclude from that must from the beginning,
llm_translation: What is the reason? Because he did not perform proper guarding. And to perform guarding from now on! Rather, we do not rely on it, we require guarding from the outset.

hebrew_text: ומִמַּאי? דִּילְמָא שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דִּבְעִידָּנָא דְּנָחֵית לְשִׁימּוּר — לָא עָבֵד לַהּ שִׁימּוּר. אֲבָל הֵיכָא דִּבְעִידָּנָא דְּנָחֵית לְשִׁימּוּר — עָבֵיד לַהּ שִׁימּוּר, הָכִי נָמֵי דְּשִׁימּוּר דְּלִישָׁה הָוֵי שִׁימּוּר.
human_translation: And from where Perhaps it is different there, as at the time when guarding is required, he did not perform guard it However, where at the time when guarding is required, he performed guard it, so too, guarding of kneading is guarding.
llm_translation: From what? Perhaps it is different there, for in the case where I am coming to preserve — I do not do the preserving. But here, in the case where I am coming to preserve — I do the preserving, for so too, preservation of something that is not yet in existence is considered preservation.

hebrew_text: וַאֲפִילּוּ הָכִי לָא הֲדַר בֵּיהּ רָבָא. דְּאָמַר לְהוּ לְהָנְהוּ דִּמְהַפְּכִי כֵּיפֵי: כִּי מְהַפְּכִיתוּ — הַפִּיכוּ לְשׁוּם מִצְוָה, אַלְמָא קָסָבַר: שִׁימּוּר מֵעִיקָּרָא מִתְּחִלָּתוֹ וְעַד סוֹפוֹ בָּעֵינַן.
human_translation: And although Rava did not retract For he say to those who cut the stalks [ kifei ] When you cut cut it for the purpose of the mitzva. Apparently, maintains it is necessary to guard from the outset, from the beginning until its end.
llm_translation: And even so, Rava did not retract. For he said to them who were turning over the baskets: "When you turn it over, turn it over for the sake of a commandment." This implies that he holds: We require guarding from the outset, from the beginning until the end.

hebrew_text: מָר בְּרֵיהּ דְּרָבִינָא
human_translation: Mar, son of Ravina,
llm_translation: Master, son of Ravina

hebrew_text: מְנַקְּטָא לֵיהּ אִימֵּיהּ בְּאַרְבֵי.
human_translation: his mother bring him in a trough.
llm_translation: He is repulsed by his mother on account of the locust.

hebrew_text: הָהוּא אַרְבָּא דְחִיטֵּי דִּטְבַעָא בְּחִישְׁתָּא, שַׁרְיָא רָבָא לְזַבּוֹנֵי לְגוֹיִם.
human_translation: a certain boat wheat, which capsized in Ḥishta Rava permitted to sell to gentiles
llm_translation: That certain individual, the fourth one of wheat who sank in the river on Friday, it is permitted for merchants to sell it to non-Jews.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רַבָּה בַּר לֵיוַאי לְרָבָא: בֶּגֶד שֶׁאָבַד בּוֹ כִּלְאַיִם — הֲרֵי זֶה לֹא יִמְכְּרֶנּוּ לְגוֹי, וְלֹא יַעֲשֶׂה בּוֹ מַרְדַּעַת לַחֲמוֹר. אֲבָל עוֹשִׂין אוֹתוֹ תַּכְרִיכִין לְמֵת.
human_translation: Rabba bar Levai raised an objection to Rava a garment in which diverse kinds, has been lost, one not sell it to a gentile; and one not fashion it a saddlecloth for a donkey. However, one fashion it a shroud for a dead body,
llm_translation: He raised an objection to Rava: A garment in which the fringes have been lost - this one may not sell to a non-Jew, and may not make from it a saddlecloth for a donkey. But they make it into shrouds for the dead.

hebrew_text: לְגוֹי מַאי טַעְמָא לָא — לָאו מִשּׁוּם דַּהֲדַר מְזַבֵּין לְיִשְׂרָאֵל?
human_translation: What is the reason not to a gentile? not due to that will resell it to a Jew?
llm_translation: Regarding a non-Jew, what is the reason for not accepting their offering? — Not because we are concerned that they will later offer it to a Jew?

hebrew_text: הֲדַר אָמַר רָבָא: לְזַבִּינְהוּ קַבָּא קַבָּא לְיִשְׂרָאֵל, כִּי הֵיכִי דְּכָלְיָא קַמֵּי פִּיסְחָא.
human_translation: Rava then said: He should sell one kav at a time, to Jew, so that will be used before Passover.
llm_translation: Rava said: "They should sell the produce in large quantities to the Jewish people, so that all the vessels will be in front of the Passover."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵין מוֹלְלִין אֶת הַקְּדֵירָה בַּפֶּסַח. וְהָרוֹצֶה שֶׁיִּמְלוֹל — נוֹתֵן אֶת הַקֶּמַח וְאַחַר כָּךְ נוֹתֵן אֶת הַחוֹמֶץ. וְיֵשׁ אוֹמְרִים: אַף נוֹתֵן אֶת הַחוֹמֶץ וְאַחַר כָּךְ נוֹתֵן אֶת הַקֶּמַח.
human_translation: The Sages taught: One not stir a pot on Passover And one who wishes to stir add the flour and afterward add vinegar, And some say: even add vinegar and afterward add the flour,
llm_translation: The Sages taught: One does not mix the pot on Passover. And one who wishes to mix it - he places the flour and afterwards places the vinegar. And some say: Even place the vinegar and afterwards place the flour.

hebrew_text: מַאן יֵשׁ אוֹמְרִים?
human_translation: Who some say?
llm_translation: Who says?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, דִּתְנַן: הָאִילְפָּס וְהַקְּדֵירָה שֶׁהֶעֱבִירָן מְרוּתָּחִין — לֹא יִתֵּן לְתוֹכָן תַּבְלִין, אֲבָל נוֹתֵן לְתוֹךְ הַקְּעָרָה אוֹ לְתוֹךְ הַתַּמְחוּי. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: לַכֹּל הוּא נוֹתֵן, חוּץ מִדָּבָר שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ חוֹמֶץ וָצִיר.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: It is Rabbi Yehuda, as we learned a stew pot or a pot that one removed seething, not add spices to them on Shabbat. However, one add to a dish or to plate Rabbi Yehuda says: One add to any except to that contains vinegar or brine,
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: It is Rabbi Yehuda, as we learned in a Mishnah: If one removed a dish or a pot that had been cooked in from the fire, one may not place spices into them, but one may place them into a bowl or into a mortar. Rabbi Yehuda says: One may place them into anything except for something that contains vinegar or brine.

hebrew_text: וְנוֹקְמַהּ כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי, (דִּתְנַן) רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: שׁוֹרָן בְּחוֹמֶץ, וְחוֹמֶץ צוֹמְתָן!
human_translation: And let us establish in accordance with Rabbi Yosei. As we learned Rabbi Yosei says, One soak them in vinegar, and vinegar will cause to contract
llm_translation: "And vengeance like Rabbi Yosei, as we learned: Rabbi Yosei says: 'Barley in vinegar, and vinegar seals them!'"

hebrew_text: כִּי אַשְׁמְעִינַן לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי, הָנֵי מִילֵּי דְּאִיתֵיהּ בְּעֵינֵיהּ, אֲבָל עַל יְדֵי תַּעֲרוֹבֶת — לָא.
human_translation: When we learn Rabbi Yosei, applies where in its pure, However, by means of a mixture, no,
llm_translation: We will ask it to Rabbi Yosei, these matters that are in his eyes, but through a mixture - no.

hebrew_text: עוּלָּא אָמַר: אֶחָד זֶה וְאֶחָד זֶה — אָסוּר, מִשּׁוּם: ״לֵךְ לֵךְ אָמְרִינַן נְזִירָא, סְחוֹר סְחוֹר, לְכַרְמָא לָא תִּקְרַב״.
human_translation: Ulla said: both these prohibited, as per Go around, go around, do not approach the vineyard, they say to the nazirite.
llm_translation: Oula said: One this and one this - forbidden, because of: "Go, go, we say to the Nazirite, measure, measure, do not approach the vineyard."

hebrew_text: רַב פַּפִּי שָׁרֵי לֵיהּ לְבוּרְדִּיקִי דְּבֵי רֵישׁ גָּלוּתָא לְמִמְחֵה קְדֵירָה בַּחֲסִיסֵי. אָמַר רָבָא: אִיכָּא דְּשָׁרֵי כִּי הַאי מִילְּתָא בְּדוּכְתָּא דִּשְׁכִיחִי עָבְדִי? אִיכָּא דְאָמְרִי: רָבָא גּוּפָא מָחֵי לֵהּ קִידְרָא בַּחֲסִיסֵי.
human_translation: Rav Pappi permitted the cooks [ burdikei ] of the household of the Exilarch to mash roasted grains into a pot Rava said: Is there who permits this matter in a place where servants are found? Some say Rava himself add roasted grains into pot.
llm_translation: Rav Pappi permits him to the burdiki of the house of Reish Galuta to wipe the pot with the cabbage. Rava said: Is there anyone who permits this matter in a place where it is common to do so? There are those who say: Rava himself wipes the pot with the cabbage.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֵין נוֹתְנִין קֶמַח לְתוֹךְ חֲרוֹסֶת אוֹ לְתוֹךְ הַחַרְדָּל. וְאִם נָתַן — יֵאָכֵל מִיָּד, וְרַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: One not add flour to ḥaroset , or to mustard, And if one added be eaten immediately and Rabbi Meir prohibits
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One may not place flour into a dish of vinegar or into mustard. And if one did so, it may be eaten immediately. Rabbi Meir prohibits it.

hebrew_text: אֵין מְבַשְּׁלִין אֶת הַפֶּסַח לֹא בְּמַשְׁקִין וְלֹא בְּמֵי פֵירוֹת, אֲבָל סָכִין וּמַטְבִּילִין אוֹתוֹ בָּהֶן.
human_translation: One not boil the Paschal in liquids or in fruit juices, However, baste and dip it into
llm_translation: We do not cook the Passover offering neither with liquids nor with fruit juices, but we may roast it and immerse it in them.

hebrew_text: מֵי תַשְׁמִישׁוֹ שֶׁל נַחְתּוֹם — יִשָּׁפְכוּ, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהֵן מַחְמִיצִין.
human_translation: Water that has been used by a baker be poured out, because leavens
llm_translation: The waters of his intercourse - they shall be poured out, because they are caustic.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא: מַחֲלוֹקֶת לְתוֹךְ הַחַרְדָּל, אֲבָל לְתוֹךְ חֲרוֹסֶת — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל יִשָּׂרֵף מִיָּד.
human_translation: Rav Kahana said: dispute to mustard, But to ḥaroset , everyone agrees be burned immediately.
llm_translation: Gemara said Rav Kahana: Dispute into the mustard, but into the clay — words of all will be burned immediately.

hebrew_text: וְתַנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: אֵין נוֹתְנִין קֶמַח לְתוֹךְ הַחֲרוֹסֶת, וְאִם נָתַן — יִשָּׂרֵף מִיָּד. לְתוֹךְ הַחַרְדָּל, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: יִשָּׂרֵף מִיָּד, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: יֵאָכֵל מִיָּד. אָמַר רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: הֲלָכָה כְּדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק לְרַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יְהוּדָה:
human_translation: And that was also taught One not add flour to ḥaroset , and if one did add be burned immediately. to mustard, Rabbi Meir says: be burned immediately, and the Rabbis say: be eaten immediately, Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehuda, said Rav Naḥman said Shmuel said: The halakha is in accordance with the Rabbis Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehuda:
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it was taught in a Baraita similarly: One may not place flour into a clay oven, and if one did so - it shall be immediately burned. Into mustard, Rabbi Meir says: it shall be immediately burned, and the Sages say: it may be eaten immediately. Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehuda, said that Rav Nachman said in the name of Shmuel: the halakha is according to the words of the Sages. Rav Nachman, son of Yitzchak, said to Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehuda:

hebrew_text: אַחֲרוֹסֶת קָאָמַר מָר, אוֹ אַחַרְדָּל קָאָמַר מָר? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ?
human_translation: the Master say with regard to ḥaroset , or did the Master say with regard to mustard? He said to him: What is practical difference
llm_translation: The Master said: Is it "Acharoset" or "Achardal" that the Master said? He said to him: For what purpose does it come out of it?

hebrew_text: לִדְרַב כָּהֲנָא. דְּאָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא: מַחֲלוֹקֶת לְתוֹךְ הַחַרְדָּל, אֲבָל לְתוֹךְ הַחֲרוֹסֶת — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל יִשָּׂרֵף מִיָּד.
human_translation: to that Rav Kahana, as Rav Kahana said: dispute to mustard. However, to ḥaroset , everyone agrees it be burned immediately.
llm_translation: Regarding Rav Kahana. For Rav Kahana said: A dispute within the mustard, but within the clay pot - everyone agrees it shall be immediately burned.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא שְׁמִיעַ לִי, כְּלוֹמַר לָא סְבִירָא לִי.
human_translation: He said to him: I did not hear that is to say, I do not hold
llm_translation: He said to him: "It does not seem to me," meaning, "I do not agree."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַב כָּהֲנָא מִסְתַּבְּרָא, מִדְּאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: אֵין הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי. מַאי לָאו? צַמּוֹתֵי הוּא דְּלָא צָמֵית, הָא חַמּוֹעֵי מְחַמְּעָא.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: It is reasonable in accordance with Rav Kahana, from that Shmuel said the halakha is not in accordance with Rabbi Yosei, What, isn’t it does not shrink even leaven
llm_translation: Rav Ashe said: The measurements of Rav Kahana are logical, as Samuel said: The halakha is not like Rabbi Yosei. What is the reason? It is because he did not fast, for fasting weakens the mind.

hebrew_text: לָא, דִּילְמָא לָא מִצְמָת צָמֵית, וְלָא חַמּוֹעֵי מְחַמַּע.
human_translation: No, perhaps neither cause to shrink nor leaven
llm_translation: Not, perhaps not from fasting you fast, and not from heating you heat.

hebrew_text: אֵין מְבַשְּׁלִין וְכוּ׳. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״בְּמַיִם״ — אֵין לִי אֶלָּא בְּמַיִם, שְׁאָר מַשְׁקִין מִנַּיִין?
human_translation: one not boil The Sages taught: “In water”; I have nothing other in water. From where other liquids?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Ein mevashlin v'chul." Tanu Rabanan: "B'mayim" - ein li ela b'mayim, she'ar mashkin minayin? English translation: "One does not cook, etc." The Rabbis taught: "With water" - I only have with water, how do we know about other liquids?

hebrew_text: אָמַרְתָּ, קַל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה מַיִם שֶׁאֵין מְפִיגִין טַעְמָן — אֲסוּרִין, שְׁאָר מַשְׁקִין שֶׁמְּפִיגִין טַעְמָן — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן!
human_translation: You said an a fortiori inference: And just as water, which does not temper the taste prohibited other liquids, which do temper the taste not all the more so
llm_translation: You said, a fortiori: And just as water that does not change its taste is forbidden, other beverages that do change their taste — certainly not!

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: ״בְּמַיִם״ — אֵין לִי אֶלָּא מַיִם, שְׁאָר מַשְׁקִין מִנַּיִין? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וּבָשֵׁל מְבֻשָּׁל״, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: Rabbi says: “In water,” I have nothing other in water. From where other liquids? The verse states: “Nor boiled in any way,” In any case,
llm_translation: Rabbi says: "In water" — I have only water, from where do I derive other beverages? The Torah teaches: "And in a cooked dish" - in any case.

hebrew_text: מַאי בֵּינַיְיהוּ? אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ צְלִי קֵדָר.
human_translation: What is between between them is that is roasted in a pot
llm_translation: What is the difference between them? There is a difference between them like the roasting of a pot.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן, הַאי ״בָּשֵׁל מְבֻשָּׁל״ מַאי עָבְדִי לְהוּ? מִבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְתַנְיָא: בִּשְּׁלוֹ וְאַחַר כָּךְ צְלָאוֹ, אוֹ שֶׁצְּלָאוֹ וְאַחַר כָּךְ בִּשְּׁלוֹ — חַיָּיב.
human_translation: And the Rabbis, that “boiled in any way,” what do they do with it? required for that which was taught one boiled and afterward roasted it, or roasted it and afterward boiled it, he is liable
llm_translation: The sages, this "cooked from being cooked," what do they do with it? They want to establish it according to the teaching: whether he cooked it and then roasted it, or he roasted it and then cooked it - he is liable.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא בִּשְּׁלוֹ וְאַחַר כָּךְ צְלָאוֹ חַיָּיב, דְּהָא בַּשְּׁלֵיהּ. אֶלָּא צְלָאוֹ וְאַחַר כָּךְ בִּשְּׁלוֹ, הָא צְלִי אֵשׁ הוּא, אַמַּאי?
human_translation: Granted, boiled and afterward roasted it, he is liable, as he boiled it However, he roasted it and afterward boiled it, it is roasted by fire, why
llm_translation: In peace, in his boiling, and afterwards he roasted it - liable, for it was in its boiling. Rather, he roasted it and afterwards he boiled it - this is roasted by fire, why?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא: הָא מַנִּי — רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא: יוֹצְאִין בְּרָקִיק הַשָּׁרוּי וּבִמְבוּשָּׁל שֶׁלֹּא נִימּוֹחַ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: יוֹצְאִין בְּרָקִיק הַשָּׁרוּי, אֲבָל לֹא בִּמְבוּשָּׁל, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא נִימּוֹחַ.
human_translation: Rav Kahana said: whose is this Rabbi Yosei, As it was taught fulfill with a wafer that has been soaked or with a boiled that has not dissolved; the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei says: One fulfill with a wafer that has been soaked but not with a boiled even if it has not dissolved.
llm_translation: Rav Kahana said: This is the teaching - it is Rabbi Yosei. As it was taught: One may go out on Shabbat with a baked loaf that is well-baked and with a cooked dish that has not been fully cooked, according to the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei says: One may go out with a baked loaf that is well-baked, but not with a cooked dish, even though it has not been fully cooked.

hebrew_text: עוּלָּא אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבִּי מֵאִיר, שָׁאנֵי הָכָא דְּאָמַר קְרָא: ״וּבָשֵׁל מְבֻשָּׁל״, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
