llm_translation: Rava said: The case of the burnt offering of a leper is different, as the Merciful One said:

hebrew_text: ״וְהֶעֱלָה הַכֹּהֵן אֶת הָעוֹלָה״ — שֶׁהֶעֱלָהּ כְּבָר.
human_translation: “And the priest shall offer the burnt-offering” that has already been offered.
llm_translation: "And the priest shall offer the burnt offering" - that he offered it already.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב שֶׁמֶן בַּר אַבָּא לְרַב פָּפָּא: לְדִידָךְ, דְּאָמְרַתְּ מַעֲלֶהָ וּמְלִינָהּ בְּרֹאשׁוֹ שֶׁל מִזְבֵּחַ, קַיָּימִין וְעָבְדִינַן מִילְּתָא לְכֹהֲנִים דְּאָתוּ בַּהּ לִידֵי תַקָּלָה, דְּסָבְרִי דְּיוֹמֵיהּ הוּא וְאָתוּ לְאַקְטוֹרֵי! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: כֹּהֲנִים זְרִיזִין הֵן.
human_translation: Rav Shemen bar Abba said to Rav Pappa: According to your that you said he brings them up and leaves them overnight at the top of the altar, do we stand and perform an action for the priests whereby they may come to a mishap. As they think that that day, and they may burn them He said to him: Priests are vigilant
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Shemen bar Abba said to Rav Papa: According to your opinion, that you said to bring it up and smear it on the top of the altar, we establish and we do the matter for the priests, that they should not come to a stumbling block, for they think that it is his day and they come to the incense. He said to him: The priests are diligent.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב אָשֵׁי לְרַב כָּהֲנָא, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב נָתָן לְרַב פָּפָּא: וְהָא כַּמָּה דְּלָא מִתְקַטְּרִי אֵמוּרִין כֹּהֲנִים לָא מָצוּ אָכְלִי בָּשָׂר, דְּתַנְיָא: יָכוֹל יְהוּ כֹּהֲנִים רַשָּׁאִין בְּחָזֶה וָשׁוֹק קוֹדֶם הַקְטָרַת אֵמוּרִין, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהִקְטִיר הַכֹּהֵן אֶת הַחֵלֶב הַמִּזְבֵּחָה״, וַהֲדַר: ״וְהָיָה הֶחָזֶה לְאַהֲרֹן וּלְבָנָיו״.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana, and some say it Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, to Rav Pappa: But, isn’t as long as the sacrificial parts have not been burned the priests may not eat the meat? As it was taught might that the priests would be permitted the breast and thigh, prior to burning the sacrificial parts Therefore, the verse states: “And the priest shall burn the fat upon the altar, and then: “The breast shall be for Aaron and his sons.
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Ashi to Rav Kahana, and some say Rav Huna son of Rav Natan to Rav Papa: And how much more so when they do not offer incense, the Kohanim are not permitted to eat meat, as it was taught: The Kohanim are permitted to eat the chest and the thigh before the offering of incense, as it is taught: "And the Kohen shall burn the fat upon the altar," and afterwards: "And the breast shall be for Aharon and his sons."

hebrew_text: וְכַמָּה דְּכֹהֲנִים לָא אָכְלִי בָּשָׂר בְּעָלִים לָא מִתְכַּפְּרִי, דְּתַנְיָא: ״וְאָכְלוּ אוֹתָם אֲשֶׁר כֻּפַּר בָּהֶם״, מְלַמֵּד שֶׁהַכֹּהֲנִים אוֹכְלִים וּבְעָלִים מִתְכַּפְּרִין!
human_translation: And, as long as the priests have not eaten the meat the owners have not achieved atonement, as it was taught “And they shall eat those things with which atonement was made teaches that the priests eat, and the owners achieve atonement.
llm_translation: And as many as priests not ate meat owners not atoned, as it was taught: "And they shall eat them by which atonement was made for them," teaching that the priests eat and the owners atone!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: כֵּיוָן דְּלָא אֶפְשָׁר — עֲשָׁאוּם כְּמִי שֶׁנִּטְמְאוּ אוֹ שֶׁאָבְדוּ. דְּתַנְיָא: יָכוֹל נִטְמְאוּ אֵמוּרִין אוֹ שֶׁאָבְדוּ לֹא יְהוּ כֹּהֲנִים זַכָּאִין בְּחָזֶה וָשׁוֹק — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהָיָה הֶחָזֶה לְאַהֲרֹן וּלְבָנָיו״, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: He said to him: Since it is impossible they rendered as ones that became ritually impure or were lost. As it was taught might if the sacrificial parts became ritually impure or were lost, the priests would not be entitled to the breast and thigh, the verse states: “And the breast shall be for Aaron and his sons” in any event
llm_translation: He said to him: Since it is not possible - they made them like those who became impure or were lost. As it was taught: If they became impure or were lost, the priests who are fit for the breast and the thigh should not be. The Talmud teaches: "And the breast shall be for Aaron and his sons," in any case.

hebrew_text: רַב כָּהֲנָא רָמֵי: כְּתִיב ״לֹא יָלִין חֵלֶב חַגִּי עַד בֹּקֶר״ — עַד בּוֹקֶר הוּא דְּלָא יָלִין, הָא כׇּל הַלַּיְלָה כּוּלָּהּ יָלִין. וּכְתִיב: ״וְהִקְטִיר עָלֶיהָ חֶלְבֵי הַשְּׁלָמִים״ — עָלֶיהָ הַשְׁלֵם כׇּל הַקָּרְבָּנוֹת כּוּלָּן!
human_translation: Rav Kahana raised a contradiction: It is written “Neither may the fat of My festive-offering remain overnight until morning” that may not remain overnight into the morning but it may remain all through the night. it is written: “And he shall burn upon it the fat of the peace-offerings” Upon it you shall complete all the offerings,
llm_translation: Rav Kahana raises an objection: It is written, "The fat of my feast shall not remain until morning" (Exodus 23:18) — until morning it shall not remain, but the entire night it shall remain. And it is written, "And he shall offer upon it all the fat of the offering made by fire" (Leviticus 3:5) — upon it he shall offer all the sacrifices!

hebrew_text: הוּא מוֹתֵיב לַהּ וְהוּא מְפָרֵק לַהּ, כְּשֶׁנִּתּוֹתְרוּ.
human_translation: raised the objection and he resolved it: were left over
llm_translation: He is asking her and he is answering her, when they were left alone.

hebrew_text: רָמֵי לֵיהּ רַב סָפְרָא לְרַב: כְּתִיב ״לֹא יָלִין לַבֹּקֶר זֶבַח חַג הַפָּסַח״ — לַבֹּקֶר הוּא דְּלֹא יָלִין, הָא כׇּל הַלַּיְלָה יָלִין. וְהָכְתִיב: ״עוֹלַת שַׁבָּת בְּשַׁבַּתּוֹ״ — וְלֹא עוֹלַת חוֹל בְּשַׁבָּת, וְלֹא עוֹלַת חוֹל בְּיוֹם טוֹב!
human_translation: Rav Safra raised a contradiction before Rav: it is written: “Neither shall the sacrifice of the feast of Passover be left over until morning” it may not remain overnight into the morning but it may remain all through the night. However, it is written: “The burnt-offering of each Shabbat on its own Shabbat the burnt-offering of a weekday is not offered on Shabbat, and the burnt-offering of a weekday is not offered on a Festival.
llm_translation: Rav Safra said to Rav: It is written, "It shall not remain until the morning, the Passover sacrifice" — it is the morning that it shall not remain, but all night it shall remain. And it is written, "The burnt offering of Shabbat on its Shabbat" — not the burnt offering of a weekday on Shabbat, and not the burnt offering of a weekday on a festival!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: כְּבָר רַמְיַיהּ נִיהֲלֵיהּ רַב אַבָּא בַּר חִיָּיא לְרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ, וְשַׁנִּי לֵיהּ: הָכָא בְּאַרְבָּעָה עָשָׂר שֶׁחָל לִהְיוֹת בְּשַׁבָּת עָסְקִינַן, דְּחֶלְבֵי שַׁבָּת קְרֵיבִין בְּיוֹם טוֹב.
human_translation: said to him: Rav Abba bar Ḥiyya already raised contradiction before Rabbi Abbahu, and he answered him: Here, we are dealing with the fourteenth occurs on Shabbat, as the fats of a Shabbat may be sacrificed on a Festival.
llm_translation: He said to him: Already he hinted to him, Rav Abba bar Chiya said to Rabbi Avahu, and he repeated to him: Here with fourteen people we are dealing with a case that falls on Shabbat, for the fats of Shabbat are offered on a festival day.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִשּׁוּם דְּחֶלְבֵי שַׁבָּת קְרֵיבִין בְּיוֹם טוֹב, אֲנַן נֵיקוּ וְנֵימָא לֵיהּ דְּהַאי קְרָא בְּאַרְבָּעָה עָשָׂר שֶׁחָל לִהְיוֹת בְּשַׁבָּת הוּא דִּכְתִיב? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: שִׁבְקֵיהּ לִקְרָא, דְּהוּא דָּחֵיק וּמוֹקֵים אַנַּפְשֵׁיהּ.
human_translation: He said to him: Because the fats of Shabbat may be sacrificed on a Festival, shall we arise and say that this verse is written with regard to the fourteenth that occurs on Shabbat, He said to him: Leave this verse alone, since it compels itself to be established
llm_translation: He said to him: Because of the fats of Shabbat, we bring offerings on Yom Tov, we should be clean and say to him that this verse, which falls on the fourteenth, is written for Shabbat? He said to him: Leave it to the verse, for it is pressed and establishes itself.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַפָּסַח שֶׁשְּׁחָטוֹ שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ, וְקִבֵּל וְהִלֵּךְ וְזָרַק שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ, אוֹ לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ, אוֹ שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ וְלִשְׁמוֹ — פָּסוּל.
human_translation: The Paschal lamb that slaughtered not for its purpose, received carried sprinkled not for the purpose or for its purpose and not for its purpose; or not for its purpose and for its purpose; disqualified.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: The Paschal lamb that one slaughtered not for its sake, and he received it and walked and threw it not for its sake, or for its sake and not for its sake, or not for its sake and for its sake — it is invalid.

hebrew_text: כֵּיצַד לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ? לְשֵׁם פֶּסַח וּלְשֵׁם שְׁלָמִים. שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ וְלִשְׁמוֹ — לְשֵׁם שְׁלָמִים וּלְשֵׁם פֶּסַח.
human_translation: How for its purpose and not for its purpose? for the purpose of the Paschal lamb and for the purpose of a peace-offering. not for its purpose and for its purpose? for the purpose of a peace-offering and for the purpose of a Paschal lamb.
llm_translation: How so for its name and not for its name? For the sake of Pesach and for the sake of Shelamim. Not for its name and for its name - for the sake of Shelamim and for the sake of Pesach.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ בָּעֵי רַב פָּפָּא: בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת תְּנַן, אוֹ בִּשְׁתֵּי עֲבוֹדוֹת תְּנַן?
human_translation: Rav Pappa raised a dilemma: Did we learn one rite, Or, did we learn two rites,
llm_translation: Gemara: Rav Papa asked: In the case of a single service, do we teach it, or in the case of two services do we teach it?

hebrew_text: בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת תְּנַן וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא, דְּאָמַר: אַף בִּגְמַר דְּבָרָיו אָדָם נִתְפָּס.
human_translation: we learn with regard to one rite, is Rabbi Yosei, who said that a person is held even for the conclusion of his statement?
llm_translation: In the service, we learned one thing, and Rabbi Yosei said: Even in the completion of his words, a person is apprehended.

hebrew_text: דְּאִי רַבִּי מֵאִיר — הָא אָמַר: תְּפוֹס לָשׁוֹן רִאשׁוֹן,
human_translation: For if Rabbi Meir, he said: Hold the first expression,
llm_translation: If Rabbi Meir - this said: grasp the first language,

hebrew_text: אוֹ דִילְמָא בִּשְׁתֵּי עֲבוֹדוֹת תְּנַן, וַאֲפִילּוּ לְרַבִּי מֵאִיר דְּאָמַר תְּפוֹס לָשׁוֹן רִאשׁוֹן — הָנֵי מִילֵּי בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת, אֲבָל בִּשְׁתֵּי עֲבוֹדוֹת — מוֹדֶה דְּמִיפְּסִיל.
human_translation: Or perhaps teach two rites. even Rabbi Meir, who said hold the first expression, this applies in one rite, but in two rites he concedes that it disqualifies.
llm_translation: Or perhaps we can learn that we were taught regarding two types of labor, and even according to Rabbi Meir who says "hold onto the first language" - those matters are in one type of labor, but in two types of labor - he concedes that it is disqualified.

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: אַהֵיָיא? אִי נֵימָא אַשֶּׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ וְלִשְׁמוֹ, בֵּין בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת בֵּין בִּשְׁתֵּי עֲבוֹדוֹת, בֵּין לְרַבִּי מֵאִיר בֵּין לְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי — אִיפְּסִיל לֵיהּ מִקַּמָּיְיתָא, דְּהָא לְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי נָמֵי, אַף בִּגְמַר דְּבָרָיו אָדָם נִתְפָּס אִית לֵיהּ. אֶלָּא: אַלִּשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ — מַאי?
human_translation: They said: To which does this If we say for a different purpose and for its own purpose, whether during one rite or during two rites, whether according to Rabbi Meir or according to Rabbi Yosei, is disqualified from the first as also Rabbi Yosei holds that a person is held accountable even for the conclusion of his statement. Rather, for its own purpose and for a different purpose; what
llm_translation: They said: Is it Ahaiya? If you say that it is not for his name and for his name, whether in one service or in two services, whether for Rabbi Meir or for Rabbi Yosei - it disqualifies him from his position, for even for Rabbi Yosei also, even in the finality of his words, a person can find fault with him. Rather: for his name and not for his name - what is it?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הַפֶּסַח שֶׁשְּׁחָטוֹ שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ, וְקִבֵּל וְהִלֵּךְ וְזָרַק שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ. הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? אִי נֵימָא כִּדְקָתָנֵי, לְמָה לִי עַד דִּמְחַשֵּׁב לְכוּלְּהוּ? מִקַּמָּיְיתָא אִיפְּסִיל לֵיהּ!
human_translation: Come hear A Paschal lamb sacrificed for a different purpose, and he received and carried and sprinkled for a different purpose, What are the circumstances? If we say as it was taught, why do I need he intended all of them, disqualified from the first
llm_translation: Come and hear: The Paschal lamb that was slaughtered not for its sake, and he accepted it and walked and threw it not for its sake. How is the case? If you say as it was taught, why do I need it until he intends for all of them? From the outset, it is disqualified for him!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָאו, הָכִי קָתָנֵי: הַפֶּסַח שֶׁשְּׁחָטוֹ שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ, אִי נָמֵי שְׁחָטוֹ לִשְׁמוֹ וְקִבֵּל וְהִלֵּךְ וְזָרַק שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ. אִי נָמֵי שְׁחָטוֹ וְקִבֵּל וְהִלֵּךְ לִשְׁמוֹ, וְזָרַק שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ. דְּהָוְיָא לַהּ שְׁתֵּי עֲבוֹדוֹת.
human_translation: Rather, is this not what is teaching: A Paschal lamb slaughtered for a different purpose, or alternatively, slaughtered it for its own purpose, but received and carried and sprinkled for a different purpose, or alternatively, he slaughtered it, and received and carried for its own purpose, but sprinkled for a different purpose, it is two rites,
llm_translation: Rather, no, thus it was taught: The Passover offering that one slaughtered not for its sake, if he indeed slaughtered it for its sake and accepted it and then went and threw it not for its sake. Or if he indeed slaughtered it and accepted it and then went for its sake, and threw it not for its sake. This constitutes two acts of labor.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא סֵיפָא: לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ, הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? אִי נֵימָא בִּשְׁתֵּי עֲבוֹדוֹת — הַיְינוּ רֵישָׁא! אֶלָּא לָאו, בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא, דְּאָמַר: אַף בִּגְמַר דְּבָרָיו אָדָם נִתְפָּס.
human_translation: say the latter clause For its own purpose and for a different purpose. What are the circumstances? If we say during two rites, that is the first clause Rather, must we not during one rite, according to Rabbi Yosei, who said that a person is held accountable even for the conclusion of his statement?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima seifa: Lishmo v'shel lo lishmo, heichi dami? Iy neima b'shte avodot — hainu reisha! Ela lav, ba'avodah achat v'Rabbi Yosei hi, de'amar: Af bigmar devarav adam nitpas." English translation: "Say the latter clause: For its own sake and not for its own sake, how is it? If you say in two services — that is the same as the beginning! Rather, no, in one service, and it is Rabbi Yosei, who said: Even in the conclusion of his words, a person is apprehended."

hebrew_text: לָא, לְעוֹלָם בִּשְׁתֵּי עֲבוֹדוֹת, וְרֵישָׁא — דְּקָאֵי בִּשְׁחִיטָה וְקָא מְחַשֵּׁב בִּשְׁחִיטָה, אִי נָמֵי, קָאֵי בִּזְרִיקָה וְקָא מְחַשֵּׁב בִּזְרִיקָא.
human_translation: No, actually during two rites, and The first clause one is standing at the slaughter and thinking about slaughtering alternatively, he is standing sprinkling and thinking about sprinkling
llm_translation: No, forever in two services, and the beginning — that stands in slaughtering and is considering in slaughtering, if you say, also stands in sprinkling and is considering in sprinkling.

hebrew_text: סֵיפָא — דְּקָאֵי בִּשְׁחִיטָה וְקָחָשֵׁיב בִּזְרִיקָה, דְּאָמַר: הֲרֵינִי שׁוֹחֵט אֶת הַפֶּסַח לִשְׁמוֹ לִזְרוֹק דָּמוֹ שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ. וְקָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דִּמְחַשְּׁבִין מֵעֲבוֹדָה לַעֲבוֹדָה, וְהַיְינוּ בַּעְיָא דְּרַב פָּפָּא.
human_translation: The latter clause one is standing at the slaughter and thinking about sprinkling he said: I am hereby slaughtering the Paschal lamb for its own purpose, to sprinkle its blood for a different purpose. And teaches us that one can intend from one rite to another rite, And this was the question by Rav Pappa
llm_translation: The latter clause — that he is engaged in slaughtering and is liable for sprinkling — for he said: "Behold, I am slaughtering the Paschal lamb for its name to sprinkle its blood not for its name." And it is implied to us that they are considered as two separate acts of service, and this is the question of Rav Papa.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: אוֹ שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ וְלִשְׁמוֹ פָּסוּל. הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? אִי נֵימָא בִּשְׁתֵּי עֲבוֹדוֹת, הַשְׁתָּא לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ אָמְרַתְּ פָּסוּל, שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ וְלִשְׁמוֹ מִיבַּעְיָא?!
human_translation: Come hear Or for a different purpose and for its own purpose, is disqualified. What are the circumstances? If we say about two rites, Now you said that for its own purpose, and for a different purpose, is disqualified, is it necessary to say for a different purpose, and for its own purpose?
llm_translation: Come and hear: whether for his sake or for the sake of another, it is invalid. How so? If you say in two types of service, now for his sake and now for the sake of another you say it is invalid, does it require both for his sake and for the sake of another?!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָאו, בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת. וּמִדְּסֵיפָא בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת — רֵישָׁא נָמֵי בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת!
human_translation: Rather, isn’t during one rite? And since the last clause about one rite, the earlier clause also about one rite,
llm_translation: Rather, no, in one service. And from the end in one service - the beginning is also in one service!

hebrew_text: לָא, לְעוֹלָם בִּשְׁתֵּי עֲבוֹדוֹת, וּבְדִין הוּא דְּלָא אִיצְטְרִיךְ לֵיהּ, וְאַיְּידֵי דִּתְנָא לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ, תְּנָא נָמֵי שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ וְלִשְׁמוֹ.
human_translation: No, actually about two rites, and by right it was not necessary Since taught for its own purpose and for a different purpose, it also taught for a different purpose and for its own purpose.
llm_translation: Not, always in two works, and in judgment that not required to him, and since that it was taught for his name and not for his name, it was also taught for not for his name and for his name.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: שְׁחָטוֹ שֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו, וְשֶׁלֹּא לִמְנוּיָו, לַעֲרֵלִים וְלִטְמֵאִין — פָּסוּל. הָכָא פְּשִׁיטָא בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת, וּמִדְּסֵיפָא בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת — רֵישָׁא נָמֵי בָּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת!
human_translation: Come hear If slaughtered for who cannot eat it, for not registered for it, for uncircumcised or ritually impure it is disqualified. Here, it is obvious during one rite, And since the latter clause, about one rite, the first clause, also about one rite,
llm_translation: Come and hear: If one slaughters it not for its intended consumers, not for its designated consumers, for uncircumcised individuals and for those who are ritually impure — it is invalid. Here, it is obvious in one context, and from the conclusion in one context — the beginning is stated in one context!

hebrew_text: מִידֵּי אִירְיָא?! הָא כִּדְאִיתָא וְהָא כִּדְאִיתָא: סֵיפָא — בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת, רֵישָׁא — אִי בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת, אִי בִּשְׁתֵּי עֲבוֹדוֹת.
human_translation: Are comparable? this as it is, and that as it is. The latter clause, about one rite, the first clause, either about one rite or about two rites
llm_translation: From the house of Irya?! This one as it was stated, and this one as it was stated: the latter part — in one service, the former part — whether in one service, or in two services.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: לְאוֹכְלָיו וְשֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו — כָּשֵׁר. הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? אִי נֵימָא בִּשְׁתֵּי עֲבוֹדוֹת, וְטַעְמָא דְּחַשֵּׁיב בִּזְרִיקָה, דְּאֵין מַחְשְׁבֶת אוֹכְלִין בִּזְרִיקָה —
human_translation: Come hear for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it, it is valid. What are the circumstances? If we say during two rites, then the reason is that he had the intention at sprinkling, because there is no intent concerning those who can eat it during the sprinkling.
llm_translation: Come and hear: for those who eat it and for those who do not eat it — it is valid. How so? If you say in two types of service, and the reason for the importance of sprinkling, for the thought of eating is not in the sprinkling —

hebrew_text: הָא בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת, כְּגוֹן בִּשְׁחִיטָה דְּמַהְנְיָא בַּיהּ מַחְשְׁבֶת אוֹכְלִין — פָּסוּל, וְהָא קַיְימָא לַן מִקְצָת אוֹכְלִין לָא פָּסְלָא!
human_translation: But during one rite, such as the slaughter, during which intent with regard to those who will eat is effective, is disqualified. for we maintain that some of those who are to eat not disqualified.
llm_translation: This is the case with one type of service, such as in the act of ritual slaughter, where the intention of the one performing the act is for eating – it is invalid. But in our case, where some of the food is intended for eating, it is not invalid!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָאו: בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת, וּמִדְּסֵיפָא בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת — רֵישָׁא נָמֵי בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת!
human_translation: Rather, doesn’t it one rite, And since the latter clause one rite, the first clause, also one rite,
llm_translation: Rather, no: in one service, and from the end in one service - the beginning is mentioned in one service!

hebrew_text: מִידֵּי אִירְיָא?! הָא כִּדְאִיתָא וְהָא כִּדְאִיתָא. סֵיפָא בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת, וְרֵישָׁא אוֹ בַּעֲבוֹדָה אַחַת, אוֹ בִּשְׁתֵּי עֲבוֹדוֹת.
human_translation: Are comparable? this as it is and that as it is. the latter clause about one rite, the first clause, either about one rite or about two rites.
llm_translation: From the house of Irya?! This one as it was said, and this one as it was said. The latter in one service, and the former either in one service, or in two services.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: פֶּסַח שֶׁשְּׁחָטוֹ בִּשְׁאָר יְמוֹת הַשָּׁנָה לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ, מַהוּ? מִי אָתֵי שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ וּמַפֵּיק לֵיהּ מִידֵי לִשְׁמוֹ וּמַכְשִׁיר לֵיהּ, אוֹ לָא?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before A Paschal lamb that one slaughtered on the rest of the days of the year for its own purpose and for a different purpose, what is its Does for a different purpose come and nullify for its own purpose make it valid, or not?
llm_translation: He asked them: If one slaughtered the Passover offering on other days of the year for its sake and not for its sake, what is the law? Does it come to not for its sake and then he immediately takes it out for its sake and renders it fit, or not?

hebrew_text: כִּי אֲתָא רַב דִּימִי אָמַר, אַמְרִיתָא לִשְׁמַעְתָּא קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי יִרְמְיָה: הוֹאִיל וְלִשְׁמוֹ מַכְשִׁירוֹ בִּזְמַנּוֹ, וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ מַכְשִׁירוֹ שֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ: מָה לִשְׁמוֹ הַמַּכְשִׁירוֹ בִּזְמַנּוֹ — אֵין מוֹצִיאוֹ מִידֵי שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ, אַף שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ הַמַּכְשִׁירוֹ שֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ — אֵין מוֹצִיאוֹ מִידֵי לִשְׁמוֹ, וּפָסוּל.
human_translation: When Rav Dimi came he said: I raised this question in the presence of Rabbi Yirmeya Since for its own purpose validates it at its proper time, and for a different purpose validates it not at its proper time, Just for its own purpose, which validates it at its proper time, does not nullify for a different purpose, so too, for a different purpose, which validates it not at its proper time, does not nullify for its own purpose, and it is disqualified.
llm_translation: When Rav Dimi came, he said, "You have spoken well in front of Rabbi Yirmeya: Since when his name makes it valid in its time, but when not in his name makes it valid not in its time: Just as when his name makes it valid in its time - one does not remove it from being not in his name, so too when not in his name makes it valid not in its time - one does not remove it from being in his name, and it is disqualified."

hebrew_text: וַאֲמַר לִי: לֹא! אִם אָמַרְתָּ בְּשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ שֶׁכֵּן נוֹהֵג בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים, תֹּאמַר בְּלִשְׁמוֹ שֶׁכֵּן אֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים אֶלָּא בַּפֶּסַח בִּלְבַד.
human_translation: And said to me: No, If you say for a different purpose, because applies to all offerings, can you say about for its own purpose that does not apply to all offerings but to the Paschal lamb alone?
llm_translation: And he said to me: No! If you said regarding not for its name, that is how it is done with all sacrifices, you should say regarding for its name, that is not how it is done with all sacrifices, only with the Passover alone.

hebrew_text: מַאי הָוֵי עֲלַהּ? אָמַר רָבָא: פֶּסַח שֶׁשְּׁחָטוֹ בִּשְׁאָר יְמוֹת הַשָּׁנָה לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ — כָּשֵׁר. דְּהָא סְתָמוֹ לִשְׁמוֹ קָאֵי, וַאֲפִילּוּ הָכִי, כִּי שָׁחֵיט לֵיהּ שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ — כָּשֵׁר,
human_translation: What about Rava said: A Paschal lamb that one slaughtered on the rest of the days of the year for its own purpose and for a different purpose is valid. In an undetermined stands for its own purpose, But nevertheless, when he slaughters it for a different purpose, it is valid.
llm_translation: What is the ruling regarding it? Rava said: A Paschal lamb that was slaughtered during the rest of the days of the year, whether for its sake or not for its sake — it is valid. For its default status is for its sake, and even so, if one slaughters it not for its sake — it is valid.

hebrew_text: אַלְמָא: אָתֵי שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ וּמַפֵּיק לֵיהּ מִידֵי לִשְׁמוֹ. כִּי שָׁחֵיט נָמֵי לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ — אָתֵי שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ וּמַפֵּיק לֵיהּ מִידֵי לִשְׁמוֹ.
human_translation: Apparently, for a different purpose comes and nullifies for its own purpose; also when slaughters for its own purpose and for a different purpose, for a different purpose comes and nullifies for its own purpose.
llm_translation: The Gemara asks: Is it possible that one comes not for its sake, yet it emerges for its sake? For if one slaughters for its sake, and it is not for its sake - it is possible that one comes not for its sake, yet it emerges for its sake.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה לְרָבָא: דִּילְמָא שָׁאנֵי הֵיכָא דְּאָמַר מֵהֵיכָא דְּלָא אָמַר. דְּהָא לְאוֹכְלָיו וְשֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו כָּשֵׁר, וְכׇל הֵיכָא דְּשָׁחֵיט לֵיהּ שֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו לְחוֹדֵיהּ — פָּסוּל, וְאַמַּאי? הָא סְתָמָא לְאוֹכְלָיו קָאֵי. אֶלָּא שָׁאנֵי הֵיכָא דְּאָמַר מֵהֵיכָא דְּלָא אָמַר. הָכִי נָמֵי, שָׁאנֵי הֵיכָא דְּאָמַר מֵהֵיכָא דְּלָא אָמַר!
human_translation: Rav Adda bar Ahava said to Rava: Perhaps where said is different from where he did not say for those who can eat it and those who cannot eat it, it is valid, but wherever he slaughters it only for the sake of those who cannot eat it, it is disqualified. Now, why Surely in an undetermined stands for those who can eat it. Rather, where said is different from where he did not say So too, where he said is different from where he did not say
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Adda bar Ahava to Rava: Perhaps it is different in a case where he said from where he did not say. For in a case where it is fit for consumption and where it is not fit for consumption, it is valid. And in every case where one slaughters it not for its intended purpose, it is invalid. And why is that? Because it stands for consumption. Rather, perhaps it is different in a case where he said from where he did not say. So too, it is different in a case where he said from where he did not say!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִידֵי אִירְיָא? בִּשְׁלָמָא הָתָם כַּמָּה דְּלָא עָקַר לֵיהּ בִּשְׁחִיטָה — סְתָמֵיהּ וַדַּאי לִשְׁמוֹ קָאֵי. אֶלָּא הָכָא — סְתָמֵיהּ לְאוֹכְלָיו קָאֵי?!
human_translation: said to him: Are comparable? Granted, there, as long as did not uproot at slaughter, in an undetermined it certainly stands for its own purpose; But here, in an undetermined does it stand for those who eat it?
llm_translation: He said to him: From the hand of a non-Jew? But there, where it did not uproot through slaughter - its status is certain and it certainly stands for its name. But here - its status stands for its consumers?!

hebrew_text: דִּילְמָא מִימַּשְׁכִי הָנֵי וְאָתֵי אַחֲרִינֵי וּמִימְּנִי עִלָּוֵיהּ, (אַחֲרִינֵי) דִּתְנַן: נִמְנִין וּמוֹשְׁכִין אֶת יְדֵיהֶם מִמֶּנּוּ, עַד שֶׁיִּשְׁחַט.
human_translation: perhaps these will withdraw and others will come and register for it. For we learned register and withdraw from it until it is slaughtered.
llm_translation: Perhaps those people will pull it and others will come after them and pull it from them, others as we learned: they count and stretch out their hands from it, until it is slaughtered.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: פֶּסַח שֶׁשְּׁחָטוֹ בִּשְׁאָר יְמוֹת הַשָּׁנָה בְּשִׁינּוּי בְּעָלִים, מַהוּ? שִׁינּוּי בְּעָלִים כְּשִׁינּוּי קוֹדֶשׁ דָּמֵי — וּמַכְשַׁיר לֵיהּ, אוֹ לָא?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before a Paschal lamb that one slaughtered on the rest of the days of the year with a change of owner, what is its Is a change of owner like a change of sanctity? And it validates it, Or, not,
llm_translation: He asked them: If one slaughtered the Passover offering on other days of the year with the intent of idolatry, what is the law? Is the intent of idolatry like the intent of sanctifying the blood - and it renders it fit, or not?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא, אַמְרִיתָא לִשְׁמַעְתָּא קַמֵּיהּ דְּרָבָא: הוֹאִיל וְשִׁינּוּי קוֹדֶשׁ פּוֹסְלוֹ בִּזְמַנּוֹ, וְשִׁינּוּי בְּעָלִים פּוֹסְלוֹ בִּזְמַנּוֹ. מָה שִׁינּוּי קוֹדֶשׁ שֶׁפּוֹסְלוֹ בִּזְמַנּוֹ — מַכְשִׁירוֹ לְאַחַר זְמַנּוֹ, אַף שִׁינּוּי בְּעָלִים שֶׁפּוֹסְלוֹ בִּזְמַנּוֹ — מַכְשִׁירוֹ לְאַחַר זְמַנּוֹ.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: I raised this question in the presence of Rava Since a change in sanctity invalidates it in its proper time, and a change in owner, invalidates it in its proper time, Just as a change in sanctity, which invalidates it in its proper time, validates it after its proper time, a change in owner, which invalidates it in its proper time, also validates it after its proper time.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said, a teaching was said before Rava: Since disqualification of the holy offering invalidates it in its time, and disqualification of the owners invalidates it in its time. Just as disqualification of the holy offering that invalidates it in its time — renders it fit after its time, so too disqualification of the owners that invalidates it in its time — renders it fit after its time.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר לִי: לֹא! אִם אָמַרְתָּ בְּשִׁינּוּי קוֹדֶשׁ — שֶׁכֵּן פְּסוּלוֹ בְּגוּפוֹ, וְיֶשְׁנוֹ בְּאַרְבַּע עֲבוֹדוֹת,
human_translation: And said to me: No, If you say about a change in sanctity, because the disqualification it is in itself, and it applies to all four of the rites,
llm_translation: And he said to me: No! If you say with regard to Shinui Kodesh - that its disqualification is in its essence, and there is in it four types of labor,

hebrew_text: וְיֶשְׁנוֹ לְאַחַר מִיתָה, וְיֶשְׁנוֹ בְּצִבּוּר כְּבַיָּחִיד. תֹּאמַר בְּשִׁינּוּי בְּעָלִים — דְּאֵין פְּסוּלוֹ בְּגוּפוֹ, וְאֵינוֹ בְּאַרְבַּע עֲבוֹדוֹת, וְאֵינוֹ לְאַחַר מִיתָה, וְאֵינוֹ בְּצִבּוּר כְּבַיָּחִיד.
human_translation: And applies after death. it applies to communal as it does to an individual. can you say with regard to a change in owner Its disqualification is not in itself; and it does not to all four rites and it does not after death, and it does not to communal as it does to an individual,
llm_translation: And there is one who is after death, and there is one who is in public assembly like an individual. You will say in the case of a change of ownership — that its disqualification is not in its body, and it is not related to the four types of labor, and it is not after death, and it is not in public assembly like an individual.

hebrew_text: וְאַף עַל גַּב דְּתַרְתֵּי לָאו דַּוְקָא, תַּרְתֵּי מִיהָא דַּוְקָא. דְּמַאי שְׁנָא שִׁינּוּי בְּעָלִים דְּלָא הָוֵי פְּסוּלוֹ בְּגוּפוֹ — דִּפְסוּלוֹ מַחְשָׁבָה בְּעָלְמָא הִיא. שִׁינּוּי קוֹדֶשׁ נָמֵי — פְּסוּלוֹ מַחְשָׁבָה בְּעָלְמָא הִיא.
human_translation: And even though two are not accurate two, at least, are accurate. For what is different about a change in owner its disqualification not being in itself? Is it that its disqualification is merely thought? a change of sanctity is also merely a disqualification thought
llm_translation: And even though both are not specifically stated, both are specifically stated. What is the difference between a change in owners that does not render it invalid in itself? - Because its invalidity is only in thought. A change in sanctity, likewise - its invalidity is only in thought.

hebrew_text: וְתוּ, הָא דְּאָמַר שִׁינּוּי בְּעָלִים אֵינוֹ לְאַחַר מִיתָה, וּלְרַב פִּנְחָס בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אַמֵּי דְּאָמַר יֵשׁ שִׁינּוּי בְּעָלִים לְאַחַר מִיתָה, מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר? תַּרְתֵּי מִיהַת דַּוְקָא נִינְהוּ.
human_translation: And furthermore, that which was said, a change in owner does not after death, According to Rav Pineḥas, son of Rav Ami, who said that a change in owner applies after death, what is there to say? at least two are accurate.
llm_translation: And come, this that said change of ownership is not after death, and to Rav Pinchas son of Rav Ammi that said there is change of ownership after death, what is there to say? Two of them specifically are.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא, אָמַר רָבָא: פֶּסַח שֶׁשְּׁחָטוֹ בִּשְׁאָר יְמוֹת הַשָּׁנָה בְּשִׁינּוּי בְּעָלִים — נַעֲשָׂה כְּמִי שֶׁאֵין לוֹ בְּעָלִים בִּזְמַנּוֹ, וּפְסוּל.
human_translation: Rather, Rava said: A Paschal lamb that one slaughtered on the rest of the days of the year with a change of owner is considered like one that does not have an owner. at its time and it is disqualified.
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: A Paschal lamb that was slaughtered on other days of the year with the intention of its owners being replaced - it is deemed as if it has no owners at its proper time, and it is invalid.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ שְׁחָטוֹ שֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו, וְשֶׁלֹּא לִמְנוּיָו, לַעֲרֵלִים וְלִטְמֵאִים — פָּסוּל. לְאוֹכְלָיו וְשֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו לִמְנוּיָו וְשֶׁלֹּא לִמְנוּיָו, לְמוּלִים וְלַעֲרֵלִים, לִטְמֵאִים וְלִטְהוֹרִים — כָּשֵׁר.
human_translation: slaughtered for who cannot eat it those who did not register people who are uncircumcised or for those who are ritually impure, is disqualified. for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it; for those who have registered for it and for those who have not registered for it; for the circumcised and for the uncircumcised; for the ritually impure and for the ritually pure, it is valid,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: If one slaughters an animal not for those who will eat it, and not for those designated to eat it, it is invalid for uncircumcised individuals and those who are ritually impure. If one slaughters it for those who will eat it and not for those who will eat it, for those designated to eat it and not for those designated to eat it, for circumcised individuals and uncircumcised individuals, for those who are ritually impure and those who are ritually pure — it is valid.

hebrew_text: שְׁחָטוֹ קוֹדֶם חֲצוֹת — פָּסוּל, מִשּׁוּם שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״בֵּין הָעַרְבַּיִם״. שְׁחָטוֹ קוֹדֶם לַתָּמִיד — כָּשֵׁר, וּבִלְבַד שֶׁיְּהֵא אַחֵר מְמָרֵס בְּדָמוֹ עַד שֶׁיִּזָּרֵק הַתָּמִיד. וְאִם נִזְרַק — כָּשֵׁר.
human_translation: slaughtered before midday it is disqualified, as it is stated: in the afternoon” slaughtered it before the daily offering it is valid, as long as another stirs its blood until the daily offering is sprinkled. And if is sprinkled it is valid,
llm_translation: The slaughter before midnight — invalid, because it is stated "between the evenings." The slaughter before the continual offering — valid, as long as it is after it has been stirred in its blood until the continual offering is sprinkled. And if it has been sprinkled — valid.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: כֵּיצַד שֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו? לְשׁוּם חוֹלֶה אוֹ לְשׁוּם זָקֵן. כֵּיצַד שֶׁלֹּא לִמְנוּיָו? נִמְנוּ עָלָיו חֲבוּרָה זוֹ, וּשְׁחָטוֹ לְשֵׁם חֲבוּרָה אַחֶרֶת.
human_translation: The Sages taught How so for those who cannot eat it? for the sake of a sick person or for the sake of an old person How so for those who did not register for it? one group registered for it, and one slaughtered it for the sake of a different group.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: How is it that it is not for his eaters? For the sake of a sick person or for the sake of an elderly person. How is it that it is not for his designated ones? They designated a group upon him, and he slaughtered it for the sake of another group.

hebrew_text: מְנָהָנֵי מִילֵּי? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״בְּמִכְסַת״ — מְלַמֵּד שֶׁאֵין הַפֶּסַח נִשְׁחָט אֶלָּא לִמְנוּיָו,
human_translation: From where are these matters, As the Sages taught “According to the number of” teaches that the Paschal lamb is slaughtered only for those who have registered for it.
llm_translation: "From where do we derive these words? For the Rabbis taught: 'In a group' - this teaches that the Paschal lamb is not slaughtered except for its designated group."

hebrew_text: יָכוֹל שְׁחָטוֹ שֶׁלֹּא לִמְנוּיָו יְהֵא כְּעוֹבֵר עַל הַמִּצְוָה וְכָשֵׁר — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״בְּמִכְסַת ... תָּכֹסּוּ״, הַכָּתוּב שָׁנָה עָלָיו לְעַכֵּב.
human_translation: might he slaughtered it for those who did not register for it, he would be as one who has violated a commandment, valid the Torah teaches “according to the number” “you shall make your count”; the verse repeated it to make indispensable,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: One might have thought that his slaughter, if not for its designation, should be like one who transgresses a commandment and it is valid. The Scripture states: "With a covering... you shall cover," indicating that the verse has imposed a restriction upon him.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: לָשׁוֹן סוּרְסִי הוּא, כְּאָדָם שֶׁאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״כּוֹס לִי טָלֶה זֶה״.
human_translation: Rabbi says: is Aramaic [ Sursi ], like one who says to his fellow: Slaughter [ kos ] me this lamb,
llm_translation: Rabbi says: it is the language of the Sursi, like a person who says to his friend, "Pour me this cup of dew."

hebrew_text: אַשְׁכְּחַן שֶׁלֹּא לִמְנוּיָו, שֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו מְנָא לַן? אָמַר קְרָא ״אִישׁ לְפִי אׇכְלוֹ תָּכוֹסּוּ״, אִיתַּקַּשׁ אוֹכְלִין לִמְנוּיִין.
human_translation: We have found for those who have not registered for it from where do we for those who cannot eat it? the verse says: “According to every man’s eating you shall make your count”; those who eat it are juxtaposed, to those who are registered
llm_translation: We find that not for its designated purpose, not for its consumers, what is the status? The verse says, "According to his eating, you shall make your count," linking consumers to designated purposes.

hebrew_text: שְׁחָטוֹ לְמוּלִין, עַל מְנָת שֶׁיִּתְכַּפְּרוּ בּוֹ עֲרֵלִים בִּזְרִיקָה. רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר: פָּסוּל. רַבָּה אָמַר: כָּשֵׁר. רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר פָּסוּל — יֵשׁ מַחְשֶׁבֶת עֲרֵלִים בִּזְרִיקָה. רַבָּה אָמַר כָּשֵׁר — אֵין מַחְשֶׁבֶת עֲרֵלִים בִּזְרִיקָה.
human_translation: slaughtered for circumcised on condition that uncircumcised achieve atonement through the sprinkling Rav Ḥisda said: disqualified. Rabba said: valid. Rav Ḥisda said disqualified intent for uncircumcised at the sprinkling. Rabba said valid intent uncircumcised not during the sprinkling.
llm_translation: He slaughters for uncircumcised individuals, on the condition that they will be atoned for through sprinkling. Rav Ḥisdah said: invalid. Rabbah said: valid. Rav Ḥisdah said it is invalid - there is the intention of uncircumcised individuals in the sprinkling. Rabbah said it is valid - there is no intention of uncircumcised individuals in the sprinkling.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה: מְנָא אָמֵינָא לַהּ? דְּתַנְיָא: יָכוֹל יִפְסוֹל בְּנֵי חֲבוּרָה הַבָּאִין עִמּוֹ? וְדִין הוּא: הוֹאִיל וְעׇרְלָה פּוֹסֶלֶת וְטוּמְאָה פּוֹסֶלֶת, מָה טוּמְאָה לֹא עָשָׂה בָּהּ מִקְצָת טוּמְאָה כְּכׇל טוּמְאָה — אַף עׇרְלָה לֹא עָשָׂה בָּהּ מִקְצָת עׇרְלָה כְּכׇל עׇרְלָה.
human_translation: Rabba said: From where do I say this As it was taught might would disqualify the members of the group who come with him. And logically Since lack of circumcision disqualifies and ritual impurity disqualifies Just as ritual impurity, partial impurity was not made to be like full impurity, so too, with lack of circumcision; partial lack of circumcision was not made to be like full lack of circumcision,
llm_translation: Rabah said: From where do I say this to her? For it was taught: Can the members of the group who come with him disqualify him? And it is just: Since a foreskin disqualifies and impurity disqualifies, just as impurity did not make any part of it impure like all impurity - so too a foreskin did not make any part of it foreskin like all foreskin.

hebrew_text: אוֹ כַּלֵּךְ לְדֶרֶךְ זוֹ: הוֹאִיל וְעׇרְלָה פּוֹסֶלֶת וּזְמַן פּוֹסֵל, מָה זְמַן — עָשָׂה בָּהּ מִקְצָת זְמַן כְּכׇל זְמַן, אַף עׇרְלָה — עָשָׂה בָּהּ מִקְצָת עׇרְלָה כְּכׇל עׇרְלָה.
human_translation: Or go this way Since lack of circumcision disqualifies and time disqualifies Just as time, partial was made to be like entire time, so too, with lack of circumcision; partial lack of circumcision was made to be like full lack of circumcision,
llm_translation: Or go on this path: Since a foreskin disqualifies and a designated time disqualifies, what is the time - he did with it some time like all time, so too foreskin - he did with it some foreskin like all foreskin.

hebrew_text: נִרְאֶה לְמִי דּוֹמֶה: דָּנִין דָּבָר שֶׁאֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים מִדָּבָר שֶׁאֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים, וְאַל יוֹכִיחַ זְמַן שֶׁנּוֹהֵג בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים.
human_translation: Let us see to which it is similar, we derive a matter, that does not apply to all offerings, from matter, that does not apply to all offerings, And time, which applies to all offerings, should not prove
llm_translation: It appears to whom is it similar: judging a matter that is not common in all sacrifices from a matter that is not common in all sacrifices, and one should not prove a time that is common in all sacrifices.

hebrew_text: אוֹ כַּלֵּךְ לְדֶרֶךְ זוֹ: דָּנִין דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא הוּתַּר מִכְּלָלוֹ מִדָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא הוּתַּר מִכְּלָלוֹ, וְאַל תּוֹכִיחַ טוּמְאָה — שֶׁהוּתְּרָה מִכְּלָלָהּ.
human_translation: Or, go this way: We derive a matter, for which no allowance from its rule, from a matter, for which no allowance from its rule, And ritual impurity should not prove as an allowance from its rule.
llm_translation: Or go on this path: judging a matter that was not permitted from its entirety, from a matter that was not permitted from its entirety, and do not prove impurity - for it was permitted from its entirety.

hebrew_text: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״זֹאת״. מַאי ״זֹאת״? אִילֵּימָא דְּכוּלַּהּ עׇרְלָה — פָּסְלָה, מִקְצָתַהּ — לָא פָּסְלָה, הַאי מִ״וְּכׇל עָרֵל״ נָפְקָא!
human_translation: the verse states: “This,” What “this”? If you say all uncircumcised disqualified, part of it is not disqualified, this is derived from “and all uncircumcised males,”
llm_translation: The Talmud says "this." What is "this"? If the entire thing is uncircumcised - it is disqualified, if only part of it - it is not disqualified, hence the verse "and any uncircumcised male" is derived!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָאו הָכִי קָתָנֵי: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״וְכׇל עָרֵל״ — כּוּלַּהּ עׇרְלָה פָּסְלָה, מִקְצָתַהּ — לָא פָּסְלָה. וְכִי תֵּימָא הוּא הַדִּין לִזְרִיקָה, דְּכוּלַּהּ עׇרְלָה מִיהָא פָּסְלָה — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״זֹאת״: בִּשְׁחִיטָה הוּא דְּכוּלַּהּ עׇרְלָה מִיהָא פָּסְלָה, אֲבָל זְרִיקָה — אֲפִילּוּ כּוּלַּהּ עׇרְלָה נָמֵי לָא פָּסְלָה.
human_translation: Rather, is this not what it is teaching: The verse states: “And all uncircumcised all uncircumcised is disqualified, part uncircumcised it is not disqualified. And if you say the same is true of sprinkling all uncircumcised, is in any event disqualified; the verse states: “This,” It is during slaughter that if all uncircumcised, is disqualified; but during sprinkling, even all uncircumcised, it is not disqualified.
llm_translation: The Talmud does not teach so, but rather thus: Scripture states "and every uncircumcised" — the entirety of it is uncircumcised renders it unfit, part of it — does not render it unfit. And if you might say the same applies to sprinkling, that if the entirety of it is uncircumcised it renders it unfit — Scripture states "this": in the case of slaughtering, the entirety of it being uncircumcised renders it unfit, but in the case of sprinkling — even if the entirety of it is uncircumcised, it still does not render it unfit.

hebrew_text: וְכִי תֵּימָא מַאי קוּלָּא דִזְרִיקָה? דְּאֵין מַחְשְׁבֶת אוֹכְלִין בִּזְרִיקָה.
human_translation: And if you say: What is the leniency of sprinkling there is no intent concerning those who may eat during the sprinkling.
llm_translation: And if you will say, what is the principle of throwing? That the intention of eating is not in the throwing.

hebrew_text: וְרַב חִסְדָּא, אַדְּרַבָּה לְאִידַּךְ גִּיסָא: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״וְכׇל עָרֵל״ — כּוּלַּהּ עׇרְלָה פָּסְלָה, מִקְצָתָהּ — לָא פָּסְלָה. אֲבָל זְרִיקָה — אֲפִילּוּ מִקְצָתָהּ נָמֵי פָּסְלָה. וְכִי תֵּימָא הוּא הַדִּין לִזְרִיקָה, דְּעַד דְּאִיכָּא כּוּלַּהּ עׇרְלָה לָא פָּסְלָה, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״זֹאת״: שְׁחִיטָה הוּא דְּמִקְצָתַהּ לָא פָּסְלָה, אֲבָל זְרִיקָה — אֲפִילּוּ מִקְצָתַהּ פָּסְלָה.
human_translation: And Rav Ḥisda on the contrary, in the opposite direction. The verse states: “And all uncircumcised all uncircumcised is disqualified, part uncircumcised, it is not disqualified. however, sprinkling, even part it is disqualified. And if you say the same is true of sprinkling that is not disqualified unless all the verse states “this” slaughter that part of does not disqualify but sprinkling even part of disqualifies
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisdah further stated in the name of the other side: The verse states "and any uncircumcised person" - if the entirety of it is uncircumcised, it renders it invalid; if only part of it is uncircumcised, it does not render it invalid. But with regard to throwing the blood, even if only part of it is uncircumcised, it still renders it invalid. And if you would say that the same applies to throwing the blood, that as long as the entirety of it is not uncircumcised, it does not render it invalid, the verse states "this" - it is specifically regarding slaughtering that if only part of it is uncircumcised, it does not render it invalid, but with regard to throwing the blood, even if only part of it is uncircumcised, it renders it invalid.

hebrew_text: וְכִי תֵּימָא וּמַאי חוּמְרֵיהּ דִּזְרִיקָה? דְּלָא מִקְּבַע פִּיגּוּל אֶלָּא בִּזְרִיקָה.
human_translation: And if you say: What is the stringency of sprinkling piggul is established only during sprinkling.
llm_translation: And if you will say, what is the stringency of throwing? That it does not establish Pigul except through throwing.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב אָשֵׁי: מִמַּאי דְּהַאי ״וְכׇל עָרֵל״ כּוּלַּהּ מַשְׁמַע? דִּילְמָא הַאי ״וְכׇל עָרֵל״ מַשְׁמַע כׇּל דְּהוּ עׇרְלָה, כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״זֹאת״, דְּעַד דְּאִיכָּא כּוּלַּהּ עׇרְלָה — לָא פָּסְלָה, לָא שְׁנָא בִּשְׁחִיטָה וְלָא שְׁנָא בִּזְרִיקָה. אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: רַב חִסְדָּא וְרַבָּה
human_translation: Rav Ashi strongly objects to this From where that this “and all uncircumcised means that all Perhaps this “and all [ kol ] uncircumcised means that any is uncircumcised. the Merciful One says “This,” is not disqualified unless all of it uncircumcised, there is no difference between slaughtering and sprinkling. Rather, Rav Ashi said: Rav Ḥisda and Rabba
llm_translation: Rav Ashi strongly objects: From where do we derive that the term "and every uncircumcised male" implies all? Perhaps the term "and every uncircumcised male" only refers to those who are uncircumcised. The Merciful One wrote "this," indicating that as long as there is even one uncircumcised individual among them, it does not invalidate the offering, whether in regard to slaughter or in regard to sprinkling. Rather, Rav Ashi said: Rav Hisda and Rabba.

hebrew_text: בְּהַאי קְרָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי: ״וְנִרְצָה לוֹ לְכַפֵּר עָלָיו״ — עָלָיו וְלֹא עַל חֲבֵירוֹ. רַבָּה סָבַר: חֲבֵירוֹ דּוּמְיָא דִידֵיהּ. מָה הוּא דְּבַר כַּפָּרָה — אַף חֲבֵירוֹ דְּבַר כַּפָּרָה, לְאַפּוֹקֵי הַאי עָרֵל דְּלָאו בַּר כַּפָּרָה הוּא.
human_translation: disagree with regard to this verse, “And it shall be accepted for him to make atonement for him” For him and not for his fellow. Rabba holds another similar to him: Just as he is eligible for atonement so another who is eligible for atonement. to exclude this uncircumcised person, who is not eligible for atonement.
llm_translation: In this verse he disputes: "And it shall be accepted for him to make atonement for him" - for him and not for his fellow. Rava thought: His fellow is similar to himself. Just as this is a matter of atonement - so too, his fellow is a matter of atonement, to exclude this uncircumcised one who is not a matter of atonement.

hebrew_text: וְרַב חִסְדָּא סָבַר: הַאי עָרֵל נָמֵי, כֵּיוָן דְּבַר חִיּוּבָא הוּא — בַּר כַּפָּרָה הוּא, [הוֹאִיל] דְּאִי בָּעֵי מְתַקֵּן נַפְשֵׁיהּ.
human_translation: And Rav Ḥisda holds this uncircumcised person as well, since he is obligated he is eligible for atonement Since if he wants, he can make himself fit
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda holds: This uncircumcised person, since it is a matter of obligation — he is like one who is covered by the atonement, since if he wants, he can rectify himself.

hebrew_text: וּמִי אִית לֵיהּ לְרַב חִסְדָּא ״הוֹאִיל״? וְהָא אִיתְּמַר: הָאוֹפֶה מִיּוֹם טוֹב לְחוֹל, רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר: לוֹקֶה. רַבָּה אָמַר: אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה.
human_translation: But does Rav Ḥisda accept since? But it was said one who bakes on a Festival for during the week: Rav Ḥisda said he is flogged Rabba said he is not flogged.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "And does Rav Ḥisdah have the term 'ho'il'? But it was stated: 'One who bakes from a Festival day to a weekday, Rav Ḥisdah said: He is liable.' Rabbah said: He is not liable."

hebrew_text: רַבָּה אָמַר אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה: אָמְרִינַן ״הוֹאִיל וְאִי מִקַּלְעִי לֵיהּ אוֹרְחִים חֲזֵי לֵיהּ, הַשְׁתָּא נָמֵי חֲזֵי לֵיהּ״ וְלָא לָקֵי. רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר לוֹקֶה: לָא אָמְרִינַן ״הוֹאִיל״.
human_translation: Rabba said he is not flogged Since if guests arrive, fit for him now too, fit for him, and he is not flogged. Rav Ḥisda said he is flogged; we do not state since.
llm_translation: Rabba said: He is not liable. We say, "Since if a bolt were to be removed, the thieves would see it, now too they see it," and he is not liable. Rav Ḥisda said: He is liable. We do not say, "Since."

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא דְּרַבָּה אַדְּרַבָּה לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָכָא מְחוּסָּר מַעֲשֶׂה, הָתָם דְּלָא מְחוּסָּר מַעֲשֶׂה. אֶלָּא דְּרַב חִסְדָּא אַדְּרַב חִסְדָּא קַשְׁיָא! אָמְרִי: כִּי לֵית לֵיהּ לְרַב חִסְדָּא ״הוֹאִיל״ — לְקוּלָּא, לְחוּמְרָא — אִית לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Granted, of Rabba and of Rabba is not difficult. Here, an action is lacking, there, no action is lacking But of Rav Ḥisda of Rav Ḥisda difficult They say, When Rav Ḥisda does not since, to be lenient to be stringent he does
llm_translation: In the case of Rabba, Rabba's argument is not difficult: here there is a lack of action, there, where there is no lack of action. Rather, in the case of Rav Ḥisda, Rav Ḥisda's argument is difficult! They said: When it comes to Rav Ḥisda, "since" he has it — for leniency, for stringency — he has it.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ מָר זוּטְרָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב מָרִי לְרָבִינָא: קָתָנֵי, הוֹאִיל וְעָרְלָה פּוֹסֶלֶת וְטוּמְאָה פּוֹסֶלֶת, מָה טוּמְאָה לֹא עָשָׂה בָּהּ מִקְצָת טוּמְאָה כְּכׇל טוּמְאָה — אַף עׇרְלָה לֹא עָשָׂה מִקְצָת עׇרְלָה כְּכׇל עׇרְלָה. הַאי טוּמְאָה הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵּימָא בְּטוּמְאַת גַּבְרֵי, וּמַאי ״לֹא עָשָׂה בָּהּ מִקְצָת טוּמְאָה כְּכׇל טוּמְאָה״ — דְּאִי אִיכָּא אַרְבְּעָה וְחַמְשָׁה גַּבְרֵי טְמֵאִין וְאַרְבְּעָה וְחַמְשָׁה גַּבְרֵי טְהוֹרִין, לָא פָּסְלִי לְהוּ טְמֵאִין לִטְהוֹרִין,
human_translation: Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said to Ravina: teaches: Since lack of circumcision disqualifies and ritual impurity disqualifies Just as ritual impurity, partial impurity was not made to be like full impurity, so too, lack of circumcision, partial lack of circumcision was not made to be like full lack of circumcision. this ritual impurity, what are the circumstances? If you say the ritual impurity of the people what partial impurity was not made to be like full impurity? that if there are four or five people who are impure and four or five people who are pure, those who are impure do not disqualify those who are pure.
llm_translation: He said to him, Master Zutra, son of Rav Mari, to Ravina: It is taught, since uncircumcision invalidates and impurity invalidates, just as impurity did not render it partially impure like all impurity - so too uncircumcision did not render it partially uncircumcised like all uncircumcision. How is this impurity comparable? If you say in terms of male impurity, and what does "did not render it partially impure like all impurity" mean - that if there were four or five impure men and four or five pure men, they do not invalidate each other, impure to pure.

hebrew_text: גַּבֵּי עׇרְלָה נָמֵי הָא לָא פָּסְלִי, דִּתְנַן: לְמוּלִין וְלַעֲרֵלִים — כָּשֵׁר. מַאי שְׁנָא טוּמְאָה דִּפְשִׁיטָא לֵיהּ, וּמַאי שְׁנָא עׇרְלָה דִּמְסַפְּקָא לֵיהּ?
human_translation: with regard to lack of circumcision as well, do not disqualify as we learned for circumcised and uncircumcised people, it is valid. What is different impurity, that it is obvious to him And what is different lack of circumcision, that he is in doubt
llm_translation: Regarding the foreskin, the Gemara asks: Is there a difference between impurity of a certainty, where it is obvious to him, and the foreskin, where there is doubt?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא בְּטוּמְאַת בָּשָׂר, וּמַאי לֹא עָשָׂה בָּהּ מִקְצָת טוּמְאָה כְּכׇל טוּמְאָה? דְּאִילּוּ אִיטַּמִּי חַד מֵאֵבָרִים — הַאי דְּאִיטַּמִּי שָׂרְפִינַן לֵיהּ, וְאִידַּךְ — אָכְלִינַן לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rather, impurity of the meat And what partial impurity was not made to be like full impurity? that if one of the limbs became impure, that which became impure we burn and the rest we eat.
llm_translation: Rather, in the case of the impurity of meat, and what did he not do with it some impurity like all impurity? For if one limb becomes impure - we burn it, and the other - we eat it.

hebrew_text: בְּמַאי אוֹקֵימְתָּא — בְּטוּמְאַת בָּשָׂר? אֵימָא סֵיפָא: דָּנִין דָּבָר שֶׁאֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים מִדָּבָר שֶׁאֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים, וְאַל יוֹכִיחַ זְמַן שֶׁנּוֹהֵג בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים. וּמַאי טוּמְאָה? אִי נֵימָא טוּמְאַת בָּשָׂר, אַמַּאי אֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים?
human_translation: How did you establish impurity of the meat. say the latter clause We derive a matter that does not apply to all offerings, from a matter that does not apply to all offerings, and time, which applies to all offerings, should not prove anything what impurity If we say impurity of the meat, why it does not apply to all offerings?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: With what is it established? - With the impurity of the flesh? Say the latter clause: We judge a matter that is not customary in all sacrifices from a matter that is not customary in all sacrifices, and let it not prove a time that is customary in all sacrifices. And what is impurity? If you say impurity of the flesh, why is it not customary in all sacrifices? English translation:

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא פְּשִׁיטָא בְּטוּמְאַת גַּבְרֵי, וּמַאי אֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים? דְּאִילּוּ בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים — עָרֵל וְטָמֵא מְשַׁלְּחִין קׇרְבְּנוֹתֵיהֶן, וְאִילּוּ בְּפֶסַח — עָרֵל וְטָמֵא אֵין מְשַׁלְּחִין פִּסְחֵיהֶן. רֵישָׁא בְּטוּמְאַת בָּשָׂר וְסֵיפָא בְּטוּמְאַת גַּבְרֵי!
human_translation: Rather, it is obvious impurity of the people And what it does not apply to all offerings? that with regard to all offerings, an uncircumcised person and one who is ritually impure send their offerings however, with regard to the Paschal lamb, an uncircumcised person and one who is impure cannot send their offerings. the first clause impurity of the meat, while the latter clause impurity of the people.
llm_translation: Rather, it is obvious regarding the impurity of men, and why is it not practiced with all sacrifices? For if with all sacrifices — uncircumcised and impure they send their offerings, but if with the Passover — uncircumcised and impure they do not send their Passovers. The beginning is regarding the impurity of the flesh, and the end is regarding the impurity of men!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִין, שֵׁם טוּמְאָה קָא פָרֵיךְ.
human_translation: said to Yes, arguing from the category of impurity,
llm_translation: He said to him: No, the name of impurity he was discussing.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: סֵיפָא נָמֵי בְּטוּמְאַת בָּשָׂר. וּמַאי ״אֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים״? דְּאִילּוּ בְּכׇל הַזְּבָחִים בֵּין שֶׁנִּטְמָא חֵלֶב וּבָשָׂר קַיָּים, בֵּין שֶׁנִּטְמָא בָּשָׂר וְחֵלֶב קַיָּים — זוֹרֵק אֶת הַדָּם.
human_translation: And if you wish, say The latter clause also impurity of meat. And what is it does not apply to all offerings? that with regard to all offerings, whether the fats have become impure and the meat remains, the meat has become impure and the fats remain, may sprinkle the blood,
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: The latter clause is primary regarding the impurity of the flesh. And what is meant by "he does not act with all the sacrifices"? For if with all the sacrifices, whether the fat became impure and the flesh remained valid, or whether the flesh became impure and the fat remained valid — he sprinkles the blood.

hebrew_text: וְאִילּוּ בְּפֶסַח, נִטְמָא חֵלֶב וּבָשָׂר קַיָּים — זוֹרֵק אֶת הַדָּם, נִטְמָא בָּשָׂר וְחֵלֶב קַיָּים — אֵינוֹ זוֹרֵק אֶת הַדָּם.
human_translation: the Paschal lamb, the fats have become impure and the meat remains may sprinkle the blood; meat has become impure and the fats remain he may not sprinkle the blood,
llm_translation: And if it is in the context of Pesach, and the fat and the meat are validly fit for consumption — one who throws the blood, if the meat and fat are validly fit for consumption — he does not throw the blood.

hebrew_text: בְּמַאי אוֹקֵימְתָּא — בְּטוּמְאַת בָּשָׂר? אֵימָא סֵיפָא: דָּנִין דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא הוּתַּר מִכְּלָלוֹ מִדָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא הוּתַּר מִכְּלָלוֹ, וְאַל תּוֹכִיחַ טוּמְאָה שֶׁהֲרֵי הוּתְּרָה מִכְּלָלָהּ. בְּמַאי? אִילֵימָא
human_translation: How did you establish impurity of meat. say the next clause We derive a matter, for which no allowance from its rule, from a matter, for which no allowance from its rule. And ritual impurity should not prove as there are an allowance from its rule, What If you say
llm_translation: In what is it established? - In the impurity of the flesh? Say the latter clause: We judge a matter that was not permitted from its entirety as a matter that was not permitted from its entirety, and do not prove impurity, for it was permitted from its entirety. In what? If you will say

hebrew_text: בְּטוּמְאַת בָּשָׂר — הֵיכָא הוּתְּרָה? אֶלָּא פְּשִׁיטָא בְּטוּמְאַת גַּבְרֵי, וְהֵיכָא הוּתְּרָה מִכְּלָלָהּ — בְּצִיבּוּר.
human_translation: impurity of the meat, where is it permitted Rather, it is obvious about impurity of the people. And where is an allowance from its rule? in the community;
llm_translation: In the impurity of flesh - where was it permitted? Rather, it is obvious in the impurity of men, and where was it permitted from its entirety - in a public domain.

hebrew_text: רֵישָׁא בְּטוּמְאַת בָּשָׂר, סֵיפָא בְּטוּמְאַת גַּבְרֵי! אִין — שֵׁם טוּמְאָה קָפָרֵיךְ.
human_translation: the first clause impurity of the meat, the latter clause impurity of the people. Yes, argues from the category of impurity
llm_translation: Beginning with the impurity of meat, ending with the impurity of men! There is no — the name of impurity is Kafareich.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: כּוּלַּהּ בְּטוּמְאַת בָּשָׂר, וְהֵיכָא הוּתְּרָה — בְּטוּמְאַת פֶּסַח, דִּתְנַן: פֶּסַח הַבָּא בְּטוּמְאָה — נֶאֱכָל בְּטוּמְאָה, שֶׁלֹּא בָּא מִתְּחִילָּתוֹ אֶלָּא לַאֲכִילָה.
human_translation: And if you wish, say entire impurity of the meat, and where is it permitted in impurity of the Paschal lamb, as we learned A Paschal lamb that comes in impurity, be eaten in impurity, as from the very outset it came only to be eaten.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: The entirety in the impurity of the flesh, and where was it permitted? In the impurity of the Passover, as we learned: The Passover that comes in impurity - is eaten in impurity, for it did not come from its inception except for eating.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: הַפֶּסַח שֶׁעָבְרָה שְׁנָתוֹ, וּשְׁחָטוֹ בִּזְמַנּוֹ לִשְׁמוֹ, וְכֵן הַשּׁוֹחֵט אֲחֵרִים לְשֵׁם פֶּסַח בִּזְמַנּוֹ — רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר פּוֹסֵל, וְרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ מַכְשִׁיר.
human_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, raised an objection a Paschal lamb that has passed its year, he slaughtered it at its time for its purpose and similarly, he slaughtered another for the purpose of a Paschal lamb at its time, Rabbi Eliezer disqualifies and Rabbi Yehoshua validates it,
llm_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, raises an objection: If one slaughtered the Passover offering after its designated time, but did so for its sake, and likewise if others slaughter for the sake of the Passover offering at its designated time - Rabbi Eliezer disqualifies it, and Rabbi Yehoshua validates it.

hebrew_text: טַעְמָא בִּזְמַנּוֹ, הָא שֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ — כָּשֵׁר. וְאַמַּאי? נֵימָא: הוֹאִיל וּבִזְמַנּוֹ פּוֹסֵל, שֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ נָמֵי פּוֹסֵל!
human_translation: The reason is at its time; But if it was not at its time, it is valid But why Let us say: Since disqualifies at its time, also disqualify not at its time.
llm_translation: Reason in its time, that which is not in its time - valid. And why? Say: Since in its time it disqualifies, that which is not in its time certainly disqualifies!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״וַאֲמַרְתֶּם זֶבַח פֶּסַח הוּא״ — הוּא בַּהֲוָיָיתוֹ: לֹא הוּא לְשׁוּם אֲחֵרִים, וְלֹא אֲחֵרִים לִשְׁמוֹ.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: It is different there as the verse said: “And you shall say: It is a Passover sacrifice “it” as it is, It, not for the purpose of other and other not for its purpose,
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: The difference there is that the verse says, "And you shall say, it is the Passover sacrifice" - it is in its essence: not for any other purposes, and not other purposes for it.

hebrew_text: בִּזְמַנּוֹ, שֶׁהוּא פָּסוּל לְשׁוּם אֲחֵרִים — אֲחֵרִים פְּסוּלִין לִשְׁמוֹ. שֶׁלֹּא בִּזְמַנּוֹ, שֶׁהוּא כָּשֵׁר לְשׁוּם אֲחֵרִים — אֲחֵרִים כְּשֵׁרִים לִשְׁמוֹ.
human_translation: At its time, is disqualified for the purpose of other other are disqualified for its purpose, not at its time, for the purpose of other is valid, other for its purpose are valid.
llm_translation: In his time, when he is disqualified for others - others are disqualified for him. Not in his time, when he is valid for others - others are valid for him.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׂמְלַאי אֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: נִיתְנֵי לִי מָר סֵפֶר יוּחֲסִין. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מֵהֵיכָן אַתְּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִלּוֹד. וְהֵיכָן מוֹתְבָךְ? בִּנְהַרְדְּעָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אֵין נִידּוֹנִין לֹא לְלוּדִּים וְלֹא לִנְהַרְדְּעִים, וְכׇל שֶׁכֵּן דְּאַתְּ מִלּוֹד וּמוֹתְבָךְ בִּנְהַרְדְּעָא. כַּפְיֵיהּ וְאִרַצִּי.
human_translation: Rabbi Simlai came before Rabbi Yoḥanan. He said to him: Would the Master teach me the Book of Genealogies? said to him: Where are you from? He said to him: From Lod. And where is your residence? In Neharde’a. said to him: we teach neither to Lodites nor to Neharde’ans, and certainly you who from Lod and your residence is in Neharde’a, pressured he agreed
llm_translation: Rabbi Shemlai came before Rabbi Yochanan, he said to him: "Master, give me a document of genealogy." He said to him: "From where are you?" He said to him: "From Lod." "And where are you settled?" "In Nehardea." He said to him: "We do not judge neither the people of Lod nor the people of Nehardea, all the more so that you are from Lod and settled in Nehardea." He kissed him and blessed him.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: נִיתְנְיֵיהּ בִּתְלָתָא יַרְחֵי. שְׁקַל קָלָא פְּתַק בֵּיהּ, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: וּמָה בְּרוּרְיָה דְּבֵיתְהוּ דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר בְּרַתֵּיה דְּרַבִּי חֲנַנְיָה בֶּן תְּרַדְיוֹן, דְּתָנְיָא תְּלָת מְאָה שְׁמַעְתָּתָא בְּיוֹמָא מִתְּלָת מְאָה רַבְּווֹתָא, וַאֲפִילּוּ הָכִי לֹא יָצְתָה יְדֵי חוֹבָתָהּ בִּתְלָת שְׁנִין, וְאַתְּ אָמְרַתְּ בִּתְלָתָא יַרְחֵי?!
human_translation: said to him: Teach me in three months. took a clod threw it at him, said to him: Berurya, wife of Rabbi Meir daughter of Rabbi Ḥananya ben Teradyon, learned three hundred halakhot in one day from three hundred Sages, and nonetheless she did not fulfill her responsibility in three years And you say in three months?
llm_translation: He said to him: "Give it to her for three months." He took a light stick and struck him with it, he said to him: "And what about the clarity of the household of Rabbi Meir, the daughter of Rabbi Hananiah ben Teradyon, as it was taught: three hundred times a day she would engage in Torah study, and even so, she did not fulfill her obligation in three years, and you say give it to her for three months?!"

hebrew_text: כִּי שָׁקֵיל וְאָזֵיל אֲמַר לֵיהּ: רַבִּי, מָה בֵּין לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ, לְאוֹכְלָיו וְשֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו?
human_translation: When was taking leave to go, he said to my teacher, What is between for its purpose and for a different purpose, for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it,
llm_translation: When he weighed and went out, he said to him: Rabbi, what is the difference between his name and not his name, for his food and not for his food?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הוֹאִיל וְצוּרְבָּא מֵרַבָּנַן אַתְּ, תָּא וְאֵימָא לְךָ: לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ — פְּסוּלוֹ בְּגוּפוֹ, לְאוֹכְלָיו וְשֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו — אֵין פְּסוּלוֹ בְּגוּפוֹ.
human_translation: He said to him: Since you are a Torah scholar, come and I will tell you for its purpose and for a different purpose, disqualification is in itself; for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it, disqualification is not in itself,
llm_translation: He said to him: Since you are a Torah scholar, come and I will say to you: Whether for His sake or not for His sake — if it is disqualified in itself, for its consumers or not for its consumers — its disqualification is in itself.

hebrew_text: לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ — אִי אֶפְשָׁר לְבָרֵר אִיסּוּרוֹ, לְאוֹכְלָיו וְשֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו — אֶפְשָׁר לְבָרֵר אִיסּוּרוֹ.
human_translation: for its purpose and for a different purpose, it is impossible to identify its prohibition; for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it, it is possible to identify its prohibition.
llm_translation: For his sake and not for his sake - if it is impossible to clarify his prohibition, for his benefit and not for his benefit - it is possible to clarify his prohibition.

hebrew_text: לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ — יֶשְׁנוֹ בְּאַרְבַּע עֲבוֹדוֹת, לְאוֹכְלָיו וְשֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו — אֵינוֹ בְּאַרְבַּע עֲבוֹדוֹת. לִשְׁמוֹ וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ — יֶשְׁנוֹ בְּצִיבּוּר כִּבְיָחִיד, לְאוֹכְלָיו וְשֶׁלֹּא לְאוֹכְלָיו — אֵינוֹ בְּצִיבּוּר כִּבְיָחִיד.
human_translation: for its purpose and for a different purpose applies in four rites, for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it does not during four rites, for its purpose and for a different purpose that applies to communal as to individual for those who can eat it and those who cannot eat it does not to the community as to an individual.
llm_translation: For His sake and not for His sake - there are four types of labor, for His sake and not for His sake - there are not four types of labor. For His sake and not for His sake - it is like an individual in the public domain, for His sake and not for His sake - it is not like an individual in the public domain.

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: פְּסוּלוֹ בְּגוּפוֹ וְאִי אֶפְשָׁר לְבָרֵר אִיסּוּרוֹ — חֲדָא מִילְּתָא הִיא, דְּמָה טַעַם אָמַר פְּסוּלוֹ בְּגוּפוֹ? מִשּׁוּם דְּאִי אֶפְשָׁר לְבָרֵר אִיסּוּרוֹ.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said its disqualification is in itself and it is impossible to identify its prohibition are one thing; what is the reason that says its disqualification is in itself? because it is impossible to identify its prohibition,
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: If its disqualification is in its body, and if it is not possible to clarify its prohibition - it is one matter, for what reason did he say its disqualification is in its body? Because if it is not possible to clarify its prohibition.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָמֵי בַּר רַב יוּדָא אָמַר רַב: מִיּוֹם שֶׁנִּגְנַז סֵפֶר יוּחֲסִין תָּשַׁשׁ כֹּחָן שֶׁל חֲכָמִים וְכָהָה מְאוֹר עֵינֵיהֶם.
human_translation: Rami bar Rav Yuda said Rav said From the day the Book of Genealogies was hidden the strength of the Sages has been weakened, and the light of their eyes has been dimmed,
llm_translation: Ramai son of Rav Yuda said Rav said: From the day the genealogy book was hidden, the strength of the sages weakened and the light of their eyes dimmed.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר זוּטְרָא: בֵּין ״אָצֵל״ לְ״אָצַל״ טְעִינוּ אַרְבַּע מְאָה גַּמְלֵי דִּדְרָשָׁא.
human_translation: Mar Zutra said: from Azel to Azel bore four hundred camels of expositions
llm_translation: Master Zutra said: Between "atzel" and "atzal" we require four hundred camels of interpretation.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, אֲחֵרִים אוֹמְרִים: הִקְדִּים מוּלִים לַעֲרֵלִים — כָּשֵׁר, עֲרֵלִים לְמוּלִים — פָּסוּל. מַאי שְׁנָא מוּלִין לַעֲרֵלִים דְּכָשֵׁר — דְּכוּלַּהּ עׇרְלָה בָּעֵינַן, וְלֵיכָּא? עֲרֵלִים לְמוּלִין נָמֵי, כּוּלַּהּ עׇרְלָה בָּעֵינַן, וְלֵיכָּא!
human_translation: It was taught Aḥerim say: first the circumcised people and then the uncircumcised people, valid. the uncircumcised people the circumcised people, it is disqualified. What is different the circumcised people the uncircumcised people, that is valid? that we require that all the people be uncircumcised, and is not the uncircumcised people the circumcised people, also that we require that all the people be uncircumcised, and is not
llm_translation: It was taught: Others say, if circumcised individuals preceded uncircumcised individuals - it is valid; if uncircumcised individuals preceded circumcised individuals - it is invalid. What is the difference between circumcised individuals preceding uncircumcised individuals, that it is valid - because we require the entirety of the foreskin, and it is not there? Uncircumcised individuals preceding circumcised individuals, similarly, we require the entirety of the foreskin, and it is not there!

hebrew_text: לֵימָא קָסָבְרִי אֲחֵרִים אֵינָהּ לִשְׁחִיטָה אֶלָּא בַּסּוֹף, וְכִדְרָבָא. דְּאָמַר רָבָא: עֲדַיִין הִיא מַחֲלוֹקֶת.
human_translation: Let us say that Aḥerim hold that slaughter is not until the end, in accordance with Rava As Rava said: It is still a dispute,
llm_translation: Let us say, others hold that it is not for slaughter except at the end, as Ravah said: It is still a dispute.

hebrew_text: הִילְכָּךְ: הִקְדִּים מוּלִין לַעֲרֵלִים — מוּלִין חָיְילִי, עֲרֵלִים לָא חָיְילִי. הִקְדִּים עֲרֵלִים לְמוּלִין — עֲרֵלִים חָיְילִי, מוּלִין לָא חָיְילִי.
human_translation: Therefore, one put the circumcised people before the uncircumcised people, circumcised people applies uncircumcised people does not apply. one put the uncircumcised people before the circumcised people, uncircumcised people applies, circumcised people does not apply.
llm_translation: Therefore: If one performed circumcision on uncircumcised individuals - the circumcision is valid, on circumcised individuals - it is not valid. If one performed circumcision on circumcised individuals - the circumcision is valid, on uncircumcised individuals - it is not valid.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה: לָא, לְעוֹלָם קָסָבְרִי אֲחֵרִים יֶשְׁנָהּ לִשְׁחִיטָה מִתְּחִלָּה וְעַד סוֹף, וְהָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — כְּגוֹן שֶׁגָּמַר בְּלִבּוֹ לְתַרְוַויְיהוּ, בֵּין לְמוּלִין בֵּין לַעֲרֵלִים, וְהוֹצִיא בְּפִיו ״לַעֲרֵלִים״, וְלֹא הִסְפִּיק לוֹמַר ״לְמוּלִין״ עַד שֶׁנִּגְמְרָה שְׁחִיטָה בַּ״עֲרֵלִים״. וּבְהָא פְּלִיגִי, דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר סָבַר: לָא בָּעֵינַן פִּיו וְלִבּוֹ שָׁוִים. וְרַבָּנַן סָבְרִי בָּעֵינַן פִּיו וְלִבּוֹ שָׁוִים.
human_translation: Rabba said: No, Actually, Aḥerim hold that slaughter is from beginning to end, and with what are we dealing here? where one decided in his mind for both of them, both circumcised and uncircumcised people, and he verbally expressed For uncircumcised people, but did not have a chance to say: For circumcised people, before the slaughter was finished For uncircumcised people. And it is with regard to this that they disagree: Rabbi Meir, holds that we do not require that one’s mouth and heart be the same; And the Rabbis hold that we require that his mouth and heart be the same.
llm_translation: Rabah said: No, I always maintain that others may slaughter it from beginning to end, and here we are dealing with what? For example, when he decided in his heart for their benefit, whether for circumcised or uncircumcised, and he uttered "uncircumcised" with his mouth, and did not have time to say "for the circumcised" until the slaughter was completed with the "uncircumcised." And they dispute in this matter, for Rabbi Meir holds: We do not require his mouth and heart to be in agreement. And the Rabbis hold: We require his mouth and heart to be in agreement.

hebrew_text: וְקָסָבַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר לָא בָּעֵינַן פִּיו וְלִבּוֹ שָׁוִין? וּרְמִינְהוּ: הַמִּתְכַּוֵּין לוֹמַר ״תְּרוּמָה״, וְאָמַר ״מַעֲשֵׂר״; ״מַעֲשֵׂר״, וְאָמַר ״תְּרוּמָה״. אוֹ: ״שֶׁאֵינִי נִכְנָס לְבַיִת זֶה״, וְאָמַר ״לָזֶה״; ״שֶׁאֵינִי נֶהֱנֶה לָזֶה״, וְאָמַר ״לָזֶה״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם עַד שֶׁיְּהוּ פִּיו וְלִבּוֹ שָׁוִין.
human_translation: But does Rabbi Meir hold that we require that his mouth and heart be the same? raises a contradiction one who intended to say teruma , but he said tithe; tithe but said teruma ; I will not enter this house, but said: That I will not derive benefit from this person, but he said: From that he has not said anything until his mouth and heart are the same.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Meir holds that we do not require his mouth and heart to be in agreement? And they raised an objection: One who intended to say "terumah" and said "ma'aser"; "ma'aser" and said "terumah." Or: "I will not enter this house," and said "to that one"; "I will not benefit that one," and said "to that one" — he did not say anything until his mouth and heart are in agreement.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: רֵישָׁא, דְּאָמַר ״סִימָן רִאשׁוֹן לְמוּלִין, וְסִימָן שֵׁנִי אַף לַעֲרֵלִים״ — דִּבְסִימָן שֵׁנִי נָמֵי פְּתִיכִי בֵּיהּ מוּלִין. סֵיפָא, דְּאָמַר ״סִימָן רִאשׁוֹן לַעֲרֵלִים, סִימָן שֵׁנִי לְמוּלִים״ — דִּבְסִימָן רִאשׁוֹן הָא לָא פְּתִיכִי בֵּיהּ מוּלִין.
human_translation: Rather, Abaye said The first clause he said: the first for circumcised people and the second even for uncircumcised people, so that in the second even circumcised people are included. The latter clause he said: the first for uncircumcised people the second for circumcised people, so that in the first circumcised people are not included,
llm_translation: Rather, Abaye said: The beginning, that which it says "the first sign for circumcised individuals, and the second sign also for the uncircumcised" — for in the second sign, it is clear that it applies to circumcised individuals. The end, that which it says "the first sign for the uncircumcised, the second sign for the circumcised" — for in the first sign, it is not clear that it applies to circumcised individuals.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי מֵאִיר לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דְּאָמַר: מְפַגְּלִין בַּחֲצִי מַתִּיר. וְרַבָּנַן לְטַעְמַיְיהוּ, דְּאָמְרִי: אֵין מְפַגְּלִין בַּחֲצִי מַתִּיר.
human_translation: And Rabbi Meir follows reasoning, as he says piggul status can be conferred at half of what renders it permitted. And the Rabbis follow reasoning, as they say piggul status cannot be conferred at half of what permits
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir according to his reasoning, as he said: invalidates in half permits. And the Rabbis according to their reasoning, as they said: do not invalidate in half permits.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַשּׁוֹחֵט אֶת הַפֶּסַח עַל הֶחָמֵץ — עוֹבֵר בְּלֹא תַעֲשֶׂה. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אַף הַתָּמִיד. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: הַפֶּסַח בְּאַרְבָּעָה עָשָׂר לִשְׁמוֹ — חַיָּיב, וְשֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ — פָּטוּר. וּשְׁאָר כׇּל הַזְּבָחִים, בֵּין לִשְׁמָן וּבֵין שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָן — פָּטוּר.
human_translation: One who slaughters the Paschal lamb with leavened bread violates a negative commandment, Rabbi Yehuda says: Even the daily offering Rabbi Shimon says: the Paschal lamb on the fourteenth for its purpose is liable; for a different purpose he is exempt. And all other offerings whether for their purpose or for a different purpose, he is exempt.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who slaughters the Paschal lamb on leavened bread transgresses a negative commandment. Rabbi Yehudah says: This applies also to the daily offering. Rabbi Shimon says: Regarding the Paschal lamb, if it is on the fourteenth for its sake, one is liable; if not for its sake, one is exempt. And all other sacrifices, whether for their sake or not for their sake, one is exempt.

hebrew_text: וּבַמּוֹעֵד, לִשְׁמוֹ — פָּטוּר. שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמוֹ — חַיָּיב. וּשְׁאָר כׇּל הַזְּבָחִים, בֵּין לִשְׁמָן בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָן — חַיָּיב. חוּץ מִן הַחַטָּאת שֶׁשְּׁחָטוֹ שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָהּ.
human_translation: And during the festival for its purpose he is exempt. for a different purpose he is liable And all other offerings whether for their purpose for a different purpose, he is liable. with the exception of a sin-offering that he slaughtered for a different purpose
llm_translation: In the festival, for its name — exempt. Not for its name — liable. And all other sacrifices, whether for its name or not for its name — liable. Except for the sin offering that was slaughtered not for its name.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ: לְעוֹלָם אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב עַד שֶׁיְּהֵא הֶחָמֵץ לַשּׁוֹחֵט אוֹ לַזּוֹרֵק
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: One is never liable unless the leavened bread belongs to the one who slaughters or to the one who sprinkles
llm_translation: Gemara: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Always not liable until it is the leaven for the one who slaughters or sprinkles.

hebrew_text: אוֹ לְאֶחָד מִבְּנֵי חֲבוּרָה, וְעַד שֶׁיְּהֵא עִמּוֹ בָּעֲזָרָה. רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין עִמּוֹ בַּעֲזָרָה. בְּמַאי קָמִיפַּלְגִי? אִילֵּימָא בְּ״עַל״ בְּסָמוּךְ קָמִיפַּלְגִי, דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ סָבַר: ״עַל״ בְּסָמוּךְ, וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן סָבַר: לָא בָּעֵינַן ״עַל״ בְּסָמוּךְ. וְהָא אִיפְּלִגוּ בַּהּ חֲדָא זִימְנָא!
human_translation: to one of the members of the group; only if is with him in the Temple courtyard Rabbi Yoḥanan said: even if is not with him in the Temple courtyard. With regard to what they disagree? If you say they disagree “with” next to, that Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish holds that “with” next to, and Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that “with,” we do not require next to they have already disagreed about this once
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Or to one of the members of the group, until he is with him in the Azarah. Rabbi Yochanan said: Even though he is not with him in the Azarah. With what are they arguing? If you say they are arguing about "al" that is adjacent, for Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish holds: "al" that is adjacent, and Rabbi Yochanan holds: we do not require "al" that is adjacent. And they only argued about this once!

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן: הַשּׁוֹחֵט תּוֹדָה לִפְנִים וְלַחְמָהּ חוּץ לַחוֹמָה — לֹא קָדַשׁ הַלֶּחֶם.
